Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Italy&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Italy+August+2018&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2018-08-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Italy&amp;rft.issn=09668845&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Italy--highlights: Political outlook
The March 2018 general election yielded a fragmented parliament, with the centre-right coalition taking 37% of the vote and falling short of a majority of seats under a new voting law. The election was also a resounding victory for the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won 32.7% of the vote and the Eurosceptic, anti-immigration Lega, which took 17.4%. After a prolonged period of coalition talks the two agreed to form an anti-establishment govern-ment in late May, nearly triggering a constitutional crisis over the proposed appointment of a Eurosceptic finance minister, which the president vetoed. The government is led by Giuseppe Conte, a law professor close to M5S, and took office on June 1st. Mr Conte's deputy prime ministers are Luigi Di Maio, the leader of M5S, and Matteo Salvini, the leader of the Lega, who has thus far overshadowed Mr Di Maio with his brash, populist rhetoric. Giovanni Tria, a technocrat economist, serves as economy and finance minister. The admin-istration will seek to test the boundaries of compliance with EU fiscal rules and some of the bloc's other policies. It has proposed a series of unrealistic and expansionary tax policies, the rollback of recent pension and labour reforms, and a means-tested "citizenship income" for job-seekers. The govern-ment is likely to be unstable, and The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect it to last a full term in office.
Italy--highlights: Business environment outlook

6.52 6.83 38 36 16 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's business environment score improves slightly during the forecast period (2018-22), rising by two places in the global rankings, owing to a series of improvements linked to reforms passed since 2011. Under the M5S-Lega administration, however, many of these are at high risk of reversal. Italy's regional ranking improves marginally, from 16th to 15th. The macro-economic environment score remains unchanged, but owing to improve-ments in other countries, Italy slips six places in our global ranking and by three places in the regional ranking. The scores for policy towards foreign investment, financing and the labour market all improve. Italy's tax system remains one of the biggest hindrances to businesses and foreign invest-ment. Compliance is costly and tax evasion remains widespread.

Economic recovery in Italy remains on track, but the real GDP growth rate is likely to slow modestly from 2018-19, remaining around 1% per year for the duration of the forecast period. The M5S-Lega administration will seek to loosen fiscal policy as much as possible, but is likely to keep the deficit within the 3% of GDP ceiling set by EU fiscal rules, as the market reaction to a larger deficit could be violent. Debt/GDP will remain around 130% for the duration of the forecast period, and we do not expect the M5S-Lega government to enact any meaningful structural reforms. Instead, it has proposed a raft of tax and spending policies that are prohibitively costly and will seek to undo recent pension and labour reforms.

The population increased at an annual average rate of 0.3% in 1999-2011. Since then the population has declined, falling to 59.4m in 2017, according to the UN's population estimates. We expect population to continue falling slightly during the forecast period, to 58.9m in 2022, reflecting the natural decline of the Italian population and lower immigrant inflows.

Italy is one of the largest and richest markets in Europe, with a population of about 6om. However, growth potential remains limited because the country is a mature consumer market with weak income and population growth pros-pects. Income levels differ greatly between the north and the south of Italy, with GDP per head in the south only about 46% of that in the north. Demographic trends will have an important impact on spending patterns, with population ageing driving healthcare expenditure.

Our baseline forecast is that Italy's weak demographic profile will act as a substantial brake on real GDP growth, which we expect to average just 0.6% per year in 2018-50. A more favourable political environment could produce better economic growth performance in the long term, but the chance of improve-ments in Italy's institutional framework being implemented in the short to medium term is low.

Background: Post-war Italy has been characterised by a weak political structure and, since the 1970s, a declining economic base. Between 1996 and 2011 Italy had a bipolar political system, dominated by a centre-right alliance and a centre-left coalition. Since 2011 the political landscape has become more fragmented, with the break-up of the centre right, the emergence of the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and a recent splintering of the centre left. Since the 2013 general election Italy has had three broad centre-left/centre-right governments. Matteo Renzi's resignation as prime minister after his flagship constitutional reform was rejected in a referendum in December 2016 led to the formation of a government led by Paolo Gentiloni, a close ally of Mr Renzi. Following the 2018 general election, an M5S-Lega government was formed.
Political structure: Parliament, which comprises two houses with equal powers, is elected for a five-year term. The president, who is elected by parliament for a seven-year term, decides, in the event of a political crisis, whether to call an election or to nominate a prime minister to try to form a government. The president also promulgates laws and may return a law to parliament for reconsideration, but has no power of veto. Executive power lies with the cabinet, which is nominated by the prime minister and approved by parliament. The prime minister cannot dismiss ministers without forming a new government. The legislative system remains unchanged following the rejection in the December 2016 referendum of a reform to reduce the powers of the Senate (the upper house). A new, predominantly proportional electoral system was adopted in October 2017.
Policy issues: The main issues are the management of, and attempts to reduce, Italy's large public debt (which stood at 131.7% of GDP in 2017), safeguarding the banking system and keeping Italy in the euro zone. In 2012 the government, led by Mario Monti, carried out a number of structural economic reforms to improve competitiveness. The process has since stalled, and the M5S-Lega government will seek to loosen fiscal policy, stimulate private consumption through tax cuts and income support to low earners, and seek to reverse or dilute recent pension and labour reforms.
Taxation: The top rate of personal income tax is 43%, and social security contributions are high, especially for employers. The corporation tax rate is 24%, reduced in 2017 from 27.5%, but additional regional and municipal taxes are levied, including the regional business tax (IRAP), to fund health services. The basic rate of IRAP is 3.5%, reduced from 3.9% in 2014. Income earned from most types of financial investment is taxed at 26%. The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 22%.
Foreign trade: The value of exports of goods (fob) stood at US$496bn in 2017, and imports (fob) were worth US$433bn. In the same year the current account recorded a surplus of US$54.3bn, or 2.8% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The March 2018 general election yielded a badly fragmented parliament. The centre-right coalition fell short of the roughly 40% of votes needed to win a majority under the most recent electoral law, the so-called Rosatellum 2, coming in at 37%. Within the coalition, the populist, anti-immigration Lega (17.4%) surpassed Silvio Berlusconi's Forza Italia (FI; 14%), which had previously been seen as the leading party on the right, and polled well ahead of the hard-right, post-fascist Fratelli d'Italia (4.4%). The election also saw a surge in support for the populist, anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won 32.7% of vote, making it by far the country's largest party. After nearly three months of difficult coalition talks, M5S and the Lega agreed to form a coalition government under the leadership of a technocratic prime minister, Giuseppe Conte. Meanwhile the mainstream centre-left Partito Democratico (PD), under the leadership of Matteo Renzi, won just 18.9% of the vote, an all-time low, leading to Mr Renzi's resignation and the temporary leadership of Maurizio Martina. The PD and its smaller coalition partners won a combined vote share of just 22.3%, and Liberi e Uguale-a formation made up of primarily of left-wing splinter parties that spun off from the PD in opposition to Mr Renzi's leadership-took 3.4% of the vote.

Political outlook: Political stability
The general election on March 4th 2018 yielded a badly fragmented parliament. It also produced a resounding victory for M5S, which won 33% of the vote, and the Lega, which secured 17%. Following prolonged post-election negotiations-including a stand-off with the president, Sergio Mattarella, over the proposed appointment as economy and finance minister of Paolo Savona, a strongly Eurosceptic economist-on May 31st M5S and the Lega agreed to form a government. The administration is led by Mr Conte, a law professor and an independent who is close to M5S. The leaders of M5S and Lega, Luigi Di Maio and Matteo Salvini respectively, serve as deputy prime ministers. Mr Di Maio has also been appointed minister of labour and social policies, and of economic development; Mr Salvini has taken the post of interior minister. Giovanni Tria, a moderate economist, has been appointed to the Ministry of Economy and Finance, but he and Mr Conte are likely to face political pressure from Mr Salvini and Mr Di Maio to enact more radical policies.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Conte government to be short lived. It is clear that Mr Salvini has no intention of dropping his campaign-style rhetoric and will continue to jockey for position with M5S. It is likely that Mr Salvini will attempt to engineer a political crisis, hoping that the president will grant an early election, at which the Lega is likely to gain ground. In the meantime the government will attempt to deliver on a part of its electoral promises and will send mixed signals regarding its intentions to comply with EU rules and common policies.
In addition to seeking looser fiscal policy constraints, the administration will press the EU hard on its immigration policies, demanding greater support for Italy in coping with vessels arriving across the Mediterranean and the processing of migrants in third countries. It will also advocate for more protective external trade policies, and possibly a loosening of EU sanctions on Russia over the annexation of Crimea.
We expect the M5S-Lega coalition to pass only a subset of the extensive and, in many cases, unaffordable policy changes that it has proposed. It has begun with less costly ones, such as stricter immigration policies and plans to dilute the 2015 Jobs Act (a labour market reform). In its 2019 budget proposal the government is also likely to seek to dilute the 2011 Fornero pension reform, in addition to disarming the budget safeguard clauses built into the country's fiscal framework that would raise value-added tax (VAT) rates and fuel excise taxes if alternative consolidation measures are not specified. A means-tested "citizenship income" for job-seekers is another priority and could be imple-mented in phases; however, it remains unclear how the government would introduce the costly two-rate "flat tax" on personal and corporate income promised by the Lega. We believe that the cost of such a measure would be prohibitive.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Italy is governed by weak, divided executives, generally comprising multiparty coalitions, in which small parties often wield disproportionate power over policy decisions. Under the bicameral parliamentary system, all bills have to be passed in the same form by both houses of parliament in order to be enacted, often resulting in delays and the dilution of measures. This is unlikely to change following the rejection of the Renzi government's constitutional reform package in December 2016, which sought to reduce drastically the legislative powers of the Senate (the upper house of parliament) and would have effectively made the parliament quasi-unicameral. The new M5S-Lega administration bitterly opposed Mr Renzi's efforts to streamline the institutional framework, and further reforms are not a part of their law-making agenda.
Efficiency may improve in the public administration, but not in the judiciary
Red tape and Italy's inefficient judicial system are likely to continue to pose problems for businesses. However, modest measures introduced in recent years to increase public-sector accountability and efficiency should help to speed up gradually some bureaucratic procedures, although given entrenched resistance to change within the public administration, the implementation of the reforms approved in 2015 is likely to be slow. The M5S-Lega administration has also stated its intention to reduce red tape, but has not yet presented an ambitious, credible simplification programme. A partial reform of the judicial system was under-taken in 2014-16. However, many of the problems facing Italy's judicial system have not been addressed, including a fee system for lawyers that acts as a disin-centive to concluding cases swiftly, a lack of specialisation among judges and a highly fragmented court system. The average number of days to resolve a contractual dispute in Italy is more than double that in some other EU member states.
Corruption is still rife in business, judging by the number of corruption scandals revealed in recent years. A bill presented in March 2010 containing measures intended to combat corruption among public officials took almost three years to become law. Since then government action appears to have intensified. In June 2014 the powers of the anti-corruption authority were strengthened, and less than a year later parliament approved another anti-corruption law, including provisions eliminating the minimum threshold for the prosecution of accounting fraud and introducing harsher prison sentences for this offense, as well as corruption of public officials, embezzlement and mafia association.
Criminal organisations will continue to pose problems for businesses and deter investment, despite the authorities' efforts to combat extortion and usury and the arrests of several mafia bosses in recent years.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next parliamentary election is scheduled for early 2023, but we expect it to be held much sooner. Italian governments typically do not last a full term, and the Lega is currently polling at about 30%-equal to or just ahead of M5S in most surveys, and well above its vote share at the March election. We believe that Mr Salvini will run in coalition with the centre-right FI and Fratelli d'Italia. The earliest window for another election would be the first half of 2019, possibly coinciding with the next European Parliament elections (in May) if relations between M5S and the Lega prove to be particularly rocky. However, the administration could last another year or two if the Lega continues to extract policy concessions from M5S and public support for the government remains high.
Political outlook: International relations
We expect Italy to remain a member of the EU and the euro zone during the forecast period (2018-22). Other foreign policy mainstays, including a close relationship with the US, and membership of NATO and the UN will remain in place. During the election campaign Mr Di Maio confirmed that he would honour these relationships if his party formed part of the government. However, relations are likely to be strained, particularly with EU and euro zone institutions. Although the prime minister, the foreign minister and the economy and finance minister are all moderate independents, there is likely to be a degree of tension between these figures and Mr Salvini and Mr Di Maio. Mr Salvini and Mr Conte have already taken a more confrontational stance with other EU countries, refusing to allow charity ships carrying migrants in distress in the central Mediterranean to disembark on Italian shores, and taking a tough line on migration measures proposed at the June European Council.
In addition to pressing for a harder stance on asylum and immigration policy, the governing parties have said that they will oppose certain aspects of recent EU trade agreements, such as the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). M5S and the Lega have also denounced EU economic sanctions against Russia, imposed in July 2014 following Russia's intervention in Ukraine, although the Italian government did not impede the extension of the sanction regime to June 2019. Our baseline view is that sanctions will remain in place, with Italy's support, for most of our forecast period.

Italy's business environment score improves slightly during the forecast period (2018-22), moving the country up two places to 36th in the global ranking and one place in the regional ranking, to 15th. The scores for policy towards private enterprise and competition, foreign investment, taxes, financing and the labour market all improve, reflecting the impact of economic reforms taken by successive governments since late 2011. Recent governments have also taken steps to reduce political opposition to foreign takeovers, and public receptive-ness to overseas investment has also improved. The parliamentary election held in March 2018 has produced a populist government that is likely to prove unstable and ineffective. There is a high risk that under the new government some of the improvements in legislation and macroeconomic performance will be reversed.
Italy scores poorly for government effectiveness. Following the rejection of Matteo Renzi's constitutional reforms, institutional reform is off the political agenda for the foreseeable future. A partial judicial reform was introduced in 2014-16, but is insufficient to resolve judicial system issues. A modest economic recovery remains on track. Promoting economic growth and employment, as well as reducing the public debt burden and repairing weaknesses in the banking sector, will remain the biggest policy challenges facing the government in 2018-22. Italy's tax system remains a major hindrance to businesses and foreign investment, and evasion is widespread. The new government's plan to carry out a radical overhaul of the tax system is unlikely to be implemented because of the expected cost, but uncertainty about the direction of tax policy has increased. Previous governments have taken some steps to encourage bank mergers and support banks' efforts to reduce the level of non-performing loans (NPLs) on their balance sheets, but progress has been slow.

Business environment outlook: Italy's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Political instability after the 2018 election will limit the possibility of significant reforms to improve competition.
2020-22: Further improvements in competition policy will depend on stabilisation of the political environment.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Modest reductions in red tape. Some streamlining of the judicial system, but lengthy delays persist.
2020-22: Organised crime, legal complexity and shortcomings in the judicial system remain deterrents.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Quotas and tariffs are in line with EU practice. Trade barriers remain low, but agricultural protection continues. The EU focuses on EU-UK trade deal in Brexit negotiations, further bilateral free-trade deals and responding to US restrictions.
2020-22: EU-US agreement will probably remain elusive. The risk of a euro area break-up, which could lead to capital controls, is low, but Greece's membership of the bloc remains in question over the long term.
Taxes
2018-19: Some labour taxes reduced in the 2018 budget, but achieving spending cuts to make further reductions will be difficult. Most political parties' promises of tax cuts after the election appear unaffordable.
2020-22: Overall tax rates stay high, but the burden of future fiscal tightening is likely to fall on public expenditure.
Financing
2018-19: Despite new legislation, bank mergers, further recapitalisation and non-performing loan (NPL) sales are slow.
2020-22: Banking sector exposure to the Italian sovereign will persist. Mergers of smaller co-operative banks and possible foreign takeovers accelerate, as will the sale of securitised bad loans. Profitability and credit provision are still weak.
The labour market
2018-19: Firms remain reluctant to increase open-ended contract payrolls. Universal unemployment benefit is gradually introduced. Some aspects of 2014-15 labour market reforms are reversed or diluted.
2020-22: Decentralised private-sector productivity-related pay deals may become more widespread; changes to public employment contracts face resistance.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Lack of political appetite for drastic current-expenditure cuts limits room for public investment. New government to review continuation of the construction of the Turin-Lyon high-speed rail link.
2020-22: Infrastructure still lags that of other euro area countries, despite some new investment.
Technological readiness
2018-19: M5S presses for further digitalisation of public services. A preponderance of smaller and family-run firms, and high levels of corporate debt keep research and development (R&D) spending low and uptake of new technologies in the private sector slow.
2020-22: Gradually improving economic and employment prospects, as well as Brexit, encourage more information and communication technology (ICT) graduates to seek work in Italy rather than abroad. Slight improvement in R&D and firm-level technology investment.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.9 6.9 44 50 12 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's assessment of the macroeconomic environment focuses not on headline real GDP growth (measured in the market opportunities category) but on economic stability and the underlying policy framework, which influence business planning, hiring and investment. Italy's macroeconomic environment score is unchanged in the forecast period. However, owing to improvements in other countries, Italy slips six places in our global ranking and by three places in the regional ranking. Despite some progress, economic reforms were introduced with a lag relative to most other struggling euro zone economies, and further measures to reverse more than a decade of stagnant productivity growth are unlikely in the current political environment. We expect Italy to keep its budget deficit within the EU's 3% of GDP limit and to continue generating primary surpluses (the budget balance excluding interest payments), but the public debt burden will remain about 130% of GDP during the forecast period.
The budget deficit will remain under control, but debt reduction will be slow
After a protracted period of stagnation, consumer prices have increased, largely owing to rising global energy costs. Demand-side inflationary pressures will remain subdued, owing to continued weak household consumption, labour market slack and high unemployment, as well as constrained wage growth.
Export growth and low global energy prices will keep Italy's current account in surplus during the forecast period. Nevertheless, concerns remain over the erosion of the country's export competitiveness, stagnant productivity and an escalating global trade conflict.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.8 6.3 43 41 17 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Policy towards private enterprise and competition remains an area in which Italy scores poorly compared with its EU peers, reflecting weak implementation and enforcement of competition rules. Generally, EU directives have been the main drivers of liberalisation in Italy, forcing successive governments (which, regardless of their political leaning, have not instinctively favoured compe-tition) to open up markets in several sectors, notably telecommuni-cations, energy and professional services. The powers of the Italian Competition Authority were strengthened and its remit extended to cover the provision of public services in 2010, but political pressure has generally limited effectiveness. This is also true of other watchdogs, including the Commissione Nazionale per le Società e la Borsa (Consob), the public authority responsible for regulating the Italian securities market, and the telecoms watchdog, Autorità per le Garanzie nelle Comunicazioni (AGCOM).
External constraints will continue to be the main drivers of liberalisation
In 2012 the then technocratic government led by Mario Monti, which came to power in late 2011 when Italy was threatened with losing financial market access at the height of the euro zone crisis, introduced a range of measures, including provisions to increase competition in retailing, taxi services, the sale of pharmaceuticals and utilities. The government also abolished minimum tariffs for several professions, including lawyers. In 2014-16 the Renzi govern-ment continued earlier progress in cutting red tape affecting businesses, stream-lining the complex tax system and, in particular, simplifying and reducing regulation of the Italian labour market. The introduction of reforms following the stress tests of the European Central Bank (ECB) in 2014 has reduced the influence of minority shareholder local charitable foundations in Italy's co-operative banks (banche popolari), paving the way for greater competition, consolidation and mergers. However, consolidation has been slow, owing to reticence to write down bad loans and new EU bail-in rules that require losses to be imposed on shareholders and junior bondholders, who are often retail investors, in return for government support.
Weak contract enforcement, few convictions for white-collar crime, and notoriously long court case backlogs will remain a prominent deterrent of foreign direct investment (FDI) and domestic business investment. Improve-ments introduced in 2014-17 include extended prison sentences for some white-collar crimes such as bribery, the establishment of support offices to reduce the backlog in Italy's Supreme Court, and an extension of the statute of limitations for serious crimes. However, political opposition and resistance from the judiciary remains strong, which will hamper implementation. With political instability likely to continue under the new M5S-Lega government, further major reforms are unlikely.
Further privatisations are likely to be delayed until after the general election
The privatisation plan that was re-launched in mid-2015 to highlight Italy's openness to foreign investment and reduce the level of public debt is likely to be abandoned under the new M5S-Lega government. This is largely because both parties have strenuously opposed the sale of state assets in the past. This means that the planned public offering of the state's remaining 30% stake in the national post office and financial services group, Poste Italiane, and the mooted sale of a 40% stake in Ferrovie dello Stato, Italy's state-owned railway utility group, are unlikely to happen. The new government's approach is most likely to favour the transfer to the CDP stakes in state-controlled firms such as the energy conglomerates, Eni and Enel, to boost revenue, and use of its powers of appoint-ment to expand its influence at the top of state-controlled companies by replacing senior executives and board members put in place by previous governments.
The new government's first legislative act, the Decreto Dignità (dignity decree) approved by the cabinet on July 2nd 2018, contains a mix of measures including provisions to reduce the use of temporary employment contracts and discourage delocalisation (the relocation by firms of jobs to low-wage countries). Compensation for unfair dismissals has also been raised. The decree also requires the repayment of state incentives and subsidies with interest if a firm lays off workers in Italy to transfer production abroad.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.9 7.3 39 34 16 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The positive impact of economic reforms will only be felt incrementally
FDI inflows into Italy have generally been low compared with other similarly sized countries, including those such as France that have traditionally been seen as no more open than Italy. The main deterrents to FDI in Italy relate to complex bureaucratic and legal procedures, barriers to entry in areas of the services sector, inadequate infrastructure, high levels of taxation and energy costs, and labour market rigidities. Under past governments labour market reforms, modest business tax cuts and streamlining of Italy's complex tax system have begun to address some of these issues, resulting in an improvement in Italy's score and rankings in this category. The new M5S-Lega government is more isolationist than its predecessors, and its programme contains no specific policies aimed at attracting FDI. Given the economy's long-standing structural deficiencies, and the likelihood that the impact of recent reforms will be felt only incrementally, inward FDI in Italy will continue to lag that in other large EU member states.
The collapse of the former state airline, Alitalia, in May 2017 highlights the difficulty of operating in Italy, even for major overseas investors such as Etihad, a UAE-based airline that bought a 49% stake in Alitalia in 2014. In April 2017 workers rejected a restructuring plan, causing much-needed financing from the airline's investors to fall through. The airline, which the government is keeping afloat with a bridge loan, is now in the hands of three special administrators who were given six months to sell the airline or liquidate it. Political uncertainty has reigned since the 2018 general election. This has put off investors with a declared interest, as well as delaying a final decision by the administrators and prompting the European Commission to launch an investigation into illegal state aid.
Judicial reforms introduced in 2014-17 should gradually improve contract enforcement, with signs that they are already reducing civil case backlogs. Legislation passed in 2015 should also encourage further financial sector consolidation, which could eventually attract FDI in the banking sector, although progress will be slow given political resistance. Bureaucratic complexity has dogged the sale of banks' securitised bad loans to foreign investors, but intense pressure from financial markets and new EU directives regarding provisioning will help to accelerate the process further. Although less ambitious than hoped for, anti-corruption legislation introduced since 2013 represents a further sign of intent to improve the operating environment for domestic and overseas investors.
Foreign takeovers, especially of luxury goods brands, are likely to continue
Corporate balance sheets and the ability to raise capital were severely damaged by the 2011-14 economic downturn. As a result, in recent years foreign companies have acquired or merged with a rising number of inter-nationally renowned Italian corporate brands, particularly in the luxury and consumer goods sectors, such as Bulgari, Valentino, Loro Piana and Luxottica. Despite signs of concerns among some law-makers regarding foreign takeovers, the trend is likely to continue during the forecast period. As illustrated by the Fiat takeover of Chrysler in 2014 and the bid by the Italian road toll company, Atlantia, for its Spanish partner, Abertis, large Italian firms are seeking opportunities to invest abroad.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.7 9.6 27 8 13 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's EU membership determines the country's foreign trade and exchange policy. Full freedom of movement of goods, services, capital and persons exists within the EU (subject to transitional restrictions for newer member states), and we do not expect any exchange controls. Bilateral trade disputes between EU countries are resolved by the Commission or, in extremis, the European Court of Justice (ECJ), the jurisprudence of which has played a major role in developing the single market. Compliance with judicial or other rulings within the EU is higher than in other regional trading blocs or the World Trade Organisation (WTO). Trade with Nordic neighbours Norway and Iceland is unrestricted under the European Free Trade Association (EFTA). The EU has a customs union with Turkey and a range of bilateral agreements with Switzerland, all of which exclude agriculture.
In other sectors trade with non-EU countries is mostly subject to moderate customs duties. The EU takes a liberal approach to trade in industrial goods, with average unweighted most-favoured-nation tariffs, which cover most countries, at about 4%. Trade between member states and third countries has been largely gov-erned by multilateral agreements administered by the WTO. In 2015 the WTO reached an agreement on trade facilitation (reducing red tape at borders, and setting binding standards for customs and movement of goods internationally), but the Doha trade talks have stalled since 2008 and are unlikely to be revived.
The American protectionist trade policy under the current US president, Donald Trump, has resulted in a sharp deterioration in the global trade environment since the beginning of 2018. We expect a full-blown trade war to be avoided, but there is a risk that protectionist measures and countermeasures adopted by the US, the EU and China will cause global trade to shrink, which would have major knock-on effects for global economic growth.
Brexit to dominate the EU trade agenda beyond the 2019 departure date
The EU's trade agenda over the coming years is set to be dominated by negotiations with the UK, ahead of Britain's formal departure from the EU in 2019. Brexit negotiations have been acrimonious, which has decreased prospects for a satisfactory final agreement. As its third most important EU export market, Italy would be a major loser from failure to secure a satisfactory EU-UK free-trade agreement.
With multilateral trade liberalisation unlikely to make progress during the forecast period, the EU is looking to bilateral agreements to boost trade such as those reached with Canada, Mexico and Japan. However, these deals face resistance within the EU. Italy's new government has said that it will ask the Italian parliament not to ratify the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with Canada because of insufficient protection of Italian foods. The EU-US Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) is unlikely to reach conclusion following the election of Mr Trump as US president.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.3 4.8 77 80 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's tax system remains highly complex, so compliance is costly
Italy's score for taxation improves slightly in the forecast period, but the country ranks fifth from last in our global ranking and bottom in our regional ranking in 2018-22. Notwithstanding some streamlining under previous governments, the tax system remains highly complex, making compliance costly and time consuming for private-sector companies. Also, despite some modest tax cuts since 2014, the tax burden has remained high and is unlikely to decline much, owing to a substantial public debt burden and EU sovereign debt reduction requirements. Tax policy remains highly uncertain under the new government.
According to Istat (the national statistics office), total tax revenue/GDP (including social security contributions) stood at 42.5% in 2017-slightly lower than in 2016 but higher than the regional aggregates of about 40% for the EU and the euro area. According to Eurostat data, Italy has the highest implicit tax rate on labour in the EU (aggregate tax revenue from labour as a percentage of the potential tax base). This was 42.6% in 2016, down from 43.6% in 2014, but 6.5 percentage points above the EU average and more than 4 points higher than the euro area aggregate. However, at 18.4% in 2016, down from 18.1% two years earlier, Italy's implicit tax rate on consumption was one of the lowest in the EU and about 2 percentage points lower than the regional average, highlighting this as an area to which fiscal tightening could be shifted from excessive labour levies.
Despite promises to reduce levies in 2016-18, labour taxes will remain high
Italy's rate of corporate tax for non-financial corporations is 24%, after a cut of 3.5 percentage points in 2017. Banks and most other financial sector firms, however, were excluded from the cut and continue to pay the 27.5% rate. In addition to a corporate tax rate, businesses also pay a regional business tax (IRAP), which is levied at a standard rate of 3.5%, and a slightly higher rate for most financial institutions. However, the central government can raise the regional business tax rate as high as 4.4% in regions running budget deficits. Regions and municipalities also apply personal income surtaxes at varying rates to offset the impact of cuts in transfers from the central government, which have been an almost constant feature of budget adjustments in recent years. Companies pay social security contributions at a high rate, by international comparison, of 30% (9.5% for employees). These are unlikely to be reduced significantly unless pension spending, which amounts to about 15% of GDP (one of the highest in Europe), is significantly reduced.
One of the policy priorities of the new government is to overhaul the tax system with the introduction of two-rate "flat" tax regime (15% and 20%), a no-tax area and a series of deductions to ensure progressivity. Independent estimates put the cost of the reform at EUR50bn, making its introduction unlikely without commensurate expenditure cuts, which would be politically unpopular and difficult to achieve. Currently the marginal personal income tax rate is 43% on gross annual incomes of more than EUR75,000.
Tax evasion and avoidance is widespread in Italy, encouraged in the past by frequent tax amnesties, a limited number and scope of inspections, and weak political will to close loopholes in tax laws. However, some progress was made during the crisis years, which may have improved compliance at least temporarily. It is unclear what the new government's stance towards tax evasion will be. Before reforming the tax system the M5S-Lega government has promised to introduce a "tax peace" scheme, which is essentially an amnesty. The Lega is also keen to abolish altogether the limit on cash payments.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.6 7.8 27 20 10 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Fragmentation remains one of the main weaknesses of the banking sector
Italy's score and global ranking improves substantially in the forecast period, reflecting the impact of a range of measures adopted by recent governments to encourage consolidation, support recapitalisation and try to tackle the issue of high NPLs. Nevertheless, the country still ranks below most other developed countries, which largely reflects delays in introducing reforms to address the Italian banking sector's weaknesses after the 2008-09 global crisis. The sector's major shortcomings are notably fragmentation, with few large banks and many small and medium-sized lenders; high operating costs because of excessive branch networks and personnel costs; low profitability; uncertainty about the quality of supervision; and heavy exposure to the sovereign, which leaves them vulnerable when concerns about government-debt sustainability increase. NPLs have declined considerably in recent years, but are still high at 11.1% of total credit as at end-2017. This is well down from 16.9% in the third quarter of 2015, but more than double the EU average of 5%.
Despite recent reforms, some consolidation and progress in reducing NPLs on banks' balance sheets, efforts to repair Italy's banking system have been beset with difficulties, largely relating to EU bail-in rules, which require losses to be imposed on shareholders and junior bondholders before government support can be granted. Although the state is ultimately likely to compensate small investors' losses, the bail-in rules have provided political capital for anti-establishment political parties and restricted government willingness to speed up bank resolutions.
Financing conditions for banks and the sovereign have been stable for several years, partially owing to the ECB's bond purchasing programme (quantitative easing, or QE), but the return of political risk in May 2018 over uncertainty about the future direction of the M5S-Lega government's economic policies, Italian government benchmark ten-year government bond yields have risen again, but to still relatively low levels. After several years of contraction or stagnation, bank credit to the private sector has expanded modestly since the beginning of 2016. The stabilisation in lending marks an important development for Italy's large number of small and medium-sized enterprises that rely largely on bank borrowing for financing.
Tighter monetary policy by the US Federal Reserve (the US central bank) and a tapering of the ECB's QE programme from the end of 2018 are likely to put upward pressure on government borrowing costs, which could also increase the cost of bank credit. Financial market volatility could also increase if political instability continues or rises under the new government.
Italy's four major banks (Intesa Sanpaolo, UniCredit, Banco Bpm and UBI Banca) are undergoing the 2018 stress tests that are being carried out by the European Banking Authority (EBA), the results of which will be made public in November. The baseline scenario is based on the ECB's December economic forecast with euro zone real GDP growth of 2.3% in 2018, 1.9% in 2019 and 1.7% in 2020 (1.4%, 1.3% and 1.3% respectively for Italy). The adverse scenario envisages a hard Brexit-like shock to economic growth in the EU, leading to a deviation of EU GDP from its baseline level by 8.3% in 2020-the most severe scenario in terms of GDP deviation of all the EBA stress tests so far.
The results of the stress tests on four other banks, conducted under the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) using the same EBA methodology, will not be published but will feed into the Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process (SREP). Banks with capital shortfalls under the baseline scenario will be required to plug the gap, whereas it will be decided on a case-by-case basis for shortfalls under the adverse scenario.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.1 5.5 62 54 17 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The labour market remains rigid, especially in an EU comparison
Recent reforms have contributed to improving the labour market score and Italy's global ranking in the forecast period, but this category remains an area in which Italy performs poorly compared with its EU peers. The Renzi government's Jobs Act legislative package passed in 2014-15 was a welcome development, but because the main reforms only applied to new private-sector hires, long-standing rigidities were only set to decline gradually. The new M5S-Lega government has promised to dismantle the Jobs Act, but its main focus has been increasing restrictions on the use of easily terminated fixed-term contracts. The Decreto Dignità approved on July 2nd 2018 allows them to be used for up to 24 months, compared with 36 months under the Jobs Act and 12 months prior to that. It also requires firms to provide a justification for the use of such contracts, which is likely to increase litigation, and pay an additional levy of 1.9% (up from 1.4%) when they extend a fixed-term contract. However, the cap of 20% of the workforce on temporary contracts for an individual firm remains unchanged. The decree also raises the minimum compensation for unfair dismissal from a minimum of four months' salary to six months and from a maximum of 24 months' salary to 36.
Other measures introduced under the Jobs Act that remain intact include reduced employment protection for long-term contracts and a much simplified contract system for labour market entrants by introduc-ing a standard open-ended employment contract with gradually increasing protection. The Jobs Act also increased the availability of unemployment benefits, streamlined the use of wage guarantee funds for temporary lay-offs or firm restructuring, and proposed to establish a new national agency to co-ordinate the activities of all employment services providers. The last of these reforms has not been implemented but was included in the M5S-Lega government programme.
The M5S-Lega government is seeking to dilute or reverse aspects of the Jobs Act
Reflecting the impact of a protracted recession, delayed reforms and weak economic recovery since late 2014, Italy's headline jobless rate remains high, at 10.7% in May 2018, compared with the euro area average of 8.4%. The youth unemployment rate was 31.9%-the third highest in the euro area and well above the 16.8% euro zone average. Despite some recent improvement, Italian labour market participation remains low, particularly among women and young people. According to Eurostat, Italy's employment rate was 62.3% in 2017, compared with the euro area average of 71%. The female employment rate was 52.5%, compared with 65.4% in the euro area.
In March 2018 Italy's three main trade union confederations and the business association, Confindustria, agreed a new national wage bargaining. It provides the basis for sectoral agreements at national level, as well as second-level plant or regional agreements linking wage increases to company performance and productivity gains. Greater use of second-level agreements would allow Italy to regain some of its lost export competitiveness, which has accompanied a decade of flat productivity growth and moderately rising wages. It could also address regional disparities in productivity and help to boost employment in southern regions where structural unemployment is higher.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.5 6.5 32 38 15 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Infrastructure quality in the south will continue to lag the rest of the country
As reflected in its unchanged score and the decline in its regional and global rankings, the quality of Italy's infrastructure is set to remain below the average of other developed countries during the forecast period. A significant disparity between the north and the south of the country will also continue. Budgetary constraints have limited public investment in the past 25-30 years, and local interest groups have succeeded in blocking or delaying several major projects in the transport and energy sectors. Corruption investigations are another relatively common reason for delays. Telecommunications costs have fallen and device ownership has risen, along with internet use and broadband penetration, but Italy continues to lag most other developed countries in these markets, and the rollout of high-speed broadband services has been slow.
Fiscal consolidation will hold back public investment in infrastructure
The economy minister in the M5S-Lega government, Giovanni Tria, has promised to revive public capital spending by curbing current spending, freeing up funds earmarked for infrastructure projects and removing administrative obstacles that have held up investments. However, Italy's high debt servicing costs combined with competing demands within the coalition suggest that a radical change in policy direction is unlikely. Since entering government M5S has continued to oppose the continued construction of the high-speed rail link through the Alps, from Turin in the north east of Italy to Lyon, a major city in south-eastern France.
Limited domestic energy sources and popular opposition to the development of nuclear-power generation will continue to cause uncertainty about security and diversification of supply. Poor infrastructure in energy distribution is likely to keep upward pressure on costs. Investment will also continue to face strong local resistance.
After a slow start, government efforts to accelerate investment in fibre-to-the-home (FTTH) networks providing high-speed internet access will make progress. Central to the government's plans is Open Fiber, which is now jointly owned by Enel and CDP. Open Fiber plans to build FTTH networks in 270 cities in Italy, investing EUR3.7bn in the development of the network, EUR3bn of this by 2020. In April 2018 the CDP also took a 4.2% stake in Telecom Italia, which plans to roll out its own fibre network. The CDP's move may eventually lead to some form of co-operation between Open Fibre and Telecom Italia that would avoid unnecessary duplication of the network.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.0 7.5 23 28 12 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption. Italy's score deteriorates in the forecast period compared with the historical period, thereby contributing to falls in both our global and regional rankings. E-commerce is growing rapidly, reflecting improvements in the online environment, for instance regarding after-sales service; however, growth is from a low base with online purchases account-ing for only 6% of retail sales (compared with 19% in the UK).
Mobile-phone penetration is one of the highest in Europe, and take-up of new technologies such as smartphones and high-speed mobile contracts has usually been impressive. Spending on innovation, and research and development (R&D) is relatively low for a developed economy, largely reflecting a preponderance of smaller and family-run firms, high levels of corporate debt, and limited public financial support. According to OECD data for 2016, total R&D spending (for both the public and private sectors) was the equivalent of 1.3% of GDP (compared with an EU average of 1.9%).
Digitalisation of public services is a policy priority
The implementation of the Three-Year Plan for the Digital Transformation of the Public Administration in 2017-19 has facilitated steady progress. Digitalisation of public services is one of the M5S's policy priorities.
We expect a slight improvement in R&D and firm-level technology investment, partly supported by the tax credit for R&D investment in effect since mid-2015 and extended in the 2017 budget law up to 2020, but growth will be from a low base. According to the European Patent Office, the number of patent applications in Europe originating in Italy increased by 4.3% in 2017, compared with average growth in Europe of 3.9%. However, Italy only accounted for 2% of the total. Relative to the size of the population, patent applications from Italy was low, at just 70 per million population, ranking Italy just 19th-well behind other major European economies such as Germany, France and the UK.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Since mid-May investors have grown more concerned about Italy's economic outlook. On May 29th-in the midst of the conflict between the president and the ruling parties over the proposed appointment of Paolo Savona as economy and finance minister-the spread of the generic ten-year government bond yield to its German equivalent spiked to 292 basis points-its highest level since 2013. However, the spread has since fallen and the yield remains moderate, at 2.8% in the secondary market at end-July 2018. Meanwhile Italian equities have fallen sharply, with FTSE MIB, Italy's main share index, losing about 9% since mid-May.
Markets have been rattled by the ambivalent stances of the government on EU fiscal rules, although Giovanni Tria has sought to reassure investors that the government will pursue orthodox policies. In an early iteration of their govern-ment contract the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and the Eurosceptic, anti-immigration Lega made several incendiary proposals, such as a renegotiation of the EU treaties to allow countries to leave or opt out of the euro area. The content was greatly watered down in the final document, and much of it is likely to be abandoned.
Observers also remain worried that the government will reverse structural reforms-such as the Fornero pension reform and the Jobs Act, which the government has already taken steps to weaken-and directly challenging EU fiscal rules. M5S and the Lega also put forward a raft of unrealistic spending plans on items such as an expansionary pension reform, the Lega's two-rate flat tax and M5S's means-tested citizenship income. These were estimated to have a positive total net impact on the deficit of 6-7% of 2017 GDP.
Given the long average maturity on government debt, of just under seven years, perennial primary surpluses (excluding interest payments) on the fiscal account and the fact that about two-thirds of tradeable public debt is held domestically, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a crisis in the near term that would lead to a loss of market access. However, owing to the EUR2.3trn public debt stock and the weakness of its banking sector, Italy would be too large to rescue without massive European Central Bank (ECB) support in the event of a large-scale crisis. A full-blown confrontation with the EU would pose a far greater threat to the euro area than the possibility of Greece's departure from the bloc.

Economic forecast: Fiscal policy

Budget balance -2.3 -2.0 -2.9 -2.8 -2.6 -2.5
Government debt 131.7 131.4 130.7 130.4 130.3 130.0
There is considerable uncertainty regarding the direction of Italy's fiscal policy. Mr Tria has asserted that the government intends to reduce the public debt and deficit. However, he has also stated that he does not intend to introduce additional corrective measures to meet the government's deficit target, of 1.6% of GDP in 2018, and has hinted that the 0.8% deficit target for 2019 agreed with the European Commission is too stringent. Signposts for changes in policy will be the autumn update to Italy's medium-term fiscal framework, due to come before parliament in late September, and the draft budget law for 2019, to be presented to the Commission in mid-October.
Our forecast for the 2018 deficit, of 2% of GDP, envisages considerable slippage from the official target. In 2019 we expect that the administration will further widen the shortfall by implementing a portion of its tax and spending pledges, including the neutralisation of the budget safeguard clauses, a partial repeal of the Fornero pension reform, greater investment in employment centres and the phase-in of M5S's citizenship income. Assuming that additional measures are taken on the revenue side, such as a tightening of tax expenditures, the deficit could be limited to 2.9% of GDP-just under the 3% ceiling mandated by the EU.
We believe that the government will not violate the 3% ceiling, as the degree of market volatility in May-June has shown that flagrantly breaching EU rules could trigger intense market pressure. This would be sharpened by the phase-out of the quantitative easing (QE) purchases of sovereign debt by the ECB at end-2018. From 2020 the deficit will narrow, from 2.8% of GDP to 2.5% of GDP in 2022, assuming that the government generates the higher primary surpluses needed to reduce the deficit as interest payments rise. We expect the debt/GDP ratio to remain about 130% for the duration of the forecast period (2018-22).

The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a QE programme that is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The programme will run at EUR15bn per month in October-December before coming to an end. Economic activity in the euro zone has softened this year, but the ECB's view of the outlook remains fairly positive. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the main refinancing rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.

Despite domestic political volatility, we believe that domestic demand growth and a broadly positive outlook for the euro zone economy as a whole will continue to sustain Italy's moderate economic recovery. Following an expansion of 1.6% in 2017, we expect growth of 1.3% in 2018. In 2019-22 we forecast that real GDP growth will average 1.1% per year, with the pace of expansion dipping to 1% in 2020, reflecting a weakening of the external environment, driven by our expectation of a mild cyclical downturn in the US.
We expect the recent boost to real household disposable income and consumption, due to modest tax cuts, to diminish, slowing private consumption growth in 2018-20. Fragile consumer sentiment (reflecting political instability), concern about the impact on savings of protracted difficulties in the banking sector and only modest growth in employment and wages will also hold back private consumption growth. These developments are likely to be only marginally compensated by a rise in transfer spending as a result of the government's expansionary fiscal policies. We forecast annual average growth in private consumption of 1% in 2018-22, compared with 1.4% in 2017.
Public consumption returned to growth in 2016-17 after five consecutive years of contraction. Growth slowed to 0.1% in 2017, but we expect a looser fiscal policy to result in a pick-up in the pace of expansion in 2018-22. It will remain modest, however, at an annual average rate of 0.5%, held down by the need to keep the budget deficit smaller than 3% of GDP. The current administration's more lenient stance towards deficit spending will raise the risk of higher levels of government consumption, however.
Fixed investment expanded for the third consecutive year in 2017; however, owing to public investment cuts, weak business sentiment and difficulty accessing bank credit, it was still more than one-fifth below its 2007 pre-crisis level. We expect the expansion to continue in 2018-22, but forecast that the pace will moderate, from 3.9% in 2017 to an annual average of 2%, held back by public capital spending constraints, slowing domestic demand growth and risks to external demand. There is a risk that the slowdown will be more abrupt, owing to elevated political uncertainty and the potential for higher interest rates. The need to replace ageing machinery and equipment, the extension of tax incentives and a gradual easing of access to credit should prevent further contractions.
Following annual average growth of 6% in 2017, we expect the pace of export growth to moderate to 2.6% in 2018, and to average 3.3% per year in 2019-22, mainly reflecting a forecast slowdown in the US in 2020 and rising trade tensions between the US and the EU. Owing to moderate domestic demand growth and external demand constraints, we expect import growth to outpace export growth during the majority of our forecast period. These forecasts assume that the erection of tit-for-tat tariff barriers between the US and the EU will not precipitate a full-blown trade war. If a trade war were to ensue, trade with non-EU countries, which absorb about 44% of Italy's goods exports in value terms, could be disrupted.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Reflecting the severe impact on the industrial sector of the 2008-o9 global crisis and the subsequent ongoing euro area crisis, industry (excluding construction) accounted for 19.9% of employment in 2017, down from 21.8% in 2007, and 19.2% of nominal gross value added, compared with 20.5% of gross value added in 2007. The manufacturing sector has long been the main strength of the Italian economy, especially Italy's family-owned, small and medium-sized export-oriented companies specialising in products that require high-quality design and engineering. However, the sector faces major challenges owing to Italy's structural problems, the uncertainties arising from the euro zone crisis and domestic political risk, and uncertainty about the global economic outlook caused by the escalation of a trade war between the US and China and rising trade tensions between the EU and the US, as well as our expectation of a cyclical slowdown in the US in 2020.
Italian industry faces major challenges owing to structural deficiencies
In 2017 manufacturing accounted for 16.4% of gross value added, down from 17.8% in 2007 and 20.3% in 1997. The sector's decline has largely been driven by the prolonged weakness of domestic demand, but also by the difficulties that Italian exporters face in remaining competitive within the European single currency area. Unit labour costs have remained well above the euro area average since 2005 and have continued to rise in Italy since 2010, whereas they have fallen in other peripheral euro area economies such as Spain, Greece, Ireland and Portugal. Weak competitiveness and further transfers of low-value-added production out of Italy are likely to lead to a further decline in manufacturing's contribution to the economy during the forecast period.
The automotive industry is one of the flagship sectors of Italian industry. It accounts for about 8% of GDP, almost one-quarter of the contribution from all manufacturing industries and about 10% of the total value of Italian exports. Fiat (Fabbrica Italiana Automobili Torino), which was renamed Fiat-Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) in 2014 after merging with a US-based producer, is the dominant producer in Italy, but the sector also comprises hundreds of firms that manufacture components or provide related services.
After declining in 2008-13, vehicle production in Italy picked up by 6% in 2014 and 45% in 2015, and slowed to 8.8% in 2016 and 3.5% last year. At 1.1m units, annual production is approaching 2007 levels. The fall in 2008-13 reflected the impact of the global economic crisis on demand in Italy and in export markets, as well as the transfer of production to lower-cost countries. A recovery in domestic and external demand drove the rise in output in 2014, whereas the double-digit increase in 2015 was largely driven by the addition of two new models to the FCA's production line at the Melfi factory in southern Italy. The drop in Italian production affected passenger-car output disproportionately. In 2013 passenger-car output was more than 70% lower than in 2000. Following a modest increase of 3% in 2014, Italian passenger-car production rose by 65% in 2015, before moderating to 7.5% in 2016 and 4.2% in 2017.
We expect growth in car registrations in Italy to slow to 1.4% in 2018 as political and economic uncertainty continues following the formation of the M5S-Lega government and rising inflation starts to eat into real wages. The decline in sales will also be driven by higher year-on-year comparisons. We forecast that growth will remain sluggish, averaging about 1.7% in 2019-22, and contracting slightly in 2020 as a result of a slowdown in economic activity linked to a cyclical cooling in the US. Commercial vehicle sales will expand more briskly in 2018, by 5.5%, following a modest contraction in 2017 after strong growth of 49% year on year in 2016. In 2019-22 commercial vehicle sales will also slow, to an average annual expansion of 1.6%, as small declines are expected in 2019 and 2020.
Fiat will face challenges in the wake of Sergio Marchionne's departure
Fiat's strategy to become a major global producer through mergers, acquisitions and alliances abroad is proving challenging and will probably not boost production in Italy, even if it is successful. The company has succeeded in raising margins globally, but has set ambitious targets through 2022, which will be all the more difficult to fulfil following the sudden departure and death of Sergio Marchionne, the firm's iconic chief executive officer since 2004, in late July 2018. Given Italy's high labour costs and other difficulties of doing business in the country, the recent trend of shifting automotive production out of Italy is likely to continue, despite FCA's repeated promise to increase domestic production. Fiat now produces about two-thirds of its vehicles abroad, in China, Brazil, Turkey, Russia, Serbia, Poland and elsewhere. It closed its Termini Imerese plant in Sicily at the end of 2011 and began producing cars at a new plant in Serbia in the first half of 2012. Integration with Chrysler could also result in more production being transferred to plants outside Italy. Following an agreement with the trade unions to introduce more flexible working practices and boost productivity and output at its plant at Pomigliano d'Arco, near Naples, the company transferred production of one of its models from Poland at the beginning of 2012. However, production at the plant was interrupted or reduced at various times during the economic crisis, when demand in the Italian and wider European car markets contracted.
Manufacturing sector performance will depend on the speed of the reforms
In the medium term the performance of the manufacturing sector will depend largely on the implementation of reforms to tackle Italy's structural deficiencies. These include issues such as lack of competition, particularly in the non­tradeable services sectors and utilities, which has meant that companies in Italy pay high prices for domestically produced inputs, such as electricity, compared with competitors elsewhere. The predominance of small companies and their lack of investment in areas such as innovation and research and development (R&D) has prevented them from moving up the value-added chain. There are about 388,000 manufacturing companies in Italy, about 97% of which employ fewer than 50 people. Firms with fewer than ten employees account for about 82% of the total.
Italian small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are often aggregated within sector-specific industrial districts, which, through a combination of co-operation and competition, help to mitigate the impact of the difficulties arising from a lack of expansion. According to the Edison Foundation, a think-tank that monitors 99 industrial districts, exports from the industrial districts fell sharply in euro terms in 2009, but have risen strongly since the beginning of 2010, and previously marginal hi-tech districts have increased their weighting in the index as they have outperformed the overall index and Italy's traditional low-tech manufacturing sectors such as clothing and textiles, and home furniture.
Italian SMEs have begun to consolidate under the pressure of intense competition and the global crisis. However, the availability of domestic funds to support mergers or recapitalisations to start new projects is likely to be curtailed by the need to reduce the government debt burden. This has contributed to a rising number of internationally renowned Italian corporate brands being acquired by foreign companies in recent years, particularly in the luxury and consumer goods sectors. Global designer brands such as Bulgari, Valentino and Lora Piana have been sold to foreign groups, and as of mid­2014 Indesit, Italy's main manufacturer of white goods, is no longer majority Italian owned. This trend is likely to continue during the forecast period.
Construction sector activity is likely to remain subdued in 2016-20
Activity in the construction sector accounted for 4.7% of gross value added in 2017-down marginally from 2016, but well below an annual average of 6% of gross value added in 2006-09-and 6.2% of employment in 2016, compared with 8.6% in 2007. After nine full-year contractions, which left output in the sector about a third below its 2006 peak in real terms, the decline appeared to bottom out in the final quarter of 2014, but activity is likely to remain subdued during the forecast period, reflecting the impact of an eight-year decline in property prices up to 2016. On the EU's harmonised measure, house prices began to fall once again on a year-on-year basis in the fourth quarter of that year, and in January-March 2018, Italy was one of only three countries included in the index where house prices were still decreasing. This will weigh on the construction recovery, as will ongoing corruption investigations involving public works contracts and large government spending cuts are also likely to dampen activity. Various governments have sought to accelerate EU co-financed infrastructure invest-ment plans to provide some support to the sector, but little progress is likely to be made, largely owing to delays at the regional and ministerial levels.
The Lega will not embark on wide-ranking liberalisation programmes
Already accounting for almost 74% of gross value added, the services sector is expected to expand broadly in line with subdued average real GDP growth during the forecast period. Those subsectors that are exposed to foreign competition, such as tourism, are likely to struggle, although security concerns in several competitor markets could help. Sectors that serve mainly the domestic market and have so far enjoyed a high level of protection from competition, such as the professions and retailing, will come under pressure as a result of reforms to reduce barriers to entry, but this is likely to be only gradual. Over the near term, the M5S-Lega government is unlikely to embark on ambitious service-sector liberalisations and would be more likely to introduce protective legislation. High-value­added services sectors, such as design, which are closely tied to clothing, textiles and automotives, Italy's main export sectors, should continue to perform well, even though in some sectors production is increasingly being moved abroad to countries where labour costs are lower.

In 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018, but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and remained close to that level in June-July. The value of the euro could yet come under further pressure from political risk in Italy, and also from monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a broad stabilisation on average, at US$1.21:EUR1 in 2018-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020.
