We expect the current account to remain firmly in surplus, but to decline from 2.8% of GDP in 2017 to 2.2% of GDP in 2018 (revised down from 2.4%), and to average 1.9% in 2019-22. This decline reflects moderate domestic demand growth, a slightly weaker outlook for merchandise trade exports and rising international energy prices (Italy is a major energy importer). Having risen to an estimated average of US$54.4/barrel in 2017, we expect global oil prices to increase to US$73.6/b in 2018 and to an average of US$73.3/b in 2019-22.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Italy
Stocks and flows
Net inward foreign direct investment (FDI) flows are low compared with most other EU countries, and Italy has generally been a net exporter of FDI. Net inflows to Italy picked up to US$34.4bn in 2011 (1.5% of GDP), from about US$10bn (0.5% of GDP) in 2010, but declined again to close to zero in 2012, owing to large disinvestments. Net inflows recovered moderately in 2013-15, averaging US$17.5bn per year (0.9% of GDP). The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that inward FDI rose to US$20bn in 2017, the equivalent of 1% of GDP. Italy attracts less greenfield foreign investment than other large European economies. The total stock of FDI was US$552bn in 2017, compared with about US$865bn in France and about one-third of that in Germany and a quarter of that in the UK. In relation to GDP, the stock of FDI was 28.4% in 2017, compared with 22.9% in 2014, lower than in any other EU country apart from Greece. FDI outflows have also generally been quite small, mainly reflecting the prevalence of small and medium-sized companies in Italy. In 2005-09 Italy recorded substantial outward FDI flows as a result of several major investments abroad in the banking and energy sectors. A similarly large outflow, of about US$52bn, was recorded in 2011, the year that Italian car manufacturer Fiat (Fabbrica Italiana Automobili Torino) bought the US Treasury's remaining stake in Chrysler.
Origin and distribution
FDI from Europe accounts for about 60-65% of company revenue and employment generated by foreign companies with operations in Italy. Companies from North America represent about 25-30% of revenue and employment, and those from Japan for about 3-4%. The manufacturing sector contributed about 40% of the total revenue and value-added of foreign­owned firms, but this has generally been on a downward path and dropped sharply in 2005, when General Motors (US) sold its stake in Fiat. The utilities and telecommunications sectors have registered the most rapid expansion. In 2016, the last year for which data are available (expressed according to the directional principle), the largest FDI stocks came from Luxembourg (EUR64.5bn), France (EUR60bn), the UK (EUR43bn) and Germany (EUR28bn).
Determinants
The main attraction for foreign companies to set up operations in Italy is the size of the domestic market, which offers a population of about 6om and average GDP per head of US$40,3oo, at purchasing power parity (PPP). Deterrents include the complexity of Italy's legal system, inefficiencies in public administration, inadequate infrastructure-particularly in the south of the country-and often high regulatory barriers to entry, especially in services sectors. In addition, studies of the determinants of FDI in southern Italy have highlighted classical deterrents to investment, such as distance from major European markets, low presence of other foreign companies and a high level of organised crime. Such studies seem to indicate that fiscal incentives and the presence of specialised producer service providers have a low impact on foreign entrants' decisions, but that human capital is an important positive variable. Italy has an abundant workforce in the south, which has attracted a few high-technology investments to areas such as Catania in Sicily, where a Franco-Italian joint venture, ST Microelectronics, has a production plant and several research centres.
Impact
According to the ITA, the Italian Trade and Investment Agency, foreign-controlled companies employ more than 1m people in Italy and generate revenue of about EUR5oobn per year. Foreign companies invest on average three and half times more in research and development (R&D) than Italian companies. However, because of the comparatively low level of inflows and their concentration in the north of Italy, the impact of FDI on the Italian economy as a whole has been limited. The depressed areas of the south, which attract limited Italian private-sector investment, would benefit substantially in terms of employment and through the spillover effect of advanced technology, management practices and production processes. However, almost all of the inward FDI stock is located in the north and centre of the country. Despite massive state investment in 1950-84, the south has continued to lag central Italy and the north in GDP per head terms (less than 55% of the average in the centre and north). The unemployment rate in the south is almost double the national average and about three times higher than that in the north.
Potential
The possibility of higher FDI inflows in the forecast period will be hampered by the uncertainty caused by the euro zone crisis and the fact that most of the factors that have deterred FDI in the past will remain in place. The Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Lega administration has also signalled a less friendly policy stance towards foreign investment, marginally tightening labour contract regulations through its so-called "Dignity Decree", definitively approved in August 2018, and providing for penalties for foreign firms that take advantage of government investment incentives and then divest or relocate production to other markets. Over the forecast period (2018-22) a slight improvement is expected in the efficiency of the public administration, as a result of recent and ongoing reforms. The performance of the state body responsible for attracting foreign investors may also improve. Given Italy's need to reduce its dependence on imported energy, there could be potential for investment in the still state-dominated energy sector as liberalisation continues to make progress and the authorities are forced to focus on investment in renewable energy sources, following the decision in mid-2011 to abandon plans to return to nuclear-power generation. Under the M5S-Lega government, which has taken an economic nationalist approach to policymaking, political opposition to foreign interest in ownership of utility networks and possibly some companies in the manufacturing sector is likely to continue, as such companies are deemed to be of a "strategic" nature. M5S, which has taken strong environmental stances in the past, may also use potential ecological consequences as a justification for limiting inward investment, particularly in infrastructure or energy projects. Banking sector reforms may increase opportunities for foreign investment in smaller Italian banks, but there appears to be limited interest at present.

Population growth is projected to come to a virtual halt
Having declined for several years in the late 1990s, Italy's total population increased moderately in 1999-2011, rising by an average of 0.3% per year. Since then the population has resumed its decline, falling to 59.4m in 2017, according to the UN's population estimates. The fall was mainly driven by the natural decline of the Italian population outpacing immigration. This trend is likely to continue, as the expectation of scarce job opportunities due to the weakness of the economy has probably reduced the influx of immigrants and driven further emigration of young Italians. The Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Lega government's tough stance on immigration may further discourage foreigners from settling in Italy. Since the EU's March 2016 agreement with Turkey, the flow of migrants from Turkey to Greece and on to northern Europe has more or less ceased, but this has coincided with a sharp increase in migrant flows to Italy. Migrant inflows have fallen sharply in 2018. This is partly due to stepped-up collaboration with the Libyan authorities, but also to the inflexible stance of the M5S-Lega administration and of the Maltese authorities, which appears to be deterring migrant vessels from seeking to cross the central Mediterranean. In the past most migrants arriving in Italy moved on to other EU countries, notably Germany.
According to Istat (the national statistics office), the proportion of foreign residents in the total population has increased steadily in recent years, from 4.5% in 2005 to 8% at end-2013 and 8.3% at end-2017, unchanged from the previous year. The majority of immigrants live in the north and the centre of Italy, where foreign residents accounted for 10.6% of the population at end-2017 (latest available data), up from about 10% in 2013. However, growth in the number of foreign nationals residing in the south has begun to outpace that in the north and the centre in recent years. The three largest national groups are Romanians, Albanians and Moroccans, who together account for about 40% of the total number of foreign residents. Even during periods of modest economic growth, shortages of skilled and even unskilled workers are likely to re-emerge in areas of high employment such as the north east, owing to deficiencies in the labour market.
Although almost 70% of Italians live in urban areas, the population is widely dispersed among numerous small cities and towns. As a result, local markets tend to be diffused and relatively small in scale. The combined population of Italy's three largest cities-Rome (the capital), Milan and Naples-accounts for less than 10% of the country's total population, although if the outer suburbs are included, the three main urban areas account for about 20% of the total population.
Reforms seek to increase labour mobility
The steady rise in the employment rate (the percentage of people aged 20-64 in employment) since the mid-1990s came to a halt in 2008. At 62.3% in 2016, just below the 62.9% employment rate in 2008, according to Eurostat, it was 10 percentage points lower than the EU28 average and the third-lowest rate in the EU. The reasons for this include cultural factors, but also the low effective retirement age and limited mobility from areas of high unemployment in the south to those of high employment in the north. Low labour mobility has been perpetuated to a large extent by the greater use of temporary employment contracts, especially for young workers, poor active labour market policies and an inadequate system of unemployment benefits. The labour market reforms approved since 2012 aim to address some of these issues gradually during the forecast period (2018-22). In spite of the projected decline in the working-age population during the forecast period, the labour force will increase moderately. This will be attributable to greater female participation as well as pension reforms, which have reduced the incentive for early retirement.
The rise in proportion of elderly will put pressure on pensions and healthcare
During the forecast period the number of people of working age will be considerably lower than the number of people reaching 65. As a result, Italy's old-age dependency ratio (the ratio of people aged over 65 to those of working age) will rise further. At an estimated 34.8% in 2017, it is the highest in the EU, and will continue to rise. This trend, combined with the continued rise in life expectancy, will continue to put upward pressure on public expenditure on pensions and care for the elderly. Italy's public pension spending has been on a steadily rising trend and is among the highest in the EU as a share of GDP. According to figures from the Ministry of the Economy, public pension spending is projected to decline gradually over the next ten years, from a peak of about 16% in 2013-14, owing to a series of reforms introduced since the beginning of the 1990s. This trend could slow marginally, however, if the M5S-Lega government is successful in undoing the 2011 Fornero pension reform, the most recent effort to improve the social security system's sustainability.

Italy is a major market, but growth potential remains limited
Italy is one of the largest markets in Europe, with a population of just under 60m, and is one of its most affluent nations. However, growth potential remains limited because the country is a mature consumer market with weak income and population growth prospects.
In 2015 the economy began to emerge from a protracted recession. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the recovery to continue during the forecast period (2018-22) but domestic demand growth will remain subdued, given high unemployment, weak business investment, the ongoing need for fiscal consolidation in Italy, high taxation and moderate wage growth.
In terms of private consumption per head, Italy is just below the euro area average, but well below Finland, Sweden, France and Germany. However, the relative weakness of Italian economic growth for much of the past 15-20 years means that GDP per head-at purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion rates that explicitly adjust for differences in price levels between countries-has fallen steadily as a percentage of the EU28 average, remaining below 100% since 2013. GDP per head at PPP rates stood at US$39,169 in 2016 and an estimated US$40,260 last year. Income levels differ greatly on a regional basis, with GDP per head in the south about 46% of that in the north. Development policies in the past 50 years have done little to close the gap.

Despite relatively high income levels, spending on food, beverages and tobacco is still high as a share of total consumer spending, at about 18%-just above the level in France but above that in the Netherlands (about 15%), Germany (13.9%) and the UK (12%). We expect it to decline only gradually during the forecast period, largely because of subdued spending on other categories of goods and services.
Consumer credit demand has begun to rise, after several years of stagnation and/or contraction. Household indebtedness is relatively low and interest rates on consumer loans have declined and are expected to rise only moderately in 2018-22, containing the proportion of disposable income spent on debt servicing. Still, we expect only moderately stronger demand for big-ticket items and branded goods, as consumers are likely to postpone purchases until sen-timent improves further and risks to the recovery diminish. Rates of ownership of traditional consumer durable goods, such as white goods and passenger cars, are generally high, so demand will be driven by technological change and the need to replace ageing stock.
Demand for electronic goods, such as computers (especially laptops and tablets) and smartphones, has shown a tendency to outperform the rest of the consumer goods market. Growth will be driven by innovations such as smartphones, tablet computers and, more recently, wearable technology. However, weak income growth will dampen demand. Personal computer (PC) access lags well behind countries such as the UK and Germany, where the penetration rate is above 90% of households, and France, where it is about 84%, compared with about 73% in Italy.
The ageing population will drive growth in healthcare spending
Demographic trends will have an important impact on spending patterns. The ageing population will continue to drive overall healthcare spending, but we expect efforts to curb public healthcare expenditure to meet budgetary targets.
Italians tend to live at home with their parents, often until their mid-thirties. Thus, a larger portion of the disposable income of those aged 18-35 has tended to be spent on leisure and consumer goods than in other countries, although this trend is likely to be offset by low salaries for many young people who have work and one of the highest youth unemployment rates (among the 15-24 age group) in Europe, despite declining gradually in recent years. In June 2018 it was 32.6%, down from a peak of 43.5% in March 2014-almost double pre-crisis levels in 2007-08.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: Italy's economic growth performance has been poor in the past two decades, even in comparison with the sluggish average rate of growth achieved by core countries within the EU. Besides undergoing severe fiscal consolidation during the 1990s in order to join the euro area, which dampened growth in that decade, the Italian economy has suffered from a steady loss of competitiveness owing to low productivity growth and rising unit labour costs (reflecting falling output, despite wage moderation since 1993)-in contrast to the situation in its main trading partners.
The weakness of Italy's political and institutional framework policy hinders policy formulation, as reforms are frequently delayed or watered down under pressure from a wide range of interest groups. The current administration has denounced the emphasis on structural reforms advocated by the EU and, at least nominally, espoused by previous governments. It may undo some of the meagre progress made in recent years and is unlikely to enact policy changes that will improve the country's competitiveness. Italy's public finances also remain weak, limiting the scope to reduce taxation or stimulate demand during cyclical downturns. Major brakes on Italy's long-term growth will be the country's unfavourable demographic profile, low labour participation rates, a collapse in fixed investment during the recent recession, and low levels of investment in research and development (R&D).
Unfavourable demographic trends will weigh on long-term growth
Demographic trends: Italy's demographic profile is particularly unfavourable. Projected net immigration is expected to be insufficient to halt the continued decline in the working-age population in the long-term forecast period up to 2050. Italy's labour market participation rate is expected to rise from current low levels of about 66%, but only moderately, reflecting an increase in the number of women joining the workforce and a gradual rise in the minimum retirement age, but it will remain well below the OECD average (about 72% in 2017) and will be insufficient to prevent an annual average decline in the labour force of 0.6% in 2018-50.
External conditions: The effects of the global crisis of 2008-09 and the height of the euro area crisis in 2010-13 will be felt for years. The risk that the sovereign debt crisis in financially stressed peripheral countries in the euro area, including Italy, will lead to a partial or even complete break-up of the single currency area, which would have severe negative consequences for Italy's long-term economic prospects, has eased, but The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that it is more likely than not that Greece will leave the euro area by the end of our forecast period. Even without Greece in the euro area, the euro zone member states are still a long way from resolving the structural shortcomings of the single currency area, and the rhetoric of the Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Lega government risks provoking instances of market volatility, particularly as European Central Bank (ECB) support through quantitative easing (QE) is phased out at end-2018.
Italian companies have generally been slow to adapt to the rigours of fixed exchange rates in the euro area and the increase in competition from goods produced in low-cost developing countries, although some traditional manufacturing sectors have undergone restructuring in recent years, notably textiles and clothing, and also automotive. This difficulty seems unlikely to change in the medium to long term. In the past, clusters of family-owned small and medium-sized export-oriented manufacturing companies located in the so­called industrial districts in the north and centre of the country showed greater flexibility and ability to adapt to changing external conditions than Italy's few large companies. However, more recently they have struggled to compete in some low- to medium-technology sectors. This is attributed to the lack of investment in R&D and innovation and marketing, as well as to difficulties in protecting and promoting the generic ''Made in Italy" brand, which has long been considered synonymous with good quality and style. To survive, Italian companies will have to expand in size and increasingly outsource low-value-added production to locations in central and eastern Europe and Asia, where costs-especially labour costs-are lower. The reluctance to relinquish control will hinder the expansion of family-owned businesses, which also often face difficult choices in terms of management succession.
With institutional change off the agenda, economic reform will be slow
Institutions and policy trends: Italy's poor growth performance has raised concerns among policymakers about the country's future economic prospects. Policy responses triggered by such debates in the past have generally been short lived. Some reforms have been introduced since the financial turmoil of late 2011. However, popular and political resistance to reform halted the Renzi government's attempt to overhaul Italy's institutional framework in 2014-16, taking institutional change off the political agenda for the foreseeable future. Without a substantial improvement in its political and institutional framework, Italy's efforts to carry out reforms will continue to lag the rapid pace of change in the world economy and the increase in competition. The M5S-Lega administration, which campaigned forcefully against the constitutional reform, has no intention of pursuing further institutional changes and will seek to loosen fiscal consolidation marginally and soften recent structural reforms.
In particular, Italy will need further liberalisation of its product and services markets, although recent reforms, if they are not reversed, should help to reduce labour market rigidities over the medium to long term. A more comprehensive system of unemployment protection envisaged under the 2012 and 2014 reforms could help to enhance labour mobility, but there may be a lack of resources without more drastic cuts in public spending on pensions, which is projected to ease from a peak of just under 16% of GDP in 2013-14 to just above 15% in 2019, according to the Treasury (before rising again until the late 2040 and falling again sharply thereafter). The M5S-Lega government has vowed to roll back the most recent reform, passed in 2011, which could lead to a deterioration in the pension spending profile. To raise long-term productivity growth, the country will also have to improve the quality of human capital. Recent education reforms have sought to address shortcomings in the education system, including high drop-out rates and mismatches between the skills needed by employers and qualifications held by potential employees.
A more favourable policy environment would boost long-term growth
Long-term performance: Our baseline forecast is that Italian GDP growth will average 0.6% per year in 2018-50, which is considerably weaker than what was until recently considered to be Italy's trend rate of growth (1.5%). The main brake on long-term growth will be an unfavourable demographic profile, which will be offset only partly by expected moderate improvements in labour productivity and technological infrastructure. Other industrialised countries will continue to grow faster than Italy, and so it will fall further behind in terms of GDP per head, which in the decade to 2017 fell from 107% of the EU28 average to 96%. In addition, decades of massive public-sector spending have done little to narrow the large income gap between the more developed centre and north of Italy and the south of the country. This imbalance is expected to continue to weigh on Italy's overall growth performance in the long term. A more favourable political environment could produce a better economic growth performance in the long term, but the chance of improvements in Italy's institutional framework being implemented in the short to medium term is limited.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Climate change is expected to have a moderate, but clearly negative effect on Italian living standards and the economy. Hotter summers increase the risk of drought, particularly in the country's southern and island regions, in many parts of which water is scarce. This will have an impact on food crops and agricultural production, and could affect human health, as well. In 2017 six of 20 Italian regions called on the government to declare a state of emergency owing to water stress. In addition to putting traditional agricultural products such wine grapes at risk, an increased incidence of drought will also heighten the risk of wildfires. Italy has about 7,600 km of coastline, and rising sea levels could put some low-lying coastal areas of the country at risk of flooding. Rising seas will be particularly problematic for the city of Venice, a major tourist destination, and more erratic weather patterns are likely to strain ageing infrastructure.
Technological developments
Despite Italy's sizeable manufacturing base and the presence of some notable high-technology firms, technological uptake has been limited, constrained in part by small average firm size and family management, which in some cases limits innovation. In 2017-18 a representative survey of nearly 24,000 industrial firms conducted by the Ministry of Economic Development found that only 8.4% had implemented technologies associated with "Industry 4.0", or the trend towards automation and data exchange in manufacturing, such as 3D printing, the Internet of Things, Cloud technologies, or Big Data analytics. The share rises sharply, from 6% of firms with fewer than ten employees, to about 47% of firms with 250 employees or more. In 2016 research and development (R&D) spending accounted for just 1.3% of GDP-well below the EU average of 2%. Meanwhile the trade balance of high-technology goods stood at -0.54% of GDP in 2015 (latest data available). Since 2016, a series of tax credits and deductions known as Impresa 4.0 has been introduced to encourage investment in R&D and productivity-enhancing technologies, but a higher level of direct support and possibly an upskilling of the labour force may be necessary to take full advantage of technological advances. Persons with a tertiary degree or employed in science and technology account for about 33% of total employment, while higher education suffers from relatively high dropout rates and long university completion times.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Thailand--highlights: Political outlook
The military-led government will remain in complete control until the next general election, which The Economist Intelligence Unit expects to be held in 2019. The new constitution (approved by the public in a referendum in 2016), which will be adopted under a newly elected government, will allow the military to maintain significant influence over executive and legislative affairs in 2018-22. The military's overarching influence will ensure political stability for most of the forecast period. However, organised, but non-violent, challenges to government cannot be ruled out, particularly later in the forecast period.
Thailand--highlights: Business environment outlook

Thailand's business environment score rises in 2018-22, helping to improve its global ranking to 38th, from 40th in 2013-17. Its regional position remains at ninth out of 17 countries. The macroeconomic environment will stabilise, although it will remain vulnerable to external conditions. We expect improvements in policies towards private enterprise and competition and towards foreign investment. The overall tax regime will remain stable and accommodative to business. Trade liberalisation will continue, with growing integration among Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) members and other countries in Asia. Long-overdue construction on a number of transport infrastructure projects will also get under way, resulting in significant gains in that area for business.

We forecast that Thailand's real GDP will expand by 4% on average in 2018, and growth will average 3.4% a year in 2018-22, compared with 2.8% in 2013-17, owing in large part to stronger external demand. Public investment in infrastructure development will also lend considerable support to growth in the early part of the forecast period. Private consumption will remain under pressure owing to high household debt. Nonetheless, a clearer political path following the elections in 2019 will reassure investors, helping to boost growth in the later years of the forecast period as a cyclical upswing in external demand takes root again. The tourism sector will remain a key support for the economy throughout 2018-22.

The rate of population growth will slow in the forecast period as a result of effective family-planning programmes, sex education and changing social norms, such as later marriages and smaller families. Continuing improvement in the prevention and treatment of infectious disease will contribute to a rising life expectancy and a growing share of the population over 65 years old. However, owing to a shortage of formal job opportunities in neighbouring countries, migrant labour from Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos will continue to grow in absolute terms. This will serve to boost the labour force in 2018-22, against the trend of a gradually declining domestic workforce.

Thailand is a sizeable market in its own right, with a population of 69m and nominal GDP equivalent to US$455.5bn at market exchange rates in 2017. The retail sector will create market opportunities, in large part owing to the continuing strength of the tourism sector. Although the current and next government will try to rely less on fiscal handouts, which have boosted household purchasing power in recent years, they will have to maintain supportive policies for key interest groups in order to ensure political stability. Household debt will remain a dampener on consumer sentiment in the forecast period, but a tax regime increasingly focused on wealth, rather than income and consumption, will avoid crimping private consumption growth further.
Thailand--highlights: Long-term outlook

The long-term outlook for Thailand's economy hinges heavily on the assumption that governments in the next ten years will possess greater political power than their predecessors to enact and continue structural reforms, as well as develop infrastructure. Such reforms will improve the business environment and raise productivity. However, there will be persistent delays, owing to fiscal constraints and difficulties in attracting foreign investment amid strong regional competition. Thailand's demographic profile will also start to have a significant, negative impact on GDP growth from the 2030s.

Background: Following a revolution in 1932, Thailand's absolute monarchy was replaced with a constitutional monarchy. While the elected government gained prominence, democracy was turbulent and subject to several coups (19 have been staged since 1932). The latest coup took place in May 2014, when the democratically elected government led by Yingluck Shinawatra was removed following months of protests and political turmoil. The Shinawatra family gained prominence in Thai politics in 2001 when Thaksin Shinawatra, a businessman-turned-politician and Yingluck's older brother, was elected prime minister. He remained in office until 2006, when he was removed by a coup. Thaksin was a populist leader, and his political prominence created a divide between the rural population in the northern provinces and the urban rich of the south. This rift is a lasting consequence of Thai democracy and has emerged from income inequality between the rural and urban parts of the country. Although the junta remains firmly in control of government, a return to a limited form of democracy is likely to give way to renewed rivalry between the two camps.
Political structure: The military officers who comprise the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO, the formal name for the junta), led by Prayuth Chan-ocha as prime minister, control an interim government made up of a 200-member National Legislative Assembly (parliament), a 35-member cabinet and a 250-member reform council. The members of these bodies were appointed by the NCPO and are mainly military officers. The king remains the symbolic head of state. Following the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej in October 2016, the crown prince, Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, ascended the throne.
Policy issues: The military-led government will focus on improving the investment environment in Thailand and head a public-investment drive in infrastructure in an effort to boost the country's long-term economic performance. The junta's continuing grip on power will reassure many foreign investors deterred by potential instability, but growing regional competition will detract from Thailand's attractiveness as an investment destination.
Taxation: Corporate income tax stands at 20%. Tax concessions are available for firms that list on the stockmarket. Value-added tax (VAT) stands at 7%. Personal income tax rises to 35% on annual taxable earnings exceeding Bt5m (US$150,000).
Foreign trade: Thailand recorded a merchandise trade surplus (fob-fob) of US$31.9bn in 2017, down from US$36.5bn in 2016. However, the current-account surplus stood at US$48.1bn in 2017, mostly unchanged from US$48.2 in 2016.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The military rules the country via a junta known as the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO), led by the former army chief and current prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha. The military coup in May 2014 led to the dissolution of the House of Representatives (parliament) elected in 2011. The NCPO appointed an interim National Legislative Assembly in its place in August 2014, consisting mainly of security officers and civilians supportive of the military. A 250-member National Reform Council, which is tasked with recommending reforms and approving a new charter, was also appointed. A new constitution was approved in a public referendum in August 2016, paving the way for fresh elections but also sealing the considerable influence of the military on the next government. However, the NCPO's planned path back to elections has been delayed by the death in late 2016 of the previous king, Bhumibol Adulyadej, and pending coronation of the new monarch, Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, as well as the slow passage of legislation relating to the new charter. The accession process has not been destabilising, partly owing to the military government's imperative to sustain the royal institution in order to legitimise its own political role. Nonetheless, the king's prominent place in Thai society will slowly diminish in coming years, as the new monarch fails to command the same level of reverence among the public that his father did.
Political outlook: Political stability
The NCPO will control the legislature until the elections, which The Economist Intelligence Unit expects to take place by mid-2019. The junta used the passing of King Bhumibol in 2016 and the subsequent royal succession as a means to postpone the return to some form of democratic system. However, any further delays will be more difficult to justify. The incidence of small-scale protests has also been rising; although most of them have not been directly related to the political situation, they do indicate an increasing unwillingness to capitulate to the military's stance against public demonstrations and political activity.
The junta has maintained strict oversight and censorship of the mass media and public debate, in an attempt to suppress dissent. It is likely to lift most of these restrictions before end-2018 in preparation for elections. Nonetheless, the junta's clampdown on freedom of speech and association is exacerbating public discontent with the current political situation. This increases the risk of large-scale public protests, especially if further indications of abuse of power by officials come to light. However, such an event still remains outside our core forecast.
A new constitution, approved in a public referendum in 2016, has cemented the military's continued influence over the government even after the next ballot. The rule of King Maha, who succeeded his much-revered late father, will have a minimal impact on political stability in 2018-22. The military establishment depends on royal endorsement for much of its political legitimacy. It has therefore ensured the continuance of the monarchy in line with the wishes of the late king and has proactively suppressed criticism of the new king via lese-majesty laws. This will continue under the current military government and, to a lesser extent, under the next administration.
King Maha has already sought to consolidate his position in the political sphere by tailoring to his preference rules concerning the delegation of the monarch's authority and control over the royal estate. Although some of these alterations indicate a slightly stronger foundational role in politics than in the previous charter, in practice royal intrusion into everyday politics will remain rare. Indeed, many of the changes were simply aimed at ensuring that the king could continue to reside outside the country for long periods without having to delegate his powers. Similarly, the transfer of royal assets from the Crown Property Bureau to the direct control of the King, announced in June, is probably an effort to further secure and delegate his power among only his closest allies.
The election of a new government will be accepted with little open resistance in the light of the 2016 constitutional referendum result. However, if strict rules prohibiting criticism of the authorities are carried over under the next govern-ment, the risk of political instability will rise markedly. This risk would already be high given the maintenance of the military's overtly central role in the political system; the Senate (the upper house of parliament) will be dominated by figures linked to the military. Therefore, challenges to the next government-in the form of political boycotts and protests-cannot be ruled out. Such challenges are more likely to occur towards the end of the forecast period, especially if the next government fails to preside over a robust and inclusive economic recovery. A significant economic downturn is not our core forecast, however. Moreover, the risk of armed civil conflict remains negligible, and any major stands against the next government and its constitutionally dictated set-up are likely to be headed by non-military political factions.
The insurgency in the Muslim-dominated southern provinces of Yala, Pattani and Narathiwat will rage on beyond the elections. This will consist of small-scale attacks targeting security forces and-occasionally-religious sites frequented by civilians. These will include sporadic attacks within agreed safe-zone areas, owing to the proliferation of insurgent groups outside the MARA Pattani, an umbrella group for six separatist movements in southern Thailand. However, the insurgency presents only a minimal threat to overall political stability. The possibility of the insurgency expanding significantly and spreading to other parts of the country remains low. We therefore do not expect the situation to threaten Thailand's important tourism sector in 2018-22.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The outlook for political and institutional effectiveness is more certain in the wake of public approval of the junta-drafted constitution and the smooth accession of the new king. Unlike the previous government, which faced major street demonstrations and legal challenges in opposition to its policies, the junta possesses near-absolute power to implement its agenda as a transitional government until the next elections. Moreover, regardless of the subsequent poll results, the military establishment has sealed overarching influence over the next government via the new charter.
The new constitution outlines an administrative structure that is formed with a larger proportion of appointed officials than previously. Moreover, rules in the constitution for the appointment of a prime minister mean that it is likely that these appointed officials will join their publicly elected counterparts in selecting an individual for the position. This is likely to result in the selection of a military-preferred candidate for prime minister. This will allow the military to dominate government decision-making, while curtailing the power of democratically elected officials. Although such changes are likely to expedite the policymaking process, they bode ill for the public accountability of government.
The NCPO has appointed technocrats to manage the economy and is determined to outline a long-term strategy for the country in addition to its short- to medium-term focus on reviving investment and private consumption. Its proposed 20-year "National Strategy" is currently being drafted and the next government will be constitutionally bound to follow it, under the explicit threat of impeachment. It is already clear that infrastructure development is likely to be a core supporting strategy within it, to sustain primary goals including rebalancing public- and private-sector development, and special economic zone development.
Nevertheless, in the near term the junta is likely still to devote significant resources to populist policies when needed to appease key interest groups, such as agricultural producers. Avoiding inflaming future political tensions will remain a key underlying priority. However, the military has not made any material progress in reconciling the political differences between the rural population of the north (who supported Thaksin) and the elite in southern Thailand (who are represented by his detractors, the Democrat Party). Therefore, although the military-appointed component of the next government will enjoy efficacy in policymaking, it will still find it difficult to satisfy the two major camps and may face rising opposition from one or both in the medium term-the same tensions that have plagued its predecessors.
Corruption will remain a significant problem in many of the country's institutions, including the military. Cases under the next government involving unelected officials, particularly those with explicit military links, may serve as a flashpoint for discontent over the new constitutional system and its lack of accountability. If open discontent does materialise it is more likely to be from a cumulative series of incidents and thus occur later in the forecast period. Continuing corruption in the local police force allows the capital, Bangkok, to host one of the world's largest shadow economies. The junta has made efforts to show a tougher stance against corruption, for instance by setting up a dedicated court to try relevant cases and proposing the death penalty for the involvement of high-level officials, as well as for foreigners, in graft. However, similar initiatives have been popular with past military governments and have shown little progress. There is little reason to believe that the junta and the next government will be any more successful in clamping down on corrupt activities.
Political outlook: Election watch
After numerous delays relating to the drafting of new "organic laws" under the new constitution in 2017 and early 2018, the prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, subsequently confirmed that elections would be held in early 2019. We believe that polls will be held in that year, as the possibility of further postponement is tempered by rising public unrest. This has reduced the junta's motivation to delay the poll yet again, for fear of provoking large-scale demonstrations. The junta will want to avoid a forceful clampdown on protesters, as this would undermine attempts by senior military officials to portray themselves as legitimate political actors in the reformed political system and the next government.
Political outlook: International relations
Western countries are gradually restoring relations with Thailand for the sake of economic ties and in response to wider concerns about China's political influence in the region, despite continuing rule by military government. The administration of the US president, Donald Trump, has led a partial rapprochement between Thailand and the US, culminating in a state visit by Prayuth in October 2017. Subsequent meetings between Prayuth and Theresa May and Emmanuel Macron, the prime minister and president of the UK and France respectively, further attest to this trend of reconcilement. Notably, however, the EU's Foreign Affairs Council has reiterated that although political ties have been re-established, talks on a free-trade agreement (FTA) between the bloc and the kingdom will not resume until the return of a civilian government. We expect the complete normalisation of Thailand's ties with governments in the West following the next election, despite the significant influence that the military will retain over the next, nominally civilian government.
Japan, which is wary of being superseded by China (with regard to large-scale investment projects), has demonstrated a willingness to preserve most diplomatic engagement and continue bilateral FTA negotiations with Thailand during the junta's rule. This means that major economic co-operation deals between the two countries will go ahead regardless, including infrastructure projects to be built under Japanese contracts.
Nonetheless, China's influence in Thailand will continue to grow in 2018-22, especially in the early part of the forecast period, while the government is under full military control. The two countries have no conflicting territorial claims in the South China Sea and are important trading partners. Economic ties are set to strengthen further as Thailand focuses on forging bilateral deals between state-owned enterprises under its public investment drive. However, this growing relationship will not be without its setbacks, as illustrated by the stop-start progress of the planned China-Laos-Thailand high-speed rail project. Such tussles will delay the economic benefits of greater regional integration.
Notably, increasing bilateral co-operation with China seems unlikely to obstruct Thailand's ongoing efforts to engage with its neighbours in the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN). This is in part because tensions between other ASEAN members and China in relation to territorial disputes in the South China Sea have eased.

Thailand's business environment score increases from 6.40 in 2013-17 to 6.74 in 2018-22. In The Economist Intelligence Unit's global rankings, Thailand improves from 40th to 38th place, but its position in the Asia-Pacific region remains at ninth out of 17 countries. The score for political environment will improve. Although significant risks will remain, political stability will be maintained for much of the forecast period, including after the next government comes to power in 2019. This is in large part because the military's central role in the subsequent government will stifle any partisan conflicts and improve political effectiveness. Separatist violence in the south will continue and is unlikely to dissipate before the end of the forecast period. The risk of unrest permanently spreading to other parts of the country is low, however.
The macroeconomic environment will stabilise in the forecast period, although it will remain vulnerable to external conditions. An improvement in the scores for policy towards private enterprise and competition and policy towards foreign investment under an elected government will encourage a moderate uptick in investment. This will be aided by an open capital account and a relatively stable currency. However, lacklustre domestic demand will continue to be a major drag on business sentiment, with high household debt weighing on private consumption prospects. The Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) will remain independent and monetary policy will be fairly conservative. Ambitious transport infrastructure projects boost the score for infrastructure by the largest increment of all the categories, as a drive to make comprehensive improvements to the country's transport capacities gets underway.
