Business environment outlook: Thailand's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The authorities reorganise the management of several state-owned enterprises but do not sell off significant assets.
2020-22: Thailand remains on the US Trade Representative's intellectual property rights (lower priority) watchlist, despite an improvement in enforcement.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: The government provides lucrative incentives for investment in several high value-added subsectors in the new Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) special economic zone spanning three provinces south-east of the capital, Bangkok.
2020-22: Opposition to the sale of assets to foreigners persists, particularly in the utilities sector. Rules allowing full foreign property ownership in the EEC provinces spur a boom in real estate investment there.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Administrative procedures for trade transactions with other members of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) are streamlined amid efforts to step up integration of the ASEAN Economic Community.
2020-22: Negotiations on an EU-Thailand pact and on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership agreement between ASEAN and Australia, China, India, Japan, New Zealand and South Korea enter the final stages.
Taxes
2018-19: New land and property taxes are introduced from 2019. The government sanctions income tax deductions on domestic hotel and travel expenses during a limited period of the year again.
2020-22: The government raises slightly the rate of value-added tax (VAT) from the current level of 7%. Inheritance tax laws are revised to expand their coverage, providing a boost to government revenue.
Financing
2018-19: The authorities continue to focus on expanding the local bourse, opening equity financing options to more firms.
2020-22: Commercial banks based in other ASEAN countries begin to offer retail services in Thailand under the ASEAN Banking Integration Framework.
The labour market
2018-19: The average provincial minimum wage rises in 2018 but low inflation allows the authorities to delay further increases. A clampdown on unregistered migrants affects the availability of low-skilled labour in the short term.
2020-22: Shortages of skilled labour increase, driving up costs in service industries in particular. The government loosens immigration controls on foreign skilled workers.
Infrastructure
2018-19: The expansion of road and rail infrastructure progresses slowly, providing a boost to the construction sector.
2020-22: Completion of the Thailand section of the China-Laos-Thailand railway is delayed. Passenger capacity expansions of Suvarnabhumi and Don Mueang airports in the capital are completed.
Technological readiness
2018-19: The government allows tax deductions for research and development expenditure in strategic sectors.
2020-22: The Board of Investment continues to prioritise projects under the ten listed sectors within the Thailand 4.0 plan.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.8 8.0 20 24 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
There will be a slight improvement in Thailand's macroeconomic environment during the forecast period. However, greater improvement in countries outside Asia will see Thailand's global ranking deteriorate from 20th in 2013-17 to 24th in 2017-21. Its regional ranking will remain static, at 6th, over the same period. Relatively low public debt, a firmly positive current-account balance and fairly stable fiscal, monetary and exchange-rate policies will underpin macro-economic stability. After several years of volatility, economic growth has been relatively steady since 2015 and is expected to remain so during 2018-22. Yet a pick-up in growth rates on a par with its peers in the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) will prove elusive. This will be mainly owing to the increasing competition from other ASEAN countries in key high-value merchandise export industries.
The economy will stabilise in 2018-22, compared with 2013-17
The military's control of government has allowed for more rapid approval of policy, including major spending plans. Up until elections in 2019 the junta will continue to use its unchecked powers to fast-track policymaking and the approval of projects, including intermittent populist policies to appease influential interest groups such as agricultural producers. Furthermore, under the constitution approved in 2016, it will be able to exert considerable influence on policymaking following the next elections, which we expect to take place in 2019. This will help to ensure that business-oriented tax reform and investment incentives are maintained and expanded in 2018-22, and that major infrastructure investment projects continue beyond the end of the forecast period. Private investment will continue to struggle in the early part of the forecast period, but this will be counterbalanced by public investment in major infrastructure projects that will act as economic stimulus. The growing tourism sector will also provide strong support to domestic demand, particularly in the services sector.
Unlike previous post-coup governments, the junta directly manages important economic portfolios (including the Board of Investment, or BOI, which provides investment incentives). It is expected to continue to exert considerable indirect influence on these following the next elections via its 20-year "National Strategy", which is likely to influence the nature of investment via its priori-tisation of certain industries. The governor of the BOT, Veerathai Santiprabhob, who took the reins in October 2015, is well respected and there is so far no indication that he will bend to political pressure. This should ensure that the BOT remains independent and credible in its regulation of the financial sector and its management of the economy (particularly in setting official interest rates and acting to reduce excess volatility of the local currency, the baht).
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.3 6.8 36 32 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
We expect a moderate improvement in policy towards private enterprise and competition as the government makes more aggressive efforts to attract investment. This will help Thailand's global ranking to improve from 36th in 2013-17 to 32nd in 2018-22. However, the country's regional rank will remain unchanged owing to concurrent improvements in other Asian countries. The military government has launched an anti-graft campaign, including a new court dedicated to trying corruption cases. Nevertheless, there is a dearth of cases involving officials linked to the current administration despite allegations of graft, suggesting that anti-corruption efforts are not insulated from political influence. Furthermore, the favouritism for politically connected businesses under the previous administration led by Yingluck Shinawatra may have been replaced by another patronage system that rewards those allied to the military and the traditional establishment.
Privatisation of SOEs will proceed at a gradual pace
Proposed reforms to state-owned enterprises (SOEs) will bolster the operational efficiency of state companies. However, privatisation remains a sensitive issue, and it is unlikely that the military-led government or its successor will try to sell off state assets, as this would redistribute economic rents away from current holders and there is little public support for this. A long-standing area of concern is the lack of protection of intellectual property (IP), but a recent upgrading of legal provisions should help to control piracy of digital and online content. The government will continue to use price controls for some basic goods to keep them affordable; prices for goods on the "sensitive" list cannot be changed without the permission of the Ministry of Commerce.
The corporate governance reform of 56 SOEs controlling assets worth over US$300bn will be completed during the forecast period. In 2014 the military-controlled government appointed a so-called superboard to oversee the reform. Another superboard, designed to oversee procurement processes, was esta-blished in 2017. The formation of these bodies may help to curb corruption in the public sector, although progress in this area is likely to be slow. A new law that will restructure SOEs and reform key parts of their business processes is likely to also be passed in the early part of the forecast period. This will expand and improve procurement processes, including increasing transparency, which will help to reduce corruption and boost competition in the public-private sphere. All of these initiatives are unlikely to be reversed following new elections, as they look likely to be included in the junta-developed, constitutionally binding 20-year National Strategy.
Following the passage of a new Copyright Act in 2015, which focuses on improving protection of IP rights on the internet, and the earlier creation of a National Committee on Intellectual Property under the prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, the US Trade Representative moved Thailand from its intellectual property Priority Watch List to its lesser Watch List status in late 2017. Thailand had been on the highest-concern list for a decade, so the downgrade should give investors some reassurance of progress in this area. Nonetheless, the still-prevalent relatively frequent occurrence of IP infringement will hinder the country's progress towards becoming a "digital economy" and act as a disincentive to international brands looking to do business in Thailand.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.4 6.9 49 43 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for policy towards foreign investment will improve moderately in 2018-22, compared with the historical period, raising both the regional and global rankings. Thailand will continue to encourage inward investment, especially in higher-value-added industries. Further incentives are almost certain to be rolled out in 2018-22 and investment approvals will continue to be fast-tracked by the BOI. The government will not revive proposals, first touted in 2007, to amend the Foreign Business Act, which would make it more difficult for foreign companies to control Thai entities unless they own a majority of shares.
The BOI's seven-year investment promotion strategy, launched in 2015, offers incentives and government support for foreign investors. It dovetails with the government's longer-term "Thailand 4.0" industrial policy in its sectoral focus. The investment promotion strategy includes incentives for setting up a business in less developed parts of the country and the promotion of ten special economic zones (SEZs) along the land borders of Thailand and its neighbours. The latter are in place to take advantage of increasing international labour flows under the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC), which was formally established in late 2015. Incentives in the ten SEZs include corporate income tax breaks in certain industries.
Incentives offered to foreign investment will increase
In addition to the ten border SEZs in development, a large coastal-situated economic zone in the form of the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) has also been designated, capitalising on an existing industrial belt along the eastern seaboard. Significant incentives will be provided for firms in the border SEZs, including double tax deductions on some utilities for a ten-year period, access to cheap credit and the granting of use of unskilled foreign labour from neigh-bouring countries. Meanwhile, the EEC will benefit from transport infrastructure upgrades better linking it to the capital, Bangkok, and major air- and seaports, in addition to a range of tax and regulatory incentives.
The promotion strategy will also introduce industrial developments based around the notion of "super-clusters". These will be collective industry hubs (for instance targeting automotive, electrical appliances, chemicals, digital, food production and medical industries). The BOI and the Ministry of Finance will provide tax and other incentives. These efforts will be undermined slightly, however, by the below-par prospects for private consumption, which are low by the standards of other countries at Thailand's income level.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.2 8.7 37 32 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Given Thailand's reliance on international trade, the government will retain a favourable foreign-trade regime, trying to accommodate the demands of influential domestic groups inclined towards protectionism while avoiding provoking any retaliation from major export markets. Most import duties for goods from other ASEAN member states have been lifted, following the formation of the AEC at end-2015. Thailand is also party to multilateral trade agreements concluded by the regional grouping, such as those in place with China and India, and a combined agreement with Australia and New Zealand. However, Thailand's existing trade deals allow signatories to exclude a number of sensitive sectors, while also keeping some non-tariff barriers in place. Thailand will continue to adhere to its commitments as a member of the World Trade Organisation. The country has accepted the obligations laid down in the IMF's Article VIII, which stipulates that transactions on the current account should be free of restrictions. Foreign investors do not face restrictions on the repatriation of profits and dividends and the central bank has eased restrictions on outward capital flows. The BOT would reimpose temporary capital controls only if excessive speculative capital flows were judged to be threatening macro-economic stability.
Thailand, along with the other members of ASEAN, will continue to liberalise its trade regime in line with its commitment to implementing the AEC. Freer movement of goods, services, investment and skilled labour (in eight selected sectors) between the ten member states came into effect at end-2015. Moreover, the progressive implementation of the ASEAN Framework Agreement on Services (AFAS) is resulting in the additional liberalisation of services subsectors; the next AFAS implementation phase in 2019 will result in the opening of subsectors including freight transport, liquefied natural gas tanker maintenance and electronic data transmission services.
Negotiation on a Thailand-EU FTA will resume
Free-trade agreements (FTAs) signed by ASEAN with China and India, as well as a combined agreement with Australia and New Zealand, are gradually being phased in. The deal with India eliminated duties on many products in 2016 and talks are under way to include services. The FTA with Australia and New Zealand will be expanded to include 96% of all product types by 2020. Formal talks on a bilateral FTA between Thailand and the EU began in 2013, but were put on hold after the 2014 coup. European and Thai businesses are keen to conclude a deal, which would compensate in part for Thailand's loss of the EU's Generalised System of Preferences status in 2015. We believe that negotiations will resume only after the next elections, which we forecast to take place in 2019. As a result, a Thai-EU deal is unlikely to be implemented before the end of the forecast period.
The baht has experienced large swings in its value in recent years, as loose monetary policy in the US, Japan and other major economies led to large speculative flows into Thailand in search of higher yields. After a prolonged period of appreciation in 2017, the local currency has seen a depreciating trend since early 2018, amid tax cuts and rising interest rates in the US that has led to a brightening of investor sentiment towards the US economy vis-à-vis emerging markets. The BOT will not reintroduce capital controls to stem this decline in the baht:US dollar exchange rate, partly in preference for a weaker currency to aid exporters. However, intermittent intervention in the foreign-exchange market to curb extreme volatility will remain the norm.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.9 7.8 11 14 5 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score in the taxes category declines marginally in 2018-22, resulting in its global and regional rankings slipping slightly. The deterioration is owing to our expectation that the government will raise value-added tax (VAT) later in the forecast period. Nonetheless, Thailand remains a very competitive territory overall for taxes. The country's tax regime is relatively simple and changes have been made in recent years to lower the overall burden. Successive governments have aimed to minimise the load on households and firms, and lowering taxes has been an important part of this strategy. As a result, its ranking in this area has improved over time (although a relatively low tax-GDP ratio is a fiscal concern in the medium to long term). The standard rate of corporate tax was gradually reduced from 30% in 2011 to 20% in 2013. The government did this with the aim of boosting the country's competitiveness as a destination for foreign investors and to mitigate the impact of higher minimum-wage levels. Tax incentives are also widely available; on the whole, Thailand's fiscal regime continues to provide fairly strong encouragement for new investment, particularly in higher value-added industries that the government considers strategically important. The personal income tax regime is relatively favourable, with the top marginal rate standing at 35% for both Thai and foreign workers on annual earnings over Bt5m (US$145,000).
The VAT rate will be raised slightly towards the end of the forecast period
The junta repeatedly postponed an increase in the standard VAT rate in 2014-17. The next government is likely to maintain the rate at 7% until late in the forecast period, when the authorities will look to consolidate the public finances after private consumption returns to a stronger footing. This decision will also be influenced by calls from international organisations such as the IMF to push the rate back up. In addition, the extension of VAT to digital services provided by foreign companies will be enforced before the end of 2018.
With increases to unpopular consumption taxes off the agenda in the earlier part of the forecast period, the military government will push for other tax reforms to raise revenue and expand the tax base. An inheritance tax was approved in July 2015 and a property tax on land and building assets will come into effect from 2019. The latter will levy tax on commercial land and buildings with a ceiling of 2%, but most applicable tax rates will be much lower than this, and with the highest duties applied to vacant land. The impact on foreign business will therefore be minor.
The government will continue to look for opportunities to provide tax sops in a bid to support consumption. These sops will range from allowing individuals to deduct income tax on purchases of selected consumer goods to income tax deductions for domestic hotel and travel expenses in particular tax years. Similarly, the government will support the real-estate market through subsidised loans and other targeted incentives, such as income tax deductions for first-time buyers in lower-income brackets, during the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.6 7.4 27 28 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score for financing will improve in 2018-22, as the banking sector will be in better health. However, improvements in the financing environments of neighbouring countries will result in Thailand's regional ranking for the category remaining unchanged. Similarly, an improvement in countries outside the region will see its global ranking slip by one place to 28th, from 27th. Increased due diligence and prudential measures among banks helped to ensure that the ratio of non-performing loans to total loans has remained stable since late 2015. This situation is expected to be sustained in 2018-22. This will bolster the overall health of the banking sector, ensuring that the supply of credit to private firms will not be significantly curtailed at any point during the forecast period.
There will be trend towards consolidation in the financial sector
The BOT and the finance ministry will continue to focus on increasing the competitiveness of the financial sector, principally via the consolidation of a number of private- and state-owned financial institutions, in anticipation of banking services liberalisation under the ASEAN Banking Integration Framework. Thailand is currently in negotiations with Malaysia, Indonesia and Myanmar to lower cross-border banking licence restrictions which will lead to greater competition in the sector, lowering the cost of finance for firms in Thailand. Reforms in this regard will be implemented between Thailand and some more advanced ASEAN neighbours towards the end of the forecast period.
The local bond market will continue to expand under the guidance of the BOT. Thailand's bond market remains small compared with its equity market. Government bonds dominate, accounting for about 80% of all bonds issued, but large and medium debt-laden companies are increasingly using the bond market to refinance their bank loans and offshore borrowings. Strengthening demand in this market will continue in the early part of the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.2 5.8 32 44 9 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The deterioration in the global and regional rankings for the labour market reflects Thailand's waning competitiveness. The country is a labour-scarce economy and unemployment is low. Labour market conditions will, in general, remain adequate in terms of supporting the operations of foreign-invested enterprises, but weaknesses, especially rising wage costs and skill shortages, will persist. The country's advantages as a cost-efficient base for labour-intensive production are diminishing, amid increasing competition from neighbouring economies such as Cambodia and Vietnam. In addition to rising relative costs for low-skilled workers, general labour shortages are a growing problem. In terms of skilled labour, problems stem in large part from Thailand's underperforming education system, which ranks poorly both globally and regionally. Educational reforms in the last two decades have been poorly and inconsistently implemented, and there are currently no plans for a major overhaul of the system. The ability of the labour force to meet the needs of businesses (in terms of specialist skills) is likely to remain subpar by global standards. Hiring foreign workers will continue to be relatively difficult and expensive, except for labour from other ASEAN countries in designated sectors. In terms of the potential for industrial unrest, Thailand is comparatively attractive as an operating location, as strikes are rare.
From January 2017 the nationwide daily minimum-wage schedule was replaced by minimum wages per province. The range of the wage floor was raised to Bt308-330 (around US$9) with effect from April 2018. Significant future increases in the minimum wage are unlikely because this would further damage Thailand's competitiveness vis-à-vis regional competitors. Persistently low con-sumer price inflation in 2018-22 should also ease the upward pressure on wages.
The retirement age will rise incrementally in 2018-22
Thailand is facing the social and economic consequences of a rapidly ageing society, including a steadily declining workforce as a share of the total population. During the forecast period the government will introduce steps to mitigate this crisis. It is drawing up proposals for a staggered increase in the retirement age of civil servants from 60 to 63 years over the next few years. This will invariably put pressure on private employers to follow suit. Accordingly, we expect the average retirement age in the private sector to rise slightly in 2018-22, but this will do little to counter the problems posed by skills shortages on the overall labour market.
Local labour will continue to decline in Thailand, with the country becoming more reliant on migrant workers, mostly from neighbouring Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos, who typically fill low-skilled vacancies. The government is in the process of opening SEZs on the country's borders, designed in part to capitalise on the supply of low-cost migrant labour sourced from its neighbours. International concerns for potential human rights abuses in Thailand, especially in the fishing industry, will result in tighter regulation and enforcement of protective measures for migrant workers. Ongoing co-ordination with the Burmese government to register migrants and issue identity documents will help to improve the situation, and will expand access to a (legal) low-cost labour pool in the medium term. However, an accompanying crackdown on migrants without proper documentation will stymie the availability of foreign workers in the outset of the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.8 6.0 56 47 9 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's infrastructure will see significant improvement in the next five years. The military government has prioritised long-pending "megaprojects", but they will still face significant delays. Improvements to telecommunications services have also been slow. Although the availability of 4G is widespread, average speeds remain slow by regional comparison. Electricity supplies have risen, but the potential for shortages remains. In 2017 60.2% of the country's electricity was generated using natural gas, according to the latest figures from Thailand's Energy Policy and Planning Office, and over 20% of natural gas is imported, making the country vulnerable to fluctuations in global gas prices. With gas supplies in the Gulf of Thailand in decline, the government's energy plans prioritise diversification of energy sources, including development of renewable energy. The government's Power Development Plan 2015 (which will be updated by end-2018) proposes to more than double the capacity of alternative energy sources by 2036, primarily in solar and biomass, and to import additional hydropower from neighbouring nations.
Many large infrastructure projects will enter construction in 2018-22
The government has had difficulty securing funding for its ambitious plans to develop infrastructure "megaprojects". Although the junta has moved a number of projects nearer to the construction phase, including the building of dual-track railways, highways and port expansions, the eventual completion date of a high-speed train linking Thailand and China, via Laos, which was originally agreed in 2010, is still unclear. Construction of a first phase of the line between the Thai capital and the north-eastern province of Nakhon Ratchasima began in mid-2017, but further sections are yet to be greenlighted. This rail project and others have been slow to progress owing to doubts over their commercial viability and wrangling over financing with Chinese and Japanese investors. Delays also partly reflect the government's efforts to take advantage of the ongoing competition for geopolitical influence between China and Japan-the Thai government has both been seeking the best deal and taken a cautious approach to shifting its alliances amid China's growing economic clout and Japan's historical investment links (Japanese FDI into Thailand still dwarfs that from China). We expect significant progress on priority projects in 2018-22, however. This is in large part owing to the junta's use of unilateral executive powers, via Section 44 of the interim constitution, which will set many projects in motion before a new government assumes power. Priority projects include road and rail upgrades on the eastern seaboard to link with Bangkok and the expansion of the U-Tapao International Airport, 140 km south-east of the capital. Many of the key projects undertaken in 2018-22 will serve the new EEC SEZ.
Airport upgrades will ease capacity bottlenecks
The state-run Airports of Thailand authority will upgrade three of the country's major airports in 2018-22 to increase passenger capacity: Don Mueang and Suvarnabhumi airports in Bangkok towards the end of the forecast period, and U-Tapao in Rayong province, southeast of the capital, by 2019. New airports will also be constructed in Chiang Mai and Phuket, although completion is likely to fall beyond the end of the forecast period. This will mainly be aimed at accommodating surging tourist arrivals from East Asia, especially China.
Thailand's telecoms networks have been slow to adopt the latest technology, exposing inefficiencies in the regulatory environment. Auctions of 4G bandwidth were completed in 2017. The regulator expects the commercial launch of 5G bandwidth in 2020, although we believe that those auctions will be completed at a similarly slow pace. Moreover, the new bandwidth is likely to lag behind equivalent offerings in most other Asian countries in terms of speed, as is still the case with 4G, owing to shortfalls in service provider technology.
The Power Development Plan 2015 lays out clear targets for energy production, consumption and imports in the period to 2036. Overall objectives include reducing reliance on natural gas, increasing imports of electricity from Thailand's neighbours, and ramping up alternative energy production, especially solar and biomass. An update to the plan, which will be published later in 2018, is also expected to promote small private power producers. Nuclear power options are still on the table, but have been subject to delays owing to public opposition and no new capacity from this form is expected to be added in the forecast period. As such, Thailand will remain reliant on natural gas for electricity production in 2018-22.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.5 5.5 50 55 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand ranks lower for technological readiness in global comparison in 2018-22 than in the historical period, as there has been no change in its overall score while progress is made in other countries. Its regional rank remains at 11th. A fundamental drag on Thailand's performance is internet use. There were an estimated 37.1 internet users per 100 population in 2017-despite being above the average for other Asian countries such as India (36.5) and Indonesia (27.7), this was well below that of Malaysia (81.2). This limits Thailand's viability for e-commerce and digital services. Its level of commercial innovation also falls below regional par. This is partly owing to the preference of international companies with manufacturing operations in the country to carry out their research and development (R&D) elsewhere. This accounts in part for the low level of patent applications per capita.
Internet use will be boosted by broadband expansion
In 2012 the Ministry of Digital Economy and Society launched the "Smart Thailand" initiative comprising two components-to improve ICT infrastructure under the "Smart Network" project and to upgrade government services under the "Smart Government" project. One of the key objectives under the Smart Network component will be to establish nearly 400,000 free high-speed wireless internet access points around the country and expand broadband internet coverage to 95% of the population. This will boost internet use among the population.
The Board of Investment has introduced import duty exemptions on raw materials used in R&D to incentivise the development of innovative capacities in the private sector. In addition, to boost innovation infrastructure, companies focused on bio-, nano-, advanced materials or digital technology are eligible for up to 13 years of corporate income tax exemption if they co-operate with public research institutions in R&D.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Thailand's military-controlled government sees economic revival as its priority and is pursuing policies aimed at boosting consumption and investment, including ramping up public spending on infrastructure. This includes the establishment of a large special economic zone, the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC), south-east of the capital, Bangkok; it will be based around new and upgraded transport links and will offer significant investment incentives. The admin-istration's sector-specific industrial policy, Thailand 4.0, will also provide additional incentives to foreign investors within and outside the EEC. Both plans fit more broadly with the 20-year National Strategy, the junta's blueprint for the country's long-term social and economic development, which was signed into law in mid-2017. The National Strategy aims to ensure the continuation of the junta's overarching economic policy agenda under future elected administrations.
The junta is also utilising Section 44 of the interim constitution, which allows it to pass legislation unilaterally in order to expedite the development of big-ticket projects. Although this strategy risks fast-tracking projects at the expense of proper public scrutiny, it will accelerate the investment process in the early part of the forecast period and will boost overall economic growth in the short term. Even after the return of an elected government, the constitutionally mandated National Strategy will ensure that public investment remains a policy priority.
Demand-side stimulatory and relief measures have played a prominent role in the junta's policy agenda, in large part to placate agricultural producers who readily protest (or threaten to do so) in order to extract concessions from the government. Such measures are likely to continue and will also focus on small and medium-sized enterprises. Nonetheless, the impetus for further such disbursements will lessen in 2018-22 as the authorities seek to consolidate the public finances.

Economic forecast: Fiscal policy

We expect the budget deficit to average the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP per year in 2018-22. The junta is trying to mitigate the fiscal impact of its infra-structure construction initiative through incremental tax reform. An increase in "sin taxes" that came into effect in September 2017 is slated to cover additional expenditure for the welfare of the elderly. Much other new recurring expendi-ture, such as the extension of free state education for those aged 12-15, designed in part to boost the junta's popularity, has no direct counterbalance on the reve-nue side and will act as a drag on the budget balance in 2018-22. A reformed schedule of property taxes, which will be applied from 2019, will boost revenue later in the forecast period, albeit only modestly, owing to the watering-down of original proposals in order to avoid public objections. Eager to expand the revenue base, the government will try to lift value-added tax (VAT) moderately in the latter part of the forecast period from the current rate of 7%. However, any increase will be gradual; the government will be wary of dampening still relatively slow private consumption growth.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy

We expect consumer price inflation to remain within the lower bounds of the 1-4% target range set by the Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) throughout the forecast period, giving the monetary authority the policy space to maintain a fairly accommodative stance. Nonetheless, monetary policy tightening by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) in 2018-19 and relatively robust economic growth in those two years will incline the BOT to raise the policy rate once in the second half of 2018 and again in 2019. This will be in part to signal to capital markets that there is enough policy room for it to defend the currency and smooth out volatility. Further tightening will be stalled until 2021 owing to still-muted inflation and a cyclical recession in the US-one of Thailand's most important export markets-in 2020. The BOT will resume minor rate increases in 2021-22 as domestic and external economic conditions strengthen.

We expect real GDP to average annual growth of 3.4% in 2018-22. Private consumption will perform better than in recent years, averaging growth of 3% a year in the forecast period (compared with 2% in the historical period). Still-high levels of household debt, which is mostly held by lower-income earners, will continue to act as a dampener on spending. Wage growth will also remain subdued in the forecast period as a whole, although some improvement in the external sector in 2018 will help to lift incomes this year. We expect exports of goods and services to grow by 4.2% a year in 2018-22, compared with 2.6% in 2013-17. Growth in this component will be underpinned throughout 2018-22 by services exports, in the form of tourism, but the volume of goods shipments will improve in the early part of the forecast period. Goods exports will slow amid a recession in the US in 2020.
Total fixed investment will grow by an average of 3.8% in the forecast period. This will be significantly stronger than the 0.9% average annual growth recorded in 2013-17. However, investment growth will be strongest towards the end of the forecast period, as private investors remain cautious in their commitments in the lead-up to and the immediate aftermath of elections that we expect to take place in 2019. Public investment will pick up following numerous delays to projects in recent years and will prop up overall investment growth.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
On the supply side of the economy, we expect the industrial sector to grow the fastest, at an average annual rate of 3.8% in 2018-22. Thailand has been successful in taking the lead in certain industrial sectors relative to its neighbours, such as the automotive industry, in addition to some high-technology subsectors, most notably electronics and machinery components. However, its relative technical capabilities and competitiveness are slowly declining owing to a lack of investment in the sector. This is partly owing to the lack of domestic opportunities-household consumption growth often pales in comparison to Thailand's neighbours. The industrial sector grew by a lacklustre 1.6% in 2017 as domestic demand struggled. Industrial growth will recover in 2018-22 amid increased public investment in infrastructure and a more stable and business-friendly policy environment. Stronger external demand in the early and latter parts of the forecast period will buoy investment sentiment in the largely export-oriented sector. Over the longer term, Thailand risks losing its role as a predominant producer of intermediate manufactured goods to fast-growing countries in the region that have cheaper labour.
The services sector will continue to be dominated by the tourism industry
The services sector will grow by an annual average of 3.3% in 2018-22. Despite a coup in 2014, growth in the sector averaged 4.8% a year in 2013-17 amid surging tourist arrivals from the wider Asian region, especially China. In the forecast period the growth rate will normalise somewhat owing in part to slowing growth in tourist arrivals and related expenditure. Similarly, the retail sector-the largest component of services-will continue to expand at a slower rate over the forecast period. In addition, the financial sector remains relatively healthy. The ratio of non-performing loans to total loans has remained fairly stable since 2015 and is far below the levels seen prior to the 2008-09 financial crisis. In addition, banks are well capitalised. Growth in household debt as a percentage of GDP has declined slightly since 2015, although the already-elevated levels of debt here will crimp demand and dampen the expansion of the sector as a whole in 2018-22. The telecommunications segment will see strong growth with the belated development of 4G networks under licences awarded in 2016, and the development of 5G networks towards the end of the forecast period, which will allow firms to meet surging demand for mobile internet services. This will dovetail with the expansion of e-commerce platforms in the country.
The agricultural sector will remain vulnerable to extreme weather cycles, including droughts and floods. Productivity is also likely to suffer as tentative efforts to reform the sector are repeatedly set back by inclement weather events, which will also mean that producers are largely unable to upgrade from current basic technologies. Some subsectors, such as fishing, will struggle early in the forecast period as the industry adapts to the market-access requirements of Western countries regarding labour rights and the government clamps down on unregistered migrant labour. We expect the agricultural sector to grow by an annual average of 2.4% in 2018-22.

We expect consumer prices to increase by an annual average of 1.5% in 2018-22, compared with 0.8% in 2013-17. Firmer commodity prices in 2018 and stronger domestic demand will lead to consumer price inflation accelerating from 0.7% in 2017 to 1.2% in 2018. Inflationary pressures will persist in 2019 but will abate in 2020, when upward pressure on global commodity prices will be impaired by an economic downturn in the US. Thereafter, stronger global economic activity will help to lift average annual inflation to 1.7% in 2021-22.

After strengthening in 2017 and early 2018, the baht is now on a downward trend against the US dollar, which we expect to continue in the remainder of this year. Tax cuts and further interest-rate rises in the US are buoying investor confidence in that market, while fears over the escalation of US-China trade disputes are undermining confidence in emerging markets in Asia. However, the fact that these trends have only come to the fore from mid-2018 means that the value of the local currency will still strengthen against the US dollar in annual average terms compared with 2017. Owing to the continuing strength of the US dollar, the baht will revert to a depreciatory trend in 2019-20 amid more rapidly rising interest rates in the US in 2019 and then an easing of external demand for Thai exports in 2020, owing in part to a cyclical downturn in the US. In these two years we expect the baht to depreciate by an average of 1.7% a year. The latter part of the forecast period will see a restoration of the currency's value as macroeconomic fundamentals strengthen, with the baht appreciating by an annual average of 1% in 2021-22.

The current-account surplus has widened considerably since 2014, driven primarily by growth in tourism-related services and weaker global commodity prices, which have led to lower-cost imports. In 2018-22 the surplus is expected to average the equivalent of 10.4% of GDP, compared with an average of 6.6% of GDP in 2013-17. However, it will struggle to widen further throughout the forecast period, as growth in the trade surplus is tempered by rising global commodity prices and a surge in imports associated with the infrastructure investment drive. A technical recession in the US in 2020 and slowing economic growth in China throughout the forecast period will also play a role in softening Thailand's goods export growth.
The surplus on the services account will continue to rise, driven by the robust tourism sector. However, we expect increasing competition for visitors from the rest of South-east Asia to temper growth in tourist arrivals, compared with the double-digit annual growth rates recorded for much of the last decade. The primary income account will remain in deficit in 2018-22, reflecting the continued repatriation of profits and dividends by foreign-owned firms. However, this will be partly offset by the effect on the secondary income account of personal transfers, notably remittances.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Thailand
Stocks and flows
Net foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows (including earnings reinvested by companies already operating in Thailand) were volatile in 2013-17 owing to political uncertainty and a downturn in external demand that dampened confidence in the business environment. From 2016 net FDI flows turned sharply negative, averaging US$11bn in 2016-17, as outbound investment by Thai companies took off while inbound flows still struggled, owing in part to the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, as well as low investor confidence in the Thai economy. In 2017 the stock of inward FDI stood at US$227.8bn, equivalent to 50% of GDP.
Origin and distribution
The privately owned manufacturing sector has traditionally attracted the largest proportion of FDI inflows into Thailand. In particular, manufacturers of automotive parts and producers of electronics and electrical appliances have attracted significant foreign interest in recent years. However, the financial and real-estate sectors have also gained prominence, and in 2017 net FDI flows into each of these two sectors exceeded those that went into manufacturing. Historically, Japanese firms have been the main investors in Thailand. Investment from China has also greatly increased in the past few years. Chinese investors, at least as much as their Japanese counterparts, are likely to gain from Thailand's infrastructure develop-ment plans, but these will essentially come in the form of services contracts in construction and logistics planning.
Determinants
Thailand has traditionally been an attractive investment destination, owing to its relatively competitive labour costs, flexible labour laws and advantageous location within the region. However, some of these advantages have been fading amid sporadic political uncertainty and increasing competition from later-developing regional neighbours. Incentives offered by the Board of Investment (BOI) generally take the form of exemptions from corporate income tax and reduced taxes on imported machinery. The BOI also offers non-tax incentives, including granting permission to bring in foreign workers, own land and take or remit foreign currency abroad. Thailand has generally been regarded as open to foreign investment. Although regulatory uncertainties do exist, the government has actively tried to address these quickly. Indeed, the new large-scale Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) special economic zone includes fast-tracked environmental assessments as an incentive. The EEC fits within the BOI's seven-year investment promotion strategy launched in 2015 that extended incentives to newer industries such as "alternative energy and environmental services" and "hospitality and wellness", while removing existing incentives in certain low-value, labour-intensive industries. The BOI has also been encouraging investment into infrastructure, through a small number of "big-ticket" projects. Although a backlog of proposals accumulated in the period leading up to the 2014 coup, the BOI subsequently expedited the investment application and approval process, and is likely to continue to do so even after the next elections.
Impact
Inflows of FDI have been volatile over the past decade. The ratio of FDI inflows to GDP fell to 1.8% in 2009 owing to the global economic crisis. Following this, FDI inflows fluctuated in 2010-17 amid flood damage and repeated bouts of political uncertainty. Large FDI inflows have helped to support overall economic growth and have contributed to Thailand's development as a leading exporter to other countries in Asia in a number of sectors, including vehicles (particularly light pickup trucks), electronics (especially computer parts) and electrical appliances.
Potential
Following the public approval of the junta-drafted constitution at a referendum in 2016 and the smooth accession of the new king, Thailand's political scene has gained a foothold of political stability. After elections that are scheduled for 2019, challenges to the new political structure and next government are unlikely to materialise before late in the forecast period at the earliest, which bodes well for steadier FDI flows in the forecast period compared with 2013-17. However, a number of other challenges may limit the potential for strong growth in FDI in the next five years. Thailand's attractiveness as a location for investment has been diminishing owing to a rising relative cost base (particularly for labour) and sluggish domestic demand outside the tourism sector. Although the current administration is keen to show a commitment to liberalisation, mainly through the legally binding 20-year National Strategy, access to important sectors such as telecommunications and utilities in the medium term remains in question. Although the standard of infrastructure in the country has improved in recent years, it remains poorer than that in Malaysia, a rival manufacturing location. However, the junta has initiated an ambitious infrastructure development programme to attempt to rectify this shortfall. Although Thailand will continue to attract foreign investment by virtue of its leading position in the development of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free-Trade Area, there is a risk that it may lose out to other countries in the region as they make improvements to their business environments at a faster rate.

Effective family-planning programmes, sex education and changing social norms, such as later marriage and smaller families, will keep Thailand's average population growth rate relatively low, at 0.2% a year, in the forecast period. By 2022 the population is forecast to reach 69.6m, with females accounting for 51.4% of the total. Owing to continued improvements in healthcare and childbirth procedures, the infant mortality rate will drop to an average of 8.6 per 1,000 live births in the forecast period, from 9.6 per 1,000 in 2013-17. Life expectancy will also improve, with men expected to live for an average of 71.9 years in 2018-22, up from 70.8 in 2013-17, while female life expectancy will rise from an average of 78.3 to 79.3 years over the same period.
Thailand's population is ageing, with the proportion of the population aged under 15 set to fall to 15.8% in 2022, from 18.8% in 2011, and the proportion aged over 65 rising steadily. This will mean that the young-age dependency ratio falls to 0.22 in 2022, from 0.26 in 2012, while the old-age dependency ratio rises from 0.13 to 0.2. This demographic trend will place further strains on healthcare provision. The country's health system is structured around a universal healthcare scheme introduced in 2001, which is coming under increasing strains from the growing old-age population. Under the initial programme, the "Bt30 scheme", which was implemented by the government led by Thaksin Shinawatra in 2001, all Thais were entitled to visit a doctor or hospital for a flat fee of Bt30 (around US$1). Following the coup in 2006 that ousted Thaksin, the military-installed government abolished the Bt30 fee, thus making public healthcare free. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this scheme to remain free in the forecast period.
Road accidents will continue to be a leading cause of death
The crude death rate is forecast at 8.1 per 1,000 in 2018-22. Age-related non-communicable illnesses such as heart disease, stroke and respiratory diseases are responsible for most deaths in Thailand, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO). In its latest country profile for Thailand, road accidents were also a leading cause of death, accounting for 5% of total deaths (based on 2012 data). Thailand continues to confront the challenge of preventing the spread of HIV/AIDS, which in the early 2000s emerged as the country's leading cause of death. Thailand was one of the first countries in Asia to launch a campaign to raise public awareness of HIV/AIDS, and recent figures confirm its effectiveness. The WHO estimates the death rate from the disease at around 23 per 100,000 people in 2016, although 450,000 people continued to live with the disease in that year. Other infectious diseases such as cholera, measles and mumps have become less common but have not been eradicated.
The labour market will tighten owing to the ageing of Thailand's population, and shortages of skilled labour are likely in the next five years. The labour force will expand by an average of 0.3% in 2018-22, to reach 38.7m by 2022, despite a decline in the working-age population. This will be largely owing to increasing numbers of women choosing to work outside the home. Migrant labour will remain abundant, with workers from neighbouring Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos continuing to dominate unskilled jobs in the construction industry and as household employees. However, Thailand will gradually become a less attractive destination for unskilled migrants over the long term. In the near term this will partly reflect a less welcoming stance on the part of the authorities, who are keen to channel unskilled migrant labour into legitimate strategic industries in border-located special economic zones. In the longer term, job opportunities in Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos will expand as those economies grow.
Rural-urban migration is still a significant demographic trend
Despite slow population growth, the number of households in Thailand is expected to rise strongly in the forecast period, mainly as a result of a reduction in average household size. Internal migration and changing social patterns mean that it is increasingly common for households to consist of nuclear, rather than extended, families. Steady economic expansion in recent years has encouraged this trend, as migrant workers from rural areas have been moving to the major cities, and particularly the metropolitan area centred on the capital, Bangkok. Although the former remains the epicentre for the urban population, other cities, including Surat Thani, Chiang Mai and Hat Yai, have also been growing rapidly. This will result in the urban population increasing to 59.8% of the total population in 2022, from 52.9% in 2017.

Thailand constitutes a sizeable market in its own right, with a population of 69m and nominal GDP equivalent to around US$455.5bn at market exchange rates in 2017. Moreover, the development of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free-Trade Area means that firms located in Thailand will continue to enjoy almost entirely duty-free access to ASEAN's population of 500m, including a burgeoning middle class with growing disposable incomes.
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that aggregate personal disposable income will grow at a faster rate in 2018-22 than it did in 2013-17, as economic activity strengthens compared with the historical period on the back of greater policy stability. Although household spending will be tempered by still-high personal debt levels, the very large tourism sector will continue to lend support to the retail sector.
High household debt will undermine disposable incomes in 2018-22
National wealth distribution remains alarmingly disparate between the regions, according to the latest data from the Asian Development Bank. Of the 8.6% of the population defined as living below the nationally defined poverty line (in 2016, living on Bt1568 or less per month), the majority reside in the rural north and north-eastern parts of the country. The capital, Bangkok, remains the wealthiest region by far: personal disposable incomes there are double the national average. Measures to narrow the wealth gap undertaken by govern-ments have tended to be short-term in nature and unsustainable. Therefore, market opportunities in the rural areas remain limited compared with urban centres.
A fairly small proportion of personal disposable income in Thailand is spent on accommodation. However, the share available for spending on consumer goods is tempered by household debt service. In particular, debt burdens among those on lower incomes have a significant negative impact on consumer demand overall and limit the prospects for social mobility among this group. As the level of debt subsides, the release of pent-up demand will boost retail sales towards the end of the forecast period. On average, retail sales volumes will grow by 2.3% a year on average.

Private consumption will grow by an annual average of 3% in 2018-22, faster than the rate of 2% in 2013-17. The next government will maintain policies aimed at supporting consumption through various subsidies and other support packages aimed at helping low-income citizens. There will also be occasional short-term measures to stimulate spending by higher-income groups. Given the still-frail state of private consumption, the value-added tax (VAT) rate is unlikely to be raised from the current level of 7% until later in the forecast period, despite previous discussion on doing so. The government will instead focus on wealth taxes, such as the new inheritance and property taxes, which will avoid burdening lower-income households, although higher "sin taxes" on alcohol and tobacco will still have a minor impact on the population at large.
Free public healthcare will hold down consumer expenditure in that area
Consumer expenditure on essential items, such as food, household goods and clothing, will fall slightly as a proportion of total expenditure as average incomes rise. The average individual outlay on hotels and restaurants is likely to increase as a result of several trends: a rise in the number of women who work (leading to a fall in the number of meals cooked at home); government efforts to promote domestic tourism; and cheaper domestic travel owing to the expansion of budget airlines and rail routes. Expenditure on leisure and education will rise at pace, as higher-income households experience the biggest gains from economic growth in the forecast period. Growth in healthcare spending is forecast to moderate in 2018-22, compared with 2013-17, owing to relatively comprehensive free public healthcare, which we do not expect to be rescinded in the forecast period. The projected increase in spending on transport and communications will largely reflect the expanding market for information technology products, which will be boosted by national upgrades to internet services.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: The past decade has been characterised by political turmoil in Thailand, with two coups in 2006 and 2014 and many (sometimes violent) anti-government protests and rallies. Economic growth has been volatile in the years since the 2008-09 global financial crisis owing to natural disasters and political crises. Although the military-led government that ousted the populist administration of Yingluck Shinawatra in May 2014 has made economic recovery a priority, growth has remained relatively sedate amid political uncertainty. Physical infrastructure remains inadequate in many respects and under increasing strain. Reform of the education system, which is sorely needed, has long been promised, but successive governments have largely failed to modernise the curriculum. As a consequence, the workforce is characterised by a low level of technical skills.
Demographic trends: Thailand's population will age over the long-term forecast period. Slower population growth and longer life expectancies will account for the demographic shift. The female labour force participation rate will be relatively high by 2030, and is expected to rise only modestly from then on. This will lead to an average annual contraction of 1% in the labour force in 2031-50. Nevertheless, a gradual loosening of regulation concerning immigrants' right to work will preclude a steeper fall in the size of the workforce. Successive governments are likely to be forced to ease immigration policies further, owing to the country's negative demographic profile.
External conditions: Thailand faces a challenging external environment in the period to 2050. Although many export-oriented, labour-intensive industries will shift away from China, Thailand will struggle to capitalise on this opportunity owing to a lack of competitiveness compared with lower-cost locations, such as Cambodia, Vietnam and Bangladesh. New regional rivals will also gain ground, including Laos and Myanmar. Closer integration with China could open up market opportunities for Thai businesses in more niche subsectors. One possibility is that Thailand may develop itself as a services centre for China, meeting that country's increasing demand for foreign holidays, regional-specific agricultural goods and other niche products. The government is already spearheading a move in that direction under its "Thailand 4.0" industrial policy and, in part, via its new Eastern Economic Corridor special economic zone. This is particularly the case for the tourism industry, and the ongoing expansion of transport infrastructure will go some way to supporting these aims. Similarly, economic and trade links will be strengthened by the development of overland transport routes between China and Thailand in the next decade or so. The development of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Economic Community, formally established in 2015, will motivate business and technical innovation in Thailand such that it retains its prominence in the region.
Institutions and policy trends: The power struggle between the established military and bureaucratic elites in the capital, Bangkok, who will continue to side with the palace to bolster their legitimacy, and the rural masses that form the majority of the Thai electorate may ease in the decades ahead. However, this will be conditional on successive governments finding a path to restructuring the economy further away from agriculture, not least by moving a far greater proportion of the workforce into industry and services. Democratically elected governments might be successful in instigating such a shift with the introduction of appropriate electoral reforms as well as a focus on medium- to long-term rural development policies, rather than just short-term relief measures.
Long-term performance: The long-term outlook for Thailand's economy is heavily dependent on whether the next government, which will be dominated by the military establishment, is able to sustain the political authority required to initiate appropriate structural reform that will continue into the medium to long term, in addition to upgrading infrastructure. Implementing compre-hensive liberalisation in a number of important sectors, such as power and communications, will help Thailand to regain some of its competiveness relative to its regional neighbours. The effects of an ageing population could be offset by improving educational attainment on the part of the existing workforce or by measures to facilitate greater immigrant access to the labour market. However, progress is likely to be slow in both areas.

Long-term outlook: Long term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Thailand published a long-term climate change adaptation plan in 2015, the Climate Change Master Plan 2015-2050. It outlines a three-pronged approach divided into mitigation, adaptation and capacity-building targets. The near-term goals included setting emission-reduction targets and establishing incentives for low-carbon emission development. Medium-term targets included reaching at least 25% of energy consumption from renewable sources. Longer-term targets are vaguer, with general goals to increase private investment in green industries and to reduce the carbon intensity of the economy. In line with this plan, Thailand signed and ratified the Paris Agreement of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP21) in 2016, committing to specific targets to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Under COP21, Thailand has pledged to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 20% from the projected business-as-usual forecast by 2030.
The main determinant of emissions levels in Thailand in the coming decades will continue to be energy sourcing. Coal-fired power plants generate close to a fifth of the country's electricity, while lesser-polluting liquefied natural gas facilities account for nearly two-thirds of electricity generation. Most of these plants are situated in the south of the country. The government will continue to push for the expansion of renewable energy sources as a share of the country's energy mix and renewable energy is likely to account for around a quarter of total generation capacity by 2040. The commissioning of nuclear power plants in Thailand is also a possibility, which would lower reliance on high-polluting forms. However, the relatively low prices of coal and gas will mean that these will continue to account for the majority of energy generation over the next two decades.
Technological developments
The junta unveiled "Thailand 4.0", a sector-specific industrial policy that aims to attract new investment towards transforming the economy, in May 2016. The name of the strategy describes the intended next stage in the sectoral development of the economy, characterised by the industrial application of state-of-the-art technology. It follows from the current domestic industrial situation that is dominated by heavy industry with advanced machinery, such as in automotive and chemicals production. The Thailand 4.0 strategy focuses on ten strategic industries that are already found in Thailand, but where value can be added via new technologies. These industries include smart electronics, high-income and medical tourism, agriculture and biotechnology, food and beverages, and automotive industries. It will also extend to developing new industries, such as robotics, aerospace, digital services, bioenergy and biochemicals, and healthcare. Incentives for investment in these sectors are likely to be offered for several years and are explicitly targeted towards the introduction of new technology, for example by offering import duty exemption on capital goods for listed industries. Thailand will make some progress in upgrading its industries, but is likely to be constrained by a limited supply of skilled labour.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.
