Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Domestic data
GDP growth: Bank of Thailand, Annual Report; Asian Development Bank, Key Indicators
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS
Population: Asian Development Bank, Key Indicators; UN, World Development Report
GDP per head: nominal GDP divided by population
Inflation: consumer price index, Department of Business Economics, Ministry of Commerce
Budget: fiscal year (October-September)
Wages: local-currency wage data derived from minimum-wage data, inflated to correspond with occasional UNIDO data for US dollar manufacturing-sector wages
Exchange rates: IMF, IFS
Commercial banks' prime rate: Bank of Thailand, Quarterly Bulletin
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; OECD, External Debt Statistics (for data on short-term debt)
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
UNIDO: UN Industrial Development Organisation
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: India--highlights: Political outlook
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) coalition government, led by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), to remain in office throughout the forecast period (2018-22). The BJP emerged as the dominant political force after the 2014 parliamentary election, and we expect the NDA to secure re-election at the next ballot in April-May 2019, albeit with a diminished majority. The BJP's electoral strength will also be gradually reflected in the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of parliament). We forecast that the BJP and its allies will secure a majority in the Rajya Sabha after 2020, enabling it to pass reform legislation with fewer obstacles. As part of the BJP's foreign policy agenda, India will establish closer strategic ties with Japan and the US, particularly in the light of its growing rivalry with China for influence in South Asia. Relations with Pakistan will remain tense, and although a major conflict is unlikely, minor crossborder military engagements will persist.
India--highlights: Business environment outlook

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The business environment will improve in 2018-22, owing in part to increased political effectiveness and the gradual implementation of reforms that will both open up the economy and boost investment in infrastructure. The rise in India's overall score is driven by higher scores for financing, policy towards private enterprise and competition and foreign exchange and trade controls. Conversely, India fails to make significant progress in the categories of policy towards foreign investment, the labour market and infrastructure, constraining the overall business environment rating.

We forecast that real GDP growth will average 7.6% a year in fiscal years 2018/19-2022/23 (April-March). Private consumption will be a key economic driver as the workforce expands and real wage growth benefits from relatively low consumer price inflation. Government expenditure directed at improving ailing infrastructure will also bolster economic growth, particularly in the first half of the forecast period. We expect gross fixed investment to pick up noticeably in the latter part of the forecast period, supported by government efforts to clean up the bad-debt-ridden banking sector, as well as improvements to the business environment.

India's economy will benefit from a growing population, and the labour force will expand by 1.8% on average in 2018-22. However, fully reaping the benefits of its young population will prove immensely difficult amid a shortage of suitable employment opportunities. Large skills gaps will persist owing to inadequacies in the education system. The tertiary education sector will broadly under-perform, with the exception of a few pockets of excellence. Underemployment and unemployment will add to social tensions. This will be exacerbated by a large gender imbalance. Continued migration into towns and cities from the countryside will also generate economic and social stresses.

Strong GDP growth supports the outlook for wage growth and will assist the expansion of the middle class, even as GDP per head will remain relatively low, at US$2,811 by 2022. Nevertheless, the consumer market will continue to grow, supported by rapidly rising income levels and a huge population of around 1.34bn. The e-commerce sector will expand rapidly on the back of higher smartphone penetration rates and urban demand.
India--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2018-30 2031-50 2018-50

India will become the world's third-largest economy by 2050 on the back of strong growth, supported by a shift in employment from rural to urban areas. However, a divergence in economic fortunes at individual and state levels will lead to social and political tensions. We forecast that India will account for 13% of world GDP by 2050 (at market exchange rates), up from just 3.4% in 2017. India's growing economic might will enable it to become an increasingly influential global diplomatic force. Owing to shared strategic geopolitical and economic interests, India will move closer to the US and Japan. The continuing rivalry for influence in South Asia will weigh on Sino-Indian ties.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars-two over the disputed territory of Kashmir. India is the second most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.34bn people in 2017, according to the UN. Its economy is the sixth largest in the world when measured in nominal US dollars, but the third largest at purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the Westminster model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government, and a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over the nature and scope of economic reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects and undertaking piecemeal liberalisation of outdated regulations, but broader reform is hindered by the NDA's lack of a majority in the Rajya Sabha (the upper house). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the NDA to obtain a majority in the upper house after 2020, which will make it easier to push legislation through parliament.
Taxation: The government will continue to make efforts to broaden the tax base in 2018-22, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax (GST) in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$148.1bn in 2017, from US$107.5bn in 2016, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$65.9bn to US$75.9bn over the period.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
India's constitution came into effect in 1950, underpinning the country's democratic system of governance. The state is secular, giving no preference to any of the manifold religious or social groups. India's democracy is well entrenched and free and fair elections for the national and state parliaments have been held for decades. The country's two major political parties include the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), the dominant component party of the ruling National Democratic Alliance (NDA), and the Indian National Congress, which governed the country for decades, often in coalition with smaller regional parties. These regional parties often dominate state assemblies, enabling them to wield significant influence on national politics through the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of parliament). The BJP holds a slim majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house) and governs with the support of smaller parties in the NDA. The NDA government has been in office since May 2014, and will face another general election in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects it to secure re-election, albeit with a diminished majority.
The BJP's ideological approach is towards the more conservative bent of the political spectrum. It has historically mixed a pro-urban middle class economic agenda with social conservatism and a more aggressive foreign and security policy. In recent years, however, the party has become more populist; it has adopted more rural-focused policies in an attempt to broaden its appeal. Congress has a more centre-left ideological approach to socio-economic issues.

Political outlook: Political stability
We expect the NDA to remain in a strong position politically in 2018-22. The NDA has been in office since 2014 and is dominated by the centre-right BJP. NDA constituent parties control 20 of the country's 29 states, including some of the largest, such as Maharashtra and Uttar Pradesh. The prime minister, Narendra Modi, is proving to be the country's most dominant political leader in decades, and we expect him to remain in a strong position to pursue his political and economic agenda after the 2019 election for the Lok Sabha.
The NDA's dominance in parliament will increase after 2020, when we expect the alliance to take control of the Rajya Sabha. Lawmakers in the upper house are elected by members of state assemblies. However, changes in the composition of state assemblies have a delayed impact on parties' strength in the Rajya Sabha, as a third of the upper-house members are elected every two years on a rotating basis. Once the NDA assumes control of the Rajya Sabha, it will be able to pass legislation without the consent of opposition parties.
Nonetheless, the BJP's tightening grip on power has resulted in a backlash from other political parties. In July 2018 opposition parties brought a no-confidence motion against the government in the Lok Sabha. Given that the BJP and its allies enjoy a majority in the lower house, the no-confidence motion failed to pass. Another such motion before the 2019 election is unlikely, with opposition parties now focused on election campaigning.
Over the forecast period political stability could be compromised by rising sectarian tensions stoked by far-right affiliates of the BJP. These groups have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu state-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups, particularly Muslims. Economic distress in the agricultural sector resulting from weak monsoons could also lead to volatility in rural areas. However, given the electoral influence of farmers, both central and state governments will be quick to mollify any large protests by providing subsidies and sops, including waiving bad loans.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The outlook for political and institutional effectiveness in 2018-22 is mixed. The BJP dominates the political landscape at national and, increasingly, state level. The party has full control of the lower house and has been gradually able to expand its presence in the Rajya Sabha. In August 2017 it became the largest party in the upper house, surpassing Congress for the first time. However, the BJP's growing dominance on the political scene has resulted in a backlash from opposition parties, as well as some of its NDA allies. This will serve to constrain the government's effectiveness as opposition parties co-operate to counter the BJP. Moreover, the BJP's right-wing affiliates are often at odds with the party's governance agenda, including on issues such as labour law reform and simplification of land-acquisition laws. Furthermore, some right-wing Hindu organisations, such as the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, have increased the pressure on the BJP to pursue a more religious-oriented, conservative governance agenda, impairing government effectiveness by diverting attention away from reform issues. We expect the BJP to secure re-election in 2019, which bodes well for policy continuity and government effectiveness. Moreover, currently the NDA lacks a majority in the Rajya Sabha, which hinders the legislative process. We believe that the NDA will secure a majority in the upper house after 2020, and it will then be able to pass legislation without approval from the opposition. This will ease the passage of laws in parliament.
In the medium to long term the BJP government's focus on so-called competitive federalism, which encourages competition among India's states, will lead to a notable improvement in political and institutional effectiveness in reform-oriented states, particularly in the south and the west. However, as the gap between richer and poorer states widens, disruption at national level could emerge. Some of the populous poorer states, including Uttar Pradesh, are important political battlegrounds that no national government can afford to neglect. There is a risk that, owing to economic disparities, poorer states will flex their political muscle to force a redistribution of fiscal resources. However, the risk of this occurring is relatively benign in the forecast period, as any such changes could trigger a backlash in the relatively prosperous southern and western states, which the government will be keen to avoid.
Political outlook: Election watch
The NDA is expected to win another term in office in the parliamentary election scheduled for early 2019, albeit with a reduced majority. Recent by-elections have brought mixed results for the ruling alliance, indicating some anti-incumbency sentiment, which will adversely affect the NDA's margin of victory in the 2019 national election.
Meanwhile, opposition parties are boosting collaboration ahead of the election in a bid to check the NDA's electoral dominance, and are attacking the government on issues such as rising agrarian distress, persistent unemployment challenges and mounting social and communal tensions. It is highly likely that several regional opposition parties and the de facto national-level opposition party, Congress, will enter into an understanding ahead of the lower-house poll. Collaboration is being led by strong regional leaders who enjoy significant popularity in their respective states, such as Mamata Banerjee, the chief minister of West Bengal. It is likely that an opposition alliance will coalesce around a popular regional figure like Ms Banerjee, rather than around the president of Congress, Rahul Gandhi, who has struggled to counter the popularity of Mr Modi. Any such alliance will make gains in the upcoming election, particularly as even small vote swings can alter results in India's first-past-the-post electoral system. However, the opposition alliance's overall electoral success will be constrained by ideological contrasts and rivalries between the leaders of its constituent parties.
In November 2018 four states will hold elections to their assemblies. Three are controlled by the BJP and are crucial to its electoral plan for 2019. We expect the BJP to secure another term in office in two of these states-Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh. Rajasthan is likely to see a very close fight, possibly ending in a hung assembly. Unexpected electoral setbacks for the BJP in these polls would heighten the risks to the NDA's chances in the 2019 national election.
Political outlook: International relations
India will continue to push for a closer relationship with the US in 2018-22, partly to counter China's growing influence in South Asia. To this effect, India has upped security co-operation with the US in recent years. Nevertheless, although India-US ties will remain warm in 2018-22, trade disputes will linger, as a protectionist trade agenda is being pushed by the US under Donald Trump's presidency. In recent weeks these trade tensions have flared, with tariffs being imposed from both sides. Although the current tensions are unlikely to escalate into a serious deterioration of relations, and we expect negotiations to ease the situation to some extent, some disputes will persist throughout 2018-22 and slow down the expansion of US-India bilateral trade.
After a period of tensions with China, in recent months Mr Modi has moved to improve ties with the country. However, China's growing presence in South Asia, particularly its close relationship with Pakistan, will continue to irk India. Moreover, long-standing border disputes between China and India will fester in the next five years. Consequently, Sino-India ties will remain fairly brittle in 2018-22. Meanwhile, India will also continue to seek closer ties with other countries with significant economic or military heft, such as Japan and Russia, in an attempt to buttress its international standing in the face of a rising China.
Border disputes with Pakistan will linger in 2018-22. A major conflict is unlikely, but minor crossborder military engagements will persist. The NDA government will continue to deepen ties with countries in the Middle East, particularly Israel, which is an increasingly important source of arms for India.

a See Guide to the business rankings model at the end of this report. b Out of 10. c Out of 82 countries. d  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam. e New section, introduced in 2018.
India's overall score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings rises to 5.68 in 2018-22, from 5.18 in 2013-17. However, its global ranking remains unchanged at 62nd out of 82 countries, owing to greater improvements elsewhere. Among its BRICS peers, India scores better than Russia (5.37), but fares worse than Brazil (6.08), China (6.07) and South Africa (6.03). India's score is dragged down by weak ratings for infrastructure, the labour market and taxes. Despite improvements in these scores in 2018-22, they will remain the worst-rated areas of the business environment. This supports our view that in 2018-22 political exigencies and a lack of a government majority in the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of parliament) until after 2020 will limit progress with reforms.
India's relatively smooth changes in government and mild risk of social unrest and armed conflict lend support to its comparatively strong score for political stability. However, the limited ability of the state machinery to meet the needs of a fast-growing and diverse economy, as well as high levels of corruption, limit its score for political effectiveness. Meanwhile, the score for foreign trade and exchange controls improves markedly in the forecast period, supported by higher scores for the categories of trade protectionism, capital-account controls and advances in the ease of doing trade.

Business environment outlook: India's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: States such as Gujarat and Haryana continue to make headway in liberalising the investment regime. Meanwhile, the new goods and services tax (GST) regime spurs the creation of more inter-state supply chains by reducing tax checks between states, which have previously delayed the movement of goods.
2020-22: After the 2019 parliamentary election the central government undertakes piecemeal privatisation of some state-run companies, but fails to meet its disinvestment targets.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign participation in key sectors, including manufacturing of defence equipment, picks up pace.
2020-22: Full ownership of multi-brand retail companies remains off limits for foreign investors. However, single-brand retail sees continued foreign investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Trade tensions with the US rise as both sides adopt an increasingly protectionist stance. There is no progress on the proposed free-trade agreement with the EU.
2020-22: The vast majority of restrictions on the free movement of capital remain in place.
Taxes
2018-19: Tax reforms lose momentum as the government's priority shifts to appeasing voters ahead of the 2019 election.
2020-22: The widening tax base and improved compliance allow for cuts to corporate tax rates.
Financing
2018-19: Higher bad-loan provisioning weighs on the profitability of the banking sector. Meanwhile, tighter regulation leads to an increase in the sector's non-performing loan ratio, as more cases of poor lending are detected.
2020-22: The share of private-sector banks in total lending continues to rise, as most public-sector banks struggle with a large volume of bad debts.
The labour market
2018-19: Reforms to labour laws move at a glacial pace due to obstruction by trade unions and opposition groups.
2020-22: Efforts to improve labour laws gather pace after the National Democratic Alliance government obtains a majority in the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of parliament) after 2020, easing the passage of reform legislation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: The government increases its budgetary allocation for infrastructure projects, such as the Bharatmala road connectivity scheme.
2020-22: Construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its completion target of August 2022.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore.
2020-22: Despite persistent efforts, the speed and reliability of internet connectivity remain poor by global standards.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.6 6.9 52 50 15 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The economy will record robust growth in 2018-22
India's score for macroeconomic environment improves marginally, from 6.6 in 2013-17 to 6.9 in 2018-22, and the country jumps two places in both the global and regional rankings. The economy will record robust expansion throughout the forecast period, outstripping growth in its counterparts in the BRICS grouping-Brazil, Russia, China and South Africa.
Twin deficits on the fiscal and current accounts will remain one of the weakest aspects of India's macroeconomic environment. The rising value of energy imports-led by higher crude oil prices, as well as increases in imports of gold, consumer electronics, machinery and equipment to cater to fast-growing consumer and industrial demand-will also add to the import bill. Fiscal pressures will continue despite rising tax collection as the government outspends its receipts to fund burgeoning development projects. Nevertheless, some fiscal consolidation measures will be undertaken from 2019 onwards, helping the government to narrow the budget deficit to the equivalent of 2.9% of GDP in fiscal year 2022/23 (April-March), from 3.5% in 2017/18.
Meanwhile, persistent efforts by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to counter inflation will yield results, and consumer price rises will remain within the RBI's target band of 2-6% throughout the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.5 5.3 57 57 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition improves to 5.3 in 2018-22, from 4.5 in 2013-17, mainly owing to a reduction in price controls and deregulation. However, India's global and regional rankings remain unchanged.
The government has made progress on streamlining the bureaucracy and merging some ministries, easing the approval process for industrial and infrastructure projects. It has also encouraged competition among states by devolving power to them to experiment locally with pro-business liberalisation. The pioneers in this process have been the southern states of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu, as well as the western state of Gujarat and the northern state of Haryana. Haryana, for example, has consolidated the granting of over 70 business approvals within one agency, the Enterprise Promotion Centre, making it easier for businesses to obtain clearances. Despite these state-level measures, however, the scope for improvement remains immense.
The government's privatisation plan will be only partially successful
Buoyed by its success in exceeding its disinvestment target of Rs725bn (US$10.8bn) for 2017/18, the government raised its target for 2018/19 to Rs800bn. However, the lukewarm response to the administration's disinvestment plans so far, such as its failed bid to divest in the flag carrier, Air India, indicate that this push is unlikely to be sustained and that the authorities will fail to meet the target in the forecast period.
The retail and wholesale distribution system remains considerably fragmented, with limited investment. The introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax (GST) in 2017, which replaced a slew of state-wide taxes, is improving the efficiency of supply chains. However, the overall distribution system will remain constrained by poor infrastructure. This will continue to create significant challenges for domestic and foreign firms. Moreover, 100% foreign direct investment (FDI) in multi-brand retail is unlikely to be permitted in the forecast period, owing to opposition from small businesses, which form a crucial vote bank for the Bharatiya Janata Party (the main component party of the governing coalition).
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.5 5.5 62 66 15 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for policy towards foreign investment is unchanged at 5.5 in 2018-22. However, its global ranking drops from 62nd to 66th as its regional peers make headway in their efforts to attract foreign investors. Nonetheless, India will continue to receive higher FDI inflows in the forecast period as the government makes efforts to ease red tape. As a result, FDI inflows will grow rapidly in the next five years, rising to US$81bn by 2022, more than doubling from US$40bn in 2017. However, the volume of inward FDI in 2022 will still be lower than that of China, which will attract FDI inflows of US$155bn in the same year.
In July 2018 Samsung Electronics of South Korea opened a factory to manufacture mobile phones in Noida, India. Samsung has said that this is the world's largest factory for mobile-phone manufacturing, and the government has claimed it as a success story of its "Make in India" promotional campaign. Nevertheless, this factory remains an exception, and the overall manufacturing sector will fail to gather significant momentum in 2018-22, owing to-among other factors-challenges of land acquisition.
Policy changes will encourage foreign investment in the automotive sector
Foreign investment in the automotive sector will remain strong in the forecast period, owing to fast growth in household incomes, which will boost demand for cars. To this end, a Japanese car manufacturer, Suzuki (the largest car maker in India by volume, holding close to 50% of the market), is investing US$1bn jointly with another Japanese company, Toyota, to maintain its hold over what is a rapidly growing market. Volkswagen of Germany is also formulating a strategy to expand its currently small presence in India. Tougher environmental standards from 2020 will support car sales as older models that do not meet these regulations are phased out. Furthermore, state governments are devising policies to support the fledging electric-vehicle (EV) industry. For example, some states, such as Gujarat and Maharashtra, are procuring EVs for their own government fleets. This will support car manufacturers, the majority of which are foreign-owned.
In July 2018 the government announced a draft e-commerce policy. It proposes the creation of a new e-commerce regulator to, among other things, enforce compliance of foreign-based e-commerce firms with foreign-investment caps in India's e-commerce sector, and enforce stricter controls on mergers and acquisitions in the sector. However, the policy is unlikely to be approved in its current form, owing to opposition from industry groups.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.1 6.4 70 62 16 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for foreign trade and exchange controls improves significantly to 6.4 in the forecast period, from 5.1 in 2013-17. As a result, the country's global ranking rises from 70th to 62nd, and its regional position improves from 16th to 13th. This progress is due to trade liberalisation and modest deregulation of capital-account restrictions. In addition, some headway will be made on reducing tariff and non-tariff barriers in 2018-22. Under its revised foreign trade policy, the government has lowered an array of export subsidies and harmonised them under two general schemes, one for goods and one for services. This is part of a broader effort to stimulate exports through supply-side reforms meant to boost the competitiveness of Indian exporters.
Most restrictions on the free movement of capital will stay in place in 2018-22
Rules governing outward investment and overseas borrowing will continue to be liberalised in 2018-22, but regulatory restrictions on the free movement of capital will largely remain in place. The authorities have significantly liberalised capital-account regulations in recent years. In 2015 the central bank permitted companies to raise local-currency-denominated debt abroad for the first time (although it still mandates that all transactions be settled in US dollars). Legislative restrictions for non-residents apply only to inflows. Despite moves by the RBI to make capital-account transactions easier, we do not expect the government to introduce full capital-account convertibility in 2018-22.
Negotiations between India and the EU on a proposed free-trade agreement have been stalled since 2013 owing to disagreement on a few contentious issues, and the deal is unlikely to be revived in the forecast period. India has a patchy record on trade liberalisation, and the government has often resorted to protectionism in the face of threats to domestic industry from foreign competitors.
India will remain fairly protectionist
In July 2018 the Directorate-General of Trade Remedies (an agency under the Ministry of Commerce and Industry) recommended tariffs for two years (until 2020) on solar panel imports from China and Malaysia, in a bid to safeguard India's domestic manufacturers. Although these measures are still under discussion, India's approach to trade will remain relatively protectionist in 2018-22. Indeed, the country's export subsidies are one of the factors that has led to a flare-up of trade tensions with the US; these subsidies are unlikely to be watered down significantly in 2018-22.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.0 5.2 72 69 16 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for taxes rises marginally to 5.2 in 2018-22, from 5 in 2013-17. As a result, the country's global and regional rankings improve marginally. However, the country's scores for subcategories within taxes remain largely unchanged, reflecting the slow pace of progress.
The nationwide GST introduced in July 2017 marks one of India's biggest tax reforms in decades. It replaced a slew of central and state indirect taxes and is a significant step towards creating a single market. Since its roll-out, the GST Council has met regularly and taken measures to simplify the GST, and cut its rates. (The GST Council comprises a group of ministers authorised with deciding changes to the rate and structure of the tax.) As GST collections pick up, the government will continue to rationalise GST rates and bring more items into lower tax brackets, although multiple tax slabs will remain in place. Furthermore, several key items, including alcoholic spirits and petroleum products, will remain outside the GST net.
Foreign investors will remain wary of the government's opaque tax regime, highlighted by the risk of retrospective changes to tax laws. Public concerns over tax evasion have led to the government increasing the regulatory power of tax authorities, raising concerns of overreach in a country where tax laws remain complex.
Corporate tax rates will fall gradually over the forecast period
The National Democratic Alliance (NDA) government has previously declared its intention of reducing corporate tax rates in a phased manner. In the budget for 2018/19, the 25% corporate tax rate applicable for businesses with turnover of up to Rs500m (US$7.5m) was extended to firms with turnover of up to Rs2.5bn. Meanwhile, efforts to widen the tax base by increasing the capacity of tax authorities and identifying non-compliers will continue. A gradual relaxation in tax rates will continue throughout the forecast period, as strong economic growth and a widening tax base will enable the government to reduce corporate tax rates without forgoing substantial amounts of revenue.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.1 5.9 57 58 12 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for financing improves from 5.1 in 2013-17 to 5.9 in 2018-22. However, India's position in the global rankings deteriorates from 57th to 58th as other countries make greater progress in this area. Nevertheless, financial regulation in India will improve throughout the forecast period, underpinned by concerns over the large volume of bad loans. In its biannual Financial Stability Report published in June 2018, the RBI indicated that it expects the non-performing loan (NPL) ratio of the banking sector to rise to 12.2% by March 2019, from 11.6% in March 2018. Nevertheless, improved bad-loan provisioning and strict regulation will support an improvement in the sector's health towards the latter part of our forecast period. The disclosure of a US$1.7bn bank fraud in January indicates that the NPL problem may go deeper than previously anticipated. Consequently, this is leading to stricter surveillance, which will result in further fraud disclosures. This will weigh on the banking sector's profitability in the coming quarters. However, in the latter half of the forecast period this should support a mild recovery in the sector. Meanwhile, the RBI's primary policy priority will remain inflation-targeting, and the central bank will carefully calibrate policy to avoid episodes of rapid inflation, such as the 10.1% average increase in consumer prices in 2013. By contrast, we expect consumer prices to rise by 4.8% a year on average in 2018-22.
The share of private banks in total lending will rise in 2018-22
Private and foreign companies will take on a rising share of financing, particularly as the bulk of NPLs continue to emanate from public-sector banks. However, state-run lenders will still account for the bulk of total lending given the vast network of the public sector, especially in rural areas. There will be divergence in the performance of state run banks, with the largest public-sector lender (also the overall largest bank), the State Bank of India, performing better than smaller state-run lenders owing to its much larger bad-loan provisioning and significant improvements to its corporate governance standards.
The RBI has indicated that it will stick to its March 2019 deadline for rolling out Basel III norms. Several public-sector banks are currently under the prompt corrective action framework (an RBI operational framework for banks that fail to meet minimum capital-adequacy and NPL requirements). Under the central bank's baseline projections, as many as six state-run lenders will miss the minimum capital-adequacy requirements by the March 2019 deadline. Thus, there may be consolidation or restructuring (including mergers) of some public-sector banks as the government attempts to revive these ailing institutions. However, outright privatisation remains very unlikely, given political pressure from trade unions and opposition parties.
Priority-sector lending targets will remain in place
Priority-sector lending (minimum mandated lending to specific sectors aimed at achieving socio-developmental objectives) will remain a feature of government policy throughout the forecast period. The RBI will continue to push both state-owned and private banks to meet priority-sector targets. Indian commercial banks and foreign lenders with more than 20 branches in India are currently required to provide 40% of their net bank credit to the priority sectors, which include agriculture, housing and renewable energy. A significant reduction in this target is unlikely in 2018-22.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.7 5.1 72 70 16 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for the labour market improves from 4.7 in 2013-17 to 5.1 in 2018-22. However, the country slips to the bottom of our regional rankings, as other regional economies make greater progress on improving labour market conditions. India has taken some limited steps towards overhauling its outdated array of labour laws (many of which have not be comprehensively revamped in decades) under the current administration. However, in 2018-22 progress will be inhibited by opposition from trade unions (including those affiliated with the ruling coalition). This does not mean that no reform will take place-indeed, there has been progress on revamping labour regulations. For example, in March 2018 the government announced that it was seeking to allow all industrial establishments to hire workers on fixed-term contracts, previously permissible only for the textile industry. However, changes to more trouble-some pieces of legislation, such as the Industrial Disputes Act, remain unlikely. A major reason for the slow progress on reforming labour laws is the government's lack of a majority in the Rajya Sabha, which means that it depends on the support of opposition parties to get legislation approved. We expect the NDA to obtain a majority in the upper house after 2020, which should speed up the legislation process.
Efforts to revamp labour laws will meet political resistance
In July 2018 the government announced that it had prepared a Code of Industrial Relations, representing the consolidation of over 40 different labour laws under four major codes covering wages, industrial relations, social security, and occupational safety, health and working conditions. Given strong resistance from opposition parties and trade unions, passage of this bill will not be swift. We do not expect the bill to be passed in the current session of parliament, or in the upcoming winter session. It is more likely that the code will be taken up in the Lok Sabha (the lower house) after the April-May 2019 election, where it could be subject to significant criticism and modifications owing to concerns raised by trade unions over the withdrawal of some protective provisions.
Some state governments, particularly in the west and south, will continue to implement labour reforms throughout the forecast period. Rajasthan has, for example, exempted establishments with up to 300 workers from the provision of the Industrial Disputes Act which requires government permission before laying off workers. Meanwhile, Maharashtra has set self-certification systems for business units covered under 16 different acts, with a view to reducing the interference of government officials as well as expediting the process of certification. However, without changes at central level, harmonisation of these reforms across states will remain a challenge throughout the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
3.0 3.5 78 78 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Significant gaps between demand supply in infrastructure will persist
The score for infrastructure improves from 3 in 2013-17 to 3.5 in 2018-22. This is driven by higher scores for road density, distribution networks and air transport. However, India remains a laggard in this category, ranked 78th out of the 82 countries, driven by weak scores for internet speed, rail density and ports. Infrastructure improvements and expansion remain key priorities for the NDA government. We expect the bulk of public investment to be diverted to transport, energy and urban-improvement projects. However, the pace of progress on projects that are already under way will remain constrained by weak government effectiveness and delays in regulatory clearances (particularly environmental approvals).
Progress on urban civic infrastructure projects, such as water supply, will be hindered by inadequate private-sector involvement given the limited returns on investment in these sectors. The private sector will instead be focused on areas that promise faster returns, like airport construction, and there will be significant progress in these areas in 2018-22. However, demand for infra-structure facilities will continue to exceed supply by a significant margin in the forecast period, placing stress on already scarce resources.
Flagship infrastructure projects are likely to miss completion targets
Two publicly funded connectivity projects, Bharatmala (road construction) and Sagarmala (port construction), will continue to be prioritised throughout the forecast period. The first phase of Bharatmala is aimed at connecting 550 of the country's districts through the national highways network, compared with only 300 connected as at 2017. The government plans to build a total of 24,800 km of roads by 2022. However, progress on this project will be hindered by limited funds, and it is likely to miss its targets.
The quality and breadth of railway services will remain a challenge in 2018-22. India has one of the largest rail networks in the world, but the quality of the network is inadequate, with accidents and poor speeds that restrain efficiency. A lack of capital investment in the sector constrains the expansion of capacity. Despite piecemeal efforts, the overall quality of the rail network will remain poor when compared with other countries with large rail networks, such as China and the US. However, rapid transit projects, including a bullet train connecting Ahmedabad to Mumbai, and several ongoing urban mass rapid transit projects, will make significant progress during the forecast period.
Government efforts to facilitate online filing for new start-ups, online payment for public services and other citizen engagement programmes, as part of an e-governance scheme, have had limited success so far. With participation from private players, the authorities will continue to promote online transactions as it continues to prioritise the digitisation of public services, although the pace of execution will be tempered by implementation challenges. For example, integration of the Aadhaar (a unique digitised identity card) platform with government transfers and subsidy payments will continue in the forecast period. Tax services are likely to be linked to the Aadhaar scheme in the next few years.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.1 6.3 41 42 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our business environment rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption. Aided by a cheap smartphone boom, India scores relatively high on technological readiness. However, despite the improvement in its-from 6.1 in 2013-17 to 6.3 in 2018-22-the country's global ranking drops one place to 42nd. This is mainly owing to weak scores for patent filings and cyber-security preparedness. Indeed, limited investment in research and development will continue to hamper a pick-up in the number of patents approved in 2018-22.
Internet speeds will remain slow by global standards
Despite achieving significant mobile-phone penetration, India lags behind in terms of mobile internet speeds. For example, India's 4G internet speeds fall well short of the global average according to a market intelligence company, OpenSignal. In June 2018 the Telecom Commission, a government agency, approved the new National Digital Communication Policy, the objectives of which include providing minimum download speeds of 50 mbps and enabling 10-gbps connectivity to all rural administrations by 2022. With an estimated investment of US$100bn, this ambitious policy aims to generate 4m jobs in digital communication and increase the sector's contribution to India's GDP from around 6% currently to 8% by 2022. However, acquiring spectrum licences and laying the requisite fibre network will create obstacles, and the government is likely to fall short of its targets.
E-commerce has become the focal point of India's digital revolution, owing to factors such as FDI-friendly regulation, a growing middle class, the availability of relatively cheap mobile connections and skilled labour to develop indigenous technology platforms. According to the government's India Brand Equity Foundation, the e-commerce market will grow from US$38.5bn in 2017 to US$200bn by 2026. Meanwhile, a report published in February 2018 from US-based Boston Consulting Group and Google says that total online consumer spending will rise from US$40bn currently to US$100bn by 2020, led by spending on e-commerce, travel and hotels, financial services and digital media. According to estimates from a local research firm, RedSeer, an e-commerce retailer, Flipkart, accounts for 46% of India's online sales, in close competition with the local operation of Amazon (US) at 30%. The e-commerce segment will continue to grow at a robust pace in 2018-22.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
As the 2019 general election approaches, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) government will shift gears from improving the business environment to a more populist agenda, in a bid to garner support from voters. This move will include efforts to improve both the design and the effectiveness of welfare programmes, as well as expanding the reach of these schemes. The government has been linking welfare transfers to bank accounts through the Aadhaar unique identity platform. In 2018-22 this platform is also likely to be linked to business transactions and tax payments, in an effort to bring greater transparency to tax administration and business procedures. The Economist Intelligence Unit also expects the government to focus on improving the quality of infrastructure. However, high levels of corruption and limited government effectiveness in implementing public works will constrain progress.
We expect the government's focus to return to less popular economic reforms after the 2019 election. These will entail greater fiscal consolidation, as well as relaxing restrictions on foreign direct investment, streamlining tax laws and simplifying regulations on doing business. The government has implemented some piecemeal labour reforms, such as allowing industrial establishments to hire workers on fixed contracts. However, more significant changes to problematic labour laws such as the Industrial Disputes Act are unlikely because of strong opposition from trade unions. Similarly, a substantial relaxation of land-acquisition laws is also unlikely in 2018-22, owing to strong opposition from farmers. More broadly, the government will continue to prioritise its electoral appeal among voters during the forecast period, and is unlikely to push for reforms that are highly politically contentious.
We expect significant economic reforms to take place at state level. However, the extent of these reforms will be uneven, with some states, such as Gujarat, Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu (traditionally considered more business-friendly), continuing to adopt noteworthy reforms while other states lag behind.

Tax reform is one of the NDA's key policy agendas, and efforts towards greater formalisation of the economy and broadening of the tax base will gather pace in fiscal years 2018/19-2022/23 (April-March). However, given the complexities in India's tax system, as well as high levels of corruption, these efforts are likely to yield mixed results. This is evident from the difficulties faced by the govern-ment and businesses in rolling out the goods and services tax (GST) that was introduced in 2017. Nevertheless, strong economic growth will support healthy progress in both direct and indirect tax collection, bolstering the public finances.
The government will increase spending on the upgrade of India's infrastructure in the next five years, as well as on subsidies and welfare payments to boost support from voters in 2018-19. As a result, it will record a persistent fiscal deficit, averaging the equivalent of 3.2% of GDP in 2018/19-2022/23. In 2018/19 an expansionary budget will preclude any reduction in the fiscal deficit, which will reach 3.6% of GDP. However, the government will revert to a path of modest fiscal consolidation after the 2019 election, and the fiscal deficit will narrow gradually to 2.9% of GDP by 2022/23.
This improving picture masks the large deficits being recorded by several state governments, which are not included in the national figure. The deep fiscal deficits of some states, such as Punjab, will pose downside risks to GDP growth by potentially crowding out private investment.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022

Short-term interest rate (year-end) 6.9 6.9 7.2 7.0 7.2 7.3
Long-term interest rate (year-end) 6.9 7.1 7.1 7.1 7.0 7.0
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will continue to make inflation-targeting the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework in the next five years. The RBI will aim to contain consumer price inflation within the 2-6% range and close to its optimum target of 4% throughout the forecast period. In order to arrest rising inflationary pressures, the RBI tightened its monetary policy stance at its meeting in June 2018, raising its benchmark policy rate, the repurchase (repo) rate, by 25 basis points. We expect another 25-basis-point increase in the repo rate in the third quarter of this year in order to calm inflation expectations. Following this, the RBI will maintain a neutral stance in 2019, before adopting a more accommodative stance in 2020 in order to offset the disinflationary impact of a downturn in the US economy in that year. The easing cycle will be completed by 2021, and the RBI will revert to a tightening stance in 2021-22, as growth in domestic demand accelerates.
Rising instances of bank fraud and a lack of transparency in the regulatory oversight of state-run banks will lead to disputes between the Ministry of Finance and the RBI over the regulatory role of the central bank. Nevertheless, the RBI will continue to enjoy a high degree of independence in setting the monetary policy agenda.

We forecast that real GDP growth will average 7.6% a year in 2018/19-2022/23. Expansion will be supported by robust increases in private consumption, averaging 7.8% annually in the next five years and making the largest contri-bution to headline growth. In addition, the economy will receive support from accelerating gross fixed investment, which will grow by an average of 8.8% a year in 2018/19-2022/23. This will be underpinned by progress in recapitalising the banking sector, although a lack of broader reforms in the sector will continue to place constraints on lending activity. Other efforts aimed at improving the business environment, such as tax reforms and the increased digitisation of government-to-business services, will also enhance investor sentiment. Public spending ahead of parliamentary and state elections will be a key source of support in the early part of the forecast period, with government consumption growing by 10.4% a year on average in 2018/19-2019/20. However, government spending will moderate over the latter half of the forecast period.
In factor-cost terms, real GDP will be driven by growth in the services sector, which will average 9.2% a year over the forecast period. The sector will make the largest contribution to headline growth, accounting for nearly 50% of nominal GDP by the end of the forecast period. Meanwhile, industry will benefit from the improving business environment and healthy investment, with output growing by 8.5% a year in 2018/19-2022/23. The agricultural sector will remain hostage to the vagaries of the monsoon. Its sluggishness will continue to dampen potential income growth in rural areas.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
As the economy moves up the value chain and productivity across the economy improves, the share of agriculture in total output will continue to gradually decline; we expect it to fall from 17.1% in 2017/18 to 14.2% by 2022/23. However, the primary sector will remain crucial, as it employs close to half of the population. As employment opportunities in the secondary and tertiary sector open up, there will, however, be a gradual shift in employment away from agriculture. Reforms to bolster supply-chain efficiency will support the sector's outlook in 2018-22. However, farm to wholesale procurement is still dominated by individual middlemen and local traders, with laws inhibiting the entry of companies in many states. This will continue to create inefficiencies in the procurement process. Nevertheless, public investment in improving agricultural logistics will support farm incomes. There is significant scope for investment to enhance the sector's productivity, as close to half of cultivable land remains dependent on annual monsoon rainfalls, rendering the sector vulnerable to poor or unevenly distributed rains. The government has recognised the sector's vulnerability to monsoon rainfalls and increased funding for irrigation schemes and crop insurance. As agriculture faces growing risks related to the availability of water, the success of these efforts will prove crucial to ensuring long-term sustainability. However, capital investment into the sector remains inadequate, and the bulk of public funding will continue to come in the form of populist short-term subsidies aimed at securing political support from farmers. We forecast that the agricultural sector will grow by 3.6% a year on average in the forecast period.

Land-acquisition challenges will inhibit faster growth in the industrial sector
The industrial sector will expand at a robust pace as the business environment improves and a robust growth outlook attracts investment and results in an expansion of capacity. We consequently expect the sector to grow by an average rate of 8.5% a year in the forecast period. The share of industry in total GDP will increase marginally from 29.1% in 2017/18 to 30.3% in 2021/22. Manufacturing will, however, continue to be concentrated in a few sectors, such as the automotive industry, and in a few locations, instead of being more broad-based across the country. Government efforts to lift manufacturing employment and output, such as through the "Make in India" initiative (which targets 100m additional jobs in manufacturing and a rise in its share of GDP to 25% by 2022) and the administration's special-economic-zone strategy, which is intended to develop manufacturing hubs throughout the country, are highly ambitious and will miss their targets. In the absence of greater liberalisation of land and labour laws, the industrial expansion will lag behind potential, which will also weigh on employment opportunities.
Accounting for 46.5% of GDP in 2017/18, the services sector will continue to be the main engine of economic expansion. The sector has shown itself to be resilient and efficient, and not entirely dependent on buoyancy in external markets. The sector's expansion will continue to be driven by already strong areas of activity such as telecommunications, as well as by services in numerous high-potential but currently underserved areas, including healthcare, retailing, hospitality and education. Information technology (IT) and IT-enabled services will remain a source of export revenue, even as growth slows as competition from countries such as the Philippines intensifies. Services will form a key sector of the economy in the forecast period, expanding by 9.2% a year on average, and its share of GDP will rise to 47.9% by 2022/23, only slightly higher than in 2017/18.

Unit labour costs (US$) 7.7 2.2 2.0 6.8 3.9 2.2
Prices of food and oil will remain the chief factors driving consumer price pressures in 2018-22. Food and beverages have a weighting of about 45% in the consumer price index, and so any volatility in agricultural output will adversely affect price stability. We expect consumer prices to rise by 4.8% on average in 2018, fuelled by higher crude oil prices. These will feed into sectors which consume large quantities of fuel, such as transport. Nevertheless, food prices will remain generally stable, with increases in agricultural output on the back of a normal monsoon offsetting the effect of higher oil prices. The government's fiscal largesse ahead of the 2019 parliamentary election will lead to greater demand-side price pressures. However, the RBI's tightening of monetary policy in 2018 will ease some of these pressures, and therefore we expect that consumer prices will rise by 4.9% on average in 2019, only slightly quicker than in 2018. As the rupee strengthens, cooling imported inflationary pressures, and crude oil prices dip, annual average inflation will moderate to 4.6% in 2020. Economic growth will subsequently strengthen in 2021-22, and upward demand-side pressures on consumer prices will increase again. A weakening rupee in 2021-22 will add to these inflationary pressures.

We expect the rupee's value to average Rs67.1:US$1 in 2018, with the US dollar strengthening compared with 2017 on the back of the tighter monetary policy adopted by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). Furthermore, a year-on-year weakening of equity inflows in 2018 will add to the pressure on the rupee. India's persistent dual deficits on the fiscal and current accounts will also keep international investors cautious. We expect the RBI to intervene in foreign-exchange markets to support the currency against sharp depreciation. Although this will help to avert a very sharp decline in the value of the rupee, the broader trend of depreciation will persist in 2019 and the currency will weaken to Rs69.1:US$1 on average in that year. However, we expect the rupee to appreciate against a weakening US dollar in 2020 as the US economy experiences a marked slowdown in that year. Although the RBI will loosen monetary policy in 2020, the stronger growth prospects in India compared with the US in that year will provide support for the rupee. As oil prices pick up again from 2021, the rupee will lose value against the US dollar. We expect this depreciatory trend to persist in 2022, when the rupee's exchange rate will weaken to an annual average of Rs72:US$1.
Depreciatory pressures could be exacerbated by capital outflows if investor confidence in India or emerging markets were to weaken. However, we believe that India's relatively healthy macroeconomic outlook, combined with the central bank's high level of foreign-exchange reserves, will limit the risk of significant exchange-rate volatility.

India's trade deficit will remain wide in 2018-22, with rising prices of crude oil (the country's largest import item in value terms) serving to drive merchandise imports. Exports will grow, but the rate of expansion will remain unflattering when compared with imports. Increasing protectionism in the US will exacerbate trade tensions with that country, which is India's largest export market, and inhibit the pace of growth in exports of both goods and services. Moreover, increasing competition from other countries will hurt India's IT and business-process outsourcing service exports in the forecast period. Although the services balance will remain positive in 2018-22, the rate of expansion in services exports will be relatively tempered, particularly in 2020, when the US undergoes a technical recession. Overall, the wide imbalance on merchandise trade will keep the current account in deficit, equivalent to an average of 2.4% of GDP in 2018-22.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in India
Stocks and flows
India's large market size and growing economy make it a favourable destination for foreign investors. Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows into India have been strong in recent years, and in 2017 the country received US$40bn in FDI inflows. This compares favourably with an average of US$17.8bn in 2005-07, before the outbreak of the 2008-09 global financial crisis. Owing to an attractive growth outlook and significant market opportunities, the stock of inward FDI has been expanding rapidly, standing at US$377.5bn in 2017, markedly higher than in 2010, when it stood at US$205.6bn. The 2017 figure was also higher than the corresponding stock in Indonesia (US$248.5bn) but significantly lower than in China (US$1.4trn) and Brazil (US$778.3bn).
Origin and distribution
According to the Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion (DIPP), the largest source of FDI is Mauritius, which accounted for 34% of FDI inflows between April 2000 and March 2018. Many foreign companies investing in India are incorporated in Mauritius for tax reasons. Singapore was the second most important foreign investor in the same period, accounting for 18% of cumulative inflows, followed by Japan (7%), the UK (7%), the Netherlands (6%) and the US (5%). The most important sector for FDI is services, which attracted US$66.2bn between April 2000 and March 2018 and accounted for 18% of cumulative inflows, according to the DIPP. The computer software and hardware sector is the second-largest recipient, attracting US$30.8bn and accounting for 8% of cumulative inflows. The financial centre, Mumbai, is the largest recipient of FDI, and garnered 31% of total FDI between April 2000 and March 2018. This was followed by the capital, New Delhi, and neighbouring areas, which received 20% of total FDI in the same period.
Determinants
India's skilled, English-speaking workforce has been a significant attraction for FDI, particularly in the information technology (IT) sector. Since coming into office the current government has liberalised the FDI regime in a number of areas, including defence, pharmaceuticals, civil aviation and single-brand retailing. It has also done away with the Foreign Investment Promotion Board, an agency that was tasked with considering and recommending FDI on a case-by-case basis. This onus now falls on individual ministries, and the administration will continue to open up the economy to foreign investors. However, more minor bureaucratic restrictions are often left unaddressed and legal uncertainties often persist, impeding the inflow of investment and hampering the ease of conducting business in India for foreigners.
Impact
FDI has had the greatest impact on India's software industry and IT-enabled services. Call centres and other forms of back-office administration have become important industries, but India is moving up the value chain. The financial, pharmaceutical, telecommunications and power sectors have also been influenced significantly by FDI. The retail sector could be similarly transformed, but a significant relaxation of regulations for multi-brand retailers is unlikely to occur over the forecast period.
Potential
Given the size of its market and rapid economic growth, India is attracting a significant amount of FDI, but the potential for even stronger inflows is hamstrung by relatively poor infrastructure, excessive bureaucracy and wrangling between government departments. The infrastructure, energy, telecoms, IT and insurance sectors are likely to be the key areas for FDI in 2018-22. Producers and assemblers of cars and automotive components are also re-evaluating India's potential, as are biotechnology firms.

The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the population will grow by 1.1% a year on average in 2018-22, down from 1.2% in 2013-17. This slight slowdown is linked to an improvement in living standards, urbanisation and generally improving economic conditions for women. According to data from the National Institution for Transforming India (NITI Aayog, the government's policy think-tank), the total fertility rate fell to 2.3 children per woman in 2015, from 3.2 in 2000. India could reach the replacement level of fertility-2.1 children per woman-within five years. In the coastal states, the fertility rate is already below the replacement rate. However, poor and populous states such as Uttar Pradesh and Bihar will continue to see strong population growth, adding to social tensions.
High levels of gender disparity will increase the risk of social unrest
The gender distribution of the population has equally important implications for social and political stability. Historically, countries with large gender disparities have tended to suffer from higher levels of social disorder. By 2022 men will outnumber women by 50m. According to the latest census, conducted in 2011, there were just 919 girls for every 1,000 boys under the age of six, marking a decline from the previous census in 2001, which showed that there were 927 girls for every 1,000 boys. More recent research from the National Family Health Survey, conducted in 2015-16, shows that a skewed sex ratio exists across almost the entire country (the gender disparity is more pronounced in urban regions rather than rural areas). This deep gender imbalance will be a source of social tensions-particularly in urban areas-and be fuelled further by the inability of many men to find suitable employment opportunities.
The agricultural sector will continue to employ the bulk of the labour force
Growth in the working-age population will remain relatively strong, at 1.4% a year on average in 2018-22. However, unlocking the economic benefits from a rising population will prove challenging. In the 1990s and 2000s China was able to transfer workers from a relatively unproductive agricultural sector to more productive work in the cities, thereby boosting economic growth and exports. India's manufacturing sector, however, has failed to take off in a similar manner, owing to the comparative lack of legislative and political efforts. The services sector, which is the primary driver of India's economic growth, has failed to create requisite employment opportunities. Agriculture therefore still constitutes the largest share of employment. The share of agriculture in nominal GDP will continue to decline over the forecast period, but this will be gradual and the sector will remain the largest employer in 2018-22.
The pace of job growth in manufacturing will be sluggish
The government hopes to raise job opportunities in employment-heavy sectors like manufacturing, in part through its "Make in India" campaign. However, a failure to pass significant land and labour reforms at national level, in conjunction with a lack of preferential access to major export markets, will put India-based manufacturing companies at a disadvantage. Data from the World Bank show that the share of industry in total employment has stagnated at the 23-24% mark since 2011, and one reason for the slowdown in job growth in industry in recent years has been a deceleration in growth in the construction sector. Although we expect job growth in industry to continue in 2018-22, the pace will be sluggish and insufficient to keep up with the expansion of the labour force.
Weaknesses in the education system will also come to the fore as more students seek secondary and tertiary education. Few universities operate at world-class levels, and the vast majority of graduates appear unequipped for the demands of employers-even in sectors such as engineering, which are crucial for long-term growth. The growing politicisation of the tertiary education sector and lack of clear focus on improving education standards by authorities means that Indian universities will broadly continue to under-perform. A few clusters of excellence will, however, gradually emerge. Competition for entry into the highly regarded Indian Institutes of Technology will intensify. As employment growth and education levels will remain below potential, we believe that India will not be able to realise the potential gains from a rising population fully. People without the necessary literacy and numeracy skills will be constrained to low-paying occupations in the domestic-oriented services sector.
