The middle class will continue to grow throughout the forecast period
Rising income levels over the forecast period mean that India's huge population will become an increasingly important market for consumer goods. Household consumption expenditure will rise from US$1.5trn in 2017 to US$2.4trn by 2022. Despite rapid economic growth, GDP per head (at market exchange rates) will remain relatively low at just US$2,811 in 2022, compared with US$12,751 in China and US$10,734 in Brazil in the same year. This will limit the bulk of consumer spending to food and basic necessities. However, this low average masks the presence of a small but growing number of middle-class households, which offers considerable potential for manufacturers and retailers. The rapid growth in personal incomes, combined with a more open domestic market, will make India an increasingly attractive market for foreign companies. Significant regional economic disparities exist and the levels of opportunity for retail businesses will vary greatly across the country in the forecast period.
Growth in the e-commerce segment will be robust
Opportunities for e-commerce will grow rapidly in urban areas, owing to their increasingly well-educated populations and growing penetration of broadband and smartphones. Businesses are already catering to this opportunity, and in May 2018 Wal-Mart (US) announced plans to acquire a majority stake in Flipkart, an Indian e-commerce company. As India continues on a solid growth path in 2018-22, the share of e-commerce in its consumer market will rise, creating opportunities for both domestic and foreign firms. In July the government announced a draft e-commerce policy, which proposes a new e-commerce regulator and a sunset clause on deep discounting by e-retailers. However, some provisions of the draft, particularly those related to mergers and acquisitions, are opposed by businesses, and it is therefore unlikely to be approved in its current form.
As India increasingly joins global value chains and its consumers become more aware of international brands, imports of electronics and consumer goods will rise. Urban consumers tend to display more brand loyalty than their rural counterparts and value loyalty programmes. For most Indians price will remain the main determinant of the level of demand. Companies in the fast-moving consumer goods sector tend to address the affordability issue by offering products in smaller sizes. This practice has been used successfully in emerging markets and offers consumers a way to develop brand loyalty early on.

As in most developing countries, food constitutes by far the largest category of consumer expenditure. Indeed, spending on food as a percentage of income will remain relatively stable over 2018-22. However, this masks that, in US dollar terms, spending in sectors such as leisure and education, as well as health, will pick up noticeably. The relatively poor state of government-provided health services means that as Indians become richer, they will spend an increasingly large amount on healthcare services provided by the private sector. Growth in the leisure and education sector will be fuelled by a rapidly expanding middle class and huge demand for educational services.
Local factors will continue to shape consumer preferences
Several non-income-related factors must be weighed carefully when assessing prospects in the Indian market. First, purchasing power is as location-specific as it is income-sensitive, and prices can vary to a considerable degree even from city to city, let alone between urban and rural areas. Second, cultural factors matter to a significant degree. Third, Indian consumers, including those who are moving up the income scale, are highly price-conscious. Fourth, it is important to note that there is hardly a single characteristic that applies across the entire country. India is a widely varying collection of markets, necessitating a strategic approach that takes regional differences into account. Finally, the steady expansion of consumer finance and the growth of a credit-card culture will increase the number of consumers in the forecast period.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: The Indian economy began to move away from a state-directed socialist model in the early 1990s, when a balance-of-payments crisis triggered the first round of economic reforms and market liberalisation. Since then, India has recorded rapid rates of expansion, with annual real GDP growth averaging 6.2% in fiscal years 1991/92-2017/18 (April-March). However, India's share in world GDP (at market exchange rates) remains far below potential, at around 3.4% in 2017. Meanwhile, the country accounts for 18% of the world's population. This highlights the fact that there is still significant scope for further economic development. Low average productivity in India remains a key reason for widespread poverty. The gap in productivity between the agriculture sector and high-growth industries, such as information technology (IT), is vast. Corruption in local authorities is still endemic, despite the fact that attempts to reduce graft have made progress at the higher levels of government under the Bharatiya Janata Party (which has led the ruling coalition since 2014). India's courts have long suffered from crippling levels of understaffing and a case backlog has built up over decades. However, the judiciary is independent from the government and is in a position to challenge government policies.
A skills mismatch will persist in the workforce
Demographic trends: Continued growth of the working-age population over 2018-50 will the support rapid rate of economic expansion. However, even as the economy grows, a large proportion of the workforce will not find employ-ment in productive formal-sector jobs. By and large, a mismatch between the skills offered by the country's workers and the demands of employers will persist, as the education and vocational training systems will fail to provide sufficient and comprehensive education. The rise of automation and growing use of artificial intelligence will meanwhile dampen employment gains even as India-based enterprises capture a larger market share of the world market for goods and services. Reaping the demographic dividend will prove immensely difficult in this environment. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the vast majority of the workforce to be absorbed by low-productivity occupations in the urban services sector in 2018-50. Still, the expansion of manufacturing and growth in high-technology areas such as telecommunications, IT and pharmaceuticals will offer oppor-tunities to expand employment for India's young and increasingly well-educated workforce.
Migration from poorer states could cause a spike in social tensions
A divergence in economic fortunes within the country will result in strong pressure for Indians from poorer states to move into more prosperous areas. In the absence of major governance improvements, states such as Uttar Pradesh and Bihar will be a source of internal migrants, putting pressure on scarce resources in cities such as the capital, New Delhi, and the financial hub, Mumbai. There is strong divergence in fertility rates between states, with Uttar Pradesh and Bihar recording high total fertility rates (TFR) of 3.1 and 3.3 respectively in 2016; the more prosperous state of Kerala has a TFR of 1.8 in the same year. This will continue in the long run and the population of Uttar Pradesh alone could surpass 400m by the middle of the century, and significant levels of internal migration will be a source of political and social tensions. Others will look abroad, such as to the Gulf region, for economic opportunities. This will lead to an upsurge in remittances over the next few decades, which will particularly drive economic activity in states with high exposure to workers' remittances such as Kerala.
The unequal gender distribution of India's population will remain a threat to social stability over the outlook period. According to the latest census, conducted in 2011, for every 1,000 boys under the age of six there were only 919 girls, marking a decline from the previous census in 2001, which showed that there were 927 girls for every 1,000 boys. Child mortality rates are higher for girls than boys, and female foeticide is practised. As this trend continues (and there is no evidence to suggest that it will not), a major imbalance between the numbers of men and women will undermine social stability.
External conditions: As its economy expands in size, India will become an increasingly important diplomatic, military and economic power. Successive governments will seek to ensure India's primacy within South Asia and cultivate ties with regional neighbours-excluding Pakistan, India's long-standing rival. We expect India's relationship with Pakistan to remain tense, as the two countries will struggle to reconcile political and strategic differences. Temporary bouts of high tension are likely. However, the growth differential between India and Pakistan will remain high, suggesting that India's military advantage over its rival will increase. Over time, this should deter Pakistan from initiating conflict. China's influential role in Pakistan and its competition for influence in South Asia with India will weigh on bilateral relations between the world's two most populous nations. Shared strategic and economic interests will bind India more closely with Japan and the US. Still, even as it becomes a major diplo-matic power, India will remain hesitant to align itself fully with the West. This is partially related to India's complex relationship with Russia, which has been a major source of military equipment. Averting the possibility of closer Russia-Pakistan ties will remain a foreign policy imperative. Long-standing links with the Gulf region and Africa and deepening investment ties will provide India with the opportunity to expand its political, economic and cultural engagement at a robust pace.
The judicial system will remain independent
Institutions and policy trends: Differing policy trends will emerge as power is increasingly decentralised in the decades ahead and moves to state level. Reform-minded states will see growth accelerate, while poorer states will demand increased funds from the central government to reduce economic disparities. The fight over control of the central government will fuel political instability as regional parties increase in influence and owing to the fact that only a few genuine nationwide parties exist. Despite state-level differences, India's democratic political system will remain firmly entrenched. The country's legal system will generally remain impartial (if slow) and the constitution will continue to be respected. Economic policy and diplomatic efforts will continue to focus on expanding global ties and integration into regional and global value chains. New technologies and the emergence of an increasingly vocal middle class will help the authorities to curb graft, particularly at local level.
Services will continue to dominate the economy in the longer term
Long-term performance: We forecast that India's real GDP growth will average 5.3% a year in 2018-50. The country's economic progress is premised on a shift up the value chain in IT, manufacturing, pharmaceuticals, business and information services, as well as other sectors. Continued government-led investment to upgrade infrastructure will improve the business environment and help to enhance the performance of the economy. One major concern over the long-term economic performance is the extent to which the government successfully manages the transition of the labour force from rural into urban areas, in the light of scarce employment opportunities in formal-sector jobs (particularly in the export-oriented manufacturing and services sector). Still, improvements in agricultural procurement practices and greater supply-chain efficiency will make rural India more resilient to weather shocks. A stronger agricultural sector will also temper the movement of Indians from rural to urban areas and the urban population will overtake the rural one only by the middle of this century.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
India will remain vulnerable to climate change and adverse changes in monsoon patterns could severely affect its agricultural sector, which remains highly rain-dependent. More generally, water scarcity will become a challenge. The government has taken steps to manage the effects of climate change, and increasingly more attention will be given to this issue. However, given the scale of environmental challenges India faces, policy measures are unlikely to reduce the country's vulnerability to climate change significantly.
India is already the world's third-largest consumer of energy, and demand will continue to grow over the forecast period. In order to add to its energy capacity as well as meet its commitments under the Paris climate accord, the government is making efforts to diversify from conventional sources of energy, such as coal-fired thermal power stations. India is one of the most active members of the International Solar Alliance (ISA), which promotes the transition to solar energy, and the ISA has established its headquarters in Gurgaon. The ISA aims to raise US$1trn in financing and install 1,000 GW of solar capacity across its 121 member states by 2030. India is likely to utilise the platform provided by the ISA to leverage funding and assistance from developed nations and multilateral agencies to develop its own solar sector.
The country has also been making strides in developing wind energy. The National Institute for Wind Energy has estimated India's wind power potential at 302 GW, with the states of Tamil Nadu, Gujarat, Karnataka, Maharashtra and Rajasthan having the greatest potential. Serious efforts in this regard have started; India's installed capacity in wind energy is now the world's fourth largest.
According to the National Institution for Transforming India (NITI Aayog, the government's policy think-tank), around 304m people in India lived without electricity in 2017. Consequently, even as renewable sources of energy will make advances, the significant gap between supply and demand in energy will mean that coal-fired thermal power plants remain critical to India's energy mix.
Migration and urbanisation
India will continue to see an influx of immigrants to urban areas, as workers move to cities in search of better-paying employment. Increasingly, public policy, which has long been rural-oriented, will tilt more towards resolving overcrowding, poor housing conditions, anaemic infrastructure and rising unsustainability in urban centres. However, the enormous scale of these challenges and limited government effectiveness will temper the pace of progress in major cities.
The biggest challenge for policymakers will be skilling and training the workforce of rural immigrants, as they will largely move from the low-skilled agricultural sector and will be less proficient in the expertise required for productive employability in services and industry.
Meanwhile, emigration to Western countries, particularly the US and Canada, as well as to the prosperous states of the Gulf, like the UAE, will remain strong. Consequently, India will remain one of the largest recipients of remittances in the coming years.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Domestic data
GDP: Central Statistics Office; all national-accounts data are for fiscal years beginning April 1st of year shown
Population: IMF, IFS
Public finance: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by the GOI's annual budget papers
Oil production: Oil & Gas Journal; Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas
Inflation, exchange rates and money supply: IMF, IFS; Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE; RBI, WSS
Yield on 91-day Treasury bills: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE
Short-term benchmark interest rate: World Bank, India CEM; IDBI prime lending rate
Direction of trade: GOI, Economic Survey (annual)
Composition of trade and the current account: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE or RBI, Annual Report
Foreign direct investment (FDI): IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; includes reinvested profits
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Abbreviations

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing Independent Greeks (AE)-has a two-seat majority in the 300-seat parliament. The government is vulnerable to further defections and there is a significant risk of an early election (it is not due until October 2019). The centre-right New Democracy (ND) is likely to win the most seats and form a coalition government.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Greece to remain subject to strict policy conditionality over the medium term and until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests over labour market reforms, pension cuts, privatisation, and tax and social security increases are likely to continue as the government strives to meet the ambitious annual primary surplus budget target of 3.5% of GDP until 2022, as agreed with Greece's euro zone creditors.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge after it exits the bail-out programme, in August 2018. How the economy performs during the transition will determine whether Greece will remain in the euro zone. We assess the risk of it leaving the zone by 2022 at more than 50%, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. We expect that public debt will still exceed 170% of GDP in 2022.
Greece does not face short-term financing difficulties as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments for almost two years after it exits the bail-out programme this month. However, the challenges posed by the very high public debt burden and a poor growth outlook mean that Grexit will remain a significant risk in the medium and long term.
We forecast that annual average inflation will edge down from 1.1% in 2017 to 0.7% in 2018, before accelerating to an annual average of 1.5% in 2019-22, reflecting higher oil prices and a pick-up in domestic demand. These trends will result in widening, but still moderate, current-account deficits in 2018-22.

Greece's score recovers modestly in our 2018-22 forecast period, from a low base. The main areas of improvement are expected in the macroeconomic environment and as a result of efforts to improve policy towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition, and the labour market.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The country's privatisation agency, under new management, gains momentum. Deals start to make progress.
2020-22: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make little progress.
2020-22: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eased gradually. The risk of Greece leaving the euro area and reintroducing exchange controls and, possibly, restrictions on trade will remain high after exit from the European Stability Mechanism.
2020-22: There is a 60% risk of Greece leaving the euro zone if growth continues to disappoint.
Taxes
2018-19: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2020-22: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up. Independence of the tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2018-19: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Steps to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) painfully slow, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2020-22: Lending hampered by need to make provisions for still high NPL portfolios. Greece's main banks sell more of their overseas subsidiaries. Some form of normalcy in sight towards the end of this period.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2020-22: EU-funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2020-22: Despite technical assistance from the EU, problems with absorption persist.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2020-22: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

a Actual.
Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule, Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of EMU in question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters have blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism programme. In 2012 public debt held by the private sector was restructured. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. After Greece exits the programme when it expires in August 2018, the country will be subject to much closer scrutiny by its creditors than other EU member states have been after they exited their programmes.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 29% and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR27.9bn (US$31.5bn) and imports (fob) amounted to EUR46.3bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR1.4bn, equivalent to 0.8% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The coalition government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, and the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE)-has survived since September 2015, despite having only a slim majority in the 300-seat parliament. Following the defection of two members of the AE, in protest at the agreement on the 27-year Macedonia name dispute, the government's majority has been reduced to just two seats. Mr Tsipras will aim to see through his parliamentary term, which ends in October 2019, but there is a significant risk of a pre-term election.
The government has been badly damaged by the authorities' handling of the emergency caused by wildfires in the Attica region in July, which resulted in the deaths of more than 90 people. The alternate minister for civil protection, Nikos Toskas, resigned on August 3rd, but the electorate will hold the entire government to account for the death toll from the disaster. Coming in the wake of more than 20 deaths caused by flash floods west of Athens in November 2017, the wildfires tragedy has heightened public anger over the shortcomings of government and public administration. As a consequence, the government is likely to be punished at the next election.
In August 2015, for the third time since 2010, the government tied its acceptance of bail-out reforms under a European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme to the objective of receiving debt relief from its official creditors. (The ESM is an inter-governmental assistance fund for countries in the euro zone.) Almost three years later, the government is on the verge of exiting the programme with minimal debt relief, and has lost much popular support along the way. Mr Tsipras aims to revive his party's political fortunes once Greece exits the programme, and will be hoping that economic growth gains momentum over the coming year.
Tensions within the government coalition will persist, including over the continued implementation of austerity measures and the Macedonia name issue. The AE has said that it will oppose the name agreement when it is brought before parliament and the senior ruling party may struggle to obtain the required majority.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Syriza trails in opinion polls behind the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis; the gap has been above 10 percentage points for some time. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the government, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as The Economist Intelligence Unit expects, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
On June 12th Mr Tsipras and Zoran Zaev, the prime minister of Macedonia (the official name of which is the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia; the constitutional name is the Republic of Macedonia), announced their agreement to change that country's constitutional name to Severna Makedonija (North Macedonia). The two leaders attended a ceremony on June 17th in the Prespes district of northern Greece, at which their respective foreign ministers, Nikos Kotzias and Nikola Dimitrov, signed an agreement on the change. The breakthrough is only the first step towards a resolution of the name dispute, and-given public opposition in both countries-the agreement may fail to come into effect. Macedonia's parliament has approved the agreement, which will be put to a referendum on September 30th, before being presented in the Greek parliament early next year.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey have risen recently. The risk of military confrontation is high, particularly in the Aegean Sea, but both sides will seek to avoid clashes. Points of contention-such as historical territorial disputes in the Aegean, the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey, and the arrest in March 2018 by Turkish police of two Greek soldiers on patrol in the border area of Evros for alleged espionage-continue to fuel distrust.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
On August 20th Greece will emerge from an eight-year period (2010-18) during which it has received a total of EUR274bn (US$323bn) in official financial support from European creditors and the IMF (EUR32.1bn from the latter) and has been subject to three economic adjustment programmes. Repaying the country's outstanding public debt, which totalled EUR344bn (about 180% of GDP) at the end of March, means that future Greek governments will be subject to huge policy constraints. Fiscal austerity and policy conditionality will remain in place for the next five years and beyond.
At the June 21st meeting of the Eurogroup, Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released on August 6th. Of this, EUR3.3bn will be used to pay down the more expensive IMF debt, and the balance will form part of a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR24.1bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
The Eurogroup meeting agreed to further debt relief for Greece, which was granted a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). It will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for loans of EUR130.9bn) and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets relating to official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries-estimated at around EUR5bn.
Greece, in return, has committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses of 3.5% of GDP in the 2018-22 forecast period and 2.2% of GDP thereafter, until 2060. It will also be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. The debt-relief measures will be subject to quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments. As these reviews will be published, transgression by Greece would adversely affect market access.
After a three-year absence, Greece has returned to the financial markets three times since July 2017. However, after August it will do so without the backstop of an official credit line. Global financial volatility delayed the issuance of a seven-year bond in February, highlighting the kind of difficulties that the country could face in future. Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs in the short term, through to early 2020. However, in the medium and long term, the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past two years, Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, alongside other negative factors, such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short-term risk, but, given that Greece is highly unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or grow its way out of its huge debt burden, it will pose a significant risk in the medium and long term.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In 2017 the budget surplus was equivalent to 0.8% of GDP and the primary surplus (budget balance minus interest payments) exceeded the bail-out programme target of 1.75% of GDP, coming in at 4% of GDP. We expect a minimal budget deficit in 2018 (0.3% of GDP), but we do not expect Greece to meet its annual primary surplus target of 3.5% of GDP this year, or in 2019-22. We forecast that the deficit will widen gradually during this period, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint and only modest economic growth.
The restructuring of government debt to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-17 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt, which rose to EUR317.4bn, or 179.1% of GDP, in 2017. Government debt is now almost entirely owed to official creditors. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will remain above 170% in 2018-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017 and is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The ECB's view of the outlook improved during 2017 and, although economic activity in the euro zone softened in early 2018, the bank is now more upbeat. We expect monthly asset purchases under the QE programme to conclude at the end of 2018. Rising commodity prices and evidence of growing domestic price pressure in some parts of the zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge in 2019-20. We expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate, to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than one-quarter, government consumption by almost one-quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments, as shown by a marked slowdown in activity in quarterly terms in the second half of last year. We forecast that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.3% in 2017 to average 1.9% per year in 2018-22. The risks to our forecast are balanced. Upside risks include a continued strong tourism performance. Downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
Seasonally and calendar day-adjusted real GDP expanded by 0.8% quarter on quarter and by 2.3% year on year in January-March. Some high-frequency data-notably for tourism-are showing signs of strength, and sentiment has improved, especially in the services sector. We have therefore revised up our 2018 real GDP growth forecast to 2%, from 1.8%. Nevertheless, this remains a disappointing rate of expansion in the context of the slump of the past decade. Moreover, the recent wildfires may damage the tourism sector, and external developments (notably the threat of a global trade war) are a cause for concern. We expect a combination of more and higher taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2018-22, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP per year, continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
A welcome development in 2017 was a sharp acceleration in fixed investment growth, albeit from a low base. We expect the momentum to continue in 2018 and beyond, with fixed investment growth averaging 5% per year in 2018-22. However, underinvestment during the crisis, and the depletion of Greece's capital stock, as well as uncertainty about the country's euro zone membership, are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. Over the medium term, we expect tourism to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 5.2% in 2018-22.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge after it exits the bail-out programme. How the economy performs over the next five years and beyond will determine whether the country will remain in the euro zone. We assess the risk of Greece leaving the zone by 2022 as above 50%, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets, and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Grexit would lead to a sovereign default and a severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then grow rapidly, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the need to achieve a primary surplus. Growth rates under this scenario would be faster than those in our medium-term forecast. We have not incorporated Grexit into our forecast numbers.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
After stagnating in 2016, Greece's seasonally adjusted EU harmonised index of consumer prices rose by 1.1% year on year in 2017, driven by higher global energy prices, notably in the fourth quarter. Inflation dipped sharply at the start of 2018, rising by just 0.3% year on year in the first quarter, before accelerating to 0.7% in the second. Economic growth is picking up, but significant slack remains in the labour market and domestic demand is subdued. Despite rising global commodity prices and increased tourism, we expect annual inflation to edge down this year, to an average of 0.7%. We forecast a pick-up to inflation of 1.5% per year on average in 2019-22 as the pace of growth quickens.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The euro exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the start of February but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and remained close to that level in June, July and early August. The euro could come under further pressure from political risk in Italy, and also from US monetary tightening. Nonetheless, we expect a broad stabilisation, with an average exchange rate of US$1.20:EUR1 in 2018-21, as the euro is supported by ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large regional current-account surplus, while the business-cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the dollar in 2020. Thereafter, we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Greece's current-account deficit has narrowed since the start of the crisis. This mainly reflects the compression of imports owing to contracting domestic demand, but is also partly the result of improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. The current-account deficit narrowed to 0.8% of GDP in 2017, from 1.1% of GDP in 2016, according to the Bank of Greece (the central bank). We forecast widening deficits in 2018-22 as import prices rise and import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, but these will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.2% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Country Forecast Turkey August 2018 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-turkey-august-2018-updater/docview/2089004876/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. The state of emergency was introduced after the failed coup attempt to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. Since 2016 the state of emergency had allowed the government to continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, to curtail freedoms of expression, assembly and association, and to politicise the judiciary. Turkey's involvement in the conflict in Syria will continue to influence the direction of its foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between them is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where they are co-operating but have been pursuing contrasting goals. [...]the central government deficit, which captures most of the public-sector expenses, expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to 1.5% in 2017.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
On June 24th Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in snap presidential and parliamentary elections, in which his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a coalition majority in parliament with the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP).
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to remain in power throughout the forecast period (2018-22), and possibly beyond.
Following the June elections, an executive presidency now replaces the former parliamentary system of government. The new system will provide few checks on the president's powers, raising the risk of discretionary policymaking.
Since the failed coup in 2016, there has been a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a complete rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high.
Turkey's relationship with the US will deteriorate in 2018-22, owing to bilateral tensions that appear hard to resolve. The possible US imposition of sanctions on Turkish banks for evading US Iran-related sanctions is a risk.
Turkey's relationship with the EU will become increasingly transactional. Turkey will not make progress with accession talks and is unlikely to manage to renegotiate the terms of its customs union with the EU.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign-policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth from 7.3% in 2017 to about 4.2% per year in 2018-22, reflecting higher taxes, higher interest rates, a gradual tightening of global liquidity and more moderate export growth.
The lira will depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar throughout our forecast period, to almost TL5:US$1 at end-2022, as a result of negative foreign investor sentiment, high inflation and a large current-account deficit.
We expect the current-account deficit to widen in 2018, to 6.7% of GDP, before contracting to a still large 4.8% per year on average in 2019-22. Turkey will struggle to meet its high external financing needs throughout our forecast period.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but in the global rankings the country falls by ten places, to 59th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, are introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2018-19: Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey not to raise interest rates significantly remains possible. The US could impose fines on several Turkish banks over alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran.
2020-22: Banking system remains stable, despite weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress on other projects.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2020-22: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then, Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe (in 1949) and NATO (in 1952), and signed an association agreement with the then European Community (in 1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election, a presidential system of government is being introduced and the post of prime minister has been abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted institutional weaknesses that, with the AKP's consent until 2013, had allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports came to US$166bn and imports to US$225bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn and a current account deficit of US$47bn (or 5.6% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".
