Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
In June Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day, Mr Erdogan's conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Both votes took place well ahead of the originally scheduled date of November 2019, as the president sought to take advantage of his current popularity. The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair. Opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the candidate of the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP), Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison; and the government restrains freedom of speech and freedom of association. However, the outcome of the elections appeared clear; Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote on a high turnout. In addition, results published by opposition observers almost mirrored those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system will grant the president wide-ranging executive powers-including in the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, will remain in power until 2023, and possibly beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to clamp down on domestic political dissent and opposition. Despite lifting the state of emergency when it expired on July 18th, the government is considering adopting stringent impediments on freedoms that would resemble those imposed as part of its terms. The state of emergency was introduced after the failed coup attempt to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. Since 2016 the state of emergency had allowed the government to continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, to curtail freedoms of expression, assembly and association, and to politicise the judiciary.
The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup appear to have eased, but security risk remains high. Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK are interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria seek to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK, but risk fuelling the conflict with the PKK in Turkey's south-east. The formation of a governing coalition between the AKP and the MHP will have a detrimental effect on attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the MHP is likely to push for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP. In addition, the MHP will advocate repatriation of Syrian refugees and adopt a tough stance on all issues related to national security, in line with Mr Erdogan's ultra-nationalist and conservative views.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held on June 24th, earlier than the originally scheduled date of late 2019. The elections were brought forward for several reasons: high and growing economic uncertainties; the continued high popularity of Mr Erdogan and the AKP; and the rise in nationalist sentiment in the context of Turkey's military operations in northern Syria.
Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote on a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election, the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP) because the HDP polled above 10% of the vote-the threshold needed to enter parliament-despite Mr Erdogan's repeated attempts to weaken it. The AKP received 42.6% of the vote; the MHP got 11.1%; the Republican People's Party (CHP) 22.6%; the HDP 11.7%; and the Good Party (IP) 10%.
Local elections will be held as planned in March 2019, despite recent signals from the AKP that point to an increasing possibility of bringing them forward to November or December. The AKP-MHP coalition would have an interest in holding these elections early, while the economic situation remains favourable. However, the coalition would struggle to pass the necessary constitutional amendment in parliament. The shift of focus to the local polls in the aftermath of the June elections is a sign that Turkey will remain in election mood until next year. Mr Erdogan and the AKP will therefore refrain from any decisions that could jeopardise the AKP's success in the local elections.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Although not our core forecast, there is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; tensions over gas exploration in the eastern Mediterranean; Turkey's forging of closer relations with countries such as China, Russia and Iran; and, more recently, growing tensions with Israel in the aftermath of the US government's decision to relocate its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. Turkey's confrontational approach to its Western allies should be viewed partly in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of his country's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals-notably, to implement an executive presidential system now that he has been re-elected as president.
The country's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and increasingly transactional rather than strategic, but we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a complete breakdown in relations. However, this might become unavoidable if the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, if the migrant deal with the EU collapses, if the US imposes sanctions on Turkey over violations by Turkish banks of US sanctions against Iran, or if Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces or withdraws from NATO, none of which can be ruled out. Operation Olive Branch, Turkey's crossborder military operation in Afrin in north-western Syria, which was launched in January 2018, has accentuated tensions with the US.
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in Syria will continue to influence the direction of its foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between them is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where they are co-operating but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector, and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, an intensification of domestic political instability, rising regional tensions and tightening global liquidity conditions could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the 2018-22 forecast period.
These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements (savings have always been low), but tend to be short-term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows, triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region, have put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, most recently in May-July 2018, fuelling a sharp acceleration in inflation as well as increasing the cost to firms of servicing their foreign debt (in local-currency terms) and thereby raising the risk of defaults for corporates.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards fiscal loosening and relatively tight, but not tightening, monetary policy.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-have given the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy in the aftermath of the July 2016 attempted coup. As a result, the central government deficit, which captures most of the public-sector expenses, expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to 1.5% in 2017.
Despite a series of tax increases this year, increased government spending on defence, security, infrastructure projects, public employment and social benefits will cause the deficit to widen further, to an annual average of 3% of GDP in 2018-19, before narrowing gradually to 1.8% in 2022. We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to decline gradually, from 28.3% of GDP at end-2017 to 26.4% in 2022. Our baseline forecast is predicated on the assumption that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The Central Bank of Turkey will have to keep its monetary policy tight in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira against the US dollar amid political volatility, higher US interest rates and balance-sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). A 300-basis-point rise in the late liquidity window lending rate on May 23rd and a further 100-basis point rise (to 17.75%) in the key lending rate on June 7th had indicated that economic orthodoxy was beginning to overcome political pressures not to raise interest rates. However, on July 24th the central bank decided not to increase rates further, despite record high inflation and the sharp depreciation of the lira against the dollar in May-July. This suggests that persistent political pressure will ensure that the central bank has only limited room for manoeuvre during the rest of the year to tighten monetary policy. This may be the result of government concerns about a likely deceleration of real GDP growth in the second half of the year.
We therefore believe that the central bank will not be able to raise rates to levels that would be credible in terms of bringing inflation down to its (highly unrealistic) 5% target in the medium term. Amid a context of increasing regional tensions, tightening global liquidity conditions and rising inflation in the short term, the central bank is likely to be unable to maintain investor confidence if financial conditions deteriorate, possibly prompting the imposition of capital controls; however, this is not our baseline scenario.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. In 2018 we expect growth to slow to 4%. This deceleration reflects the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates, a gradual tightening of global liquidity (feeding into a depreciation of the lira), increased domestic instability and higher inflation, all of which will offset planned stimulus measures to boost employment and investment. There are considerable downside risks to our forecast, stemming from foreign capital inflows being deterred by further political instability in the transition to a presidential system of government, regional tensions, domestic financial fragilities and the higher interest-rate environment in advanced economies. We forecast that real GDP growth will average 4.3% per year in 2019-22.
We expect household consumption growth to moderate from 6% of GDP in 2017 to a still solid 3.7% per year in 2018-22 as a result of higher interest rates and slower employment growth. We expect government consumption growth to accelerate from 5.1% in 2017 to an annual average of 5.8% in 2018-19, easing to a more moderate but still robust average of 4.8% in 2020-22.
The deterioration in the business environment and the reduction in foreign investors' confidence since the attempted coup in 2016, and an increase in the corporation tax rate to 22% from 2018 will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration in yearly investment growth, reflecting public-sector retrenchment and firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
The lifting in June 2017 of Russian sanctions on Turkey (notably in the tourism sector), the positive effect on export competitiveness of the lira's depreciation against the US dollar, and strong external demand have contributed to a rebound in exports of goods and services. However, we expect export growth to slow in 2018-22, owing to global trade tensions following the US decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminium imports. We expect a nominal depreciation of the lira against the US dollar and the euro during the forecast period; this will dampen import growth but support external competitiveness.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation is stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target, at 15.6% year on year in June. Reflecting the political constraints on the ability of the central bank to tighten monetary policy further, the recent depreciation of the lira against the US dollar and rising global commodity prices, we forecast that inflation will average 12.7% this year. We expect inflation to decline gradually during the forecast period, reaching 8.1% at end-2022. There are significant upside risks to our revised forecast if the lira depreciates much more rapidly than we currently forecast.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The lira lost 17% of its value against the US dollar in 2017. In 2018 we expect a further depreciation of 17%, owing to high levels of political uncertainty and decreasing confidence on the part of foreign investors. This pace of depreciation assumes a relatively benign political environment, a mild shift towards a more conservative economic stance, a gradual tightening of global monetary conditions and relatively tight domestic monetary conditions. Shocks to any of these assumptions, such as the broad global sell-off in emerging-market assets in April-July 2018 after a faster pick-up in nominal yields in the US, would lead to a more abrupt depreciation. In 2019-22 we expect the pace of depreciation against both the US dollar and the euro to slow in nominal terms. This will result in a mild appreciation in real terms after six consecutive years of real effective depreciations.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Owing to particularly large trade deficits at the end of 2017 and in early 2018, the depreciation of the lira against the euro and the US dollar, and rising global commodity prices, we expect the current-account deficit to widen from 5.6% of GDP in 2017 to 6.7% of GDP this year. However, moderating capital inflows will keep the lira weak and interest rates relatively high, contributing to a slowdown in import demand and a consequent narrowing of the current-account deficit during the forecast period. Turkey's substantial external financing needs will be difficult to meet if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates further. We expect the rebound in tourist arrivals in 2017 to continue, but the sector will remain vulnerable to a possible resurgence of terrorist attacks.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The ruling centre-right Cambiemos coalition is under increasing political pressure amid recent currency volatility and an IMF bailout (the Fund is unpopular in Argentina), but will be hoping to get its policy agenda back on track in time for the presidential election in October 2019, when Mauricio Macri will seek a second term. However, the opposition will increasingly obstruct policy. Cambiemos lacks a congressional majority, meaning that the administration has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda on an ad hoc basis with various factions of Argentina's dominant Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party).
Currency depreciation pressure amid an emerging-market sell-off has introduced substantial political uncertainty, but major changes to economic policymaking are not envisaged under the terms of the IMF lending arrangement, other than a more rapid tightening of fiscal policy. The US$50bn stand-by arrangement, approved on June 20th, includes targets for a tightening of fiscal policy to produce a primary fiscal balance by 2020 (in order to contain growth in the public debt/GDP ratio and reduce inflationary deficit financing), and provisions for central-bank target independence to be enshrined in law, to help to tackle the inflation problem (the root of Argentina's external competitiveness problem, which is in turn driving devaluation pressures). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that programme targets will be met, and will gradually reduce inflation and engender macro-economic stability over time.
A spike in interest rates and a tightening of fiscal policy amid currency pressures will weigh on economic activity; we have revised our forecast for real GDP growth in 2018 and now expect a full-year contraction of 0.3%. For now, our view of medium-term GDP growth remains broadly unchanged, although the risks to our forecasts have risen substantially. Under our benign baseline forecast, we expect growth to average 3.3% in 2020-22.
More front-loaded currency weakening than previously projected will provide some boost to external competitiveness, but even so, the current-account deficit will remain large in 2018, and import cover will dip from 7.6 months to around seven months this year. Thereafter, we expect the current-account deficit to narrow steadily, to below 3% of GDP in 2022.
Argentina's GDP per head is among the highest in the region and, combined with improved access to credit, moderate rates of economic growth in the medium term will boost purchasing power and create market opportunities. Still-high poverty rates and income inequality will restrict the pool of consumers, but to a lesser extent than in many other countries in the region.

Argentina's global business environment score improves in 2018-22, and the country jumps 12 places in the global ranking. Policy adjustment is underway as the government works to tighten macro-economic policy, reduce state intervention in the private sector and encourage private investment. But in many areas improvements will take time to materialise.
Country forecast overview: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2020-22: Continued work to build faith in legal and regulatory frameworks. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2018-19: Proactive, welcoming approach to foreign investment. Attempts to resolve outstanding disputes with creditors.
2020-22: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance, comprising Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.
2020-22: Possibility that new free-trade agreements are signed with the EU and Canada.
Taxes
2018-19: Further gradual reductions of export taxes to encourage domestic supply. Tax reforms to promote investment and reduce tax pressure.
2020-22: Comprehensive tax reform to improve federal-provincial revenue sharing a possibility, but obstacles to reform persist. System remains complex, despite recent reforms.
Financing
2018-19: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2020-22: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2018-19: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of unions remains strong.
2020-22: Limited progress on labour reform. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2018-19: The Macri administration continues to improve contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes.
2020-22: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Quality of e-commerce business environment is good. Upgrade of 4G capabilities.
2020-22: More progress on increasing scope of e-government as part of process to reduce red tape. Increase in research and development spending as percentage of GDP, but still relatively low compared with more developed markets.

Background: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983, after 50 years of instability and military regimes. Economic liberalisation in the 1990s drove firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and fail-ure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of Fernando de la Rúa's centre-left government. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party) began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanage-ment drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015.
Political structure: A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house); in practice, however, the presidency dominates. The presidential term is four years. There are 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district, each with its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies and the commodity supercycle contributed to GDP growth of an annual average 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to controls and ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. These policies did not reduce devaluation speculation and left the economy extremely vulnerable to currency crisis. Macroeconomic adjustments to try to reduce economic distortions are taking place under Mr Macri; these include the shift to a free float at the end of 2015, fiscal and monetary tightening, and reforms to boost domestic supply, but the pace of adjustment has been insufficient to prevent severe currency pressure, and in mid-2018 the government was forced to turn to the IMF for a stand-by lending arrangement involving tighter fiscal targets.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at a lower rate of 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. Under a tax reform approved at end-2017, the corporate income tax rate will fall to 30% in 2019 and 25% in 2021. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions (deposits and withdrawals).
Foreign trade: The current account moved from surplus to deficit in 2010. By 2017 the deficit had widened to 4.9% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
An economic downturn induced by a combination of severe drought and a collapse in confidence amid strong currency pressures earlier this year will weigh on the position of the president, Mauricio Macri. Argentina was hit hard by an emerging-market sell-off in May, and although turbulence in the foreign-exchange market has subsided since July with the announce-ment of a US$50bn IMF stand-by lending arrangement, recent developments could have lasting political consequences for the government. The Fund is supportive of Argentina, and The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect dramatic changes in the direction of economic policy, which is already geared towards macro-economic and microeconomic reforms to restore stability and promote more solid, stable economic growth (although the pace of macroeconomic policy adjustment will be faster). The problem for the president, Mauricio Macri, and his ruling centre-right Cambiemos coalition, is that the Fund has a very poor reputation in Argentina, reflecting its role before and after the country's deep economic crisis of 2001-02. Argentina's return to the Fund amid a fresh economic downturn will weigh on the government's approval ratings with little more than a year to go until the presidential election in October 2019.
The government will be hoping to get its policy agenda back on track in time for the election, when Mr Macri will seek a second term, but this will be challenging. Cambiemos lacks a congressional majority and has to negotiate legislative support on an ad hoc basis with various factions of the Partido Justicialista (PJ, the Peronist party). The PJ, which dominated politics for decades before Mr Macri's victory in 2015, is struggling to regroup from that defeat and is beset by internal divisions. The party is currently split between a left-wing, populist faction led by the former president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15), and a centrist faction that as yet has no clear leader. So far, the PJ's divisions have worked in the government's favour, helping it to pursue its legislative agenda with the support of moderate Peronists.
But the political environment is changing, amid a renewed economic downturn and as the opposition begins manoeuvring for position ahead of the 2019 presidential election, and the government will struggle to push its agenda through before the election takes place. In the aftermath of its strong performance in the October 2017 mid-terms, the government moved quickly to pass reforms to the tax system, pensions and competition policy (in May it managed to pass capital market reforms). But in coming months, major reforms will be on hold, and opposition challenges to policy initiatives that are presented will increase. All this means that much-needed reforms to increase the flexibility of labour markets, improve the effective-ness of the judiciary, and enhance investor confidence in institutions and contract rights will be on the back burner. On our current assumption that Mr Macri wins a second term in 2019, we expect that improvements in these areas will start to yield results more clearly late on in our five-year forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The next presidential election is due in October 2019. Notwithstanding Mr Macri's current difficulties, we continue to assume that he will win a second four-year term, based on our assumption of a recovery in GDP and a substantial reduction of inflation by then. There are large, and growing, risks to this forecast. Reflecting the difficulties faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist party has been able to complete two consecutive terms in office since the 1920s. The emergence of a strong challenger from the Peronist party is therefore likely (although it is as yet unclear who this will be), and the election will be closely fought. The strongest Peronist challenge seems most likely to come from its moderate, pragmatist wing, given recent corruption allegations surrounding Ms Fernández and high-ranking officials in her govern-ment, who dominate the left-wing populist branch of the party. This may actually work against Mr Macri as, in a second-round vote, he would face a stiffer contest from a moderate pragmatist than from the populist wing of the party, which retains a loyal base of supporters but also has high rejection rates among the wider population.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
We expect relations with key international partners to remain strong under the Macri administration, which has worked hard to restore Argentina's international image since it came to office in 2015. The government is keen to seek trade deals under the auspices of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union).However, although Mercosur has reversed its protectionist tendencies, anti-globalisation sentiment has grown in the OECD. Mr Macri is continuing to seek support for an EU-Mercosur trade deal from his counterparts in Europe, and negotiations are continuing, although they are slow moving. In the meantime, Mercosur members including Argentina have pushed for free-trade negotiations elsewhere, including with Canada and China, and for closer relations with the Pacific Alliance, a free-trade area covering Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico. However, the window of opportunity for agreeing trade deals may be closing, depending on the results of Brazil's presidential election in October and with Argentina's own presidential election approaching next year.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Tighter financing conditions amid concerns over the large twin fiscal and current-account deficits, a spike in inflation following recent severe currency depreciation pressures, and a steep fall in economic activity amid weak confidence and severe drought have introduced substantial political uncertainty. However, major changes to economic policymaking are not envisaged under the terms of the three-year, US$50bn IMF stand-by arrangement (SBA), other than a more rapid tightening of fiscal policy. The govern-ment has made progress since it came to office at the end of 2015 and began grappling with the task of restoring macroeconomic stability while improving conditions for business. But macroeconomic adjustment is clearly incomplete, with inflation and the federal government deficit both extremely high.
Still-high inflation has contributed to currency overvaluation, which has in turn produced a large and growing current-account deficit. These imbalances contributed to the sharp peso adjustment of April-June, and to the government's decision to seek an IMF lending deal to restore market confidence. The SBA was approved on June 20th and an initial disbursement of US$15bn was released immediately for deficit financing and to help to restore reserves coverage ratios. The deal includes targets for a tightening of fiscal policy to produce a primary fiscal balance by 2020 (in order to contain growth in the public debt/GDP ratio and reduce inflationary deficit financing), and provisions for central-bank target independence to be enshrined in law, to help to tackle the inflation problem (the root of Argentina's external competitiveness problem, which is in turn driving devaluation pressures).
We expect that programme targets will, on the whole, be met, and will gradually reduce inflation and engender macro-economic stability over time. This will have positive implications for the external sector and growth. The biggest risks to this outlook are political, and reflect the possibility that voter (as well as business) confidence in the Macri admin-istration and the economic outlook will feed into further market volatility and a deep recession. This would not only complicate the adjustment process, but also threaten our assumption that Mr Macri will secure a second term in power, raising questions as to the future direction of economic policy under a new government.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In its first two years of office the government pursued gradual fiscal tightening (so as not to thwart economic growth), but, in the face of market pressure, it has now accelerated the pace of adjustment under the auspices of the IMF deal. The fiscal targets set out in the deal were broadly in line with our expectations and allow for a relatively gradual adjustment, partly reflecting provisions that allow for increased social safety net expenditure. For 2018 the primary federal government deficit target is 2.7% of GDP, for 2019 it is 1.3% of GDP, and for 2020 the government is targeting primary fiscal balance. Our own forecasts assume that these targets will be met, except in 2019, when we expect an additional 0.2 percentage points in spending under provisions of the IMF deal allowing for increased social safety net spending in the event of a rise in the poverty rate.
Bearing in mind that the government beat its fiscal target in the first half of 2018 by a substantial margin, the 2018 target should be achievable, although it will require cuts to planned capital spending, which will have a knock-on impact on economic growth. Apart from capital spending, primary spending restraint this year and in the rest of the forecast period will come via a phasing out of costly energy subsidies and the recent approval of a social security reform that will produce substantial savings (0.4% of GDP per year from 2018). The biggest risks to meeting the fiscal target centre on the government's ability to maintain public-sector wage restraint amid above-target inflation and strong public-sector union power, as well as below-target revenue, reflecting a sharp deceleration of economic activity this year.
The government is-for now at least-facing a problem with liquidity rather than solvency. We assume that, despite this liquidity problem, deficit financing will not prove problematic, owing to the IMF deal, and also assuming that market access improves from around 2019. That said, the public debt/GDP ratio is likely to continue to rise in 2018 to well over 60% of GDP, before stabilising in the remainder of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Having tightened monetary policy sharply to help to stem currency pressures, the Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the central bank) will unwind its rate rises only very slowly. Further currency depreciation is possible in the short term, and further rate rises remain a risk, but for now we expect rates to stay on hold, at 40%. Tight monetary policy is having an impact, as is evident in the sharp deceleration of growth in the monetary aggregates (which the bank has recently begun monitoring more closely as a complement to the policy rate), and we expect the central bank to begin to unwind its dramatic rate rise over the next few months. This process will be complicated, however, by weak confidence in the nascent inflation-targeting regime, which means that inflation expectations are not well anchored and pass-through from currency depreciation into consumer prices is high. We do still expect monthly inflation to start to ease late in 2018, once the effects of currency depreciation and tariff adjustment start to fade. This should allow for gradual monetary easing, beginning in the fourth quarter and continuing for an extended period thereafter, providing for moderately positive real interest rates in the medium term.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Reflecting data for May-June, which show that a steep decline in agriculture production amid a severe drought has given way to a more broad-based contraction in output, we have made a further downward revision to our GDP forecast for 2018, and now expect a technical recession to result in a contraction in full-year growth of 0.3% in 2018. This forecast represents a dramatic change from the start of the year, when market expectations were for growth of over 3%, and demonstrates that Argentina's economic output is not yet sufficiently diversified to withstand the impact of drought on the important agricultural sector (agriculture accounts for a fairly hefty 11% of GDP, and agro-industry is also important to the economy). But on top of drought, output is being hit by tighter macroeconomic policy and the jolt to confidence following currency turmoil and the IMF bail-out.
Our forecasts currently assume that activity will fall in seasonally adjusted sequential terms in both the second and third quarter, before a recovery gathers steam in the fourth quarter. Assuming that a return to normal harvest levels next year, (as well as a restoration of confidence as disinflation begins), we expect GDP growth to reach 2.2% in 2019. For both 2018 and 2019 there is an unusually high degree of uncertainty attached to our forecasts. There is, on the one hand, a not-insubstantial risk that policy tightening on top of drought could tip Argentina into a deeper recession. But, on the other hand, activity could rebound slightly more quickly than we currently have pencilled into our forecasts if real currency adjustment proves a more rapid-than-expected spur to export manufacturing activity.
For now our forecasts for the second part of the forecast period (2020-22) are unchanged, although the risks to these forecasts have risen substantially. Under our benign baseline forecast, we expect growth to average 3.3% in 2020-22, coming in below 3% in 2020 amid moderately weaker growth in the US and China in those years, before accelerating above 3% in 2021-22. This projected acceleration in 2021-22 rests on the assumption that that implementation of recently passed and ongoing structural reforms will gradually boost economic activity. There is increasing downside risk to this assumption, in the form of a weakening of consumer and business confidence, and the potential for a much more tense presidential election period in 2019.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
The reduction of inflation will continue to be complicated in the short term by further gradual increases in utilities tariffs as these are brought closer in line with market prices. On top of this, rapid recent peso depreciation, in a context of unanchored inflation expectations, will produce substantial pass-through effects, keeping inflation high in the short term. However, assuming that macroeconomic policy remains tight under the auspices of the IMF deal, domestic demand remains subdued, and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environment for agricultural and other producers, we continue to expect gradual disinflation in the medium term. It will take quite some time, however, for inflation to fall to single-digit levels. According to our baseline forecast, this will not happen until early 2021.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The peso was badly hit in the second quarter of 2018 as investors that had previously given the administration the benefit of the doubt over its ability to reverse macroeconomic imbalances zeroed in on the country's large fiscal and current-account deficits. The latter reflects clear overvaluation of the peso, a problem that worsened last year as huge inflows of portfolio capital produced real currency appreciation. As a result, at end-2017 the real effective exchange rate was 14% stronger than the average of the previous 20 years. Recent currency adjustment will go some way to reversing this trend, assuming that disinflation occurs as expected from late 2018 (so that inflation does not eat away at recent competitiveness gains), although there are substantial risks to this assumption. Under our baseline forecast we expect the peso to continue to depreciate in both nominal and real terms, to address the problem of currency overvaluation, taking the exchange rate to Ps29.85:US$1 at end-2018 and Ps39.9:US$1 at end-2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
More front-loaded currency weakening than previously projected will provide some boost to external competitiveness, but even so, in 2018 the current-account deficit will remain large as a percentage of GDP, with the boost to net exports of goods and services becoming more evident from 2019. Even in 2022 we expect the current-account deficit to remain substantial (although more manageable), at 2.7% of GDP. After a period of huge inflows of portfolio capital in 2016-17, access to finance will be scarcer and more costly in 2018-19; meanwhile, inflows of foreign direct investment will average an unspectacular 2.1% of GDP in 2018-22. This introduces risks to our assumption that import cover will improve gradually over the medium term, although inflows of IMF credit will be supportive of reserves.

Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services

Full text: Chile--highlights: Political outlook
Sebastián Piñera of the centre-right Chile Vamos (CV) coalition won the presidential election in late 2017 and took office in March. However, a change in the electoral process led to a more proportional system that challenged the traditional domination of centre-left and centre-right coalitions; as a result, no coalition currently holds a majority in either house of Congress. This will make policymaking difficult, and means that the legislative agenda will move more slowly and be kept broadly centrist, in order to attract the necessary votes. Government effectiveness will remain the best in the region, owing to competent officials and cross-party support for pro-market policies. The country will rank highly in measures of stability and rule of law.
Chile--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.50 7.77 20 20 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile remains top in Latin America in our business environment ranking in the forecast period. Its strengths include a longstanding, well-functioning market economy, an open foreign investment regime, a strong fiscal position, and deep and sophisticated capital markets. The country will remain at the forefront of regional and Pacific Rim integration efforts, underpinning the free-trade framework. Improvements to education and infrastructure, including renewable energy supply, will come online during the forecast period, further supporting the environment for business.
Chile--highlights: Economic outlook

Annual growth will average 3.2% in 2018-22. Although a marked acceleration from the previous five-year period, this is still relatively tepid compared with Chile's growth rates in the 1990s and during the commodities supercycle. Faster growth owes to a recovery in copper prices and investment, and will be supported by Chile's productive capacity, relatively good infrastructure, and prized political and institutional stability. The current account will remain in deficit, despite a growing trade surplus, owing to higher debt repayments and profit repatriation by multinational firms, but it will remain manageable. Deficits will be financed through capital inflows, particularly foreign direct investment.
Chile--highlights: Demographic outlook
Population (m) 2012 2017 2022
Total 17.3 18.1 18.7

Period averages (%)   2013-17 2018-22
Population growth   0.8 0.7
Working-age population growth   0.9 0.5
Labour force growth   1.5 1.2
At an estimated 18.1m in 2017, Chile's small population is growing at a slower rate than those of most of its neighbours. Population growth has largely followed global trends towards the lower birth rates of more affluent societies. The birth rate has fallen steadily in the past decade or so, from 16.4 per 1,000 people in 2002-07 to 13.9 per 1,000 in 2013-17, and is forecast to slow further, to 13.1 per 1000 in 2018-22. Chile also has an older demographic profile than most regional countries, with those aged 65 and over accounting for over 10% of the total population, and set to rise to 13% by 2022. The labour force is forecast to grow at an annual average of 1.2% in the forecast period. Health indicators are broadly comparable with other OECD economies.

Ample government infrastructure concessions and expansion in the renewables sector will provide opportunities. But Chile's market opportunities are constrained by the country's small population. However, persistently high wages, combined with political stability and effective economic management, will continue to attract investment. Rising household consumption from 2018, bolstered by high employment, real wage gains and low inflation, will lift consumer expenditure. High income inequality will gradually recede.
Chile--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2018-30 2031-50 2018-50

Growth of real GDP per head 2.6 2.1 2.3
Growth of real GDP 3.2 2.4 2.7
Labour productivity growth 2.6 2.7 2.7
Broad consensus in favour of orthodox monetary and fiscal policies will underpin steady long-term economic growth, but this will come under some challenge from new left-wing political parties. Free-trade agreements, both signed within and outside the region, will help Chile to attract foreign investment and further diversify the economy. Average annual GDP growth is forecast to reach 3.2% in 2018-30, moderating to 2.4% in 2031-50. The capital stock will continue to grow and investment will rise to over 25% of GDP. However, as growth in the working-age population slows, so will the increase in labour supply, causing economic growth to become more dependent on productivity gains.

Background: In 1988 the military ruler, Augusto Pinochet, lost a referendum to allow him to stay in office. The centre-left Concertación de Partidos por la Democracia coalition (now Nueva Mayoría-NM) won the December 1989 general election and the next four presidential elections. A realignment of forces helped the centre-right to win the 2010 election. Michelle Bachelet of the NM, who was president in 2006-10, won the 2013 election and took office for a new four-year term in March 2014. A centre-right president, Sebastián Piñera, took office for his second term on March 11th 2018 (his first was in 2010-14).
Political structure: The political system is presidential, with a bicameral legislature that comprises a 43-seat Senate (the upper house) and a 155-seat Chamber of Deputies (the lower house). The presidential term is four years, and consecutive re-election is not permitted. This structure may be subject to change-possibly towards a more prime-ministerial model-as part of ongoing constitutional reform. The judiciary is independent, but the executive exerts some influence through the nomination of temporary judges and the control of promotions to the Supreme Court. Monetary policy is in the hands of the autonomous Banco Central de Chile (the central bank). Chile has 15 regions, 54 provinces and 346 municipalities.
Policy issues: The two major coalitions remain in broad consensus on preserving a liberal market economy and maintaining an orthodox monetary and fiscal policy framework. However, a new left-wing coalition (the third-largest force in Congress) has demanded more social spending. A new proportional electoral system will see issues such as regional devolution and a conflict involving the Mapuche indigenous people rise up the political agenda as politics becomes more fragmented.
Taxation: Corporate income tax is assessed at two stages. Declared profit is subject to a 27% first-category tax (FCIT). When profit is distributed to shareholders or partners, a 35% second-category tax applies, minus a credit for FCIT. Tax rate on dividends and interest payments to non-banks is 35%. Royalties and fees transferred abroad are subject to a 30-35% withholding tax. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at 19%.
Foreign trade: The general import tariff rate is 6%, but the trade-weighted effective average rate is below 2%, owing to preferences granted through trade accords. Exports in 2017 were worth an estimated US$69.2bn; imports stood at US$61.3bn.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Present government: Sebastián Piñera of the centre-right Chile Vamos (CV) coalition, who was previously president in 2010-14, won the December 2017 presidential runoff and took office for a new four-year term on March 11th 2018. CV is chiefly composed of the conservative Unión Demócrata Independiente, and the centre-right Renovación Nacional (Mr Piñera's party), but also includes the smaller Evolución Política (Evópoli). No party holds a majority in either house of Congress following last year's election, but CV holds the largest number of seats in both chambers. The opposition includes the centre-left Nueva Mayoría (NM) coalition, which led the previous government (2014-18), and under a previous configuration, called the Concertación, governed Chile from 1990 to 2010. After the last election, the left-wing Frente Amplio has emerged as the third-largest force in Congress. The centrist Democracia Cristiana (DC) broke from NM in April 2018, and currently forms the fourth-largest bloc in the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and third-largest in the Senate (the upper house). Independent parties, largely leaning centre-left, also form a presence.
CV holds 19 of 43 seats in the Senate and 72 of 155 in the Chamber of Deputies. It will need to rely on votes from other coalitions or dissident members of the opposition to pass legislation. The most likely votes are to come from DC, but support is only likely to come on an ad hoc basis, as DC has ruled out an alliance with CV and declared itself firmly of the left. Nevertheless, the necessity to get opposition parties and coalitions on board will keep policymaking broadly centrist.

Political outlook: Political stability
Since taking office in March Mr Piñera has maintained relatively strong levels of public support, with an approval rating of 52% in June, according to Adimark, a local pollster. The government's agenda has so far moved slowly, but plans for Mr Piñera's four-year term, which will end in 2022, include expected revisions to a 2014 tax reform (although a reduction in corporate tax has been aband-oned in order to fund increases on social spending), as well as reforms to the pension system, which has been the cause of several public protests in recent years.
Reforms are likely to follow a broadly centrist path, as a more right-leaning agenda would face challenges, given a more fractured legislature after the 2017 general election. A change in the election process has led to a more propor-tional system that ends the traditional domination by centre-left and centre-right coalitions; as a result, no coalition presently holds a majority in either the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) or the Senate (the upper house).
The centre-left opposition has been in disarray since last year's electoral defeat, with no clear consensus among the parties on how to approach Mr Piñera's government. Left-wing elements have vowed to oppose the administration, while those in the centre have flirted with being more co-operative. In April this led the centrist DC to split from the centre-left NM to form its own bloc. Votes from DC, which holds 14 of 155 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and six of 43 in the Senate, could help the government to form a majority in both houses of Congress, (CV holds 72 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 19 in the Senate). However, support from DC is likely to come only on an ad hoc basis. As a result, the legislative agenda should move more slowly than in the past, as policy differences between the coalitions will become more apparent after decades of relative policy consensus. The risk of political gridlock will be higher later in Mr Piñera's term, should his popularity or the country's economic performance unexpectedly stumble.
Mr Piñera's planned reform of Chile's outdated immigration system, announced in April, should stem the flow of immigrants (largely from Haiti and Venezuela), and curb rising anti-immigrant sentiment around perceptions of crime and strains on public services; annual flows of immigrants have doubled since 2014. A rise in petty crime (although overall crime rates remain among the region's lowest) will continue to be a cause of concern.
Mr Piñera's platform included a more progressive stance on indigenous rights, including constitutional recognition for the Mapuche (Chile's largest indigenous group), which should gain cross-coalition support. This should help to ease a slow-burning conflict in Chile's southern regions. Social protests will continue, especially concerning education and the pension system, but The Economist Intelligence Unit does not believe that these will reach the same level as in Mr Piñera's last term in office (2010-14), as the government has so far taken a more conciliatory approach.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Chile's system of government is considered the most effective and technically adept in Latin America, thanks in part to a high degree of political stability and a highly professional bureaucracy. This is unlikely to change substantively in the forecast period, but there are several risks to political effectiveness. Corruption in Chile remains low, even compared with OECD standards-it is the 26th least corrupt country in the world, according to the 2017 Corruption Perceptions Index prepared by Transparency International, a global anti-corruption watchdog. Nevertheless, recent years have seen several prominent scandals in both the public and private sectors, which have fuelled a sense of impunity for elites. Still, the scale of wrongdoing is not equivalent to current scandals in other countries in the region, and public prosecutors have so far proved energetic in bringing a number of perpetrators to account.
Moreover, since the peaceful transition to democracy in 1990, successive administrations have operated with a broad consensus around maintaining the open and liberal economic model instituted by the military regime of Augusto Pinochet, while also strengthening democratic institutions. Since 1990 this meant domination by the two centre-left and centre-right coalitions. However, the last election under new electoral rules resulted in a more fractured legislature, returning Chile to its pre-dictatorship political landscapes of coalitions of the right, left and centre. Although this should slow policymaking, it will also have the effect of promoting consensus (in order to pass legislation) and will keep policymaking broadly centrist. Nevertheless, political engagement and turnout remain low, posing a challenge to long-term confidence in the system. Efforts to promote regional government and divest power to the regions (Chile is highly centralised) could also increase the quality of government. Given that no coalition holds a majority (a situation that is likely to continue in future governments) dramatic policy shifts are unlikely. Bills to change organic constitutional provisions require a four-sevenths majority, while bills re-interpreting or modifying the constitution respectively require either a three-fifths or two-thirds majority.
A civil service reform in 2003 helped to increase meritocracy by reducing the amount of political appointees at the head of government agencies and departments by over four-fifths, and making civil servants accountable to an independent directorate. This has also helped to reduce fraudulent use of public funds, which, although relatively minor in comparison with most other countries in the region, had become a problem under some governments. Official transparency and efficiency has also been fostered by the centralisation of the procurement tenders of all government departments and public-sector agencies in a single online platform.
Chile's judicial system is relatively efficient and transparent. The criminal justice system was modernised over a period of six years, following reforms in 1999 that created an office of public prosecutions and established a legal aid service, as well as a new code for penal procedures. Chile ranks highly in most measures of rule of law, protection of private property and overall institutional effectiveness.
Political outlook: Election watch
Presidential and legislative elections were last held in late 2017. The next national elections will be regional and municipal elections in October 2020. The next presidential and legislative elections will take place in late 2021. Although it is too early to say who will win the next presidential election, there has been alternation between the left and right since 2010. Consecutive re-election is prohibited.
Political outlook: International relations
Chile will maintain generally solid relations with the US and other Latin American countries in 2018-22. Under the framework of the Pacific Alliance, an integration project that also includes Peru, Colombia and Mexico, Chile will continue to support regional integration efforts, and seek to improve ties with Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, whose members are Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) and Asia-Pacific economies. Chile will also support the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), the successor agreement to the Trans-Pacific Partnership, made following the withdrawal of the US. The CPTPP was signed by its 11 members in Chile in March; we expect Chile to ratify the deal this year, and for the agreement to come into force in 2019. Ties with China will also continue to deepen, given ongoing trade and investment flows. Relations with neigh-bouring Bolivia will remain complicated, owing to ongoing border disputes and Bolivia's demand for the return of sovereign access to the Pacific coast; deliberations resumed at the International Court of Justice in The Hague in March. Lack of full diplomatic relations (as has been the case since 1978) will lead to the occasional eruption of diplomatic rows.

a See Guide to the business rankings model at the end of this report. b Out of 10. c Out of 82 countries. d  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela. e New section, introduced in 2018.
A liberal regulatory framework will support the investment climate.
Chile's investment climate will remain the most attractive in Latin America in 2018-22 according to The Economist Intelligence Unit's Business Environment Rankings, which compare the quality and attractiveness of investment conditions in 82 of the world's largest economies. Chile ranks first in the region and 20th globally in the 2018-22 forecast period, boosted by its longstanding and well-functioning market economy, open investment regime, strong fiscal position, sophisticated capital markets, and large network of free-trade agreements (FTAs). Its macroeconomic environment ranking improves globally and the country maintains its first place ranking regionally in the forecast period, as GDP growth will begin to pick up after the slowdown of recent years. The score for foreign trade and exchange controls remains unchanged, as does that for taxes, although Chile falls slightly in the global ranking in both categories owing to improvements elsewhere. Both the score and global ranking for infrastructure improve in the forecast period, as do the score for financing, and the score and regional and global ranking for the labour market, driven by ongoing education reform to improve access and quality. The labour market will also experience some improvements as the government seeks to address the rigidity of a recent labour reform. The score and global ranking for political stability improves slightly, but the country falls to second place regionally.
In terms of market opportunities, Chile's GDP per head is the highest among major Latin American countries, at an estimated US$15,341 in 2017. It is forecast to reach US$21,657 in 2022, and to exceed US$25,000 by 2025-a figure generally regarded as separating developed from middle-income countries. Structurally, Chile's business environment ranking suffers from the modest size of its domestic market, but this is mitigated by the country's large network of FTAs, which expand its potential market and enable more than 90% of its trade to be conducted on a preferential basis.
