Business environment outlook: Chile's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government focuses on improving the business climate through simplification of tax processes.
2020-22: Cutting of red tape with investor-friendly measures possible.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Investment regime among the world's most liberal. Newly upgraded pro-investment agency maintains investor-friendly policies, focusing on areas in which Chile has competitive advantage, seeking to move beyond natural resources.
2020-22: Chile's network of bilateral double-taxation and investment-protection accords widens further.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Narrow import-tariff dispersion (0-6%) and free capital flows owing to multiple free-trade agreements.
2020-22: Export development remains a policy priority. Comprehensive Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership comes into force, widening Chile's Pacific Rim free-trade network.
Taxes
2018-19: Corporate tax structure simplified to boost investment, but tax cuts unlikely. Maximum personal rate lowered.
2020-22: Simplification of tax code possible, including new tax-savings mechanisms.
Financing
2018-19: Government-backed loan guarantees available. Domestic long-term interest rates high, and bank lending practices conservative. Global credit becomes more costly as US interest rates rise.
2020-22: Further measures to facilitate financing for small businesses, particularly new ventures.
The labour market
2018-19: Reforms to labour regime implemented, strengthening trade unions and reducing flexibility further.
2020-22: Liberalisation of working arrangements possible, along with performance-related pay in public sector.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Generally good telecommunications and technological infrastructure expanded further. Investment in power generation and highway network continues, but energy sector remains vulnerable to shortages.
2020-22: Upgrading of transport infrastructure through concessions. New energy investment comes on stream, following connection between north and central grids, benefitting the expansion of non-conventional renewable sources.
Technological readiness
2018-19: "Start-Up Chile" programme continues to attract small technology firms to the country with government support.
2020-22: Government focuses on upgrading digital infrastructure, including an expansion of rural broadband and public Wi-Fi hotspots.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.0 8.6 16 9 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Fiscal prudence and low levels of debt support macroeconomic stability
Chile's global rank for its macroeconomic environment improves in the forecast period, moving Chile into the top ten in our global ranking for this category; the country also maintains its position as the most stable and resilient economy in Latin America. The country retains the top regional spot despite relatively soft economic growth. (we forecast that real GDP will expand by an average of 3.2% in 2018-22, substantially lower than the average of 5.3% in 2010-13, a period of high commodity prices.) The government has promised to bring down the fiscal deficit during its term, which coincides with the forecast period, by 0.2% per year starting in 2018, which is in line with the prudent economic management of the past four decades. We expected that the fiscal deficit will average 1.4% of GDP during the forecast period. Chile's macroeconomic environment will be supported by a solid institutional framework and a general consensus favouring orthodox fiscal and monetary policies, free markets, and integration in the world economy.
Generally prudent fiscal management has allowed the government to maintain very low levels of public debt (24.5% of GDP in 2017). Although the deficit has seen a steady rise since 2007 (when it was 3.9% of GDP) and is expected to rise further, to a high of 27.6% of GDP by 2020, this is a manageable level and by far the lowest in the region. Macroeconomic stability has traditionally been supported by Chile's system of cyclically adjusted fiscal accounts (under a structural fiscal rule adopted in 2001), which has required that it save part of the fiscal proceeds derived during periods of unusually high copper prices and/or GDP growth rates in two sovereign wealth funds. These funds, which held combined assets of US$24.5bn in June 2018 (around 8% of forecast 2018 GDP), serve to cushion the country from volatility in copper prices and the risk of natural disasters by allowing it to implement countercyclical fiscal policies with limited negative impact on the local economy. However, a consistent overestimation of long-term copper prices and GDP growth has led to some deterioration in the fiscal accounts in recent years.
The Banco Central de Chile (BCCh, the central bank) has been independent for more than two decades, and its autonomy is unlikely to come under threat in the forecast period. It is a widely respected institution owing to the success of its inflation-targeting regime, which has held average annual inflation within the BCCh's target range of 2-4% per year in most years since its full implementation in 1999. Inflation has generally remained at the lower end of the range in recent years, and stood at 2.5% in the 12 months to June.
The BCCh is complemented by an efficient banking supervisory body, the Superintendencia de Bancos e Instituciones Financieras, which has helped to maintain a modern and well-capitalised banking sector that remains vigorous and profitable, and has proved resilient to external shocks such as the 2009 global financial crisis. The securities and insurance regulator, the Comisión del Mercado Financiero, and the pensions supervisor, the Superintendencia de Pensiones, are also part of the regulatory landscape.
Chile also has an independent Consejo Fiscal Asesor (CFA, fiscal council), created in 2013, which helps to increase transparency in the public finances. The CFA publicly evaluates both fiscal performance, and official projections and plans, and generates its own macroeconomic and budgetary forecasts. In June the government introduced a bill to Congress that seeks to grant political and operational autonomy to the CFA (renaming it the Consejo Fiscal Autónomo).
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.5 8.5 8 9 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile will remain the regional leader in policy toward private enterprise
Decades of consistent market-friendly policy and reforms keep Chile in the top position in Latin America and in ninth place in our global rankings for policy towards private enterprise and competition. Following various privatisation programmes-mostly in the late 1980s under the military regime of Augusto Pinochet (1973-90)-Chile has only a small number of companies left in state hands, most notably Codelco, the world's largest copper producer. Governments on both the right and left of the political spectrum have pursued market-oriented solutions to economic problems. In recent years red tape has been significantly reduced-for instance, a company can now be created online in a single day and without cost. Similarly, Chile's bankruptcy legislation was modernised with the passage of a new law that came into force in October 2014. According to the World Bank's Doing Business 2018 report, Chile ranked 55th out of 190 nations in terms of the cost of regulations for conducting business in 2017. It is second best in Latin America after Mexico (49th).
Following a period of strained relations between the business community and the former president, Michelle Bachelet, the return of Mr Piñera to the presidency has been largely welcomed by the private sector, given his economic track record during his first term in office (2010-14), as well as his campaign promise to adopt more pro-market policies, including a simplification of the tax rules, modernisation of the environmental evaluation system to speed up the permitting process and a reduction of red tape. We expect progress on these fronts during Mr Piñera's current four-year term; a reform to the environmental evaluation system was presented in August.
In an effort to reduce red tape, in May the government has announced the creation of an office to accompany domestic and foreign investors during the permitting process. The Oficina de Grandes Proyectos Sustentables (GPS), seeks to act as the one-stop shop for investors. The Ministry of Economy, where the GPS office is located, estimates that 203 invest-ment projects across all sectors, worth US$65bn, could materialise in the next four years. The government also instructed the ministry to identify other investment bottlenecks. Other measures to ease investment included allowing the ministry to issue temporary permits, and also to update the registry or mining concessions in the country.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
9.6 9.6 3 3 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile's foreign investment regime is the third-ranked in the world and the top-ranked in Latin America for 2018-22. Policy is open and pro-business, based on a constitutionally guaranteed principle of non-discrimination between local and foreign investors. The country attracted a total of US$6.4bn in foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows in 2017, compared with US$12.4bn in 2016, due to a combination of declining geological conditions (ore grades), tense industrial relations and higher labour costs, which led to stagnation in new mining projects, according to the UN Conference on Trade and Development. The country was the sixth-largest FDI recipient in Latin America (after Brazil, Mexico, Colombia, Argentina and Peru). Figures from the first quarter show that the country attracted US$6.9bn in FDI, more than for full-year 2017.
Chile will remain the world's top destination for copper mining investment. The Comisión Nacional del Cobre (Cochilco, the state copper commission) has previously indicated that mining investment will exceed US$64.9bn in 2017-26, attracted by the country's vast mineral wealth, close proximity to coastal ports and reputation for political and economic stability. A rebound in metal prices (demand for some key commodities like copper and lithium is expected to increase in the forecast period), paired with more pro-market policies put forward by the current administration, is likely to push investment higher. We forecast FDI of US$17.5bn per year on average in 2018-22.
InvestChile shifts its focus to attract all kinds of investment
Unlike the previous administration, which adopted sector-specific policies to attract foreign investment-focusing on the mining, energy, food and tourism industries-the Piñera government has announced a non-discriminatory, multi-sectoral approach. The economy minister, José Ramón Valente, has said that the government investment promotion agency, InvestChile, will not just focus on attracting FDI or on greenfield projects, but will also promote foreign investment in the acquisition of local companies to develop local industry, working closely with the recently created GPS office.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.7 8.7 27 32 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile has more FTAs than any other country globally
Chile's trade regime is among the most open in the world, although rapid trade liberalisation elsewhere in the world means that the country's global rank slips from 27th to 32nd in the forecast period. The country has a low trade-weighted average effective import tariff rate as a result of its large network of FTAs and various economic association agreements. These total 26 agreements and involve more than 64 countries, which account for over 86% of global GDP and more than 64% of the global population. The most important are FTAs signed with the EU (February 2003), the US (January 2004), China (October 2006) and Japan (August 2007). Chile also has FTAs with South Korea, Malaysia, Turkey, the European Free-Trade Association (consisting of Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland), Canada, Central America, Australia, Vietnam, Hong Kong and Mexico. Chile is also a member of the dynamic Pacific Alliance free-trade bloc, together with Mexico, Colombia and Peru, and has more limited agreements with India, New Zealand, Singapore and Brunei. These agreements offer firms based in Chile a potential market of over 4bn people, as 94% of Chile's trade is conducted on a preferential basis. Furthermore, Chile offers an unusually narrow range of import tariff dispersion, ranging from 0% to 6%. The country has no exchange restrictions affecting capital or trade flows, but there are reporting formalities with respect to foreign investment exceeding US$10,000.
Chile is currently negotiating the modernisation of its FTA with the EU, as well as the deepening of its FTA with South Korea. It is also negotiating a bilateral commercial agreement with Brazil, and, together with its partners in the Pacific Alliance, is negotiating an accord to strengthen economic and commercial relations with the Alliance's associate countries, Australia, Canada, New Zealand and Singapore. Its most recently agreed FTA was made with Uruguay in October 2016 (it has not yet been signed into law). Chile also recently modernised its FTA with Canada to include a new chapter on investments, as well as a deepening of its FTA with China, a commercial agreement with Indonesia, a public procurement agreement with Brazil and a commercial liberalisation agreement with Argentina.
With the failure of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) following the decision of the US president, Donald Trump, to pull the US from the deal, Chile and the ten other remaining countries signed the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) in March; we expect it to enter into force in the coming months.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.4 7.4 16 17 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile's score for tax policy remains unchanged in the forecast period, but progress elsewhere causes it to slide to 17th place globally in the ranking, although the country maintains in first place in the region. Total taxes remain relatively low on a global comparison, but, according to the Doing Business 2018 report, the time it takes to file taxes in Chile is 291 hours a year, compared with an OECD high-income average of 160.7; Chile ranks 72nd of 190 countries in the category for paying taxes. The tax regime underwent major change in 2014, following passage of a tax reform that was signed into law in September that year. The reform was designed to raise fiscal revenue by US$8.2bn annually by the end of Ms Bachelet's term, to fund reforms to the education system and improvements to healthcare. Although the backbone of the reform was an increase in corporate taxes, it created a dual taxation system that, for many in the private sector, was too complicated to fully implement. As a result, the government signed into law a "reform to the reform" in February 2016 that left only one system in place, the so-called semi-integrated system, in which companies pay a 27% corporate tax rate, and shareholders also pay income tax, but with businesses permitted to deduct some earnings if these are reinvested. The second mechanism of the original system, which establishes a corporate tax rate of 25%, along with a 10% income-tax levy on shareholders, remains an option for family-run and small businesses.
The government is seeking to simplify the current tax system
During his 2017 presidential campaign, Mr Piñera promised that he would lower the corporate tax rate from 27% to 25%, the average of its OECD peers. However, on June 1st Mr Piñera backtracked and said that the government would leave the corporate tax rate at current levels, citing the weaker economy and the need to raise additional revenue to fund social programmes and other fiscal needs. The government has announced its intention to meet its other promise, to simplify the tax system, in a bill expected to be introduced to Congress by September at the latest, which is likely to include additional levies, including a tax on digital platforms, and, possibly, increased taxes on sugary and alcoholic drinks, or taxes on foods with high contents of calories, sugar, sodium and fat.
Following close to two years of massive protests against the country's private pension providers, the movement has lost some of its momentum. The government has announced plans to address the core of the problem, low pension payments (the majority are below the minimum wage, which is currently around US$420/month), with a bill to be introduced to Congress in the second half of 2018. Although the details are yet to be unveiled, the reform is likely to include provisions to strengthen the contributions provided by the government to the most vulnerable members of the population (the elderly, women and the middle class), and to increase employee contributions to 14% from the current 10%, to be paid entirely by the employer.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.1 8.5 7 7 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The financial sector is well developed, with a solid institutional framework
Chile remains the leader in Latin America in terms of financing and remains in seventh place in the global rankings in 2018-22. Its capital market is sophisticated, and has been growing in terms of liquidity and market capitalisation, helped by a solid institutional and legal framework. This has involved rapid adoption of new financial instruments, the appearance of new intermediaries and payment systems, and a continued updating of rules, regulations and methods of official supervision. Despite Chile's small population (just 18.1m) and annual GDP per head (an estimated US$15,431 in 2017), stockmarket capitalisation was large at the end of 2017, at US$298bn (US$273bn at the end of June 2018), up from US$218bn a year earlier. The country's privately run pension funds (AFPs) are by far the main players on the demand side. By end-June 2018 they were managing a total of US$202bn, of which US$114bn was invested in Chile (US$92.7bn in fixed-income and US$21.8bn in variable-income securities). The 55 insurance companies operating in the country are also substantial investors, with a combined portfolio of around US$64.2bn at end-2017, as are over 500 mutual funds, which managed around US$60.5bn at end-May. There are also more than 100 publicly traded investment funds, managing a combined total of US$22.9bn as at end-2017.
Chilean companies with solid credit ratings will continue to have good access to long-term finance through credits and leasing, and large companies will retain access to a variety of other options, such as stock and bond issues, as well as a competitive and flexible syndicated loan market for maturities of up to ten years. Blue-chip businesses will have access to long-term funding locally-through bank loans with maturities of up to seven years, or local bond issues with maturities of up to 30 years-owing to the use of an inflation-indexed unit of account, the unidad de fomento, which eliminates inflation risk.
Recent downgrades of the long-term foreign currency rating by the major ratings agencies have not had a larger impact on the borrowing costs of companies, suggesting that such downgrades were largely priced in. The government has said that its goal is to regain its previous rating by the end of its term in 2022.
Chile has a relatively high stock of external debt, particularly by the corporate sector, which increased by 20% between 2007 and 2014 as local companies took advantage of low international interest rates to finance regional expansion. According to the BCCh, external debt due in the next 12 months was US$37.7bn at the end of the first quarter, compared with foreign reserves that month of US$38.1bn. This leaves the country vulnerable to a financial shock. Nevertheless, BCCh data also suggest that only a small proportion of corporates' foreign debt is not covered either by foreign currency earnings or foreign currency hedging operations, which should mitigate risk.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.2 6.4 32 25 3 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile performs somewhat less well in the labour market category compared with other elements of the business environment ranking. Its score and ranking improves in 2018-22 owing to education reforms, which we anticipate will increase the supply of educated and skilled workers in the forecast period, pushing Chile to 25th place globally and first place in the region. These were begun under the Bachelet government (2014-18) to address long-running deficiencies in the country's education system, which although better than that of neighbouring countries, lags behind that of the developing Asia region and the other countries in the OECD (of which Chile is a member). The reform expands access to pre-school, university and technical education, and over the coming years will see 15 new career and technical education centres opened across the country (one in each region) for vocational education. Nonetheless, businesses have long complained that the labour regime is too rigid. It offers strong worker protections through both restrictive regulations and high firing costs (one month's wage per year worked in the company).
Labour reform is in its early stages of implementation
A labour reform approved in 2017 strengthened unions, as it expanded the categories of workers who can join a union, established a floor for negotiations (not permitting a company to offer workers weaker benefits than they had previously) and prohibits the replacement of striking workers. It also prohibits companies from extending benefits to non-union members. So far, the impact of the reform has been muted (only 9% of Chilean workers belong to a union, although the level is higher in the mining sector). The government has said that it expects to introduce a bill to congress to address some of these issues, including the issue of replacement during strikes, which should be more business friendly. It is yet to announce a date or the specific contents of the bill.
The Piñera administration has announced its intention to keep a focus on vocational training. It sent a bill to Congress in May proposing to provide free tuition to 70% of poorer students that attend technical universities. It is estimated that 167,000 students could benefit from passage of the bill, at an annual cost of US$475m. The government has said that its goal is for 90% of students in vocational and technical centres to receive free tuition, contingent on economic growth and the state of the public finances.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.8 7.0 28 26 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile retains first place in the regional ranking for infrastructure in the forecast period and climbs to 26th in the global ranking. The country's telecommuni-cations and technological infrastructure is modern, particularly by regional standards, as the regulatory system for telecoms encourages competition and the early adoption of new technologies. The country's transport infrastructure is resilient and has withstood the several earthquakes and other natural disasters that regularly impact the country. There are nine reconstruction plans in place following a series of natural disasters that have impacted the country since 2010, including an earthquake and tsunami in February 2010 that impacted the centre-south region, a series of earthquakes, tsunamis and floods that took place in the north in 2014-15, and the Calbuco volcano eruption of 2015; virtually all damaged infrastructure has been repaired or rebuilt. Reconstruction efforts following a massive wildfire that engulfed large areas in the centre-south in January and February 2017 are still ongoing.
The 2018 budget allocated US$3.7bn for the Ministry of Public Works. Funds will go towards transport infrastructure, including the renewal of public roads, as well as construction of new water reservoirs and irrigation infra-structure. A new underground railway line in the capital, Santiago, opened in November 2017, while a second line is currently under construction and expected to be opened in 2019. Three new lines have also been announced, targeted for completion in 2026. The new lines will expand Santiago's subway system, which is already one of the most extensive metro systems in Latin America. Additional transport funding will be allocated to the two largest metropolitan areas outside the capital, Gran Valparaíso and Gran Concepción, aimed at alleviating some of the congestion that these areas have been experiencing. Chiloé Island will be connected to the mainland through a 2.8 km bridge within the forecast period. There will also be upgrades to five regional airports and construction of a new terminal at the Santiago airport, while early works for a new deepwater port in central Chile are expected to continue, as well as expansion works on several other ports.
Concessions system will remain the norm for infrastructure development
Chile's robust infrastructure is attributable in large part to a successful concession system that was launched in the early 1990s. This stream of public-private partnerships helped to revamp the main north-south highway, Ruta 5, finish construction of numerous regional highways and an urban highway system in Santiago, as well as give a facelift to all major ports and airports in the country. The system saw a steady slowdown from the mid-2000s, when most projects were completed, but some new projects were announced as part of the previous government's US$28bn 2014-21 concessions agenda. Mr Piñera has stated that infrastructure investments during his term are expected to reach around US$20bn, of which US$8bn will come in the form of concessioned works. Some of the projects under consideration are the expansion of the busiest stretches of the Ruta 5 to four or six-lanes; construction of the southern extension of Ruta 5 (Carretera Austral) between Puerto Montt and Villa O'Higgins; and a coastal highway parallel to Ruta 5.
The completion of a key transmission line will reduce costs further
Although energy infrastructure has been seen as the weak link in Chile's infrastructure matrix, this changed during Ms Bachelet's second term, with the implementation of a long-term strategy that extends beyond the forecast period (Energía 2050), as well as a decline in the price of renewable energies, which helped to push an increase in clean energy sources, and the connection between the north and central energy grids. These efforts have helped to contain the price of energy, which for years was a major hindrance to invest-ment.
The completion of a transmission line connecting the main north and central-south electricity grids has been delayed as a result of community opposition. Although originally slated for completion in December 2017, it has now been pushed to end-2018. Once completed, the growing non-conventional renewable energy (NCRE) sector is expected to increase further, as the central-south is where most consumers are situated. NCRE projects already account for 18% of the country's energy supply, and are likely to meet a target of 20% of generation in 2020, five years ahead of schedule.
Following its predecessor's efforts, the Piñera government announced a series of commitments in the energy field. Among the measures included in the "Ruta Energética 2018-21" programme are plans to decarbonise the existing matrix through the conversion of coal-powered plants to cleaner sources, increase the number of electric vehicles tenfold in the four-year period, reduce by 25% the amount of time required to approve the permit of energy projects, and promote energy efficiency among large-scale users (mining and industry, mainly) through a new regulatory framework.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.6 7.2 33 33 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption.
Chile's score for technological readiness is the highest in the region and 33rd in the global ranking for the forecast period, supported by strong internet usage and efforts by successive governments to improve the country's technological and innovation capacity. Nevertheless, the country suffers from low rates of investment on research and development (R&D). According to figures from the OECD, R&D investment in Chile was 0.4% of GDP in 2016, compared with an OECD average of 2.5%. Following four years of declining figures, investment in the telecoms sector rose by 9.7% in 2017, to US$1.57bn, with 44% focused on mobile telecoms and the remaining 56% on fixed infrastructure, according to the Subsecretaría de Telecomunicaciones (Subtel, the telecoms regulator). Internet usage in the country is high. As at March 2018, mobile broadband internet access was 91.1%, while fixed broadband internet access was 47.7%. Mobile subscriptions are also high, with 129.1 subscribers per 100 inhabitants by end-March, up from 124.6 subscribers registered at end-2017, according to Subtel.
The local retail sector has made important efforts to strengthen its e-commerce strategy. According to figures from the Cámara Nacional de Comercio (CNC, the national chamber of commerce), online sales in 2017 rose by 31.7% from 2016, to an estimated US$4bn. The CNC forecasts that e-commerce sales in 2018 will surpass US$5bn.
The new science ministry will lead national science and technology policy
Congress recently approved the creation of the new Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation, which will be tasked with advising the president on all policies, programmes and plans designed to strengthen science and technology. The new ministry will have a technical advisory committee, which will periodically review the ministry's policies, while an inter-ministerial committee, comprised of the ministers of science, finance, economy and education, will be tasked with developing a national science policy, which will be sanctioned by the president.
As part of its tax reform plans, the government recently announced that it is considering taxing international digital companies, including online retail giants such as Amazon (US) and Alibaba (China), ride-hailing applications such as Uber (US) and Cabify (Spain), entertainment companies such as Netflix (US) and Spotify (Sweden), and homesharing sites such as AirBnB (US). The govern-ment is currently considering how to move forward, with several options at hand, including imposing a new transaction tax, enforcing the value-added tax (VAT; currently at 19%) and enforcing customs duties for imported goods. The finance minister, Felipe Larraín, has said the new tax could bring in hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue.
The government of Mr Piñera has announced plans to digitalise the public sector as part of its efforts to reduce red tape and bureaucracy. To that end, on July 10th it introduced a bill to congress that orders all administrative decisions to be conducted digitally, rather than, aside from in exceptional cases, on paper, allowing citizens to conduct business with the government over the internet through a digital platform. In addition the bill makes it mandatory to digitally preserve all of the generated files, as well as recognise the validity of digitised documents that were originally issued on paper. The government is also proposing the creation of an open data strategy for the public sector, to be followed by an open data platform.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government of Sebastián Piñera to maintain Chile's record of broadly sound macroeconomic policymaking. Expectations of more business-friendly policies under Mr Piñera (despite little concrete progress so far) are helping to boost confidence and bring about a recovery in investment after four years of contraction. To that end, Mr Piñera will undertake a simplification of tax rules and reduction of red tape, including moving more business registration processes online. Mr Piñera has also promised to create new incentives for entrepreneurship and innovation, and will place a greater emphasis on infrastructure. His public investment plans will aim to improve inter-urban transport nationwide, boost the percentage of paved roads, and increase the rural presence of fibre-optic and wireless internet. He will also increase political autonomy for regional governments to help to better direct local investment. A recently created US$9bn infrastructure fund will support concessions for public-private infrastructure projects.
Mr Piñera's government has discussed reforms to education and healthcare, including universal free pre-schooling. In June Congress approved the creation of a new Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation, which will advise the president on improving science-related policies and increasing investment in research and development (which was just 0.4% of GDP in 2016, compared with an OECD average of 2.5%). The government has also proposed new funding and administrative reforms to better direct healthcare spending, particularly for the elderly. Pension reform will remain an important item on the agenda; Mr Piñera has proposed increasing employer contributions, but has said that he would keep the unpopular privately administered funds in place.
Energy policy will remain high on the agenda, as Chile, an oil importer, suffers from high costs and vulnerability to energy shortages; further tax incentives for investors in renew-ables are likely, and the Piñera administration is likely to continue the controversial use of hydroelectric power in southern Chile. Greater concern about the environment and reduced regulation have spurred investment in renewables, and a target for 20% of the energy generation mix to be based on renewable sources is expected to be reached by 2020 (the current level is 17%); Mr Piñera has proposed setting the goal at 100% by 2040.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy

We expect lower fiscal deficits amid firmer economic growth, spending restraint and reforms to the fiscal rule that guides policy. This rule sets a structural surplus target based on certain economic assumptions, including projected copper prices and long-term potential GDP growth. The finance minister, Felipe Larraín, wants to improve the framework, because consistent over-estimation of economic growth and the long-term copper price in recent years allowed for higher levels of spending and weakened the public finances. Mr Larraín has announced fiscal austerity measures for the government and state-owned companies. Current plans envision eliminating a combined US$5bn (around 1.6% of forecast 2018 GDP) from expenditure over four years.
Given the very gradual nature of the cuts, the government's plan appears credible, and we believe that this will help to gradually narrow the deficit over the forecast period, a process that will be further supported by stronger real GDP growth and higher copper prices. Following a fiscal deficit of 2.8% of GDP in 2017, we expect a narrowing to 2% in 2018. However, the threat of strike action at Chile's largest mines (several contracts come up for renewal in the second half of the year) poses a threat to this forecast. Assuming fiscal austerity proceeds as expected and copper prices hold (our current forecast is for an annual average copper price of US$3.39/lb in 2018-22), we forecast a narrowing of the fiscal deficit to 0.7% of GDP by 2022. Faster consolidation will be precluded by countercyclical fiscal spending and revenue declines in the face of a forecast slowdown in the US in 2020.
Continuing fiscal deficits will cause the public-sector debt to rise from 24.5% of GDP in 2017 to 27.6% of GDP in 2020, before falling slightly thereafter as the primary deficit narrows and eventually turns to surplus. Only around 19% of central government debt is external. The government is unlikely to face difficulties in accessing financing: Chile's external bonds traded at just 142 basis points above comparable US Treasury notes in June-by far the lowest among Latin America's large economies. In the event of a shock, the government could tap reserves held in its economic and social stabilisation fund, which stood at US$14.6bn in June, and a pension reserve fund, valued at US$9.9bn. The first ever withdrawal (US$314m) from the pension reserve fund since its inception in 2006 was made in September 2017; the last time that any amount greater than US$500m was withdrawn from the stabilisation fund was in the wake of the 2009 financial crisis.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates

Long-term interest rate (av) 4.2 5.3 5.2 5.4 6.0 6.0
The Banco Central de Chile (BCCh, the central bank) has kept its policy rate on hold at 2.5% since May 2017, after four 25-basis-point cuts in January-April last year. Notwithstanding pressures resulting from tightening by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank), the BCCh has so far shown itself to be cautious of resuming a tightening cycle given signs of economic recovery and relatively muted inflation; the decision to keep rates on hold at the BCCh's July meeting was unanimous. We do not forecast further cuts and expect monetary tightening to begin in early 2019. The BCCh has shown itself to be unfazed by recent currency weakening, although a continued steep fall in the value of the peso (not our baseline forecast) could see tightening resume sooner. We forecast an end-2022 policy rate of 4.5%.

Solid economic fundamentals and improvements in business confidence support brighter medium-term growth prospects, but Chile's open economy exposes it to global developments, particularly changes in prices and demand for commodities-minerals (mainly copper) account for about 50% of goods exports, and the country depends on imported oil. Nevertheless, a more supportive external environment and renewed business confidence will support an economic recovery this year. First-quarter growth figures show that a stronger than expected recovery is underway, with seasonally adjusted quarter-on-quarter growth of 1.2%, and year-on-year growth of 5%. This growth was driven particularly by investment growth and stronger private consumption. We forecast real GDP growth of 3.7% in 2018, slowing slightly, to 3.6%, in 2019. A brief cyclical deceleration in the US in 2020 will slow Chile's growth to 2.4% that year as lower confidence translates into a fall in investment growth, but a return to higher copper prices in 2020-21 will bring growth back up to an average of 3.1% a year in 2021-22. Although these rates will represent a significant improvement from recent years, growth will be about half the rate posted during the commodities boom.
Private consumption growth will be supported by low real interest rates-notwithstanding mild monetary tightening forecast from early 2019-and falling unemployment. Fiscal austerity will keep government consumption growth muted. Investment will return to growth, supported by public investment projects and resurgent copper investment as prices recover; nonetheless, investment growth will remain below the levels seen during the commodities supercycle. External trade will, on average, not contribute to overall GDP, as growth in imports due to recovering domestic demand will offset any gains from stronger external-especially Chinese-demand for exports.
Industrial activity will barely return to growth in 2018 as mining output increases, supported by higher copper prices. Construction activity will be supported by investment in commercial projects and public works. Growth in services will be reason-able, aided by Chile's advanced retail, shipping and transport sectors, a growing tourism sector, and the country's role as a regional hub for business and financial services. Barring weather-related shocks, growth in agriculture will remain strong in 2018-22, supported by growing Asian demand for Chilean fresh fruit.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Mining will remain among the largest sectors of the economy over the forecast period. With around 170m tonnes in proven high-grade copper reserves-22% of the world's total in 2017-which have the added advantage of being in close proximity to the sea, Chile has been the favourite global destination for copper mining investment over the past two decades. This has made it by far the world's largest copper producer, with output of 5.3m tonnes in 2017, around 27% of the total world copper output. Despite a projected lower copper price environment compared with the 2006-13 boom years, the country will remain a competitive mining investment destination because of its privileged geological conditions, as well as its political and economic stability. The market is divided between Codelco, the state copper firm, and private mining companies, with the latter combined accounting for two-thirds of output. Major multinational mining companies with a presence in Chile include BHP Billiton (Australia), Rio Tinto (UK-Australia), Xstrata (Switzerland), Anglo-American (UK), Freeport McMoRan (US) and Grupo México (Mexico). There are also numerous local private companies, such as Antofagasta.
Output has weakened in recent years, mainly reflecting the decline of copper prices and ore grades. Having grown by over 6% in 2013, output growth then stagnated in the subsequent two years before falling in both 2016 and 2017. The decline in 2017 owes largely to a 43-day strike at Escondida, the country's largest mine, in February and March, as well as flooding in several northern mines. Growth should return this year, as prices and investment have recovered. Nonetheless, declining ore grades have forced mines to invest heavily to keep output stable. Codelco plans US$20bn in investment in the 2017-21 period. The current level of investment should bring production above the 6m-tonne mark by 2020, with substantial gains thereafter.
Codelco's investment plan includes five so-called structural projects: the underground transformation of Chuquicamata (around 56% complete, due to be online by 2019); construction of a new mine level at the company's underground El Teniente mine (47% complete, with start-up due in 2023); the expansion of processing capacity at its Andina and Rajo Inca mines (due in 2025 and 2021 respectively); and an expansion at the Radomiro Tomic mine (currently under review). Codelco's production reached 1.84m tonnes in 2017, up slightly from 1.83m tonnes in 2016. Factoring in the impact of new investment, Codelco expects its copper output to rise until it exceeds 2.1m tonnes in 2020.
The market will continue to be driven mostly by demand from Asia (particularly a rapidly urbanising China, which accounts for around 40% of global copper demand). This will provide support for copper demand, but overall Chinese economic growth is expected to moderate in the years to come, and the price of copper will not return to its recent historical high of 400.4 US cents/lb in 2011 during the forecast period. Instead, after falling to an average of 221 US cents/lb in 2016, copper prices will remain weak, averaging 339 US cents/lb in 2018-22. Although lower than the 2011 level, this is still high by historical standards.

The peso's value is strongly linked to copper prices, and we expect higher copper prices and firmer external demand for Chile's exports to support the peso over the forecast period. However, as was evident in April-May, the peso will remain vulnerable to shifts in global risk sentiment, amid ongoing US monetary tightening. We expect the peso to trade at Ps653.7:US$1 at end-2018, before strengthening slightly thereafter amid local monetary tightening, which will narrow interest-rate differentials with the US. Rising copper prices will keep the peso strong in 2020-22, averaging Ps615.3:US$1. The BCCh will have access to ample international reserves (US$37.7bn in July, equivalent to around 60% of estimated total annual merchandise imports) with which to prevent excessive fluctuations, tied particularly to shifts in copper prices.

The current account will remain in a slight deficit in the forecast period, as a growing trade surplus (supported by higher copper prices and export volumes), is offset by a large primary income deficit, owing to rising debt service and profit repatriation by multinational firms based in Chile. The current-account deficit will widen slightly from 1.5% of GDP in 2017 to 1.6% of GDP in 2018. As a percentage of GDP, the trade surplus will remain relatively stable, averaging 2.9%. The services deficit will narrow slightly as a percentage of GDP, reflecting rising income from tourism, but will remain in deficit owing to Chile's dependence on foreign transport services. The secondary income (transfers) surplus will decline slightly as a share of GDP compared with previous years, reflecting higher outward remittance flows due to a rise in inward migration.
Inward foreign direct investment (FDI) will rise in nominal terms in 2018 from a low in 2017: inward direct investment in the first quarter of 2018, at US$6.8bn, exceeded the amount received in full-year 2017 (US$6.4bn). The increase in FDI will be supported by a slight recovery in copper prices (the mining sector typically accounts for a large proportion of inward FDI flows), as well as renewed confidence under the Piñera government. Net portfolio inflows are expected to remain elevated in 2018-22. Chile's deep, open financial system will support high debt and equity-investment inflows in the medium term. Foreign-exchange reserves are forecast to rise only slightly, to US$40.4bn by end-2022, resulting in a slight fall in import cover, but this will remain ample, at nearly five months.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Chile
Stocks and flows
After a dip in 2009 caused by the drying-up of mergers and acquisitions activity during the global recession, foreign direct investment (FDI) in Chile has rebounded sharply in subsequent years. However, FDI fell dramatically between 2015 and 2017, falling from US$21.1bn to US$6.4bn, largely reflecting lower copper prices. However, a recovery appears to be underway this year, with first-quarter FDI reaching US$6.9bn-more than the amount received in full-year 2017. Despite its small size, Chile has historically been an important destination for FDI, particularly in its mining, energy and transport infrastructure sectors. The country's favourable climate for foreign businesses pushed the stock of FDI to US$206.2 in 2017, according to IMF data, resulting in an FDI stock/GDP ratio of 74.5%, compared with much smaller ratios for Brazil (37.9%) and Mexico (48.1%).
Chile's importance as an investor in other regional markets has also increased in recent years, with a focus on the airline, shipping and retail sectors. However, outward flows have declined considerably in recent years, and totalled just US$4.8bn in 2017, down from an annual average of US$15.9bn in 2011-15. This reflected a global decline in cross-border mergers and acquisitions activity, and also political uncertainty throughout Latin America (where most Chilean outward investment flows) ahead of a busy election season in the region. A large stock of outward FDI in 2016 (US$95.4bn, equivalent to 34.4% of GDP, according to data from the Banco Central de Chile-the central bank) is testament to the success of Chilean firms abroad.
Origin and distribution
The US was the largest source of the accumulated FDI stock in Chile in 2016, according to the latest available central bank data, accounting for 14.1% of the total stock of FDI, up from 13.7% in 2015. US investment has been broadly distributed, although it has made a strong contribution to wholesale and retail trade, largely owing to a US retailer, Walmart, acquiring the largest local supermarket chain, D&S, in 2009. The second-largest source was Canada, accounting for 8.9% of investment in 2016. This largely reflects expansion plans by Canadian mining firms in the country, which have grown considerably in recent years. Following was Spain, accounting for 7.5% of the total. Spanish investment has slowed since the 2008-09 financial crisis, but the large stock reflects earlier investments in utilities and infrastructure, where many Spanish firms operate through build-operate-transfer (BOT) concessions. There is also important participation in telecommunications and financial services, mainly by firms such as Telefónica and Santander. The next largest source of the FDI stock is the Netherlands, also accounting for 7.5% of the total in 2016 (although the Netherlands is a favoured European business location, so this investment may partly have come from other countries). Other sources include Brazil (4% of the total in 2016), the UK (3%), Japan (2.3%) and Italy (1.2%). However, much of the FDI flowing to Chile is routed through tax havens such as Bermuda, the Cayman Islands, the Bahamas, Luxembourg and others, making it difficult to ascertain fully the countries of origin. Regarding the sectoral distribution of FDI stocks, mining accounted for 29% of the total in 2016, followed by financial services (28.2%) and utilities (electricity, gas and water, at 8.9%). Other important sectors that have attracted significant foreign investment in recent years include manufacturing, transportation, communications, real estate and business services, and retail.
Determinants
Chile's foreign investment regime, which has been in place for three decades, is one of the most liberal in the world. There is a well-respected principle of non-discrimination between local and foreign investors, who also enjoy additional protection as a result of the rapidly expanding network of investment-protection accords and double-taxation treaties signed with other countries. Generally sound regulation, combined with political and economic stability, and firm growth, have helped to boost FDI inflows since the early 1990s. Moreover, Chile's managerial talent and well-qualified labour force (by regional standards), together with a strong rule of law, low crime rates and a large network of free-trade agreements (FTAs), have attracted a growing number of multinationals to use Chile's capital, Santiago, as a headquarters for Latin America. Moreover, the entry of Chile into the OECD in 2010 has made it subject to various investment-related provisions and guidelines relating to liberalisation of capital movements and trade in services (including business and financial services, insurance, culture, tourism, and travel).
Impact
FDI funded a growing share of gross fixed investment in Chile in the 1990s. FDI averaged 25.5% of gross fixed investment in 1996-98, compared with 10.4% in 1990-92. In 2001-06 FDI funded 28% of the gross fixed investment that materialised in Chile in that period, contributing to the modernisation of infrastructure, including telecoms. The ratio rose to an annual average of 37.8% in 2007-15, owing to large mining and energy investments. It has slipped significantly since, reaching just 10.8% in 2017, but is expected to rise, albeit to a more modest annual average of 23.6% in 2018-22. FDI has also made a major contribution in terms of the transfer of technology and managerial expertise, and has helped to foster competition between local and foreign firms in most major consumer markets, thereby providing Chileans with wider product ranges and lower prices than in neighbouring countries. Outward FDI has grown as Chilean businesses have expanded abroad and has helped to consolidate many local firms into becoming important regional players in their respective sectors. Although outward FDI flows dropped to US$4.8bn in 2017, down from an annual average of US$12.2bn in 2007-15, this is still a robust level (outward FDI stock totalled US$90.5bn in 2016, according to the central bank). The fact that Chilean firms operated in a competitive domestic environment well before regional peers liberalised their own economies has enabled businesses to position themselves successfully in neighbouring countries. In no sector has this been more evident than in retail, where firms such as Ripley, Paris and Falabella have aggressively expanded into other markets such as Peru, Argentina, Colombia and Brazil.
Potential
Chile will continue to attract large FDI inflows, owing to its transparent business operating conditions, political stability, a fundamentally sound economy, a huge network of FTAs, double-taxation and investment-protection accords, the most modern infrastructure in Latin America, and a growing pool of skilled labour. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects FDI inflows to average 5% of GDP annually in 2018-22, slightly below the pre-crisis average of 7.2% of GDP in 2004-08, but well below the level of 9.2% of GDP recorded in 2011-15, during the commodities supercycle. The major acquisitions common in the banking, telecoms and utilities sectors over the past two decades are unlikely to be repeated at the same pace, given already near-complete levels of economic openness and liberalisation. Nevertheless, the services sector (for example) will have ample opportunities in a market in which incomes are expected to continue to grow steadily. Renewable energy and related industries (such as lithium extraction) will also attract significant investment.

Working-age population grows slowly while overall demographic profile ages
Chile's population growth rate is forecast to decelerate modestly, from 0.8% to 0.7% per year between 2018 and 2022. This will bring the total population to 18.7m by 2022, leaving Chile the least populated of Latin America's seven largest economies, and the only of the seven that will have a population below 20m by 2022. The national statistics office projects that the rate of natural population growth-the crude birth rate minus the death rate-will continue to slow, from 8.6 per 1,000 annually in 2010-15 to 7.4 in 2015-20, and 6.2 in 2020-25. Although Chile displays a maturing demographic profile, the share of the working-age population will remain roughly stable, at around 68% of the total, in 2018-22. The rise in the share of the population above working age (13% will be 65 or older by 2022) will bring this statistic to among the highest of 12 Latin American countries covered by The Economist Intelligence Unit's Country Forecasts.
Chile has traditionally been an immigrant-receiving country, although not to the same extent as other South American countries such as Argentina or Brazil. Before the Second World War, migration largely came from Europe and the Middle East, whereas since the 1970s most migrants have come from neigh-bouring Peru and Bolivia, with migrants often working in low-skilled jobs in agriculture and construction, or as domestic help. However, the pace of inward migration has accelerated since 2005, with the number of foreigners in the country increasing by 123% between 2005 and 2014, to around 416,000. This represented the highest proportion of foreign-born people living in Chile since 1920. As at 2017, the government estimates there are now around 1m foreigners living in the country, of which it estimates that 300,000 are undocumented.
The immigration surge largely owes to the arrival of Venezuelans and Haitians in the light of humanitarian crises in both countries, as well as increased econ-omic migration from countries such as Colombia, Ecuador and the Dominican Republic, attracted by the higher wages and quality of life in Chile. We expect net inward migration to continue, given Chile's relative pros-perity within Latin America, but expect it to proceed at a more moderate pace than in 2015-17, as the government has instituted new laws to control the inward flow. Outward migration from Chile peaked during the 1973-90 dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet, but has slowed considerably since. The government esti-mates that around 500,000 Chileans live abroad, largely in Argentina, the US and Sweden.
Inward immigration is rising but will not boost overall population growth.
Chile's basic health indicators are similar to other OECD countries, reflected in an average life expectancy of 79.9 years in 2018-22 (82.4 years for women and 76.5 years for men) and infant mortality of 6.6 per 1,000 live births. Demand pressures on the healthcare system are more akin to those of an industrialised country than a developing one. Infectious diseases and problems such as malnutrition are largely under control outside of small pockets of extreme poverty. However, age and "lifestyle-related" conditions associated with sedentary living and increased consumption of processed foods, such as obesity (75% of the population are overweight or obese), heart disease, colon cancer and diabetes, are on the rise.
Public healthcare policies will increasingly target obesity and unhealthy lifestyles. Only 2.5% of children under six were at risk of malnutrition in 2010, but 22.8% were overweight (9.7% of these obese). A universal health plan, the Plan de Acceso Universal con Garantías Explícitas (Plan AUGE), was created in 2005, offering fixed-price treatments for 80 conditions, including many expensive illnesses. The policy is sold at a fixed price and guarantees a maximum waiting time for medical attention for each condition. The public system covers around 80% of the population, against 17% covered by private insurance. The Piñera government has introduced plans to reduce waiting times and the accessibility of care in the public system, but no major reforms to the provision of care appear on the cards.
Labour market reform will fail to incorporate informal workers
Modest growth in the working-age population will add some pressure to the labour market in the medium term. The economy was close to full employment in 2013, with unemployment at a historical low of 6%, but weak growth has caused unemployment to rise since then, to 7.2% in the April-June rolling quarter of 2017. This is low by regional standards. Informality is estimated to cover around 36% of the labour force, according to the OECD-also a low figure by Latin American standards (it is frequently over half, even in large economies). However, the informal sector represents a large pool of untapped labour, which could, if brought into the formal market, boost long-term growth and tax revenue

After contracting, income per head in US dollar terms will grow in 2017
Chile's market opportunities are constrained by its small population, estimated at 18.1m in 2017 (forecast to grow to 18.7m by 2022), but its high income-combined with a legacy of political stability and effective economic management-will continue to make the country one of the most attractive destinations for investment in the region. In most of the past three decades it has outperformed all of the other economies in Latin America in terms of GDP growth, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects slower but still-firm expansion of 3.2% on average in 2018-22. Inequality has been decreasing over the past decade, allowing a larger share of the population to access consumer goods and services. Low levels of unemployment and rising real incomes have supported this trend. However, inequality is still pronounced, and there are also income discrepancies between metropolitan and northern regions, and less affluent regions in the centre-north and centre-south.
Potential for more exports and import purchases will remain strong
The impact of weaker economic growth and sharp peso depreciation will begin to ease, with Chile's GDP per head in US-dollar terms rising to US$16,695 in 2018 (from US$15,341 in 2017), and reaching US$21,657 by 2022. According to IMF data for 2015, Chile's GDP per head (as measured in US dollars at purchasing power parity) is the highest in Latin America (excluding the Caribbean). In tandem with rising incomes, consumption will rise over the next five years (albeit at a slower pace than in the previous five-year period), to reach US$13,590 per head by 2022. Chile's open economy and abundance of natural resources have encouraged specialisation in export-oriented activities, particularly mining. Copper and other minerals have long been Chile's main sources of export revenue, but a slump in global prices in 2015-17 provided an additional spur to non-traditional exports after years of policies promoting trade diversification. Chile is the world's second-largest salmon exporter (despite having no native salmon population), the fifth-largest wine exporter (and seventh largest producer) and the largest regional exporter of fresh fruit. The country also has a fast-growing tourism sector. However, Chile's potential is limited by its small manufacturing base, which is dominated by agro-industrial output. As a result, a large share of consumer goods-such as electronics, cars and clothing-are imported. The share of imports in household expenditure will rise in 2018-22 as higher levels of discretionary spending boost demand for more diverse and expensive foreign goods.
Market opportunities: Consumer expenditure

Consumer markets in Chile are well developed and competitive, owing to a free-market-oriented economy that has encouraged participation by foreign firms, as well as import penetration for a wide range of consumer goods. This has helped to bring prices down and attract a large number of participants, despite the small size of the economy, in effect turning it into a showcase market for firms wishing to expand in the region. For example, around 50 carmakers compete in the Chilean market, including Chinese and Indian firms.
Other highly competitive sectors include telecom-munications and retail. Supporting consumer expenditure is a deep and sophisticated financial sector that has historically benefitted from ample credit supply, relatively low interest rates and narrow loan-deposit spreads. Large foreign and local firms co-exist in the banking and insurance sectors, with the insurance sector enhanced by high and rising statutory obligations. The private pension market is highly liquid and-uniquely among Latin American economies-has created a large pool of institutional investors, deepening local capital markets. Despite this, the conservative lending practices of the banking system mean that small and medium-sized enterprises often find it difficult to obtain financing; these constraints do not present a problem for larger blue-chip firms, which can access a wider range of financing options. In addition, there has been an expansion by retail chains into consumer lending (and even into mortgage lending and insurance brokerage) in recent years. Although this has helped to boost credit availability to some of Chile's lower-income households, there are concerns about the looser lending standards of retailers.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Chile's long-term outlook benefits from continued adherence to prudent monetary and fiscal policies, coupled with a commitment to the rule of law and protection of property rights. A wide network of bilateral free-trade agreements (FTAs) has helped Chile to attract foreign direct investment, while simultaneously helping local firms to expand abroad. It has also helped to diversify the economy into areas in which the country had previously lacked comparative advantages, although a pronounced bias towards mining, the country's single largest industry and source of exports, will persist. Chile's efforts to become a regional platform for multinational corporations will continue, facilitated by the country's reputation for stability and security, its well-developed financial system, and the quality of its transport and communi-cations infrastructure, as well as a comprehensive network of FTAs, double taxation agreements and investment protection accords. Chile's catch-up with the US has been good, with GDP per head-in US dollars at purchasing power parity (PPP)-increasing from 20% of that of the US in 1990 to 40% in 2017. This slow convergence will continue as growth outpaces that of the US, to reach a forecast 43% in 2022.
Initial conditions: Chile is a small country, representing only a 0.2% share of world population in 2017, but it punches above its weight in its share of world GDP (0.4% at PPP), and global exports are strong (0.3% of the total). Chile's GDP per head of US$15,341 in 2017 at market rates was the highest among Latin American economies (excluding the Caribbean). In PPP terms, GDP per head was US$24,080 in 2017, also the highest among non-Caribbean Latin American countries. In 2010 Chile became the second Latin American country after Mexico to become a member of the OECD. Chile will continue to attract manufacturing investment, but its competitiveness as a global manufacturing centre will lag behind that of its Asian rivals. That said, Chile will continue to find success in non-traditional production such as agro-industry and fisheries-and possibly some consumer goods, once Asia's labour cost advantages erode. As a commodity producer, Chile faces more volatile terms of trade than its Asian competitors, whose comparative advantage is founded on low-cost manufacturing rather than raw materials. This implies that Chile's growth will remain strongly linked to international copper prices for the foreseeable future. The peso remains weak against its 20-year average, which will help to boost competitiveness for non-mining exports.
Demographic trends: Although Chile's population is still young by international standards, its demographic profile is ageing. Annual population growth will average 0.6% in 2018-30, above the 0.4% growth of the working-age group in the period, which signals a rising dependency ratio. Nevertheless, the labour force will grow during the same period, owing to a drop in young-age dependency. Despite Chile's relative affluence and the quality of its social services, immigration has not significantly contributed to overall population growth in recent decades. Although it may begin to do so over the next decade, the effect will not be significant. As a result, the demographic outlook will be dominated by trends among the native-born population, whose birth rates will continue to fall.
External conditions: Growth in export industries will be boosted by Chile's large network of FTAs. However, the single most important external factor affecting the Chilean economy is the international price of copper. Prices have fallen substantially, from a peak of US$4/lb in 2011 to a low of US$1.96/lb in December 2015, owing to the global slowdown and the end of the so-called commodities supercycle; they have since recovered to around US$3/lb in 2018, but remain at the mercy of global sentiment. In the long term, however, demand growth from China and India, as well as other emerging economies, will keep copper prices high by historical standards. Chile has diversified its export base over the past 15 years, notably into non-traditional sectors such fruit, salmon and wine. Nonetheless, mining (mainly copper) still accounts for approximately half of total exports, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this dominance to diminish only marginally, given Chile's unique geological and geographical advantages in natural resource extraction. Service exports will also grow, benefitting from Chile's position as a regional business hub. Open and liquid capital markets make the country the most developed financial centre in the region-and second in size only to Brazil and Mexico-with ample crossborder opportunities in banking, insurance and securities markets arising from deeper regional integration. Finally, growing international awareness of the country's significant natural beauty will provide a major boost to tourism in the medium and long term.
Institutions and policy trends: Chile will maintain its strong pro-market policy direction of the past three decades. However, social pressures and the rising expectations of the middle classes will lead to an increase in public-sector participation in certain sectors. Governments will dramatically extend state funding of university places (tertiary education currently remains highly market-oriented) and renewable energy. Civil service reforms will support bureaucracy efficiency and transparency, and steps to reduce red tape will benefit the business environment as administrative procedures are simplified. Modernisation of the judiciary will accelerate legal procedures, which already benefit from one of the most independent and least corrupt judicial systems globally. Governance will be characterised by professionalism and credibility, offering investors minimal risks of policy reversals. Public frustration with graft and collusion will prompt reforms to reduce corruption. Constitutional reform will lead to a degree of symbolic decentralisation and a more parliamentary (rather than presidential) system of government.
Long-term performance: Chile's tradition of policy continuity, abundant natural resources, a favourable investment climate and modern infrastructure will be supportive of firm economic growth in the long term. The Chilean economic model will remain investment- and export-led, based on solid macroeconomic fundamentals, monetary stability and countercyclical fiscal management. Productivity growth will be helped by investments in new technologies and a gradual move towards higher value-added activities (made evident by the shift from agriculture to agro-industry). The financial sector will remain competitive, owing to a large pool of institutional investors (private pension funds, mutual funds and insurance companies), providing businesses and households with ample financing through credit and capital markets.
In the long term, modernisation of the education system and a more flexible labour market will be necessary to unlock higher potential growth; both these issues are being tackled by the Piñera government. The 2015 linking of Chile's north and central electricity grids could prove the catalyst for a revitalisation of the country's fragile energy matrix, which has resulted in Chile having some of the highest energy costs in the region. The lack of major fossil fuel reserves will provide an impetus towards developing renewable energy sources, and the country is on course to meet a target of 20% power generation via renewables in 2020, five years ahead of schedule (a long-term objective of 70% by 2050 appears more than feasible). At the same time, there is significant opposition to major hydroelectric projects on environmental grounds, and some green alternatives such as solar energy remain expensive, suggesting that Chile will be burdened by energy insecurity into the medium term. Overall, we forecast that average annual GDP growth will reach 3.2% in 2018-30, falling to 2.4% in 2031-50. As growth in the working-age population slows, economic expansion will become more dependent on productivity gains and less so on the contribution of labour.
