Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Chile's long coastline and diverse topography leave it highly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Changing climate dynamics will increase the likelihood and severity of natural disasters such as floods, droughts and landslides. These will directly disrupt some sectors of the economy, including agriculture and tourism, and will especially affect the country's water resources. According to climate change projections by Chile's meteorological office, precipitation in Chile's south-central area, and also in the northern part of Patagonia, should see temperatures rise and also see precipitation fall by around 60% between 2030 and 2059. Given that this is the heart of Chile's agricultural region, and also for its farmed salmon industry, this will have a serious impact on the Chilean economy. Temperature rises affecting the oceans will also affect sea life, causing less abundance and diversity available to Chile's fishing industry. This has been felt to some extent already in recent years, with an El Niño effect in 2016 affecting the fishing industry, and a major drought affecting the country in 2018. The drought has caused the government to declare a water emergency in 61 communes given water shortages, with 102 also declared in an agricultural emergency. The Universidad de Chile says at least 25% of the factors contributing to this year's drought reflect human action.
Although there is no national plan to combat climate change, or mitigate its effect, there are many sectoral or short-term plans to deal with the problem. However, in July the government proposed a law on climate change, which will be discussed between July and December this year, and presented to Congress in July 2019. Although the law is still in its early stages, it is expected to establish a medium- and long-term framework for reducing the effects of climate change, and create the institutions to help climate change adaptation and mitigation efforts.
An aging demographic profile
Chile's demographic profile shows an increase proportion of the population over 65. According to government statistics from 2015, 3m people were over 65, making up around 16.7% of the population. This is expected to climb to over 20% of the population by 2025. Between 1992 and 2017, the proportion of the population older than 60 grew by 5 percentage points, while that under 15 declined by 10 percentage points. This makes Chile one of the oldest populations in Latin America and the Caribbean (behind only Cuba and Uruguay). In addition to a lower birth rate, this also reflects an increase in life expectancy in the past 20 years as Chile has become a more affluent society. The aging of the population presents a unique challenge for a developing country, where until recently the challenge was providing sufficient economic growth and jobs for a working-age population.
The effect of Chile's aging population has already been seen in the country's politics, with the state of the country's pension system becoming a major issue in the 2017 election. The government has also had to address the fiscal costs of an aging population by promoting the hiring of senior citizens (to keep them in the workforce) and incentivising the postponement of retirement. The government has also sought to increase the number of doctors specialised in geriatrics working in the public health system and adapt urban infrastructure to accommodate the needs of the elderly. The shrinking percentage of the working-age population as a percentage of the overall population has also made immigration more attractive to Chilean policymakers. The country has bowed to political pressure to standardise its immigration system after a massive inflow in 2015-17, but still remains committed to welcoming regulated inward immigration.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World GDP and trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Manufactures price: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodities: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
World copper prices: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Ps:US$ exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
GDP growth by demand component: Banco Central de Chile (BCCh, the Central Bank), Boletín Mensual; 2003 prices
Copper production: BCCh, Boletín Mensual; m tonnes of all copper products
Average copper price: LME, quoted in BCCh, Boletín Mensual
US$ copper exports: BCCh, Boletín Mensual
US$ GDP: IFS; current prices, from local currency at annual average exchange rate
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Chile to prices in the US
Demographic profile data: UN, population projections, medium variant; ILO, labour force projections
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Real GDP growth per head: real growth in GDP deflated by population growth
Budget balance: non-financial public sector (NFPS) balance only; Ministerio de Hacienda
Inflation: BCCh; December 1998=100
Wage and salary inflation: BCCh
Wage costs and unemployment rate: BCCh, Boletín Mensual
Exchange rate: BCCh; market rates expressed as Ps:US$
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity (PPP) for tradeable products to annual average exchange rate
Interest rates: IFS; bank rate offered (charged) on deposits (loans) of 30-89 days; given in annual terms by compounding weighted average monthly rates
Balance of payments: BCCh
Total external debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
Total debt service: World Bank, Global Development Finance; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
ILO: International Labour Organisation
LME: London Metal Exchange
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
An early election in October 2017 was won by the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, who has since become chancellor at the head of a majority coalition government of the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to last a full five-year term.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to significant tensions with other EU member states as it did in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition. This is largely because of the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
The new government will focus on integration and immigration policy, including by taking a prominent role on this issue within the EU. It will attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. Significant structural reforms are unlikely, owing to low government cohesion.
We forecast that the government budget will remain in deficit-albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP-throughout the 2018-22 forecast period, as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to 67.2% by 2022, from 78.2% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 3.1% in 2017. We forecast a continuation of strong growth this year, at 2.9%, and a moderation to 1.6% on average in 2019-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2018-22, driven by structural domestic factors, including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. We expect annual average EU harmonised inflation of 2% in 2018-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain broadly stable, at 1.6% of GDP on average in 2018-22, driven mainly by a strong surplus on the services balance, supported by tourism inflows.

Austria's business environment score rises between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22), mainly owing to the improved economic outlook. Austria's strengths as a business location include good infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal. Risk of disruption, owing to trade dispute between the EU and the US.
2020-22: EU maintains focus on bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment continues to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Internet use remains slightly below several regional peers, but research and development remains relatively high.
2020-22: Further progress made on upgrading the large manufacturing sector to take advantage of new technologies.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic, and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government will focus on migration and integration issues, including in the EU context. It will also attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and implement other measures to improve the business environment, including through enabling more flexibility in the labour market.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: Trade relations are dominated by Germany, which accounts for about one-third of total imports and exports. The current-account surplus is driven by strong tourism exports boosting the services surplus. We expect modest current-account surpluses throughout the forecast period.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The governing coalition consists of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this coalition to prove relatively stable and to sit out a full term to 2022. This follows several years of little progress on reforms and coalition (as well as party) in-fighting under the grand coalition of the ÖVP and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ), which fell apart in May 2017. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP, reformed the party around himself, and moved it closer to the FPÖ on issues such as immigration and integration. As a result, he led the ÖVP to the largest share of the vote in the early election in October last year, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on the party's result in 2013. The SPÖ's share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The FPÖ increased its share of the vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5%, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
In mid-December, after just over a month and a half of negotiations, the ÖVP and the FPÖ formed a coalition. Under Mr Kurz the ÖVP has moved closer to the FPÖ in many policy areas, and the negotiations therefore went relatively smoothly. To assuage concerns from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Moreover, EU policy is handled by the chancellery instead of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is headed by an FPÖ appointee.
The chancellor is from the ÖVP, but the election was nevertheless a decisive moment in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has, to a large extent, been replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties had together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, but a renewed grand coalition had become almost impossible following a breakdown in relations and the reform gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz also owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue, and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP's and the FPÖ's programmes, we do not expect the government to implement significant structural reforms, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, on which they are significantly less aligned than they are on social and cultural matters. In addition, the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on topics such as immigration and integration into firm policy proposals. The initial phase of the government's term is likely to be relatively smooth, owing in part to the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union until the end of 2018. Later in the term the FPÖ might struggle to distinguish itself from the ÖVP, which could lead to tensions between the parties, creating a moderate risk of an early election.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The most recent general election was held on October 15th 2017. We expect the government to remain in office until the end of its term, which ends in late 2022, maintaining its majority in the Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament). There is a risk of an early election, although we believe that the probability of a snap vote is small. The next election for the (primarily ceremonial) post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants. Domestic pressure on the govern-ment to be seen as acting against this inflow, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. The new government plans to cut child benefit payments flowing abroad, potentially leading to tensions with eastern member states in particular.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that his government will be pro-EU, and that Austria's EU membership will not be questioned in the coming years. The government wants Austria to be a leading voice in the bloc, especially on migration reform, which should be facilitated by the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union. We expect the govern-ment to move forward with proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ into government, in 2000, led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations, the reception has been more muted this time. In that period a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands. However, this will, at times, lead to tensions with fellow EU members, as shown by the fact that a number of countries are now sharing less intelligence with Austria because the ministries concerned are headed by the FPÖ.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The new government plans to move integration and immigration policy further to the right, including through curtailing benefits for asylum-seekers and cutting child benefits that are sent abroad. It has also presented plans that focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing corporate tax rates and introducing more flexible working hours. Furthermore, it plans to cut a number of labour market programmes aimed at the long-term unemployed and integrating migrants into the labour market. Although it has announced a push to centralise and streamline the welfare system-to which several major stake-holders, including state governors, are likely to object-it does not plan to reform the so-called Proporz system, under which the ÖVP and the SPÖ had apportioned public entities and functions (state companies, public services, subsidies and regulatory responsibilities). This is despite suggestions from both coalition parties-especially the FPÖ-in the past that they would want to do this. We therefore expect reforms to remain limited to small-scale efforts in only a few areas, such as the labour market, and that the government will struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Driven by both a lacklustre recovery following the financial and euro zone crises and a lack of fiscal consolidation, the fiscal accounts have remained in modest deficit in recent years and within the 3% of GDP limit set by the EU. Strong growth contributed to a narrowing of the deficit to 0.7% of GDP in 2017.
The government plans to achieve a small budget surplus in 2019 by cutting spending and at the same time reducing income taxes and the country's sizeable tax wedge. However, it has not yet clearly outlined the spending cuts that it intends to make, barring a number of smaller measures, including cutting spending on asylum-seekers, and we therefore do not share the government's optimism that a surplus can be reached in 2019. Nevertheless, continued robust economic growth will contribute to a further narrowing of the deficit in the coming years; we expect it to average 0.3% of GDP in 2018-22.
The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from 78.2% in 2017 to 67.2% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain in a worse state than in countries such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low interest-rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low, in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The programme will run at EUR15bn per month in October-December before coming to an end. Economic activity in the euro zone has softened this year, but the ECB's view of the outlook remains fairly positive. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the main refinancing rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but the economy subsequently stalled and underperformed compared with regional peers, notably Germany. This was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltering reform process in recent years contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers, and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. However, the economic recovery gained significant momentum from the second half of 2016. Although in previous years the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, owing in part to a surge in employment in the manufacturing sector. We expect a continued gradual improvement in labour market indicators in the coming years. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.9% this year. Export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, real GDP growth was 3.1% in 2017-above the level in Germany for the first time since 2005, and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-after an underperformance compared with fundamentals in recent years-largely to continue this year. However, we forecast slower real GDP growth, of 2.9%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to be less pronounced in 2018. Nevertheless, increasing labour shortages will contribute to business investment pushing up investment growth in the first half of our five-year forecast period. Driven by the improvement of the labour market, domestic demand will be the main driver of growth. In the following years we expect a further moderation of growth, to 1.6% on average in 2019-22-around the economy's potential growth rate. Government policy is likely to be supportive of growth in the coming years, and the main risks are external. As a highly open economy, Austria is vulnerable to global economic developments. We expect the impact of the trade dispute between the EU and the US to be limited for Austria. However, an escalation beyond one more round of mutual tariff impositions, including on automotive imports by the US, continues to pose a significant downside risk to the outlook.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets, and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy price base effects caused a gradual increase in inflation in 2017, leading to a full-year average of 2.2%. We expect full-year average inflation of 2% in 2018, driven in large part by the uptick in global oil prices in the first half of 2018. A strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect price growth to stay above the euro zone average in 2019-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors seen in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
In 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018 but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and remained close to that level in June-July. The value of the euro could yet come under further pressure from political risk in Italy, and also from monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a broad stabilisation on average, at US$1.20:EUR1 in 2018-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. Thereafter we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values have helped the trade balance to move into surplus in recent years, from a deficit in 2009-13. However, the increase in oil prices in 2017 pushed it back into a modest deficit, and we expect gradually widening trade deficits throughout the forecast period. Nevertheless, we expect the current account to remain in surplus, with the main driver being the healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourist inflows. This will ensure that the current-account surplus will tick down only slightly throughout 2018-22 but will average 1.6% of GDP.

Country Forecast Venezuela August 2018 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-venezuela-august-2018-updater/docview/2086023409/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. After years of ineffectual leadership, most citizens, even those opposing the PSUV, distrust opposition parties. [...]they are incapable of channelling the anger generated by the country's economic crisis. [...]wastefulness at state-owned firms and massive corruption and clientelism schemes built around the delivery of subsidised goods and services would be hard to roll back without antagonising government backers, risking political instability. [...]we would expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA. [...]we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+August+2018+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2018-08-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Economic collapse and the erosion of the patronage scheme supporting the president, Nicolás Maduro, put the ruling regime's internal cohesion in jeopardy. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a traumatic rift that will end in regime pragmatists allowing opposition participation in a "mixed admin-istration" as a way to remain in power from 2019 onwards. There is a risk that the existing regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,000% at the end of 2017 and will average over 10,000% in 2018. GDP will continue to contract in 2018-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and hyperinflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate a fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices as oil output slumps, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 82th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2018-22, making the country the least attractive invest-ment location in our ranking. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition. Property rights remain weak.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Opaque currency controls add to uncertainty, severely restrict private-sector access to foreign exchange and impede trade. New government in 2019 starts removing exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Amid severely high inflation, financing remains only available in the short term and banking sector shrinks in real terms.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Underinvestment in the water and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2018-19: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies.
2020-22: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is how to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 1.4% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Despite a decimated economy and spiralling hyperinflation, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) and the president, Nicolás Maduro, retain their hold on power. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition, most likely ushering in a government with nominal opposition participation-a "mixed administration"-in 2019. We expect curtailed political stability in 2019-22. The opposition, of which the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) is the biggest grouping, remains in disarray. Apart from infighting, this reflects the PSUV's systematic campaign to disenfranchise opposition parties and sideline them from state institutions. After years of ineffectual leadership, most citizens, even those opposing the PSUV, distrust opposition parties. Thus, they are incapable of channelling the anger generated by the country's economic crisis.
In this context of unrest and repression, the PSUV is increasingly dependent on the military for support. The country is run by civic-military alliance and a network of businessmen with military or political connections. The accord is sustained by opportunities for arbitrage and corruption made possible by foreign-exchange controls, subsidised imports of basic goods and control of public-sector companies. Within this arrangement, factions are primarily explained by personal and patronage ties, which means that different civic-military factions coexist within the regime. The ultimate source of resources flowing through this patronage system is PDVSA, the state-owned oil company, whose exports account for the vast majority of foreign-exchange inflows into the country.
Jeopardising the civic-military-business alliance is a rapid decline in oil production due to mismanagement and underinvestment. Resultant strains have been highlighted by recent purges in the military. Furthermore, in June Mr Maduro reshuffled key positions in the administration, giving increased power to Diosdado Cabello, a long-time internal rival who has extensive military and business ties; Mr Cabello will now lead the Constituent Assembly (ANC, the country's de facto legislature). We interpret this as Mr Maduro attempting to regain internal support, even at the expense of personal power. Regardless, discontent seems to remain, as exemplified in July by unusually public criticism of the administration by other high-ranking PSUV members. Although Mr Cabello is a leading PSUV figure it is unclear if his recent elevation will quell discontent within the party. Indeed, unless the administration turns PDVSA around (we see this as unlikely, as the government lacks the required expertise or financing), we believe that the patronage system supporting Mr Maduro will be at risk of collapse by 2019.
Internal fracture in the regime may happen earlier than 2019, as the secular trend towards lower oil output may be hastened by sanctions on oil trade by the US, PDVSA's largest cash-paying market. Similarly, unpaid debts may lead to seizures of PDVSA's shipments or infrastructure, which would impede trade. If such measures become commonplace and/or reach Citgo, PDVSA's US-based subsidiary, exports could be disrupted indefinitely.
Regardless of the timing, what happens following the internal fracture is hard to predict. The transition is likely to be violent. The PSUV's internal stability is a concern, as the end of the current set-up is likely to unleash jostling for position between the PSUV's varied civic-military factions. If no faction secures sufficient internal consensus, a period of chaos of indeterminate duration may ensue.
Alternatively, the regime may reconfigure itself, with an outright military government or PSUV civilian figureheads fronting a military-heavy admin-istration. These would probably look to Russia and China, erstwhile backers, for aid to stabilise both the economy and PDVSA. However, we believe that the required financing-tens of billions of US dollars per year-is beyond Russia's means. Despite recent announcements, China has scaled back its financial support for Venezuela since 2015.
With these financing sources unavailable, the reconfigured regime may still reach internal stability and-given the opposition's weakness-remain in power, albeit resigned to the country's and PDVSA's impoverished state. However, given that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, stabilis-ation of PDVSA and the economy would be likely to take priority under a new government, and we expect regime pragmatists to seek western assistance-specifically from multi-laterals and governments. As these financiers will demand democratic reforms, we believe that the most likely outcome is a "mixed administration", in which pragmatically minded regime leaders allow opposition participation to gain international legitimacy. Given past behaviour, there should be no shortage of opposition figures willing to participate.
The main risk to this "mixed administration" baseline view is that regime pragmatists will be unable to convince other regime members of the benefit of this arrangement. Democratic reforms that western lenders would insist on may not be acceptable to some PSUV figures. Similarly, foreign financing would underpin a macroeconomic programme that-by eliminating the economy's distortions-would close avenues for corruption and upset regime insiders. Other hurdles of uncertain size will remain. These include the judiciary, the ANC and violent supporters of the current regime, known as colectivos. If these risks materialise in sufficient force, our alternative scenarios-a permanently impoverished nation or chaos of indeterminate duration-could materialise.
Overall, we expect a chaotic transition starting in late 2018 or early 2019. The process will be highly uncertain and may feature several false starts, and we expect the remainder of the forecast period to be characterised by political instability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Mr Maduro comfortably won re-election on May 20th. However, voter turnout was exceedingly low, at 46%, denting the president's legitimacy and introducing questions about the regime's actual control of the population. (The PSUV's get-out-the-vote operation uses a combination of ideological affinity and coercive tactics.) We do not expect free and fair elections in the short term. Based on our assumption of a new government comprised of government and opposition pragmatists, an electoral timetable may be announced, as international financing will almost certainly come with demands for democratic reforms.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Most regional governments have denounced the Venezuelan government, as has the EU. The most effective measures have come from the US, which has instituted country-level sanctions that deny Venezuela the possibility of refinancing its debts. Sanctions banning the oil trade outright are not part of our baseline assumption, but a hawkish US foreign policy team increases the risk of this happening. A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia and China. Both have provided financing in the past but seem unwilling to provide the several billions of dollars needed to stem the decline of oil output.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government remains unable and unwilling to undertake the policy changes needed to address its main challenges, namely declining oil production, hyperinflation and mounting arrears on external debt. Most sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including those of PDVSA) are now in arrears. The government has called for debt restructuring, but it appears impossible, owing to US financial sanctions and, more fundamentally, because the government lacks a credible economic programme. There is no sign yet of lawsuits by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer the hope of late payment to lengthy legal battles. Investors may also be waiting for news of policy changes or, given strains in the PSUV, a change in leadership. In the meantime, both the sovereign and PDVSA are open to legal challenges in the US. Asset seizures could hit exports, the regime's economic lifeline.
In the meantime, the government must grapple with a severe economic crisis. Monetisation of large public deficits and dwindling exports have led to foreign currency rationing and hyperinflation. The government has devalued the official exchange rate, but monetary imbalances persist and foreign-exchange continues to be rationed. Economic policy will remain interventionist in the short term, deepening the economic crisis that drives our baseline forecast of a move towards a mixed administration.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies to be implemented. However, the administration will face considerable internal limitations in addressing key policy challenges. For example, wastefulness at state-owned firms and massive corruption and clientelism schemes built around the delivery of subsidised goods and services would be hard to roll back without antagonising government backers, risking political instability. Thus, we would expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA.
Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. Internal cohesiveness in the mixed administration will be key, as the PSUV is ideologically opposed to such borrowing and multilateral financing is likely to come with conditions on democratic reforms. Meanwhile, PDVSA must open itself to foreign investment to secure the finance needed to bring output back on track. This will require considerable political capital, as it would imply a wholesale revision of the sector's institutional framework. Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV will remain a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members, who would oppose accepting international assistance and reforming policy.
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. As a result, we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published data on fiscal accounts since 2011, when the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit was 12% of GDP. We forecast an NFPS deficit of 15.5% of GDP in 2018, which will largely be financed by printing money. High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2018-22 period, ending 2022 at 7% GDP.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. In mid-July money supply (M2) grew by 65% month on month. The government has not announced any change in policy other than planning to take five zeroes off the currency. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyper-inflation, and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Amid ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-20, following an estimated contraction of 13.9% in 2017. Our forecast recovery in 2021-22 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF financial and institutional assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of the country's oil wealth at its centre. However, the reform programme will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we only expect a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of over 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also continue to contract, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in investment in the oil sector. Oil output-already in the midst of a long decline owing to mismanage-ment and underinvestment-has contracted beyond expectations in recent months; we now expect it to bottom out at 1.1m barrels/day (b/d) in late 2019, down from an average of 2m b/d in 2017. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from around 2019, oil production will start a recovery in the second half of 2020, but will remain well below 2m b/d even at the end of our forecast period in 2022. Export volumes will only start to recover in 2021, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Decimation of domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly has estimated that monthly inflation was 80% in April, bringing year-on-year inflation to over 13,000%. We expect inflation to average well over 10,000% in 2018. There is a high risk of a hyperinflationary spiral in coming months that increases inflation to well above our current forecast and necessitates a dramatic adjustment, probably involving a resort to currency substitution.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 96%. The rate is supposedly determined by an auction system, but the government-which mono-polises the country's exports-has not supplied the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible, even at the current rates. In late July the black-market exchange rate was around BsF3,500,000:US$1; the official rate stood at BsF172,800:US$1.
Given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market and growing hyperinflation, the government may, as part of a stabilisation plan, introduce a new domestic currency or attempt some kind of currency substitution in the future. Under our current political assumptions, similar measures may be undertaken after 2019. The exact nature and implementation of the plan is hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We expect the current-account surplus to reach US$12bn in 2018. This figure is buoyed by non-payment on interest on bonded debt (US$5.5bn) and our exclusion of repayments to Chinese lenders-a decision taken to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data on debt, on which our forecasts are based. We expect the government to continue to accumulate arrears into 2019. By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following a renegotiation of debt-external financing will be restored and imports will begin a recovery. We expect the surge in imports to tip the current account into a deficit of US$1.8bn (or 2.5% of GDP at the less highly-distorted exchange rate) in 2020. As the government will then be complying with its debt obligations, the restructured debt will actually mean increased outflows in interest payments. This, coupled with the slow recovery of the oil sector and years of unmet import demand, will mean that the current-account deficit will remain high, at over 4.5% of GDP on average in 2021-22.
However, we expect that the new administration will secure enough financial and investment inflows to provide sufficient financing, stabilising balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming a pragmatic mixed administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on a substantial assistance package from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-22, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Abstract: To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. The state of emergency was initially introduced after the failed coup attempt to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. Since 2016 the state of emergency has allowed the government to continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, to curtail freedoms of expression, assembly and association, and to politicise the judiciary. [...]the central government deficit, which captures most of the public-sector expenses, expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to 1.5% in 2017.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Turkey+July+2018+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2018-07-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.issn=09668632&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
On June 24th Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in snap presidential and parliamentary elections. Mr Erdogan's conserva-tive Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a coalition majority in parliament with the right-wing, Nationalist Action Party (MHP).
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to remain in power throughout the forecast period (2018-22), and possibly beyond.
Following the June elections an executive presidency now replaces the former parliamentary system of government. The new system will provide few checks on the president's powers, raising the risk of discretionary policymaking.
Since the failed coup in 2016 there has been a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a complete rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high.
Turkey's relationship with the US will deteriorate in 2018-22, owing to bilateral tensions that appear hard to resolve. The possible US imposition of sanctions on Turkish banks for evading US Iran-related sanctions is a risk.
Turkey's relationship with the EU will become increasingly transactional. Turkey will not make progress with accession talks and is unlikely to manage to renegotiate the terms of its customs union with the EU.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign-policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth from 7.3% in 2017 to about 4% per year in 2018-22, reflecting higher taxes, higher interest rates, a gradual tightening of global liquidity and more moderate export growth.
The lira will depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar throughout our forecast period, to almost TL5:US$1 at end-2022, as a result of negative foreign investors' sentiment, high inflation and a large current-account deficit.
We expect the current-account deficit to widen in 2018, to 6.7% of GDP, before contracting to a still large 4.8% per year on average in 2019-22. Turkey will struggle to meet its high external financing needs throughout our forecast period.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but in the global rankings the country falls by ten places, to 59th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, are introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2018-19: Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey not to raise interest rates significantly remains possible. Risk of the US imposing fines on several Turkish banks over alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran.
2020-22: Banking system remains stable, despite weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Spending on research and development remains moderate at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2020-22: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.
