Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe (in 1949) and NATO (in 1952), and signed an association agreement with the then European Community (in 1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following Mr Erdogan's re-election, a presidential system of government will come into effect and the prime minister position has been abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted institutional weaknesses that, with the AKP's consent until 2013, had allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports came to US$166bn and imports to US$225bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn and a current account deficit of US$47bn (or 5.6% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
On June 24th Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day Mr Erdogan's conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Both votes took place well ahead of the originally scheduled date of November 2019, as the president sought to take advantage of his current popularity. The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair-opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the candidate of the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP), Selahattin Demirtas, campaigned from prison; and the government restrains freedom of speech and freedom of association. However, the outcome of the elections appears clear; Mr Erdogan secured about 53% of the vote on a turnout of 86%. In addition, results published by opposition observers almost mirrored those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. Under the new system the president will be granted wide-ranging executive powers, including in the selection of the majority of top officials in the judiciary, while parliament will be greatly weakened. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, will remain in power until 2023, and possibly beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to clamp down on domestic political dissent and opposition. He will also seek to delegitimise and weaken the main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP). However, Mr Erdogan will probably not renew the state of emergency when it expires on July 18th. The state of emergency was initially introduced after the failed coup attempt to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. Since 2016 the state of emergency has allowed the government to continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, to curtail freedoms of expression, assembly and association, and to politicise the judiciary.
The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup appear to have eased to a large extent, but security risk remains high. Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK are interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1980s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria are seeking to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK, but risk further fuelling the conflict with the PKK in Turkey's south-east. The formation of a parliamentary coalition between the AKP and the MHP will have a detrimental effect on attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the MHP is likely to push for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP. In addition, the MHP will advocate repatriation of Syrian refugees and adopt a tough stance on all issues related to national security, in line with Mr Erdogan's ultra-nationalist and conservative views.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held on June 24th, earlier than the originally scheduled date of late 2019. The elections were brought forward in the light of high and growing economic uncertainties, the still high popularity of Mr Erdogan and the AKP, and the rise in nationalist sentiment in the context of Turkey's military operations in northern Syria.
Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round of the election, securing 52.6% of the vote on a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority but secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP. This was due to the fact that the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic party (HDP) secured more than 10% of the vote, thereby crossing the necessary threshold to enter parliament despite Mr Erdogan's repeated attempts to weaken the movement. The AKP received 42.6% of the vote; its coalition partner, the MHP, 11.1%; the CHP 22.6%; the HDP 11.7%; and the Good Party (IP) 10%.
Local elections will be held as planned on March 2019, despite recent signals from the AKP that point to an increasing possibility of bringing them forward to November or December 2018. The AKP-MHP coalition would probably have an interest in holding these elections early, while the economic situation remains favourable. However, the AKP-MHP coalition would struggle to pass the necessary constitutional amendment in parliament. The shift of focus to the local polls in the aftermath of the June elections is a sign that Turkey will remain in election mood until next year. As a result, Mr Erdogan and the AKP will refrain from making any decisions that could jeopardise the AKP's success in the local elections.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. There is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding these allies' concerns that under Mr Erdogan Turkey is pivoting eastwards towards Russia, China and Iran. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; the US's military backing of PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; tensions over gas exploration in the eastern Mediterranean; Turkey's forging of closer relations with non-Western countries; and, more recently, growing tensions with Israel in the aftermath of the US's decision to relocate its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of the country's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals-notably, to implement an executive presidential system now that he has been re-elected as president.
The country's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and increasingly transactional rather than strategic, but we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a complete breakdown in relations. However, this might become unavoidable if the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, the US imposes sanctions on Turkey over violations by Turkish banks of US sanctions against Iran, or Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces or withdraws from NATO, none of which can be ruled out. Operation Olive Branch, Turkey's crossborder military operation in Afrin in north-western Syria that was launched in January 2018, has accentuated tensions with the US. The operation cleared the area of US-backed, PKK-affiliated Kurdish groups that are intent on establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey.
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in neighbouring Syria will continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where they are co-operating but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, an intensification of domestic political instability, rising regional tensions and tightening global liquidity con-ditions could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period (2018-22).
These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements (savings have always been low), but tend to be short-term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows, triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region, have put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, most recently in May-June 2018, fuelling a sharp acceleration in inflation as well as increasing the cost to firms of servicing their foreign debt (in local currency terms) and thereby raising the risk of defaults for corporates.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards fiscal loosening and relatively tight monetary policy.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-have given the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy in the aftermath of the July 2016 attempted coup. As a result, the central government deficit, which captures most of the public-sector expenses, expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to 1.5% in 2017.
Despite a series of tax increases this year, increased government spending on defence, security, infrastructure projects, public employment and social benefits will cause the deficit to widen further, to an annual average of 3% of GDP in 2018-19, before narrowing gradually to 1.8% in 2022. We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to decline gradually, from 28.3% of GDP at end-2017 to 26.4% in 2022. Our baseline forecast is predicated on the assumption that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The Central Bank of Turkey will have to keep its monetary policy tight in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira against the US dollar amid political volatility, higher US interest rates and balance sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). A 300-basis-point rise of the late liquidity window lending rate on May 23rd, an announcement on May 28th to simplify the central bank's monetary policy framework and a further 100-basis point rise (to 17.75%) in the key lending rate on June 7th suggest that economic orthodoxy is overcoming political pressures not to raise interest rates.
We expect that the Central Bank of Turkey will gradually have additional leeway to respond to currency weakness and inflationary pressures now that Mr Erdogan has secured his re-election. However, we do not expect that this relatively larger capacity will be sufficient to enable the central bank to raise interest rates to levels that would be credible in bringing inflation down to its (highly unrealistic) 5% target. In the light of Mr Erdogan's unorthodox comments on interest rates, further political pressures against significantly tighter monetary policy cannot be ruled out. In the context of rising regional tensions, tightening global liquidity conditions and rising inflation in the short term, this could prevent the central bank from maintaining investor confidence if financial conditions deteriorate, possibly prompting the imposition of capital controls; however, this is not our baseline scenario.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply, from an annual average of 3.3% in 2016 to 7.3% in 2017, supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand.
In 2018 we expect growth to slow to 4%. This deceleration reflects the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates, a gradual tightening of global liquidity feeding into a depreciating currency (against the US dollar), increased domestic instability and higher inflation, all of which will offset planned stimulus measures to boost employment and investment. There are considerable downside risks to our forecast, stemming from foreign capital inflows being deterred by further political instability in the transition to a presidential system of government, regional tensions, domestic financial fragilities and the higher interest rate environment in advanced economies. We forecast that GDP growth will average 4.3% per year in 2019-22.
We forecast that household consumption growth will moderate from 6% of GDP in 2017 to a still solid 3.7% per year in 2018-22 as a result of higher interest rates and slower employment growth. We expect government consumption growth to accelerate from 5.1% in 2017 to an annual average of 5.8% in 2018-19, easing to a more moderate but still robust average of 4.8% in 2020-22.
The deterioration in the business environment and foreign investors' confidence since the attempted coup in July 2016, and an increase in the corporation tax rate to 22% from 2018 will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration in yearly investment growth, reflecting public-sector retrenchment and firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
The lifting in June 2017 of Russian sanctions on Turkey (especially in the tourism sector), the positive effect of a depreciating lira (against the US dollar) on export competitiveness and strong external demand have contributed to a rebound in exports of goods and services. However, we expect export growth to slow in 2018-22, owing to global trade tensions following the US decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminium imports. Our expectations of a nominal depreciation of the lira during the forecast period will dampen import growth and support external competitiveness.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation is stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target, at 15.6% year on year in June. Reflecting the political constraints on the ability of the central bank to tighten monetary policy further, the recent depreciation of the lira against the US dollar and rising global commodity prices, we believe that inflation will average 12.7% this year. We believe that inflation will decline gradually in the forecast period, reaching 8.1% at end-2022. There are significant upside risks to our revised forecast if the lira depreciates much more rapidly than we are currently forecasting.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The lira lost about 17% of its value against the US dollar in 2017. In 2018 we expect a further depreciation of about 16% in the light of high political uncertainty and decreasing foreign investors' confidence. This pace of depreciation assumes a relatively benign political environment, a mild shift by the authorities to a more conservative economic stance, a gradual tightening of global monetary conditions and relatively tight domestic monetary conditions. Shocks to any of these assumptions, such as the broad global sell-off in emerging-market assets in April-June 2018 after a faster pick-up in nominal yields in the US, would lead to a more abrupt depreciation. In 2019-22 we expect the pace of depreciation to slow in nominal terms. This will result in a mild appreciation in real terms after six consecutive years of real effective depreciations. We expect the lira to average TL4.93:US$1 in 2022, compared with TL3.65:US$1 in 2017.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Owing to particularly large trade deficits at the end of 2017 and in early 2018, the depreciation of the lira and rising global commodity prices, we expect the current-account deficit to widen from 5.6% of GDP in 2017 to 6.7% of GDP this year. However, moderating capital inflows will keep the lira weak and interest rates relatively high, contributing to a slowdown in import demand and a consequent narrowing of the current-account deficit during the forecast period. Turkey's substantial external financing needs will be difficult to meet if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates further. We expect the rebound in tourist arrivals in 2017 to continue, but they will remain vulnerable to a possible resurgence of terrorist attacks.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
An early election in October 2017 was won by the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, who has since become chancellor at the head of a majority coalition government of the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to last a full five-year term.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to significant tensions with other EU member states as it did in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition. This is largely because of the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
The new government will focus on integration and immigration policy, including by taking a prominent role on this issue within the EU. It will attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. Significant structural reforms are unlikely, owing to low government cohesion.
We forecast that the government budget will remain in deficit-albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP-throughout the 2018-22 forecast period, as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to 67.6% by 2022, from 78.2% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 3.2% in 2017. We forecast a continuation of strong growth this year, at an upwardly revised 2.9%, and for growth to moderate to 1.7% on average in 2019-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2018-22, driven by structural domestic factors, including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. We expect annual average EU harmonised inflation of 2% in 2018-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain broadly stable, at 1.8% of GDP on average in 2018-22, driven mainly by a strong surplus on the services balance, supported by tourism inflows.

Austria's business environment score rises between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22), mainly owing to the improving economy. Austria's strengths as a business location include good infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal. Risk of disruption, owing to trade dispute between the EU and the US.
2020-22: EU maintains focus on bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment continues to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Internet use remains slightly below several regional peers, but research and development remains relatively high.
2020-22: Further progress made on upgrading the large manufacturing sector to take advantage of new technologies.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic, and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government will focus on migration and integration issues, including in the EU context. It will also attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and implement other measures to improve the business environment, including through enabling more flexibility in the labour market.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: Trade relations are dominated by Germany, which accounts for about one-third of total imports and exports. The current-account surplus is driven by strong tourism exports boosting the services surplus. We expect modest current-account surpluses throughout the forecast period.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The governing coalition consists of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this coalition to prove relatively stable and to sit out its full term until 2022. This follows several years of little progress on reforms and coalition (as well as party) in-fighting under the grand coalition of the ÖVP and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ), which fell apart in May 2017. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP, reformed the party around himself, and moved it closer to the FPÖ on issues such as immigration and integration. As a result, he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election in October last year, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on the party's result in 2013. The SPÖ's share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The FPÖ increased its share of the vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5%, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
In mid-December, after just over a month and a half of negotiations, the ÖVP and the FPÖ formed a coalition. Under Mr Kurz, the ÖVP has moved closer to the FPÖ in many policy areas, and the negotiations therefore went relatively smoothly. To assuage concerns from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Moreover, EU policy is handled by the chancellery instead of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is headed by an FPÖ appointee.
The chancellor is from the ÖVP, but the election was nevertheless a decisive moment in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has, to a large extent, been replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties had together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, but a renewed grand coalition had become almost impossible following a breakdown in relations and the reform gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz also owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue, and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP's and the FPÖ's programmes, we do not expect the government to implement significant structural reforms, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, on which they are significantly less well aligned than they are on social and cultural matters. In addition, the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on topics such as immigration and integration into firm policy proposals. The initial phase of the government's term is likely to be relatively smooth, owing in part to the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union until the end of 2018. Later in the term, the FPÖ might struggle to distinguish itself from the ÖVP, which could lead to tensions between the parties, creating a moderate risk of an early election.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The most recent general election was held on October 15th 2017. We expect the government to remain in office until the end of its term, which ends in late 2022, maintaining its majority in the Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament). There is a risk of an early election, although we believe that the probability of a snap vote is small. The next election for the, primarily ceremonial, post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this inflow, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. The new government plans to cut child benefit payments flowing abroad, potentially leading to tensions with eastern member states in particular.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that his government will be pro-EU, and that Austria's EU membership will not be questioned in the coming years. The government intends Austria to be a leading voice in the bloc, especially on migration reform, which should be facilitated by the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union. We expect the government to move forward with proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ into government, in 2000, led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations, the reception has been more muted this time. In that period, a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands. However, this will, at times, lead to tensions with fellow EU members, as shown by the fact that a number of countries are now sharing less intelligence with Austria because the ministries concerned are headed by the FPÖ.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The new government plans to move integration and immigration policy further to the right, including through curtailing benefits for asylum-seekers and cutting child benefits that are sent abroad. It has also presented plans that focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing corporate tax rates and introducing more flexible working hours. Furthermore, it plans to cut a number of labour market programmes aimed at the long-term unemployed and integrating migrants into the labour market. Although it has announced a push to centralise and streamline the welfare system-to which several major stakeholders, including state governors, are likely to object-it does not plan to reform the so-called Proporz system, under which the ÖVP and the SPÖ had apportioned public entities and functions (state companies, public services, subsidies and regulatory responsibilities). This is despite suggestions from both coalition parties-especially the FPÖ-in the past that they would want to do this. We therefore expect reform momentum to be limited and that the government will struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Driven by both a lacklustre recovery following the financial and euro zone crises and a lack of fiscal consolidation, the fiscal accounts have remained in modest deficit in recent years and within the 3% of GDP limit set by the EU. Strong growth contributed to a narrowing of the deficit to 0.7% of GDP in 2017.
The government plans to achieve a small budget surplus in 2019 by cutting spending, and through reducing income taxes and the country's sizeable tax wedge. However, it has not yet clearly outlined the spending cuts that it intends to make, barring a number of smaller measures, including cutting spending on asylum-seekers, and we therefore do not share the government's optimism that a surplus can be reached in 2019. Nevertheless, continued robust economic growth will contribute to a further narrowing of the deficit in the coming years; we expect it to average 0.4% of GDP in 2018-22.
The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from 78.2% in 2017 to 67.6% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain worse than in countries such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low interest-rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low, in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The programme will run at EUR15bn per month in October-December before coming to an end. Economic activity in the euro zone has softened in early 2018, but the ECB's view of the outlook remains fairly positive. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate, to 0.25%, in early 2020, followed by five more rises that lift the main refinancing rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but the economy subsequently stalled and underperformed compared with regional peers, notably Germany. This was particularly striking, given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltering reform process in recent years contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers, and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. However, the economic recovery gained significant momentum from the second half of 2016. Although, in previous years, the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, owing in part to a surge in employment in the manufacturing sector. We expect a continued gradual improvement in labour market indicators in the coming years. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.8% this year. Export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, real GDP growth was 3.2% in 2017-above the level in Germany for the first time since 2005, and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-after an underperformance compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue this year, although we forecast slower real GDP growth, of 2.9%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to have largely been a one-off. Nevertheless, increasing labour shortages will contribute to business investment pushing up investment growth in the first half of our five-year forecast period. Driven by the improvement of the labour market, domestic demand will be the main driver of growth. In the following years we expect a further moderation of growth, to 1.6% on average in 2020-22, around the economy's potential growth rate. Government policy is likely to be supportive of growth in the coming years, and the main risks are external. As a highly open economy, Austria is vulnerable to global economic developments. We expect the impact of the trade dispute between the EU and the US to be limited for Austria. However, an escalation beyond one more round of mutual tariff imposition, including on automotive imports by the US, continues to pose a significant downside risk to the outlook.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets, and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy price base effects caused a gradual increase in inflation in 2017, leading to a full-year average of 2.2%. The recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect price growth to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors seen in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
For most of 2015-16 the euro moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1, before a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the US presidential election led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1 in 2016. However, in 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018 but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and remained close to that level in June. The value of the euro could yet come under further pressure from political risk in Italy, and also from monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a broad stabilisation on average, at US$1.21:EUR1 in 2018-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. Thereafter, we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values have helped the trade balance to move into surplus in recent years, from a deficit in 2009-13. However, the increase in oil prices in 2017 pushed it back into a modest deficit. We expect the trade account to remain slightly in deficit throughout the forecast period. The main driver of the current-account surplus will therefore be the healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourist inflows. This will ensure that the current-account surplus remains broadly unchanged throughout 2018-22, at 1.8% of GDP on average.

Country Forecast Venezuela July 2018 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-venezuela-july-2018-updater/docview/2067486994/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. [...]wastefulness at state-owned firms and massive corruption and clientelism schemes built around the delivery of subsidised goods and services would be hard to roll back without antagonising government backers, risking political instability. [...]we would expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA. [...]we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. [...]we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2018-22 period, ending 2022 at 6.8% GDP.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+July+2018+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2018-07-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Economic collapse and the erosion of the patronage scheme supporting the president, Nicolás Maduro, put the ruling regime's internal cohesion in jeopardy. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a traumatic rift that will end in regime pragmatists allowing opposition participation in a "mixed admin-istration" as a way to remain in power from 2019 onwards. There is a risk that the regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,000% at the end of 2017 and will average over 10,000% in 2018. GDP will continue to contract in 2018-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate a fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 82th position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings, making it the least attractive investment location in the world. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition. Property rights remain weak.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Opaque currency controls add to uncertainty, severely restrict private-sector access to foreign exchange and impede trade. New government in 2019 starts removing exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Amid severely high inflation, financing remains only available in the short term and banking sector shrinks in real terms.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Underinvestment in the water and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing
Technological readiness
2018-19: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies.
2020-22: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is how to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 1.3% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Despite a decimated economy and spiralling hyperinflation, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) and the president, Nicolás Maduro, retain their hold on power. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition, most likely ushering in a government with nominal opposition participation-a "mixed administration"-in 2019.
The opposition, of which the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) is the biggest grouping, remains in disarray. Apart from infighting, this reflects the PSUV's systematic campaign to disfranchise opposition parties and sideline them from state institutions. After years of ineffectual leadership, most citizens, even those opposing the PSUV, distrust opposition parties. This has left them incapable of channelling the anti-government sentiment brewing in response to the country's dire economic situation.
In this context of unrest and repression, the PSUV is increasingly dependent on the military for support. The country is run by civic-military alliance and a network of businessmen that enjoy military or political connections. The accord is sustained by opportunities for arbitrage and corruption made possible by foreign-exchange controls; subsidised imports of basic goods; and control of large and inefficient public-sector companies. Within this opaque arrangement, factions are primarily explained by personal and patronage ties, which mean that different civic-military factions coexist within the regime. The ultimate source of resources flowing through this patronage system is PDVSA, the state-owned oil company, whose exports account for the vast majority of foreign-exchange inflows.
Jeopardising the arrangement is a rapid decline in oil production due to mismanagement and underinvestment. Resultant strains have been highlighted by purges of the military, the latest coming in March. Furthermore, in June Mr Maduro reshuffled key positions in the administration, giving increased power to Diosdado Cabello, a long-time internal rival who has extensive military and business ties; Mr Cabello will now lead the Constituent Assembly (ANC, the country's de facto legislature). We interpret this as Mr Maduro attempting to regain internal support, even at the expense of personal power. Mr Cabello is a leading figure in the regime, but other factions within the PSUV also exist. Unless the administration turns PDVSA around (we see this as unlikely, as the government lacks the required expertise or financing), we believe that the patronage system supporting Mr Maduro will be at risk of collapse by 2019.
Internal fracture in the regime may happen earlier than 2019, as the secular trend towards lower oil output may be hastened by sanctions on oil trade by the US, PDVSA's largest cash-paying market. Following Mr Maduro's victory in an internationally repudiated presidential election on May 20th, the US rolled out sanctions designed to complicate PDVSA's exports. Similarly, PDVSA's unpaid debts may lead to asset seizures that impede trade. In May ConocoPhillips, a US firm pursuing collection of an arbitration award, seized PDVSA's infrastructure in the Caribbean, disrupting exports. The parties are reportedly negotiating an agreement and some seizures have been reversed, but if such measures become commonplace and/or reach Citgo, PDVSA's US subsidiary, exports could be disrupted indefinitely.
Regardless of the timing, what happens following the internal fracture is hard to predict. The transition is likely to be violent. The PSUV's internal stability is a concern, as the end of the current set-up is likely to unleash jostling for position between the PSUV's varied civic-military factions. If no faction secures sufficient internal consensus, a period of chaos of indeterminate duration may ensue. Alternatively, the regime may reconfigure itself, with an outright military government or PSUV civilian figureheads fronting a military-heavy admin-istration. Such administrations would probably look to Russia and China, erstwhile backers, for aid to stabilise both the economy and PDVSA. However, we believe that the required financing-tens of billions of US dollars per year-is beyond Russia's means. China has scaled back its relations with Venezuela since 2015. Given that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, stabilisation of PDVSA and the economy would be likely to take priority under a new government, and we would expect regime pragmatists to seek western assistance-specifically from multilaterals and governments. As these financiers will demand democratic reforms, we believe that the most likely outcome is a "mixed administration", in which pragmatically minded military and PSUV leaders allow opposition participation as a way of gaining inter-national legitimacy. Given past behaviour, there should be no shortage of opposition figures willing to participate.
The main risk to our baseline view is that regime pragmatists will be unable to convince other regime members of the benefit of this arrangement. Democratic reforms that western lenders would insist on may not be acceptable to some PSUV figures. Similarly, foreign financing would underpin a macroeconomic programme that-by eliminating the economy's distortions-would close avenues for corruption and upset regime insiders. Other hurdles of uncertain size will remain. These include the judiciary, the ANC and violent extremist supporters of the current regime known as colectivos.
Overall, we expect a chaotic transition starting in late 2018 or early 2019. The process will be highly uncertain and may feature several false starts. We expect curtailed political stability in 2019-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Mr Maduro comfortably won re-election on May 20th. However, voter turnout was exceedingly low, at 46%, denting his legitimacy and introducing questions about the regime's actual control of the population. (The PSUV's turn-out-the-vote operation uses a combination of ideological affinity and coercive tactics.) We do not expect free and fair elections in the short term. Based on our assumption of a new government comprised of government and opposition pragmatists, an electoral timetable may be announced, as international financing will almost certainly come with demands for democratic reforms.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Most regional governments have denounced the Venezuelan government, as has the EU. The most effective sanctions have come from the US, which has instituted country-level sanctions that deny Venezuela the possibility of refinancing its debts. Sanctions banning the oil trade outright are not part of our baseline assumption, but a hawkish US foreign policy team increases the risk of this happening. A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia and China. Both have provided financing in the past, but seem unwilling to provide the several billions of dollars needed to stem the decline of oil output.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government remains unable and unwilling to undertake the policy changes needed to address its main challenges, namely declining oil production, hyperinflation and mounting arrears on external debt. Most sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including those of PDVSA) are now in arrears. The government has called for debt restructuring, but it appears impossible, owing to US financial sanctions and, more fundamentally, because the government lacks a credible economic programme. There is no sign yet of lawsuits by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer the promise of late payment to lengthy legal battles. Investors may also be waiting for news of policy changes following the May election or a change in leadership. In the meantime, both the sovereign and PDVSA are open to legal challenges in the US. Such seizures could hit exports, the regime's economic lifeline.
In the meantime, the government must grapple with a severe economic crisis. Monetisation of large public deficits and dwindling exports have led to foreign currency rationing and hyper-inflation. The government has devalued the official exchange rate, but monetary imbal-ances persist and foreign-exchange continues to be rationed. Economic policy will remain interventionist in the short term, deepening the economic crisis that drives our baseline forecast of a move towards a mixed administration.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect more orthodox economic policies to be implemented. However, the administration will face considerable internal limitations in addressing key policy challenges. For example, wastefulness at state-owned firms and massive corruption and clientelism schemes built around the delivery of subsidised goods and services would be hard to roll back without antagonising government backers, risking political instability. Thus, we would expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA.
Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. Internal cohesiveness in the mixed administration will be key, as the PSUV is ideologically opposed to such borrowing and multilateral financing is likely to come with conditions on democratic reforms. Meanwhile, PDVSA must open itself to foreign investment to secure the finance needed to bring output back on track. This will require considerable political capital, as it would imply a wholesale revision of the sector's institutional framework. Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV will remain a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members, who would oppose accepting international assistance and reforming policy.
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. As a result, we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published data on fiscal accounts since 2011, when the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit was 12% of GDP. We forecast an NFPS deficit of 15.5% of GDP in 2018, which will largely be financed by printing money. High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2018-22 period, ending 2022 at 6.8% GDP.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. At the end of May M2 increased by 6,297% year on year. The government has not announced any change in policy other than planning to take three zeroes off the currency. However, the plan has been put on hold for logistical reasons. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation, and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Amid ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-20, following an estimated contraction of 13.9% in 2017. Our forecast recovery in 2021-22 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF financial and institutional assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of the country's oil wealth at its centre. However, the reform programme will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we only expect a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of over 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract as well, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in investment in the oil sector. Oil output-already in the midst of a long decline owing to mismanagement and underinvestment-has contracted beyond expectations in recent months; we now expect it to bottom out at 1.2m barrels/day (b/d) in early 2020, down from an average of 1.95m b/d in 2017. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from around 2019, oil production will start a recovery in the second half of 2020, but will remain well below 2m b/d even at the end of our forecast period in 2022. Export volumes will only start to recover in 2021, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly has estimated that monthly inflation was 80% in April, bringing year-on-year inflation to over 13,000%. We expect inflation to average over 10,000% in 2018. There is a high risk of a hyperinflationary spiral in coming months that increases inflation to well above our current forecast and necessitates a dramatic adjustment, probably involving a resort to currency substitution.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 95%. The rate is supposedly determined by an auction system, but the government-which mono-polises the country's exports-has not supplied the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible, even at the current rates. In late June the black-market exchange rate was around BsF2,600,000:US$1; the official rate stood at BsF96,000:US$1.
Given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market and growing hyperinflation, the government may, as part of a stabilisation plan, introduce a new domestic currency or attempt some kind of currency substitution in the future. Under our current political assumptions, similar measures may be undertaken after 2019. The exact nature and implementation of the plan is hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We expect the current-account surplus to reach US$5.6bn in 2018 (2.4% of GDP at the distorted exchange rate, which overstates the GDP in dollar terms), owing to continued import compression. However, Venezuela's lack of access to foreign finance means that the current-account surplus will not be enough to meet the country's financing needs. Indeed, excluding arrears, we calculate that principal repayments of sovereign and state-owned companies' bonded debt alone will amount to US$3.5bn in 2018. As such, we expect further arrears in 2018 and 2019. By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following a debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored and imports will begin a recovery. We expect the surge in imports to tip the current account into a deficit of 6.2% of GDP in 2020 at a less highly distorted exchange rate. The restructured interest payment schedule will mean lower outflows, but the slow recovery of the oil sector and years of unmet import demand will mean that the current-account deficit will remain high, at over 4.5% of GDP in 2021-22.
Assuming that a new administration takes power from around 2019, we expect financial and investment inflows to provide sufficient financing, stabilise balance-of-payments dynamics and help to rebuild reserves coverage. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming a pragmatic unity government capable of retaining power, it hinges on a substantial assistance package from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-22, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The ruling centre-right Cambiemos coalition government is under increasing political pressure amid recent currency volatility and an IMF bailout (the Fund is unpopular in Argentina), but will be hoping to get its policy agenda back on track in time for the presidential election, when the president, Mauricio Macri, will seek a second term. However, the opposition will increasingly obstruct policy. Cambiemos lacks a congressional majority, meaning that the administration has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda on an ad hoc basis with various factions of Argentina's dominant Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party).
Currency depreciation pressure amid an emerging-market sell-off has introduced substantial political uncertainty, but major changes to economic policymaking are not envisaged under the terms of the IMF lending arrangement, other than a more rapid tightening of fiscal policy. The US$50bn stand-by arrangement was approved on June 20th and includes targets for a tightening of fiscal policy to produce a primary fiscal balance by 2020 (in order to contain growth in the public debt/GDP ratio and reduce inflationary deficit financing), and provisions for central-bank target independence to be enshrined in law, to help to tackle the inflation problem (the root of Argentina's external competitiveness problem, which is in turn driving devaluation pressures). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that programme targets will be met, and will gradually reduce inflation and engender macro-economic stability over time.
A spike in interest rates and a tightening of fiscal policy amid currency pressures will weigh on economic activity, and we have revised our forecast for real GDP growth in 2018 to 0.8%, down from 1.6% previously. For now, our view of medium-term GDP growth remains broadly unchanged, although the risks to our forecasts have risen substantially. Under our benign baseline forecast, we expect growth to fluctuate around 3% in 2020-22.
More front-loaded currency weakening than previously projected will provide some boost to external competitiveness, but even so, the current-account deficit will remain large in 2018, and import cover will dip from 7.6 months to around seven months this year. Thereafter, we expect the current-account deficit to narrow steadily to below 3% of GDP in 2022.
Argentina's GDP per head is among the highest in the region and, combined with improved access to credit, moderate rates of economic growth in the medium term will boost purchasing power and create market opportunities. Still-high poverty rates and income inequality will restrict the pool of consumers, but to a lesser extent than in many other countries in the region

Argentina's global business environment score improves in 2018-22, and the country jumps 12 places in The Economist Intelligence Unit's global ranking. Economic policy adjustment is under way as the government works to tighten macro-economic policy, reduce state intervention in the private sector and encourage private investment. But in many areas improvements will take time to materialise.
Country forecast overview: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2020-22: Continued work to build faith in legal and regulatory frameworks. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2018-19: Proactive, welcoming approach to foreign investment. Attempts to resolve outstanding disputes with creditors.
2020-22: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance, comprising Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.
2020-22: Possibility that new free-trade agreements are signed with the EU and Canada.
Taxes
2018-19: Further gradual reductions of export taxes to encourage domestic supply. Tax reforms to promote investment and reduce tax pressure.
2020-22: Comprehensive tax reform to improve federal-provincial revenue sharing a possibility, but obstacles to reform persist. System remains complex, despite recent reforms.
Financing
2018-19: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2020-22: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2018-19: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of unions remains strong.
2020-22: Limited progress on labour reform. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2018-19: The Macri administration continues to improve contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes.
2020-22: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Quality of e-commerce business environment is good. Upgrade of 4G capabilities.
2020-22: More progress on increasing scope of e-government as part of process to reduce red tape. Increase in research and development spending as percentage of GDP, but still relatively low compared with more developed markets.

Background: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983, after 50 years of instability and military regimes. Economic liberalisation in the 1990s drove firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and fail-ure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of Fernando de la Rúa's centre-left government. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party) began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanage-ment drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015.
Political structure: A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house); in practice, however, the presidency dominates. The presidential term is four years. There are 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district, each with its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies and the commodity supercycle contributed to GDP growth of an annual average 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to controls and ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. These policies did not reduce devaluation speculation, and left the economy extremely vulnerable to currency crisis. Macroeconomic adjustments to try to reduce economic distortions are taking place under Mr Macri; these include the shift to a free float at the end of 2015, fiscal and monetary tightening, and reforms to boost domestic supply, but the pace of adjustment has been insufficient to prevent severe currency pressure, and in mid-2018 the government was forced to turn to the IMF for a stand-by lending arrangement involving tighter fiscal targets.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at a lower rate of 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. Under a tax reform approved at end-2017, the corporate income tax rate will fall to 30% in 2019 and 25% in 2021. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions (deposits and withdrawals).
Foreign trade: The current account moved from surplus to deficit in 2010. By 2017 the deficit had widened to 4.8% of GDP.
