Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Argentina was hit hard by an emerging-market sell-off in May, and although turbulence in the foreign-exchange market has subsided with the announce-ment of a US$50bn IMF stand-by lending arrangement, recent developments could have lasting political consequences for the government. The Fund is supportive of Argentina, and The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect dramatic changes in the course of economic policy, which is already geared towards macroeconomic and microeconomic reforms to restore stability and promote more solid, stable economic growth. The problem for the president, Mauricio Macri, and his ruling centre-right Cambiemos coalition, is that the Fund has a very poor reputation in Argentina, reflecting its role before and after the country's deep economic crisis of 2001-02. Argentina's return to the Fund will, therefore, weigh on the government's approval ratings, and will embolden the opposition, with less than 18 months to go until the presidential election.
The government will be hoping to get its policy agenda back on track in time for the presidential election, when Mr Macri will seek a second term. However, the opposition will be smelling blood and will increasingly obstruct policy. Cambiemos lacks a congressional majority, meaning that the administration has to negotiate legislative support on an ad hoc basis with various factions of the Partido Justicialista (PJ, the Peronist party). The PJ, which dominated politics for decades before Mr Macri's election victory in 2015, is struggling to regroup from that defeat and is beset by internal divisions. The party is currently split between a left-wing, populist faction and a centrist faction that, as yet, has no single, clear leader. The PJ's divisions have until now worked in the government's favour, allowing the government to pursue its legislative agenda with the support of moderate Peronists. Moreover, until now Mr Macri has remained relatively popular, with voters giving him the benefit of the doubt on the need for economic adjustment. But patience is wearing thin.
In this environment, the opposition will begin manoeuvring for position ahead of the presidential election, and the government will struggle to push its agenda through. In the aftermath of its strong performance in the October 2017 mid-terms, the government moved quickly to pass reforms to the tax system, pensions and competition policy (and in May managed to pass capital market reforms). But in coming months, major reforms will be on hold, and opposition challenges to policy initiatives that are presented will increase. All this means that much-needed reforms to increase the flexibility of labour markets, improve the effective-ness of the judiciary, and enhance investor confidence in institutions and contract rights will be on the back burner. On our current assumption that Mr Macri wins a second term in 2019, we expect that improvements in these areas will start to yield results more clearly late on in our five-year forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The next presidential election is due in October 2019. Notwithstanding the president's current difficulties, we currently continue to assume that Mr Macri will win a second four-year term, based on our assumption of a recovery in GDP and a substantial reduction of inflation by then. There are large, and growing, risks to this forecast. Reflecting the difficulties faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist government has won a second consecutive term since the end of the military dictatorship in the 1980s. The emergence of a strong challenger from the Peronist party is therefore likely (although it is as yet unclear who this will be), and the election will be closely fought.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
We expect relations with key international partners to remain strong under the Macri administration. The country took over the rotating presidency of the G20 in December 2017, and is pursuing an agenda centred on the future of jobs, infrastructure and food security; although limited progress on this agenda is likely in a difficult international environment, Argentina's holding of the G20 presidency is another important milestone in the government's efforts to restore Argentina's international image. The government is keen to seek trade deals under the auspices of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union). The problem for Argentina and its Mercosur partners is that, just as the grouping has started to reverse its own protectionist tendencies, anti-globalisation sentiment has grown in the OECD. However, Mr Macri is continuing to seek support for an EU-Mercosur trade deal from his counterparts in Europe, and negotiations are continuing, although they are slow moving. In the meantime, Mercosur members including Argentina have pushed for free-trade negotiations elsewhere, including with Canada and China, and for closer relations with the Pacific Alliance free-trade area.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Currency depreciation pressure amid an emerging-market sell-off has intro-duced substantial political uncertainty, but major changes to economic policymaking are not envisaged under the terms of the three-year, US$50bn IMF stand-by arrangement (SBA), other than a more rapid tightening of fiscal policy. The govern-ment has made progress since it came to office at the end of 2015 and began grappling with the task of restoring macroeconomic stability while improving conditions for business. But macroeconomic adjustment is clearly incomplete: inflation came in at 26.3% in May, amid continued utilities tariff rises (intended to reduce the fiscal burden of subsidies), and the fiscal deficit remains substantial, at 6% of GDP in 2017.
Still-high inflation has contributed to currency overvaluation, which has in turn produced a large and growing current-account deficit. These imbalances have contributed to the sharp peso adjustment of the past two months, and to the government's decision to seek an IMF lending deal to restore market confidence. The US$50bn SBA was approved on June 20th and an initial disbursement of US$15bn was made available immediately for deficit financing and to help to restore reserves coverage ratios. The government may treat the deal as precautionary going forward, and future drawdowns will depend on market access. The deal includes targets for a tightening of fiscal policy to produce a primary fiscal balance by 2020 (in order to contain growth in the public debt/GDP ratio and reduce inflationary deficit financing), and provisions for central-bank target independence to be enshrined in law, to help to tackle the inflation problem (the root of Argentina's external competitiveness problem, which is in turn driving devaluation pressures).
We expect that programme targets will be met, and will gradually reduce inflation and engender macro-economic stability over time. This will have positive implications for the external sector and growth. The biggest risks to this outlook are political, and reflect the possibility that voter (as well as business) confidence in the Macri admin-istration and the economic outlook feeds into further market volatility and economic activity. This would not only complicate the adjustment process, but also threaten our assumption that Mr Macri will secure a second term in power, raising questions as to the future direction of economic policy under a new government.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In its first two years of office the government pursued gradual fiscal tightening (so as not to thwart economic growth), but, in the face of market pressure, it has now accelerated the pace of adjustment under the auspices of the Fund deal. The fiscal targets set out in the deal were broadly in line with our expectations and allow for a relatively gradual adjustment, partly reflecting provisions that allow for increased social safety net expenditure. For 2018 the primary fiscal deficit target is 2.7% of GDP, for 2019 it is 1.3% of GDP, and for 2020 the government is targeting primary fiscal balance. Bearing in mind that the government beat its fiscal target in the first five months of 2018 by a substantial margin, the 2018 target should not be difficult to meet, although it will require cuts to planned capital spending, which will have a knock-on impact on economic growth. Apart from capital spending, expenditure restraint will come via a phasing out of costly energy subsidies and the recent approval of a social security reform that will produce substantial savings (0.4% of GDP per year from 2018). The biggest risks to meeting the fiscal target centre on the government's ability to maintain public-sector wage restraint amid above-target inflation and strong public-sector union power, as well as below-target revenue, reflecting a sharp deceleration of economic activity this year.
The government is-for now at least-facing a problem with liquidity rather than solvency. We assume that despite this liquidity problem, deficit financing will not prove problematic, owing to the IMF deal, and assuming that market access improves from 2019 as currency pressure subsides. Argentina's recent upgrade from "frontier" to "emerging" market status in the MSCI index (MSCI is an index provider whose classifications are widely used by global investors), will also help in the medium term, by allowing for increased capital inflows from institutional investors. All that said, the public debt/GDP ratio is likely to continue to rise in 2018 to just over 60% of GDP, before stabilising in the remainder of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the central bank) has tight-ened monetary policy sharply to help to stem currency pressures, and will unwind its rate rises only very slowly. Over little more than a week at the start of May the bank raised the policy rate by 1,275 basis points, to 40%. Further currency depreciation is possible in the short term, and further rate rises remain a risk (although for now we expect rates to stay on hold). Recent sharp policy tightening and a rebuilding of reserves following the disbursement of the first tranche of IMF funds should restore some calm, allowing the central bank to begin to unwind its dramatic rate rise over the next few months. This process will be complicated, however, by weak confidence in the nascent inflation-targeting regime, which means that inflation expectations are not well anchored and pass-through from currency depreciation into consumer prices is relatively high. Persistently weak confidence in the inflation target led in June to the departure of the central bank president, Federico Sturzenegger, in an effort to restore credibility in policymaking. His replacement, the former finance minister, Luis Caputo, is well known and well regarded, but, more than staffing changes, real progress on disinflation will be required to restore confidence in monetary policymaking.
The BCRA has been clear in its view that current price pressures are temporary, and we share this view. But in the meantime, the latest steep peso slide will feed through to a spike in prices in May-July. We do still expect monthly inflation to start to ease towards 1% on a con-sistent basis late in 2018, once the effects of currency depreciation and tariff adjustment start to fade. This should allow for gradual monetary easing beginning in the fourth quarter and continuing for an extended period thereafter, providing for moderately positive real interest rates in the medium term.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Reflecting data for April showing the substantial impact of a severe drought on economic activity we have made a further downward revision to our growth forecast for 2018, from 1.6% to 0.8%. This forecast represents a dramatic change from the start of the year, when market expectations were for growth of over 3%, and demonstrates that Argentina's economic output is not yet sufficiently diversified to withstand the impact of drought on the important agricultural sector (agriculture accounts for a fairly hefty 11% of GDP, and agro-industry is also important to the economy). On top of drought, output is likely to be effected at mid-year by tighter macroeconomic policy and the jolt to confidence following the currency turmoil and IMF bail-out. Our forecasts currently assume that activity will follow the pattern of previous severe droughts and will begin to recover in the third quarter. Reflecting this positive carryover effect, and assuming a return to normal harvest levels next year, (as well as a restoration of confidence as disinflation begins), we now expect GDP growth to reach 3% in 2019. For both 2018 and 2019 there is an unusually high degree of uncertainty attached to our forecasts. There is, on the one hand, a not insubstantial risk that policy tightening on top of drought tips Argentina into full-blown recession. But, on the other hand, activity could rebound more quickly than we currently have pencilled into our forecasts if real currency adjustment prompts a more rapid than expected impetus to export manufacturing activity.
For now our forecasts for the second part of the forecast period (2020-22) are unchanged, although the risks to these forecasts have risen substantially. Under our benign baseline forecast, we expect growth to fluctuate around 3% in 2020-22, dipping below 3% in 2020 amid a projected cyclical downturn in the US, before accelerating back above 3% in 2021-22. This projected acceleration in 2021-22 rests on the assumption that that implementation of recently passed and ongoing structural reforms will gradually boost economic activity. There is increasing downside risk to this assumption, in the form of a weakening of consumer and business confidence, and the potential for a much more tense presidential election period in 2019.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
The reduction of inflation will continue to be complicated in the short term by gradual increases in utilities tariffs as these are brought closer in line with market prices. On top of this, rapid recent peso depreciation, in a context of unanchored inflation expectations, will produce substantial pass-through effects, keeping inflation high in the very short term. However, assuming that macroeconomic policy remains tight under the auspices of the IMF deal, domestic demand remains subdued relative to the boom years of 2004-11, and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environment for agricultural and other producers, we continue to expect gradual disinflation in the medium term. It will take quite some time, however, for inflation to fall to single-digit levels. According to our baseline forecast, this will happen towards the end of 2020.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The peso has been badly hit in the past three months as investors that had previously given the administration the benefit of the doubt over its ability to reverse macroeconomic imbalances zeroed in on the country's large fiscal and current-account deficits. The latter reflects clear overvaluation of the peso, a problem that worsened last year as huge inflows of portfolio capital produced real currency appreciation. As a result, at end-2017 the real effective exchange rate was 14% stronger than the average of the previous 20 years. Recent currency adjustment will go some way to reversing this trend, assuming that disinflation occurs as expected from late 2018. In the short term, we believe that co-ordinated efforts by the government and the central bank to regain the confidence of investors will be successful in preventing further uncontrolled devaluation of the peso in coming weeks. However, we expect the peso to continue to depreciate in both nominal and real terms, to address the problem of currency overvaluation. Under our baseline forecast, the currency will depreciate to Ps28.96:US$1 at end-2018 and Ps38.52:US$1 at end-2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
More front-loaded currency weakening than previously projected will provide some boost to external competitiveness, but even so, in 2018 the current-account deficit will remain large, with the boost to net exports of goods and services becoming more evident from 2019. Even in 2022 we expect the current-account deficit to remain substantial (although more manageable), at 2.8% of GDP. After a period of huge inflows of portfolio capital in 2016-17, access to finance will be trickier and more costly in 2018-19; meanwhile, inflows of foreign direct investment will average an unspectacular 2.1% of GDP in 2018-22. This introduces risks to our assumption that import cover will continue to improve gradually over the medium term, although inflows of IMF credit will be supportive of reserves.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing Independent Greeks (AE)-has a two-seat majority in the 300-seat parliament. The government is vulnerable to further defections and there is a significant risk of an early election (the next election is due by September 2019). The centre-right New Democracy (ND) would probably win the most seats and form a coalition government.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Greece to remain subject to strict policy conditionality over the medium term and until Greece's debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests over labour market reforms, pension cuts, privatisation, and tax and social security increases are likely to continue as the government strives to meet the ambitious annual primary surplus budget target of 3.5% of GDP until 2022, as agreed with Greece's euro zone creditors.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge after it exits the bail-out programme. How the economy performs during the transition will determine whether Greece will remain in the euro zone. We assess the risk of it leaving the euro zone by 2022 at more than 50%, given the difficulties that the country will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. We expect that public debt will still equal about 170% of GDP in 2022.
Greece does not face any short-term financing difficulties as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments for almost two years after it exits the bail-out programme in August 2018. However, the challenges posed by the very high public debt burden and a poor growth outlook mean that Grexit will remain a significant risk over the medium and long term.
We forecast that annual average inflation will edge down from 1.1% in 2017 to 0.7% in 2018, before accelerating to an annual average of 1.5% in 2019-22, reflecting higher oil prices and a pick-up in domestic demand. These trends will result in widening, but still moderate, current-account deficits in 2018-22.

Greece's score recovers modestly in our 2018-22 forecast period, from a low base. The main areas of improvement are expected in the macroeconomic environment and efforts to improve policy towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition, and the labour market.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The country's privatisation agency, under new management, gains momentum. Deals start to make progress.
2020-22: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make little progress.
2020-22: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eased gradually. The risk of Greece leaving the euro area and reintroducing exchange controls and, possibly, restrictions on trade will remain high after exit from the European Stability Mechanism (ESM).
2020-22: There is a 60% risk of Greece leaving the euro area if growth continues to disappoint.
Taxes
2018-19: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is tough. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2020-22: Small progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up, independence of the tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2018-19: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Steps to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) painfully slow, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2020-22: Lending hampered by need to make provisions for still high NPL portfolios. Greece's main banks sell more of their overseas subsidiaries. Some form of normalcy in sight towards the end of the forecast period (2018-22).
The labour market
2018-19: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2020-22: EU-funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2020-22: Despite technical assistance from the EU, problems with absorption persist.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2020-22: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

a Actual.
Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule, Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of EMU in question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters have blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme. In 2012 public debt held by the private sector was restructured. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. After Greece exits the programme when it expires in August 2018, the country will be subject to much closer scrutiny by its creditors than other EU member states have been after they exited their programmes.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 29% and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR27.9bn (US$33.5bn) and imports (fob) amounted to EUR46.3bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR1.4bn, equivalent to 0.8% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The coalition government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE)-has survived since September 2015, despite having only a slim majority in the 300-seat parliament. Following the defection of two members of the AE, in protest at the agreement on the 27-year Macedonia name dispute, the government's majority has been reduced to two seats. Mr Tsipras will aim to see through his parliamentary term, but the government will be vulnerable to further defections ahead of the next parliamentary election (due by September 2019). The name issue in particular has the potential to destabilise the government.
In August 2015 the government tied its acceptance of bail-out reforms under a three-year (2015-18) programme through the European Stability Mechanism (ESM, an inter-governmental assistance fund for countries in the euro zone), the country's third since 2010, to obtain debt relief from its official creditors. Almost three years later, the government is on the verge of exiting the programme, but it has lost much popular support along the way. Mr Tsipras is hoping to revive his party's political fortunes once Greece exits the programme, having secured further debt relief, and will be hoping that economic growth gains momentum over the coming year.
Tensions within the government coalition will persist on a range of issues, including the "enhanced surveillance" to which Greece will be subject once it exits the bail-out programme; continued implementation of austerity measures; and the Macedonia name issue. The AE has said that it will oppose the agreement when it is brought before parliament and the senior ruling party may struggle to obtain the required majority.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The Syriza leadership is hoping to take credit for a clean exit from the bail-out programme to boost support for the government. However, the party trails in the polls behind the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, and the gap has been above 10 percentage points for some time. It is possible that this will narrow during the next election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little popular enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the government, the election is ND's to lose. If, as The Economist Intelligence Unit expects, ND wins the largest share of the vote at the next election, the party would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. But it would probably have to secure the support of one or more other parties to muster a parliamentary majority.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
On June 12th Mr Tsipras and Zoran Zaev, the prime minister of Macedonia (the official name of which is the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, FYROM; the country's constitutional name is the Republic of Macedonia), announced their agreement to change the latter's constitutional name to Severna Makedonija (North Macedonia). The two leaders attended a ceremony on June 17th at the Prespes lake district in northern Greece, at which their respective foreign ministers, Nikos Kotzias and Nikola Dimitrov, signed an agreement to change the country's name. The breakthrough is only the first step towards a resolution of the name dispute, and-given significant public opposition in both countries-the agreement may ultimately fail to come into effect. The agreement will be put to a referendum in Macedonia and must be approved by both countries' parliaments before it can come into force.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey have risen recently. The risk of military confrontation is high, particularly in the Aegean Sea, but we think that both sides will seek to avoid clashes. Points of contention-such as historical territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea, the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the failed coup in Turkey in July 2016, and the arrest in March 2018 by Turkish police of two Greek soldiers on patrol in the border area of Evros for alleged espionage-continue to fuel distrust.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
On August 20th Greece will emerge from an eight-year period (2010-18) during which it has received a total of EUR274bn ($US323bn) in official financial support from European creditors and the IMF (EUR32.1bn from the latter) and has been subject to three economic adjustment programmes. Repaying its outstanding public debt, which was EUR344bn (or about 180% of GDP) at the end of the first quarter of 2018, means that future Greek governments will be subject to huge policy constraints. Fiscal austerity and policy conditionality will remain the order of the day for the next five years and beyond.
At the June 21st meeting of the Eurogroup, Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme. This paves the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn. Of this, EUR3.3bn will be used to pay down the more expensive IMF debt, and the balance will constitute a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR24.1bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality resulted in the government opting for the more expensive option.
The Eurogroup meeting agreed to further debt relief for Greece, which was granted a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility, EFSF). It will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for loans of EUR130.9bn) and a return of profits from the securities market programme (SMP) and the Agreement on Net Financial Assets (ANFA) from official sector holders of Greek debt, estimated at around EUR5bn.
Greece, in return, has agreed to long-term fiscal prudence. The country must achieve annual primary budget surpluses of 3.5% of GDP in our 2018-22 forecast period and of 2.2% of GDP thereafter, until 2060. Greece will also be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. The debt-relief measures will be subject to quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to the agreed prudence. Furthermore, these reviews will be published, so Greece's market access would be adversely affected if it were to transgress.
After a three-year absence, Greece has returned to the financial markets three times since July 2017. However, after August it will do so without the backstop of an official credit line. Global financial volatility temporarily delayed the issuance of a seven-year bond in February, highlighting the kind of difficulties that Greece could face in future.
The country will have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs over the short term, through to early 2020. However, over the medium and long term, the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. Over the past two years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but this has been at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing, given the low base. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, alongside other negative factors, such as poor demographics and a rather weak business environment. Grexit is not a short-term risk, but, given that Greece is highly unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or grow its way out of its huge debt burden, it will pose a significant risk over the medium and long term.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Greece recorded a small surplus of 0.6% of GDP (ESA 2010 methodology) in 2016 and a primary surplus (budget balance minus interest payments) of 3.7% of GDP, outperforming its budget targets under the third economic adjustment programme. In 2017 the budget surplus increased to 0.8% of GDP and the budget primary surplus exceeded the target of 1.75% of GDP, coming in at 4% of GDP. We expect a broadly balanced budget in 2018, with only a minimal deficit, but we do not expect Greece to meet its annual primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP this year (or in the next four years). We forecast that the deficit will widen gradually from 2019 onwards, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint and moderate economic growth.
The restructuring of government debt to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary budget surpluses in 2016-17 were not sufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt, which rose to EUR317.4bn, or 179.1% of GDP, in 2017. Government debt is now almost entirely owed to official creditors. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal GDP growth rates over the medium term, the public debt/GDP ratio will remain about 171% in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. However, the ECB's view of the outlook improved markedly during 2017 and, although economic activity in the euro zone softened in early 2018, a more upbeat tone has emerged. We expect an end to monthly asset purchases under the QE programme at the end of 2018. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate, to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter, government consumption by almost 25%, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, under way since the beginning of 2017, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments, as demonstrated by the marked slowdown in activity in quarterly terms in the second half of 2017. We forecast that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.3% in 2017 to an average of 1.9% per year in 2018-22. The risks to our forecast are balanced. Upside risks include another strong tourism season. Downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
According to preliminary data released by the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT, the national statistics office), seasonally and calendar day-adjusted real GDP expanded by 0.8% quarter on quarter and by 2.3% year on year in January-March. We forecast growth of 1.8% in 2018, but still expect a combination of more and higher taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts to put pressure on household disposable income. We expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2018-22, but this will be from a low base and will be constrained by primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP per year, still high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
A welcome development in 2017 was a sharp acceleration in fixed investment growth, albeit from a low base, and we expect growth momentum to continue in 2018 and beyond. We expect fixed invest-ment growth to average 5% per year in 2018-22. However, underinvestment during the crisis and the depletion of Greece's capital stock, as well as uncertainty about Greece's euro zone membership, are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. Over the medium term we expect tourism to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 5.3% in 2018-22. An escalation of trade tensions between the US and the EU is the main risk to external trade growth in the short term.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge after it exits the bail-out programme. How the economy performs over the next five years and beyond will determine whether the country will remain in the euro zone. We assess the risk of Greece leaving the euro area by 2022 as above 50%, given the difficulties that the country will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets, and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Grexit would lead to a sovereign default and a severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then grow rapidly, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the need to achieve a primary surplus. Growth rates under this scenario would be faster than those in our medium-term forecast. We have not incorporated Grexit into our forecast numbers.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
After stagnating in 2016, Greece's seasonally adjusted EU harmonised index of consumer prices (HICP) rose by 1.1% year on year in 2017, driven by rising global energy prices, particularly in the fourth quarter. The HICP rose by 0.8% year on year in May, up from 0.5% in the previous month, marking the fastest rate of growth since December 2017. Economic growth is picking up, but major slack remains in the labour market, and domestic demand is subdued. Despite rising global commodity prices and tourism, we expect annual inflation to edge down this year, to an average of 0.7%. We forecast a pick-up to inflation of 1.5% per year on average in 2019-22 as the pace of growth quickens.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
In 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in February 2018, but weakened to US$1.17:EUR1 by late May in response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy. The value of the euro could yet come under further pressure from political risk in Italy and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a stabilisation on average, at US$1.21:EUR1 in 2018-21, as the euro is supported by a recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, and the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. Thereafter we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
There has been a marked reduction in Greece's current-account deficit since the start of the crisis, mainly reflecting the compression of imports as a result of contracting domestic demand, but also improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. The current-account deficit narrowed to 0.8% of GDP in 2017, from 1.1% of GDP in 2016, according to data published by the Bank of Greece (the central bank). We estimate widening deficits in 2018-22 as import prices continue to rise and import volumes gradually pick up in line with higher domestic demand, but the deficits will be smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.2% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit.

Inflation (av; %) 1.7 Inflation (av; %) 1.5
Background: The political geography of Europe has been defined by two world wars and the legacy of the cold war, during which Europe was divided into two blocs. The ending of Soviet control over central and eastern Europe from 1989, followed by the collapse in 1991 of the Soviet Union, provided an opportunity to expand the EU eastwards. Ten new member states (eight from the former communist bloc) were admitted to the EU in 2004, followed by a further two in 2007, and Croatia in 2013. In June 2016 the UK electorate voted in a referendum to withdraw from the EU. The economic transition of the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) has proceeded more smoothly than that of other east European countries. The effects of war in former Yugoslavia in the 1990s and a slower pace of reform have shaped developments in south-east Europe.
Political structure: All 28 EU member states are parliamentary democracies, although in some of the newer, former communist members in particular the substance of democracy-including a political culture based on trust and healthy levels of political participation-is often absent. The communist period lasted much longer in the former Soviet Union, and political developments in most parts of that region have been characterised by a drift towards authoritarianism.
Policy issues: Many aspects of domestic policy for EU member states-in particular those relating to the single market-are decided collectively at the EU level. Nineteen EU member states share the euro as their currency. These countries are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank. They are supposed to comply with common fiscal rules, although these have often been ignored. During the euro zone debt crisis several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) ceded varying degrees of policy control to the EU and the IMF in exchange for receiving financial support. Although the euro zone crisis has passed its peak, normalisation remains a long way off. The Economist Intelligence Unit continues to attach a 60% probability to Greece leaving the euro zone during its medium-term forecast period (2018-22). Outside the EU, the speed and extent of reform and institutional change vary widely. Countries with proximity to Western markets and with stable political outlooks have proceeded faster and more successfully with economic stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation. Institutional problems, such as weakness in the rule of law and widespread corruption, plague much of non-EU Europe.
Taxation: Individual tax regimes operate in all countries. All EU member states must operate a system of value-added tax (VAT), with a minimum of 15% as the standard rate.
Foreign trade: If intra-EU trade is included, the EU accounts for about half of all global trade. About 60% of trade conducted by EU member states is intra-regional.

Summary
Political stability
Popular disaffection with mainstream parties will persist during the forecast period. Anti-establishment parties formed a government in Italy in May, setting Italy on course for a clash with the EU over immigration and budgets, two issues that are becoming the focus for wider conflicts in the bloc.
Six months after the German election, a government was formed in March. A coalition crisis that broke out in June over migration policy reinforces the Economist Intelligence Unit's view that political instability will increase in coming years.
In the UK, Brexit outcomes are finely balanced between two scenarios: staying in a customs union and being closely aligned to single-market rules; and a snap election that would probably install a pro-Brexit government that takes a tougher line. The risk of a no-deal Brexit would be greater in the second scenario.
Russia will continue to pursue a muscular foreign policy. We expect EU sanctions on Russia to be maintained and for relations to remain difficult.
Economic policy
We do not expect the EU to undertake the ambitious reforms advocated by the French president, Emmanuel Macron, which will meet resistance from member states wary of an increase in risk-sharing.
Tensions arising from negotiations over the EU's seven-year budget framework for 2021-27 will intensify. We do not expect agreement on the budget framework until after European Parliament elections in May 2019.
We expect the European Central Bank to begin normalising monetary policy in 2019, with an increase in the deposit rate, and a rise in the main refinancing rate in early 2020.
Economic growth
We forecast average real GDP growth in the EU28 of 1.9% in 2018-22, following estimated growth of 2.5% in 2017.
We expect a real GDP growth slowdown in the UK in 2018-19, to 1.5% per year, owing to Brexit uncertainty. Growth will pick up in 2019-22.
The EU has responded with retaliatory tariffs to the imposition by the US of tariffs on steel and aluminium imports. Germany will aim to avoid an escalation that leads to the US imposing tariffs on European automotive exports.
Business environment rankings
The business environment has improved in most European countries as the post-crisis economic recovery has gathered pace. However, fragilities remain.

EU28: EU15 plus EU13.
Political outlook: Political stability
The UK's vote in June 2016 to leave the EU represents a serious challenge to the future cohesion of the bloc. Despite the professed unity of the other 27 member states, the departure of one of the EU's biggest members will continue to reverberate after the UK leaves in March 2019. For example, its departure will leave a big hole in the EU budget, which will be difficult to overcome without generating antagonism within the bloc.
Brexit is by no means the only challenge. The EU's problems have been compounded by a broader populist insurgency against the political mainstream, which brought to power an anti-establishment government in Italy on June 1st. Across the continent, populist parties and politicians are putting pressure on the mainstream political parties to address their concerns, especially on the subject of migration and integration policies.
Immigration is becoming an increasing focus of conflict in the EU
Italy's new government has already clashed with the EU over immigration, a long-festering issue that is fast becoming the focus for wider conflicts in the bloc. In June, Italy and Malta both refused to accept ships full of migrants rescued en route to Europe, with the new Italian government insisting that other EU countries shoulder more of the burden of immigration from Africa. Also in June, a conflict erupted in the coalition government in Germany when the Christian Social Union (CSU) demanded a change in Germany's policy towards migrants arriving at the border.
In addition, the issue of refugee relocation is a focal point for tensions between the EU and a core of central European countries. In September 2015 the European Council established a temporary scheme to relocate across the EU some of the Syrian refugees who had arrived in Italy and Greece, with the aim of sharing the burden of accommodating them. This was particularly controversial in central and eastern Europe, where governments characterised it as an attempt by western Europe to export the consequences of misguided foreign policies, and claimed that it raised the prospect of terrorist attacks as a result of Islamist infiltration. Public opposition to the scheme has been substantial across the region. The EU is also in conflict with Hungary and Poland over rule-of-law issues.
The Catalonia crisis, which escalated in October 2017 after pro-independence citizens voting in an illegal referendum on the region's independence from the rest of Spain encountered state violence, poses another threat to the cohesion of the EU. The change of government in Spain in June may lead to an easing of tensions between the central state in Madrid and the pro-independence bloc in Catalonia, but the Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect an early resolution of the conflict.
Meanwhile, relations with Russia are strained. This is the result of many issues, including the expansion of NATO into eastern Europe; Western intervention in Kosovo in 1999; the 2008 war between Russia and Georgia; the 2014 Russian annexation of Crimea and conflict in eastern Ukraine; Russia's intervention in Syria; alleged attempts by Russia to interfere in political processes in the West; and the nerve-agent attack on a former Russian intelligence officer on British soil in March 2018. The EU has responded by imposing sanctions against Russia and expelling Russian diplomats.
There is no room for complacency, as underlying problems remain unresolved
The lesson of the past decade, since the global economic and financial crash of 2008, is that politicians have underestimated the economic and political challenges. Threats to the future of the EU, including the sovereign debt crisis, the migration crisis and the populist insurgency, have not been resolved. The existential threat to the euro has certainly lessened since the height of the sovereign debt crisis in 2010-13, when the danger of one of the peripheral economies being forced out of the euro zone, through a loss of investor confidence and a spike in bond yields, weighed heavily on sentiment and investment. The commitment of the European Central Bank (ECB) to the euro has largely neutralised speculative pressure in the bond markets, but the single currency is still vulnerable. Popular disaffection with the political order in Europe remains substantial. This is likely to fuel support for anti-establishment parties and bring about destabilising political realignments in the coming years.
The management of Europe's crises has been complicated by the weakened position of the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, following her party's poor performance in the September 2017 federal elections and the onset of an embryonic coalition crisis in June 2018. France's president, Emmanuel Macron, has sought to re-energise the Franco-German partnership; last year he laid out sweeping plans for EU and euro zone reform. Many of Mr Macron's ideas are not new-some of them already enjoy widespread support in the EU-but the energy with which he is championing his vision for Europe contrasts sharply with Ms Merkel's more managerial and reactive European leadership style.
A decision on reform proposals will be made at the EU summit on June 28th-29th. In mid-June Germany and France presented a shared set of proposals. This included a commitment to a small euro zone budget, which had previously seemed a political non-starter in Germany. However, this will run up against objections from other, smaller member states, which will hold on to their traditional red lines. Nevertheless, the strength of the Franco-German axis, with support from a number of southern member states, is likely to be sufficient to lead to a relatively ambitious set of reforms, which will nevertheless take several years to fully implement.
Migration is likely to be the headline-grabbing issue at the summit. A domestic political crisis has forced Ms Merkel to seek out a deal to cut migration with European partners. Despite a broadly-shared wish to cut the number of arrivals by increasing border security and striking deals with northern African countries to limit departures, disagreements remain on how to handle the issue of the redistribution of asylum-seekers across the bloc. The political pressure to move on this issue, including from the new populist Italian government, leads us to expect that a number of new measures will be announced, including plans to strengthen the EU's border control agency, Frontex.
Budget negotiations will test EU cohesion
Tensions arising from negotiations over the EU's next seven-year budget framework for 2021-27 will also play into the debate on EU reform. The European Commission has proposed that all member states increase their financial contribution to meet the shortfall in the budget created by the withdrawal of the UK, the fourth-largest contributor. Germany and eight central and east European countries are willing to pay more into the budget, whereas others (including Austria, the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark) would prefer to reduce the budget after Brexit. Agreement on the budget framework is unlikely until the second half of 2019, after the European Parliament elections in May 2019. We expect the Commission to secure larger budget contributions from all EU member states, but achieving this is likely to involve a reallocation (or "modernisation") of funds, which is likely to include shifting funds from the eastern member states to the crisis-hit southern members. This will also reflect a shift in the balance of power within the EU after Brexit, as the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark will have lost the UK as an ally.
Coalition dispute points to difficulties ahead for Germany
It took almost six months to form a government following the September 2017 general election. The government is another grand coalition of the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU) with the CSU (its Bavarian sister party) and the Social Democratic Party (SPD). The election dealt a blow to the two leading parties, which recorded their worst results since the 1950s (32.9% and 20.5% respectively), and also brought the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) into the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament).
The AfD performed better than expected, polling 12.6% nationally, and did especially well in the former east Germany, where the party became the second-largest political force. Exit polls indicated that the issue of migration and refugees was the main reason for voting for the AfD, with many voters signalling that this was a protest vote.
Pressure from the AfD has recently led to ructions in the CDU-CSU alliance. The CSU is under pressure from the AfD ahead of the Bavarian state election in October, and Horst Seehofer, the interior minister and leader of the CSU, has tried to outflank the insurgent party on the immigration issue. His demand for Germany to turn back at the border migrants who had previously registered in other EU countries has led to a mini-crisis in the government. Ms Merkel argued that this would lead to a domino effect of border closures, as Austria would close its border with Italy if Germany sent migrants back to Austria, and that it was in any case a decision for her, not Mr Seehofer. The dispute was temporarily paused when Ms Merkel promised to work towards a European solution on the migration issue. The CSU will decide on July 1st whether the agreement reached at the EU summit is good enough to curb migration into Germany. Should the party deem it inadequate and insist on border checks, the coalition could fall apart. We expect Ms Merkel to come home with sufficient concessions for Mr Seehofer to save face and for the coalition to remain intact.
The next few years are likely to be a testing time for Germany, with the rise of the AfD putting pressure on the conservative CSU and causing difficulties for the CDU/CSU coalition. The SPD will also struggle to revive its fortunes as the centre of political gravity shifts to the right. Tensions will persist between the CDU and the CSU, and the question of Ms Merkel's successor and the future direction of the CDU will continue to hang over the Christian Democratic bloc. Meanwhile, the AfD will do its best to test the government.
An unstable political settlement in Spain
Spain has also been a source of recent political volatility. On June 1st Mariano Rajoy, the former leader of the conservative People's Party, became the country's first prime minister to be forced out of office through a censure measure. The motion was tabled by Pedro Sánchez, the leader of the centre-left Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE), following a series of damning verdicts in the so-called Gürtel corruption trial, which implicated a number of former PP officials and policymakers and resulted in a fine for the party.
Mr Sánchez now leads a very weak minority government, which controls just 84 of 350 seats in the Congress of Deputies, the dominant lower chamber of parliament. To unseat Mr Rajoy and become prime minister, the PSOE leader assembled an unlikely ad hoc majority in Congress, including the populist Podemos, the PSOE's rival on the political left, and a number of smaller, regional nationalist parties, including the two main Catalan pro-independence formations. Mr Sánchez has stated that he intends to see out the current parliamentary term, which ends in mid-2020, but there is a high risk of policy paralysis, which could potentially lead him to call an election sooner.
The PSOE government's legislative remit will be tightly constrained. Mr Sánchez will seek to overcome this through powers of decree, but has pledged to maintain the PP's fiscal plans for 2018, after which the 2018 budget could be rolled over to 2019 and possibly even to 2020. The prime minister has also admitted that the PSOE will be able to make only superficial changes to the PP's landmark 2012 labour reform, which he had previously pledged to scrap.
With few other firm policy promises, the core of Mr Sánchez's mandate will be to open a more productive dialogue with the pro-independence government in Catalonia. His political strategy appears to centre on projecting an image of leadership, both at national and EU level. He has appointed a highly qualified cabinet, composed mainly of women, and will seek to build the PSOE's credibility ahead of the next election.
Few policy changes after the re-election of Mr Putin
On March 18th Vladimir Putin was re-elected to a fourth term as president, securing a record 76.7% of the vote on a turnout of 67%. Mr Putin's re-election was widely expected, given his approval ratings of around 80%, and in the absence of credible opposition candidates. Although the election itself was a non-event, it ushers in a period of political uncertainty as various factions of the elite jockey to secure their position in the post-Putin political order-assuming that Mr Putin stands down at the end of his term in 2024. In Mr Putin's fourth term, we expect a greater focus on domestic policy, in an effort to arrest falling living standards and bolster growth following the 2015-16 recession. However, even modest liberalising reforms are unlikely and we expect the state to retain its dominant role in the economy. In the foreign policy arena, we believe that Russia will continue to pursue a muscular policy, with the aim of asserting its status as a major player on the global stage. The country's international influence will be strengthened by the conclusion of international business deals in strategic sectors such as oil, nuclear-power plants and military equipment.
Conventional politics upended across the continent
Recent elections across Europe have followed the Italian and German pattern, with voters increasingly favouring alternative or populist parties over their mainstream counterparts. The result has been greater political fragmentation, protracted negotiations to form governments and the emergence of unusual government coalitions. Elections held in the Netherlands, Norway, Austria, Iceland and the Czech Republic in 2017 illustrated the trend towards increased political fragmentation, as well as a more complicated policymaking outlook.
Spain faces a constitutional crisis over the Catalan question
Another impetus towards the breakdown of post-war political arrangements and fragmentation comes from regional movements demanding greater autonomy or independence in countries such as Belgium, Italy, Scotland, Spain and elsewhere, including in eastern Europe. Spain has been plunged into political crisis by an illegal referendum and subsequent unilateral declaration of independence in Catalonia. The central government responded by using Article 155 of the constitution to dismiss the Catalan government and assume control of the region in late October 2017, and called new regional elections.
In the regional election in Catalonia in December 2017, pro-independence parties won a parliamentary majority, with less than 50% of the popular vote. The liberal, pro-unity Ciudadanos (Citizens) topped the poll with 25.4% of the vote. The election confirms the polarisation of views on independence. It produced little numerical change in the balance of power between the electoral blocs of pro-independence and pro-unity parties, despite a turnout above 80%, which the unionists hoped would deliver them victory.
The separatist parties-the Catalan Republican Left (ERC), the centre-right Junts per Catalunya (JuntsxCat; Together for Catalonia) and the anti-capitalist Popular Unity Candidates (CUP)-won a combined 47.5% of the vote and 70 seats in the 135-seat parliament, compared with 47.7% and 72 seats in 2015. The three pro-unity parties-Ciudadanos, the Socialists' Party of Catalonia (PSC) and the conservative People's Party (PP)-won a combined 43.5% and 57 seats, up from 39.2% and 52 in 2015. The non-aligned Catalunya en Comú (the Comuns, associated with Podemos-We Can) polled 7.5% and won eight seats.
Ciudadanos is the largest party, with 37 deputies and 25.4% of the vote. Its strong performance came mainly at the expense of the PP, whose support slumped from 8.5% to 4.2%. Ciudadanos will be unable to form a government, but its success in Catalonia is a warning to the PSOE and the PP, the two main national parties.. The regional election result was in line with our forecast and was a major blow for Mr Rajoy.
With a number of prominent pro-independence politicians in custody and facing serious charges, ranging from rebellion and sedition to misappropriation of funds, and the former regional president and several other ministers claiming to lead a government in exile in Belgium, the pro-independence movement faces serious challenges in agreeing on the political direction for Catalan separatism. This could take the form of a renewed push for independence or, more probably, pressure for a legal referendum, as well as protests over what the pro-independence movement regards as the unjust treatment of its leaders at the hands of the Spanish state. The election of Mr Sanchez as prime minister raises the chances of a reduction in tensions between the national and the regional government. However, we expect the Catalonia conflict to drag on.
The Brexit negotiations will test EU cohesion
The Brexit negotiations began in June 2017, after the UK government invoked Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union on March 29th of that year, beginning the formal two-year process of the country's withdrawal from the bloc. In the Article 50 letter, Theresa May, the prime minister, confirmed that the UK would not seek membership of the EU's single market. This is in line with the government's intention to honour the Brexit vote by taking control of laws, borders and budget. The UK will also leave the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ).
The UK would like tariff-free access to EU markets, but customs union membership would mean a common external tariff and would prevent it from negotiating trade deals with other countries. The UK will thus try to negotiate a free-trade agreement with the EU and has proposed alternatives to customs union membership, including a "highly streamlined" arrangement and a new "customs partnership" that reduce non-tariff barriers to trade such as technical regulations, compliance requirements and rules-of-origin documentation. We expect the new relationship to be phased in gradually, to minimise disruption. This may mean continued adherence to EU rules for a period after withdrawal.
A deal would be mutually beneficial, but the risk of no deal is high
The UK will formally leave the single market at the end of the Article 50 process in March 2019. UK and EU negotiators have reached agreement on large parts of the draft withdrawal agreement that they intend to finalise by October 2018, such as citizens' rights, the financial settlement, Euratom and on most areas relating to separation provisions. There is also full agreement on the terms of the transition period, which will last for 21 months after the UK's formal withdrawal. During this period, the UK will maintain access to the single market, but will be bound by the obligations of membership. The UK made several concessions that are unpalatable to Brexiteers: EU law will still be applicable; EU budget contributions will continue; the UK will have no say over fishing quotas; and there will be reciprocal free movement and subsequent entitlement to settled status until the end of the transition period. A win for the UK is that it will not be bound by the EU's trade policy, enabling it to negotiate and agree (but not implement) new trade deals during the transition.
There is an increasing risk that the EU and the UK will fail to reach agreement on the Irish border issue, and that this will scupper the withdrawal agreement. The proposals for a customs partnership and the highly streamlined customs arrangement have so far been met with scepticism and it is looking increasingly likely that the government will implement some form of its "backstop" proposal to effectively keep the UK in a customs union with the EU beyond the end of the transition period in 2021. Under this scenario, the UK would remain subject to single-market rules in many areas and the scope of a future trade agreement with the EU would therefore be limited.
However, this would be in breach of Mrs May's "red lines" and could trigger a revolt by Brexiteers, leading to the prime minister's removal, a snap election and the return of a committed pro-Brexit government. We would expect a pro-Brexit government to pursue a tougher line in the negotiations and aim for a comprehensive free-trade agreement outside the single market and customs union. Trade flows with the EU should be facilitated by the close nature of the future trading relationship, which should involve some degree of regulatory alignment. However, a viable alternative solution to the EU customs union would still need to be found, and a hardline stance on both sides would increase the risk of a breakdown in the negotiations.
Realistically, only the framework of a trade deal will be agreed by the time the UK withdraws in 2019, as completing the withdrawal agreement will take priority in 2018. However, transition arrangements will allow negotiations to continue, and we expect a deal to be in place by 2021.
Political outlook: Election watch
We expect political risk to remain high in Europe throughout the forecast period. In the euro zone, in particular, the negative political fallout from the financial crisis, coming on top of the long-term erosion of the post-war political party system, is proving to be electorally disruptive. Moreover, recent evidence suggests that fragmentation and difficulties forming a government occur even in countries that are registering solid rates of growth, such as Ireland, and in traditionally politically stable countries, such as the UK.
The new Italian government is likely to be unstable and short-lived
The general election in Italy on March 4th 2018 yielded an acutely fragmented parliament. It also produced a resounding victory for the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won about 32% of the vote, and the Eurosceptic anti-immigrant Lega, which won about 17%.
Amid heightened market volatility, and following a prolonged period of post-election negotiations-including a stand-off with the president, Sergio Mattarella over the proposed appointment of Paolo Savona, a strongly Eurosceptic economist, to the post of minister of economy and finance-M5S and Lega reached a last-minute deal to form a government on May 29th. The administration is led by Giuseppe Conte, an independent law professor close to M5S. The leaders of M5S and the Lega, Luigi Di Maio and Matteo Salvini, will serve, respectively, as deputy prime minister, and as labour and economic development minister and interior minister. Giovanni Tria, a more moderate economist, has been appointed to the economy and finance ministry, while Mr Savona will be minister of EU affairs.
We expect the Conte government to be short-lived and to send mixed signals to the EU institutions and other member states. In addition to seeking looser fiscal policy constraints, the administration will press the EU hard on its immigration and migration policies, demanding greater support for Italy coping with vessels arriving across the Mediterranean. It will also press for a tougher line on EU free-trade agreements, particularly the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), and may seek a loosening of sanctions on Russia over the annexation of Crimea.
The government's domestic policy priorities include a tougher stance on unauthorised migration; policies meant to reduce poverty, such as a means-tested "citizenship income" for job-seekers; a rollback of recent reforms to the public pension system and the labour market; the implementation of a two-rate "flat tax"; and the disarmament of safeguard clauses in the country's fiscal framework that would automatically raise fuel excise and value-added tax rates if alternative fiscal consolidation measures are not specified. So far, Mr Conte's government has pledged to continue reducing the public deficit, which came in at 2.3% of GDP in 2017, but it could announce a more dramatic shift in policy in the update to its medium-term fiscal framework, to be released in September, and its draft 2019 budget, due to go before parliament by October 2019.
We expect the M5S-Lega coalition to pass only some of the measures it has proposed, beginning with the less costly ones, such as tougher immigration policies, plans to dismantle the 2012 pension reform, and measures to disarm the budget safeguard clauses. Proposals for a "citizenship income" and a two-rate flat tax could be implemented in phases or postponed until sufficient resources can be found. The public deficit-which we currently forecast at 2% of GDP this year and 2.3% of GDP in 2019-is likely to widen, although the government is not expected to breach the 3% of GDP maximum mandated by fiscal compact rules.
Crossing this psychological threshold would be likely to trigger another intense bout of market turmoil as the ECB phases out its sovereign quantitative easing purchases, making it very difficult for the government to finance its costly policy plans at sustainable rates. Owing to investor concerns over the administration's intentions, Italian assets are likely to prove more volatile in the coming months. For now, we do not envisage any major changes in the country's meagre GDP growth outlook, which we forecast at 1.3% this year and 1.1% in 2019.
Turkey heading for one-man rule after June elections
Parliamentary and presidential elections were due to have been held in November 2019, but were brought forward to June 24th 2018. As we had forecast, the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, won re-election easily in the first round. This completes the transition to an executive presidency, following a constitutional referendum in April 2017. Turkey will effectively move to one-man rule by Mr Erdogan.
The transfer of executive powers to the presidency means that there will be few checks and balances on the president. No prime minister will be appointed. Mr Erdogan will draft the state budget and directly choose ministers and senior officials, as well as judges. In addition, he will have the ability to issue executive decrees on social, economic and political issues. Parliament will have only limited powers as Mr Erdogan's Justice and Development Party (AKP) holds a majority of the seats with its coalition partner, the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Given his popularity, the fragmentation of the opposition and the positive coverage he gets from state media, we expect Mr Erdogan to remain in office with enhanced powers for at least one more five-year term, and quite possibly a further such term (the maximum allowed) up to 2028.
Fine Gael minority coalition government will not survive full term
The collapse of Leo Varadkar's Fine Gael-led minority coalition government in Ireland was narrowly averted in late November 2017. Our view remains that the government does not have the capacity or cohesion to address effectively the mounting economic and political challenges facing Ireland. As a result, we continue to believe that the government will not survive a full term to February 2021 and that a snap election will take place in the second half of 2018 or in early 2019. However, the landslide victory by 66.4% to 33.6% for those campaigning to liberalise Ireland's highly restrictive abortion law in the historic referendum in May was a boost for Mr Varadkar, who campaigned for a "yes" vote, and for his government. He will seek to build on the momentum of the referendum result to increase his party's support.
Given voter disillusionment with the three established parties-Fine Gael, Fianna Fail and the Labour Party-we expect the next election to be inconclusive, as in February 2016. Another such outcome would put greater pressure on Fine Gael and Fianna Fail to set aside their historical differences and form a grand coalition.
At the 2016 general election none of the established parties was willing to contemplate entering a coalition with the nationalist Sinn Fein party led by Gerry Adams, which had links to the now disbanded Irish Republican Army. We think that this is unlikely to change after the next election, but a transition is now under way in Sinn Fein. The leadership has passed to Mary Lou McDonald, one of the party's younger members, who is not associated with the conflict in Northern Ireland.
