Political outlook: Intra-regional tensions
Policy-related tensions remain high within the euro zone, but the risk that they will prompt a breakdown in inter-governmental relations has fallen sharply over the past 18 months, as economic growth has picked up across the bloc. The ECB has overcome objections in a number of countries-notably in Germany-to its use of unconventional policy instruments. However, the breathing space created by the ECB's programme of sovereign quantitative easing has, up to now, not been used by political leaders to bolster the economic recovery with a strong united position on fiscal policy and structural reform.
The rise of anti-establishment political sentiment across much of the bloc has generated increased pressure for economic policymaking that is focused on national considerations rather than on the integrity of the euro zone, creating new centrifugal forces at a time when policymakers are already struggling to remedy the institutional shortcomings of the single currency. Huge political capital has been invested in keeping the euro zone together in recent years. This should ensure its survival in the short term, but the risk of a partial break-up in the medium term remains significant. Greece is unlikely to face any short-term financing problems once its exits its third bail-out programme in August 2018. However, Greece's membership of the euro zone will remain in question over the medium and long term, given its high public debt burden (almost 180% of GDP in 2017) and its poor long-term growth prospects.
Hungary and Poland will continue to clash with the EU over refugees and other issues
The nationalist, socially-conservative governments in Hungary and Poland have come into conflict with the EU over the bloc's refugees relocation policy and by creating what the Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, has called an "illiberal" state. In addition to refusing to take their allocation of refugees, the Hungarian and Polish governments have curbed the independence of the judiciary, imposed government control over the public service media and clamped down on civil-society groups. The European Commission has referred several of these measures to the ECJ but it has so far struggled to find an effective response. Attempts to invoke Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, possibly resulting in the suspension of a member country's voting rights, are unlikely to succeed. They require the unanimous vote of all members, and Hungary and Poland have made clear that they would support one another in such an event.
Tension between Turkey and the EU will remain high
Despite talk of agreeing a new roadmap to ease tensions and improve co-operation in the main areas of interest such as security, trade and investment, neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc anymore. However, neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested, the EU will probably seize this opportunity to suspend the accession process. This would almost certainly prompt the country to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the movement of migrants and refugees into Europe. A settlement of the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but talks collapsed in July 2017. We maintain our forecast that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period.
Tensions between Turkey and the US, the country's traditional ally, have risen since the failed coup in July 2016. The Turkish government has sharply stepped up its anti-Western rhetoric in recent months, and attributes the recent sharp depreciation of the lira to a foreign plot. In addition, the US government refuses to extradite Fethullah Gulen, a cleric whom the Turkish government believes organised the failed coup. In the coming months, the US could impose international financial sanctions against Turkish banks that facilitated transactions that did not comply with US Iran-related sanctions. Such a step would further strain the relations between the two countries.
Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. Russia has lifted almost all sanctions and Turkey has acquired S-400 Russian air defence missiles, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have so far pursued contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and there is a significant risk that new tensions will emerge.
Mr Erdogan's state visit to Greece on December 7th-8th 2017-the first such visit by a Turkish president in 65 years-was a tense affair. Greater co-operation on issues such as trade and security may result, but points of contention will continue to fuel distrust. Historical territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea or more recent events, such as the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the failed coup in Turkey in July 2016, and the arrest and imprisonment of Greek soldiers who strayed over the Turkish border on March 1st 2018, will continue to be flashpoints. We expect relations to remain tense, with sporadic flare-ups, but we do not expect an outbreak of conflict.
Russia-West tensions are at their highest level since the cold war
East-West political tensions are at their highest since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Russia is slowly dismantling the security and arms control agreements that were put in place in at the end of the cold war. Russia's opposition to the post-cold war security architecture was evident in its decision to withdraw from the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe (CFE) and its breach of the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) treaty, which bans short- and medium-range ballistic missiles. Western countries have accused Russia of funding opposition parties in western Europe and employing cyber warfare against Western targets, as well as engaging in a propaganda war through media outlets that it controls in the West.
Russian-Western tensions intensified when a former Russian intelligence officer, Sergei Skripal, and his daughter Yulia were found unconscious on March 4th, having been attacked with a nerve agent in the UK city of Salisbury. The UK government accused the Russian state of being behind the attack. Despite the tough talk from the UK, so far the measures taken, including the expulsion of 23 Russian diplomatic staff, have been rather modest.
Tensions with Russia are unlikely to abate
Russia has said that the EU and the US are interfering in its sphere of influence, supporting the "colour revolutions" in former Soviet space. Russia has accused NATO of going back on its post-cold war commitments by expanding relentlessly, first taking in central Europe and the Baltic republics, then Albania and Croatia in 2009 and, most recently, Montenegro in June 2017. Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH) and Macedonia are now in the waiting room for admission. The Iraq war and colour revolutions fuelled Russian insecurity and convinced Russia that the US wanted "regime change" in the country, and possibly the break-up of the Russian Federation. In the face of such an existential threat, from the Kremlin's perspective any countermeasures are justified.
In March 2014 Russia annexed Crimea and has since been providing military support to pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine. The EU imposed sanctions on Russia's energy, defence and banking sectors in July 2014 following the downing of a passenger plane over Ukrainian territory controlled by Russian-backed separatists. The sanctions are subject to regular renewal, requiring the approval of all 28 EU member states. The Minsk II ceasefire agreement, signed in February 2015, is unlikely to lead to a resolution of the conflict in Ukraine. Russia sees Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO as a direct threat to its national interests. The current status quo, of a regularly breached ceasefire and contained levels of fighting, is likely to endure for several years. This will serve Russia's interests, as a frozen conflict will prevent closer integration with the EU.
Russia is opposed to EU and NATO integration with the countries of the former Soviet Union. Regime change in any country in Russia's immediate neighbourhood, particularly via a pro-Western popular uprising similar to the Ukrainian Maidan revolution in 2014, would trigger a crisis in relations between Russia and the West.
We do not expect political or economic upheaval in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) region in 2018. The exceptions to this outlook are Uzbekistan, where the new president will continue to pursue a reformist course, and Armenia and Georgia, where street protests have led to change in governments and which will outpace most of the region in terms of economic growth. In Kazakhstan, uncertainty will increase regarding the succession of the long-time president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, and the launch of the Astana International Finance Centre will not be an investment game-changer. We believe that no significant political or economic change will take place in the other central Asian countries (the Kyrgyz Republic, Turkmenistan and Tajikistan). The vulnerability of several countries, including Tajikistan and the Kyrgyz Republic, to political and social instability will remain high.
Economic policy
Euro zone reform efforts are being stepped up
The threat of a euro zone break-up has receded in recent years as the region's economic recovery has strengthened and broadened, and as its institutional underpinnings have become more resilient. The commitment in July 2012 by the president of the European Central Bank (ECB), Mario Draghi, to "do whatever it takes" to preserve the euro represented a turning point for the bloc, the resilience of which to shocks has also been bolstered by the establishment of an EU banking union and a permanent rescue fund. EU leaders are currently making a renewed push for further integration of the economic and monetary union. Proposals put forward by the European Commission in December 2017 included turning the European Stability Mechanism-the euro zone's bail-out fund-into a European Monetary Fund (EMF) that would provide a backstop for the banking union; a stabilisation function for the euro area, which would deal with asymmetric shocks by providing resources to support investment at the national level; and a euro zone economy and finance minister who would oversee the EMF and serve as vice-president of the European Commission.
Some aspects of these plans will meet internal resistance and will struggle to get off the ground. The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that, although strengthening the existing structures would be helpful, such proposals are not essential for the continuation of the region's economic recovery. EU leaders will present reform proposals at a summit in late June 2018.
The UK's departure from the EU will encourage policymakers to address some of the structural deficiencies that have held back the economy in recent years, including lacklustre productivity growth, insufficient innovation and poor infrastructure. The chancellor, Philip Hammond, announced a National Productivity Investment Fund to boost the UK's digital infrastructure and spending on research and development over the next five years. Proposals to reform the UK's housing market have focused on introducing greater speed and flexibility into the planning process. There will also be a new effort to improve vocational skills. We expect these measures to support the recovery in productivity, but they are still too modest in size and scope to close the UK's productivity gap with its G7 peers.
The Queen's Speech in June 2017 set out the government's legislative agenda, which was dominated by Brexit. Eight of the 27 bills relate to the transfer of EU law into British law, a UK customs regime, independent trade policy, controls on immigration, fisheries policy, agricultural policy, nuclear safeguards and the UK's ability to impose international sanctions. In a further sign that Brexit is the government's priority, the parliamentary session will last for two years rather than one, ending two months after the UK's withdrawal at end-March 2019.

A conservative fiscal bias has prevailed across most of the region since the global crisis in 2008-09, leaving policymakers to rely heavily on low interest rates and unconventional monetary policy tools as the main levers with which to manage their economies. This created a significant degree of exposure to the impact of the monetary policy cycle in the US, where we expect further tightening in 2018-19. Although we continue to expect monetary policy to remain accommodative in most countries, we now expect fiscal policies to be slightly more supportive during our five-year forecast period (2018-22).
We expect fiscal consolidation to exert a much less powerful drag on growth in 2018-22 compared with the preceding five years. Almost all European countries improved their fiscal positions in 2009-17. Although we expect fiscal policies to be slightly more supportive of economic growth, significant fiscal loosening remains off the agenda for most countries, especially for those with high public debt loads, owing to the rigidity of the rules agreed by EU members at the height of the euro zone crisis. The average euro zone government debt/GDP ratio was 86.7% at end-2017, but Belgium, Cyprus, Greece, Italy and Portugal had debt ratios in excess of 100%, and those for France and Spain were only slightly below 100%. Hefty debt loads will remain a challenge for much of the euro zone for many years. Although the cost of debt servicing has fallen dramatically in recent years owing to the exceptionally low interest rates that currently prevail across the bloc, borrowing costs are set to rise gradually as monetary policy is normalised.
The UK government is targeting steady deficit reduction
The UK's fiscal position improved in 2016-17, and we expect this improvement to be maintained in 2018-22, despite a fiscal loosening in the November 2017 autumn budget. We forecast that the deficit will stabilise at about 1.8% of GDP in 2018, after coming in at 1.9% of GDP in 2017. We expect the deficit to narrow to 1.6% of GDP by 2020 and 1% of GDP by 2022. We forecast that public debt will decline from 88% of GDP in 2018 to 81% of GDP by 2022.
Within the EU, over the past two years a number of national governments have shown signs of pushing back against centralised fiscal constraints, which are significantly more rigorous as a result of changes introduced in response to the crisis. In 2016 tensions between several member states and the European Commission, which enforces the EU's budgetary rules, came to a head. In early July 2016 the Commission proposed that Spain and Portugal should be fined for their failure to meet deficit targets in 2015, but the Commission ultimately stepped back from this position. The episode highlighted the growing tension between the strict fiscal rules agreed at the height of the crisis and the mounting political and economic arguments within member states for a greater degree of fiscal flexibility.
The tight budget constraints facing the Russian government are abating, owing to higher oil prices. We expect oil prices to average more than US$73/barrel in 2018-22-an improved but still challenging outlook, compared with an average price of about US$50/b in 2015-17. The Ministry of Finance will continue to pursue a conservative fiscal policy in 2018-22, but the adjustment to expenditure is likely to be less radical than planned, particularly in the short term, given Mr Putin's recent social spending promises; rising global oil prices; plans to reduce defence spending in favour of other areas; and the government's conservative oil price forecasts, which almost guarantee that revenue will outperform expectations. We expect the budget to return to a small surplus in 2018, of 0.3% of GDP. The budget surplus will increase but remain below 1% of GDP throughout our forecast period.

Despite the healthy economic outlook across the region, an absence of corresponding inflationary pressure means that the ECB will keep monetary policy accommodative in 2018-19. Policy interest rates will remain below zero and an asset purchase programme will run at EUR30bn (US$37bn) per month until September and at EUR15bn per month in October-December, before coming to an end.
The ECB and regional central banks are moving towards policy normalisation
Economic growth and tightening labour markets should mean that sufficient inflation will begin to emerge in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take the first step towards normalising its main refinancing rate in 2020, before embarking on a gradual tightening cycle that would bring the interest rate to 1.5% by end-2022. The next increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability. The stock of assets held by the ECB will rise to about EUR2.6trn (US$3.2trn) by the end of 2018, and be maintained at this level throughout the forecast period.
When setting interest rates, other central banks will have to weigh up the net effect of a moderating euro zone economy and greater protectionism elsewhere with their desire to normalise monetary policy. Caution is likely to win out: we expect the Bank of England (the UK central bank) to delay its next increase in interest rates to August, and rate rises in late 2018 are now more uncertain in the Czech Republic and Sweden. It is still likely that Norges Bank (Norway's central bank) will tighten policy in September and that the Swiss National Bank (SNB) will lift its policy interest rate by a small amount in 2019, although we now expect the SNB to reduce its foreign-exchange interventions in 2019, rather than in late 2018.
The BoE is keen to normalise monetary policy
The UK economy has been sufficiently resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote for its central bank to increase the main policy interest rate from 0.25% to 0.5% in November 2017, the first rate rise in a decade. The monetary policy committee (MPC) of the Bank of England kept policy unchanged in June 2018. The chief economist, Andy Haldane, voted to increase interest rates by 25 basis points to 0.75%, increasing the number of MPC members in favour of tighter policy to three, from two previously. The committee's hawks are still outnumbered by six other members who preferred to keep the policy rate at 0.5% in June. However Mr Haldane's vote makes it more likely that the balance of opinions on the MPC will shift in favour of higher interest rates in the months ahead. We maintain our forecast for a rate rise at the policy meeting on August 2nd.
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy, domestic political uncertainty and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region have already put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, and most lately in April-June, fuelling an acceleration in inflation. Under political pressure not to raise rates significantly, the Central Bank of Turkey is constrained in its ability to tighten monetary policy. In the event of another severe weakening of the lira after the elections, it could abruptly tighten monetary policy and reimpose capital controls. However, this is not our baseline scenario.
In Russia, the fall in oil prices, which led to a significant contraction in real GDP and household consumption in 2015-16, has underlined the imperative for reforms to encourage investment and diversification away from commodity exports. However, we do not expect significant reforms to be undertaken during Mr Putin's fourth term, and the Russian president will continue to prioritise social and political stability. We expect state involvement in the economy to remain substantial. In his March 1st state of the nation speech, Mr Putin set out some of his socioeconomic goals for his next presidential term. His agenda appeared to include fragments of competing policy agendas proposed by Aleksei Kudrin, a former finance minister, and the Stolypin Club, an economic research group led by a business ombudsman, Boris Titov. The Kudrin camp emphasises the need to reduce the role of the state in the economy and to increase competitiveness and productivity by investing in human capital, in contrast to the Stolypin Club's call for a more statist and Keynesian policy agenda. Reform of the tax system-including an increase in the value-added tax rate-and a gradual rise in the pension age appear likely. Institutional reform to strengthen the rule of law and protection for businesses looks much more difficult to achieve.
Policy to be kept tight to support the Turkish lira and lower inflation
The Turkish lira has been highly volatile and on a generally depreciating path against all major currencies since mid-2013, when the prospect of a gradual reduction in ultra-loose global liquidity and an eventual tightening of policy took shape. After a sharp fall in the nominal value of the lira against the US dollar in 2017, we expect the pace of depreciation to slow slightly during the forecast period. There are substantial risks to this forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region.
Inflationary pressures have continued to weaken in Russia
Russia has seen steady consumer price disinflation since late 2015, with inflation under 2.5% year on year in January-May 2018, well below the Central Bank of Russia's 4% inflation target. Disinflation has been assisted by record harvests in 2016-17, as well as the relative strength of the rouble (against the US dollar and the euro). The weakening of the rouble in April could boost imported inflationary pressures, and we expect inflation to pick up modestly in the second half of the year, almost reaching the 4% target near the end of 2018, as the rouble depreciates against the US dollar compared with 2017 and consumer demand increases. In 2019-22 we expect inflation to remain close to-but slightly above-the 4% target (very low levels by historical standards).
Higher oil prices and a relatively tight monetary policy led to an average appreciation of the rouble against the US dollar in 2017 and in the first quarter of 2018. However, when the US imposed new sanctions on Russia on April 6th, the rouble lost about 12% of its value against the dollar, reaching Rb64.8:US$1 on April 11th. Taking into account the tightening of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve (the Fed, the US central bank) and the uncertainty surrounding possible new US sanctions, we forecast a modest depreciation of the rouble against the dollar, to an average of Rb60.2:US$1 in 2018.
We forecast an overall slight nominal appreciation in 2019-22, owing to increasing oil prices, although a downturn in the US business cycle will lower oil prices slightly and weaken the rouble in 2020. The rouble is correlated with oil prices, so any rapid fall in oil prices could lead to renewed volatility.
For central and east European countries with currencies pegged to or managed against the euro (mostly in the western Balkans), risks of volatility have moved in line with expectations of tightening by the Fed. However, we do not see significant risks to the currency boards in Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH) or Bulgaria, or to the peg in Macedonia. Croatia had been more of a concern, in the light of the 2015 legislation to force banks to convert Swiss franc-denominated loans into euro. However, the country's improved external and fiscal positions, and increased demand for the kuna as a result of a strong tourism performance, have driven appreciation, which we forecast will continue in 2018.
Currencies across the former Soviet Union depreciated sharply in 2015 as a result of the weakening of the rouble and lower oil prices, which hit commodity exporters. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan both officially abandoned their US dollar pegs in 2015. In practice, only Kazakhstan has allowed its currency to float. Given Kazakhstan's trade ties to the Russian economy, it would lose competiveness if the tenge appreciated significantly against the rouble. Azerbaijan appears to have returned to a US dollar peg since April 2017.

The UK economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. Average annual real GDP growth was firm in 2016 and 2017, at 1.9% and 1.8% respectively. However, the annual pace of growth slowed throughout 2017. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects real GDP growth to average 1.4% in 2018 and to remain broadly stable in 2019, at 1.5%.
We expect the modest slowdown in 2018-19 to be led by a deceleration in domestic demand. Consumer spending will weaken in response to the continued squeeze on real household incomes from high inflation. Consumer spending was fairly resilient to this pressure in 2017, reflecting employment gains, high levels of household borrowing and a decline in the savings ratio. In 2018 we expect employment growth to slow and greater uncertainty about the economic outlook to push up precautionary savings. Consumer spending will recover in 2019-22 as inflation eases, uncertainty recedes and unemployment edges lower. However, increased borrowing costs arising from tighter monetary policy will hold back the pace of the recovery in these years. We forecast that investment spending will decelerate in 2018-19 as a result of heightened un-certainty during difficult Brexit trade negotiations and higher cost pressures as a result of sterling's depreciation, before recovering in 2020-22 as these effects fade.
Mitigating the extent of the domestically driven slowdown in 2018 will be a positive contribution to GDP growth from the external balance as export volumes benefit from a competitiveness boost as a result of sterling's depreciation, while the weaker domestic demand environment reduces import growth. From 2019 we expect the trade balance to exert a drag on GDP growth owing to our forecast for a recovery in domestic demand, which will push up import growth again. Our expectation of a business cycle downturn in the US in 2020 and a deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU, which should take effect in 2021 and result in looser trade ties than before, will also constrain exports in 2020-22. We expect real GDP growth to pick up to 1.7% on average in those years.
The economic impact of the UK's vote to leave the EU on the wider regional economy could be substantial. In addition to the direct effect via trade and investment channels, over time the referendum result is also likely to compound centrifugal political and institutional dynamics in the EU and the euro zone. However, the short-term economic fallout from Brexit will be modest for Europe as a whole.

The euro zone recovery has gathered pace
The outlook for the European economy is brighter than it was two years ago, but growth is now decelerating. Real GDP growth gained momentum in 2017 as the recovery that had been building since 2013 became broad based. We expect EU28 growth to slow this year, from 2.5% in 2017 to 2.2%, before slowing to an annual average of 1.8% in 2019-22. Virtually all member states have registered firmer rates of expansion, and although country-level disparities persist, the region's recovery is looking healthier. In our view the economic recovery has further to run, partly because it is rooted in factors that will underpin sustainable demand, such as rising employment and household deleveraging. Furthermore, there remains significant slack in the euro zone economy that has yet to be absorbed.
Nevertheless, first-quarter GDP data and survey-based indicators show a natural moderation in activity from above-average growth rates in 2017. Our forecast, therefore, is that growth will slow in the euro area in 2018, to 2.1%, and then more clearly, to an annual average of 1.7% in 2019-22.
Additional risks to the region's economic prospects stem from external factors, notably monetary policy tightening in the US and protectionist sentiment washing through the global economy. The US let the EU's exemption from steel and aluminium tariffs expire in June, and the EU retaliated with its own measures on June 22nd. In turn, the US administration may decide to impose higher tariffs on EU automotive imports. This will be economically painful for both sides. We expect disagreements on trade to linger, but not to escalate to the point of an outright trade war. Nevertheless, the EU's trade surplus with the US-worth US$115bn in 2017-is unlikely to decline much in the coming years, meaning that trade will remain a politically sensitive topic that is likely to come back on to the agenda at any time.
The longer-term outlook for the euro zone also looks challenging. Demographic factors will begin to exert a more powerful drag on an increasing number of countries. We do not expect policymakers to find solutions to some of the euro zone's institutional shortcomings. In particular, they are unlikely to reform the fiscal policy framework. This means that tensions will increase between member states over targets for budget deficits.
In Germany the domestic demand-driven pick-up in real GDP growth accelerated in 2017, bringing headline growth to 2.5%. We forecast 2.1% growth in 2018, with the rate of economic expansion easing gradually thereafter, to 1.7% on average in 2019-22. Growth will be slower in France (owing to structural rigidities in the tax system and the labour market) and Italy (reflecting a weak demographic profile, political instability and a slow pace of reform).
In southern Europe the economic recovery on the Iberian peninsula may have peaked in 2017. After real GDP growth of 3% in Spain in 2017, we forecast average growth of 2.2% in 2018-22. Portugal recorded real GDP growth of 2.7% in 2017, and we forecast an expansion of 2.3% this year and 1.6% on average in 2019-22. Meanwhile, Greece will exit its third bail-out programme this year, but we are sceptical that the country will experience rapid growth. The Greek economy returned to growth in 2017 and should experience a modest rebound in 2018-22. The UK economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote, but is losing momentum and will slow in 2018-19 as economic uncertainty weighs on spending and investment, before recovering gradually.
The Visegrad countries can look forward to above-average growth rates
Much of central and eastern Europe faces a challenging environment in the longer term. However, countries that benefit from EU funding in particular will see real GDP growth well above the EU average in 2018-22. A deadline at the end of 2015 for fund drawdowns from the EU's 2007-13 fiscal period brought an end to a surge in investment spending. Funding inflows for projects under the 2014-20 funding period were slow to begin in 2016, holding back activity last year, but funds began to flow again in 2017 and projects are under way that will lift economic growth rates during the forecast period (2018-22). We expect that growth in Germany-a major market for these countries-will remain solid. The German economy's changing structure, with investment and private consumption rising, will provide a boost to central and east European countries with strong trade links to their larger neighbour.
Economic activity is picking up in south-east Europe
In south-east Europe the situation is generally improving after a protracted and difficult post-crisis recovery. We expect continued strong real GDP growth in the region's biggest economy, Romania (which grew by 7% in 2017), of 5% in 2018 and 3.4% per year in 2019-22. However, rapid wage growth is driving a consumer boom that is sucking in imports and inflating the current-account deficit, and tax cuts have widened the fiscal deficit. Bulgaria will also maintain the momentum established in 2015-17. In 2018-22 we expect real GDP growth to average 2.9%. This sustained pick-up is driven by improved performance in the euro zone, robust export performance and increased expenditure on infrastru-cture projects, which received a boost from a surge in the inflow of EU funds.
Growth in the western Balkans to accelerate; Baltics and Visegrad to slow
Economic activity in the western Balkans has picked up in the past three years, reflecting a combination of favourable base effects and externally driven cyclical factors such as low oil prices. In 2015-16 private investment and exports were the main drivers of growth in Albania, Montenegro and Serbia, with private consumption remaining weak, pointing to a more balanced growth trajectory. The region has undergone a significant economic adjustment in the years since the global economic crisis in 2007-09, largely correcting fiscal and current-account imbalances (with some notable exceptions, such as Montenegro). Inflation has fallen to historical lows for the region, allowing a more accommodative monetary policy that has supported growth. The revival of investment is set to continue, and over the medium and long term the western Balkans should benefit from the structural reforms that are now under way in most countries. On the downside, high public and/or private debt loads, and (in some cases) continued large fiscal deficits remain impediments to faster growth. We do not think that the fallout from the Brexit vote will be unduly negative for the Balkans, whose slow progress towards EU membership is set to continue.
We forecast average real GDP growth in the western Balkans (Albania, Bosnia and Hercegovina-BiH-Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia) of about 3.2% in 2018-22. We forecast that growth in the three Baltic states will decelerate from an average of 4.6% in 2017 to 3.4% per year in 2018-19.
Greece's economy has been in almost permanent recession since 2008. Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter during this period, government consumption also by nearly a quarter, house-hold consumption by a fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery that got under way in 2017 is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. We forecast that real GDP will expand by 1.9% per year on average in 2018-22, following growth of 1.3% in 2017.
In Turkey domestic political instability, the perceived risk of terrorist attacks and uncertainty about the global economic outlook weighed on the economy in 2015-16, but relative stability following the April 2017 presidential reform referendum and fiscal stimulus measures have supported a rebound to growth of 7.3% in 2017. We expect growth to slow to an annual average of about 4.2% in 2018-22, reflecting the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates and a gradual tightening of global liquidity. The main downside risk is that further political instability stemming from the transition to a presidential system of government could deter foreign capital inflows. Upside risk stems from government plans to extend stimulus measures, but this could also result in a larger than expected fiscal deficit.
Russia's economy has moved into a recovery phase
Real GDP in Russia grew by 1.5% in 2017, up from a contraction of 0.1% in 2016. The return to growth was mainly driven by private consumption and, to a lesser extent, fixed investment. In 2018 we expect a similar growth picture, with private consumption assuming even more of the burden for driving growth as one-off government infrastructure projects are completed. As indicated in the March state of the nation address given by Vladimir Putin, the president, government spending on wages and pensions should pick up this year. Economic stabilisation and a higher average oil price are supportive of a rise in gross fixed capital formation, but international sanctions, the lack of a "culture of failure", and broader political and business uncertainty will remain significant constraints. We expect import growth to slow, lessening the negative contribution from the external balance. Overall, this points to a slight increase in real GDP growth in 2018, to 1.7%. In the medium term outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, subdued investment levels, a weak financial sector, international sanctions, low productivity growth, a difficult business environment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth. We forecast that growth will average 1.7% per year in 2018-22, mainly driven by private consumption and, to a lesser extent, fixed investment, as in 2017.
The possible end of Russian gas transit in 2019 represents a big risk
Real GDP fell by a cumulative 16.4% in Ukraine in 2014-15 amid conflict and a chaotic political situation. The disruption of these years accentuated a structural change in the Ukrainian economy away from heavy industry and towards agriculture. The economy recovered in 2016, driven by vigorous growth in private invest-ment, alongside a recovery in private consumption. Real GDP grew by 2.5% in 2017, fuelled by private consumption and gross fixed capital formation. Better external conditions, increased social spending (boosting consumption) and a solid recovery in investment (domestically funded) supported growth. In 2018 we expect real GDP growth to rebound, to 3%, and in 2019-22 we expect growth to average 2.6%, led by household consumption. The probable end of Russian gas transit in 2019-when the current transit contract expires and the Nord Stream 2 pipeline connecting Russia to the EU through the Baltic Sea is supposed to begin operations-represents a risk.
Growth and exchange-rate movements in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) region are highly correlated to movements in global oil prices, especially in large oil exporters such as Russia, Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan. Owing to important trade links and high levels of remittance flows, the performance of the Russian economy has a direct impact on that of smaller CIS countries in Central Asia (the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan) and the South Caucasus (Armenia and Georgia, not CIS members). We forecast growth of 1.7% in Russia, 1.6% in Azerbaijan, 3.6% in Kazakhstan and 3% in Ukraine in 2018. Given our forecast for a broadly stable oil price of around US$73.4/barrel in 2018-22, barring other major developments the growth outlook for most countries is unlikely to change significantly from this year's final outturn.

The slump in global oil prices in late 2014 exacerbated a marked disinflationary trend in Europe, but helped to boost the region's real economy in 2015, and to a limited extent in 2016, as households benefited from higher real earnings and businesses from lower input costs. Since late 2016 inflation has picked up, with base effects-notably those related to energy prices-providing much of the initial impetus in early 2017. Despite the healthy economic outlook, inflation pressures in the euro zone remain modest. In May 2018 euro zone inflation accelerated to 1.9%, from 1.2% in April, but this increase was mostly due to higher energy prices. Nonetheless, we have revised our euro zone inflation forecast for 2018 to 1.6%, from 1.4% previously. We expect inflation to average 1.7% in the EU28 in 2018 and 1.9% per year in 2019-22.
In a number of specific instances across the region, different inflationary patterns will be recorded-Turkey, for example, will struggle throughout the forecast period to bring its inflation rate down to its 5% official target. Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high, as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of plunging global oil prices since mid-2014. Assuming that the Central Bank of Turkey keeps monetary policy tight and does not loosen it again too soon, we see inflation gradually easing, achieving the 5% target by end-2022.

The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings model seeks to measure the attractiveness of a country's business environment and its major components. The model's assessment of the business environment-based on the opportunities for and hindrances to the conduct of business-enables us to rank each of the 82 countries covered on its overall position and in each of ten categories on a global and a regional basis. The model uses quantitative data and expert assessments to measure the attractiveness of countries' business environments. The framework has been designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies in formulating their global business strategies and investment location decisions. The overall scores (on a 1-10 scale) and rankings are based on scores for 91 indicators, grouped into ten categories.
There is a moderate improvement in Europe's aggregate regional scores between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22), reflecting the transition from the post-crisis period to one in which recovery and repair, although patchy, have, in most countries, been under way for some time. Western Europe's score remains broadly stable, rising from 7.46 in the historical period to 7.67 in the forecast period, and eastern Europe's score moves up from 6.07 to 6.50 over the same timeframe. Across the region, the strongest ranking improvements are recorded by Denmark, Romania, Croatia and Cyprus. By contrast, Turkey drops by ten places, Switzerland by six, and Greece and Ireland by four. Western Europe is ranked second globally out of six regions, after North America (8.21), and eastern Europe is ranked fourth, after North America, western Europe, and Asia and Australasia (6.79), but performs better than Latin America (5.74), and the Middle East and Africa (5.62).
EU countries remain well represented in the top 20 of our global rankings. Two non-EU countries, Switzerland and Norway, also occupy leading positions. The large number of west European countries in the top 20 reflects the high degree of political stability in the region (a post-crisis rise in social and political tension notwithstanding), large and competitive domestic markets, and a strong degree of openness to world trade. Although we continue to highlight the risks of political fragmentation and rising anti-establishment sentiment, we do not forecast a marked anti-market backlash in policy choices.
Recent years have brought considerable improvement to the investment climate of central and eastern Europe. The early reformers among the countries of central Europe led the way in the early 1990s in adopting far-reaching stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation programmes. Reform in the Balkans has been much more uneven and subject to periodic reversals, but significant progress has been made even here. Factors such as a low-cost but well-qualified labour force, proximity to developed markets and, in some cases, ample natural-resource endowments have attracted considerable foreign direct investment to the region during the past decade. However, many east European countries still face fundamental reform challenges; meeting those challenges will test already fraying relations between governments and electorates, and heighten the risk of political instability and social unrest.
The outlook for the business environment in the countries of the former Soviet Union is mixed. In Russia the business environment has suffered as a result of Western sanctions and a rise in tariff and non-tariff barriers. There is little evidence that the government intends to undertake disruptive structural reform to improve the dynamism of the economy. Low energy prices have prompted some regional commodity exporters, notably Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, to attempt to open up and diversify their economies. Ukraine has committed itself to an ambitious reform programme; however, its economic prospects will be harmed by disruption of trade and financial ties with Russia. Throughout the region the barriers to enacting wide-ranging reform remain formidable.
Data sources and definitions
Methodology
The forecast tables have been constructed from the individual data series available in the respective Economist Intelligence Unit Country Forecasts. In addition, the Economist Intelligence Unit runs the National Institute's Global Econometric Model (NIGEM), which is developed and maintained by the London Business School at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Abstract: In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. [...]wastefulness at state-owned firms and massive corruption and clientelism schemes built around the delivery of subsidised goods and services would be hard to roll back without antagonising government backers, risking political instability. [...]we would expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA. [...]we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. [...]we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2018-22 period, ending 2022 at 6.9% GDP.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Economic collapse and the erosion of the patronage scheme supporting the president, Nicolás Maduro, put the ruling regime's internal cohesion in jeopardy. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a traumatic rift that will end in regime pragmatists allowing opposition participation in a "mixed admin-istration" as a way to remain in power from 2019 onwards. There is a risk that the regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,000% at the end of 2017 and will average over 10,000% in 2018. GDP will continue to contract in 2018-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate a fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 82th position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit business environment rankings, making it the least attractive investment location in the world. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition. Property rights remain weak.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Opaque currency controls add to uncertainty, severely restrict private-sector access to foreign exchange and impede trade. New government in 2019 starts removing exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Amid severely high inflation, financing remains only available in the short term and banking sector shrinks in real terms.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Underinvestment in the water and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing
Technological readiness
2018-19: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies.
2020-22: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is how to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 1.3% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Despite a decimated economy and spiralling hyperinflation, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) and the president, Nicolás Maduro, retain their hold on power. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition, most likely ushering in a government with nominal opposition participation-a "mixed administration"-in 2019.
The opposition, of which the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) is the biggest grouping, remains in disarray. Apart from infighting, this reflects the PSUV's systematic campaign to disfranchise opposition parties and sideline them from state institutions. After years of ineffectual leadership, most citizens, even those opposing the PSUV, distrust opposition parties. This has left them incapable of channelling the anti-government sentiment brewing in response to the country's dire economic situation.
In this context of unrest and repression, the PSUV is increasingly dependent on the military for support. The country is run by civic-military alliance and a network of businessmen that enjoy military or political connections. The accord is sustained by opportunities for arbitrage and corruption made possible by foreign-exchange controls; subsidised imports of basic goods; and control of large and inefficient public-sector companies. Within this opaque arrangement, factions are primarily explained by personal and patronage ties, which mean that different civic-military factions coexist within the regime. The ultimate source of resources flowing through this patronage system is PDVSA, the state-owned oil company, whose exports account for the vast majority of foreign-exchange inflows.
Jeopardising the arrangement is a rapid decline in oil production due to mismanagement and underinvestment. Resultant strains have been highlighted by purges of the military, the latest coming in March. A rigged election on May 20th saw Mr Maduro re-elected, but exposed cracks in regime. Of those casting votes for Mr Maduro's re-election, the vast majority selected the PSUV proper, with a minority choosing Mr Maduro's Somos Venezuela. The PSUV proper is led by Diosdado Cabello, a long-time internal rival of Mr Maduro who has extensive military and business ties. Mr Cabello is a leading figure in the regime, but other factions within the PSUV also exist. Unless the administration turns PDVSA around (we see this as unlikely, as the government lacks the required expertise or financing), we believe that the patronage system supporting Mr Maduro will be at risk of collapse by 2019.
Internal fracture in the regime may happen earlier than 2019, as the secular trend towards lower oil output may be hastened by sanctions on oil trade by the US, PDVSA's largest cash-paying market. Following the May 20th vote, the US rolled out sanctions designed to complicate PDVSA's exports. Similarly, PDVSA's unpaid debts may lead to asset seizures that impede trade. In May ConocoPhillips, a US firm pursuing collection of an arbitration award, seized PDVSA's infrastructure in the Caribbean, disrupting exports. The parties are reportedly negotiating an agreement but if such measures become commonplace and/or reach Citgo, PDVSA's US subsidiary, exports could be disrupted indefinitely.
Regardless of the timing, what happens following the internal fracture is hard to predict. The transition is likely to be violent. The PSUV's internal stability is a concern, as the end of the current set-up is likely to unleash jostling for position between the PSUV's varied civic-military factions. If no faction secures sufficient internal consensus, a period of chaos of indeterminate duration may ensue. Alternatively, the regime may reconfigure itself, with an outright military government or PSUV civilian figureheads fronting a military-heavy administration. Such administrations would probably look to Russia and China, erstwhile backers, for aid to stabilise both the economy and PDVSA. However, we believe that the required financing-tens of billions of US dollars per year-is beyond Russia's means. China has scaled back its relations with Venezuela since 2015. Given that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, stabilisation of PDVSA and the economy would be likely to take priority under a new government, and we would expect regime pragmatists to seek western assistance-specifically from multilaterals and governments. As these financiers will demand democratic reforms, we believe that the most likely outcome is a "mixed administration", in which pragmatically minded military and PSUV leaders allow opposition participation as a way of gaining inter-national legitimacy. Given past behaviour, there should be no shortage of opposition figures willing to participate.
The main risk to our baseline view is that regime pragmatists will be unable to convince other regime members of the benefit of this arrangement. For example, democratic reforms that western lenders would insist on may not be acceptable to some PSUV figures. Similarly, foreign financing would underpin a macroeconomic programme that-by eliminating the economy's distortions-would close avenues for corruption and upset regime insiders. Other hurdles of uncertain size will remain. These include the judiciary, the de facto legislature that is the Constituent Assembly and violent extremist supporters of the current regime known as colectivos.
Overall, we expect a chaotic transition starting in late 2018 or early 2019. The process will be highly uncertain and may feature several false starts. We expect curtailed political stability in 2019-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Mr Maduro comfortably won re-election on May 20th. However, voter turnout was exceedingly low, at 46%, denting his legitimacy and introducing questions about the regime's actual control of the population. (The PSUV's turn-out-the-vote operation uses a combination of ideological affinity and coercive tactics to corral voters.) We do not expect free and fair elections in the short term. Based on our assumption of a new government comprised of government and opposition pragmatists, an electoral timetable may be announced, as international financing will almost certainly come with demands for democratic reforms.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Most regional governments have denounced the Venezuelan government, as has the EU. The most effective sanctions have come from the US, which has instituted country-level sanctions that deny Venezuela the possibility of refinancing its debts. Sanctions banning the oil trade outright are not part of our baseline assumption, but a hawkish US foreign policy team increases the risk of this happening. A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia and China. Both have provided financing in the past, but seem unwilling to provide the several billions of dollars needed to stem the decline of oil output.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government remains unable and unwilling to undertake the policy changes needed to address its main challenges, namely declining oil production, hyperinflation and mounting arrears on external debt. Most sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including those of PDVSA) are now in arrears. The government has called for debt restructuring, but it appears impossible, owing to US financial sanctions and, more fundamentally, because the government lacks a credible economic programme. There is no sign yet of lawsuits by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer the promise of late payment to lengthy legal battles. Investors may also be waiting for news of policy changes following the May election or a change in leadership. In the meantime, both the sovereign and PDVSA are open to legal challenges in the US. Such seizures could hit exports, the regime's economic lifeline.
In the meantime, the government must grapple with a severe economic crisis. Monetisation of large public deficits and dwindling exports has led to foreign currency rationing and hyper-inflation. The government has devalued the official exchange rate, but monetary imbal-ances persist and foreign-exchange continues to be rationed. Economic policy will remain interventionist in the short term, deepening the economic crisis that drives our baseline forecast of a move towards a mixed administration.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect more orthodox economic policies to be implemented. However, the administration will face considerable internal limitations in addressing key policy challenges. For example, wastefulness at state-owned firms and massive corruption and clientelism schemes built around the delivery of subsidised goods and services would be hard to roll back without antagonising government backers, risking political instability. Thus, we would expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA.
Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. Internal cohesiveness in the mixed administration will be key, as the PSUV is ideologically opposed to such borrowing and multilateral financing is likely to come with conditions on democratic reforms. Meanwhile, PDVSA must open itself to foreign investment to secure the finance needed to bring output back on track. This will require considerable political capital, as it would imply a wholesale revision of the sector's institutional framework. Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV will remain a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members, who would oppose accepting international assistance and reforming policy.
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bend in the economy. As a result, we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published data on fiscal accounts since 2011, when the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit was 12% of GDP. We forecast an NFPS deficit of 15.5% of GDP in 2018, which will largely be financed by printing money. High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2018-22 period, ending 2022 at 6.9% GDP.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. At the end of May M2 increased by 6,297% year on year. The government has not announced any change in policy other than planning to take three zeroes off the currency. However, the plan has been put on hold for logistical reasons. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation, and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Amid ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-20, following an estimated contraction of 13.9% in 2017. Our forecast recovery in 2021-22 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF financial and institutional assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of the country's oil wealth at its centre. However, the reform programme will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we only expect a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of over 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract as well, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in investment in the oil sector. Oil output-already in the midst of a long decline owing to mismanagement and underinvestment-has contracted beyond expectations in recent months; we now expect it to bottom out at 1.2m barrels/day (b/d) in early 2020, down from an average of 1.95m b/d in 2017. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from around 2019, oil production will start a recovery in the second half of 2020, but will remain well below 2m b/d even at the end of our forecast period in 2022. Export volumes will only start to recover in 2021, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly has estimated that monthly inflation was 80% in April, bringing year-on-year inflation to over 13,000%. We expect inflation to average over 10,000% in 2018. There is a high risk of a hyperinflationary spiral in coming months that increases inflation to well above our current forecast and necessitates a dramatic adjustment, probably involving a resort to currency substitution.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 95%. The rate is supposedly determined by an auction system, but the government-which mono-polises the country's exports-has not supplied the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible, even at the current rates. In early June the black-market exchange rate was around BsF1,200,000:US$1; the official rate stood at BsF90,000:US$1.
Given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market and growing hyperinflation, the government may, as part of a stabilisation plan, introduce a new domestic currency or attempt some kind of currency substitution in the future. Under our current political assumptions, similar measures may be undertaken after 2019. The exact nature and implementation of the plan is hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We expect the current-account surplus to reach US$5.6bn in 2018 (2.4% of GDP at the distorted exchange rate, which overstates the GDP in dollar terms), owing to continued import compression. However, Venezuela's lack of access to foreign finance means that the current-account surplus will not be enough to meet the country's financing needs. Indeed, excluding arrears, we calculate that principal repayments of sovereign and state-owned companies' bonded debt alone will amount to US$3.5bn in 2018. As such, we expect further arrears in 2018 and 2019. By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following a debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored and imports will begin a recovery. We expect the surge in imports to tip the current account into a deficit of 6.3% of GDP in 2020 at a less highly distorted exchange rate. The restructured interest payment schedule will mean lower outflows, but the slow recovery of the oil sector and years of unmet import demand will mean that the current-account deficit will remain high, at over 5% of GDP in 2021-22.
Assuming that a new administration takes power from around 2019, we expect financial and investment inflows to provide sufficient financing, stabilise balance-of-payments dynamics and help to rebuild reserves coverage. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming a pragmatic unity government capable of retaining power, it hinges on a substantial assistance package from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-22, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
