Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The ruling centre-right Cambiemos coalition government is under increasing political pressure amid recent currency volatility and an IMF bailout (the Fund is unpopular in Argentina), but will be hoping to get its policy agenda back on track in time for the presidential election, when the president, Mauricio Macri, will seek a second term. However, the opposition will increasingly obstruct policy. Cambiemos lacks a congressional majority, meaning that the administration has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda on an ad hoc basis with various factions of Argentina's dominant Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party).
Currency depreciation pressure amid an emerging-market sell-off has introduced substantial political uncertainty, but major changes to economic policymaking are not envisaged under the terms of the IMF lending arrangement, other than a more rapid tightening of fiscal policy. The US$50bn stand-by arrangement was approved on June 20th and includes targets for a tightening of fiscal policy to produce a primary fiscal balance by 2020 (in order to contain growth in the public debt/GDP ratio and reduce inflationary deficit financing), and provisions for central-bank target independence to be enshrined in law, to help to tackle the inflation problem (the root of Argentina's external competitiveness problem, which is in turn driving devaluation pressures). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that programme targets will be met, and will gradually reduce inflation and engender macro-economic stability over time.
A spike in interest rates and a tightening of fiscal policy amid currency pressures will weigh on economic activity, and we have revised our forecast for real GDP growth in 2018 to 1.6%, down from 2.3% previously. For now, our view of medium-term GDP growth remains broadly unchanged, although the risks to our forecasts have risen substantially. Under our benign baseline forecast, we expect growth to fluctuate around 3% in 2020-22.
More front-loaded currency weakening than previously projected will provide some boost to external competitiveness, but even so, the current-account deficit will remain large in 2018, and import cover will dip from 7.6 months to around seven months this year. Thereafter, we expect the current-account deficit to narrow steadily to just below 3% of GDP in 2022.
Argentina's GDP per head is among the highest in the region and, combined with improved access to credit, moderate rates of economic growth in the medium term will boost purchasing power and create market opportunities. Still-high poverty rates and income inequality will restrict the pool of consumers, but to a lesser extent than in many other countries in the region.

Argentina's global business environment score improves in 2018-22, and the country jumps 12 places in our global ranking. Economic policy adjustment is under way as the government works to tighten macroeconomic policy, reduce state intervention in the private sector and encourage private investment. However, in many areas improvements will take time to materialise.
Country forecast overview: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2020-22: Continued work to build faith in legal and regulatory frameworks. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2018-19: Proactive, welcoming approach to foreign investment. Attempts to resolve outstanding disputes with creditors.
2020-22: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance, comprising Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.
2020-22: Possibility that new free-trade agreements are signed.
Taxes
2018-19: Further gradual reductions of export taxes to encourage domestic supply. Tax reforms to promote investment and reduce tax pressure.
2020-22: Comprehensive tax reform to improve federal-provincial revenue sharing a possibility, but obstacles to reform persist. System remains complex, despite recent reforms.
Financing
2018-19: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2020-22: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2018-19: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of unions remains strong.
2020-22: Limited progress on labour reform. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2018-19: The Macri administration continues to improve contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes.
2020-22: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Quality of e-commerce business environment good. Upgrade of 4G capabilities.
2020-22: More progress on increasing scope of e-government as part of process to reduce red tape. Increase in research and development spending as percentage of GDP, but still relatively low compared with more developed markets.

Background: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983, after 50 years of instability and military regimes. Economic liberalisation in the 1990s drove firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and fail-ure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of Fernando de la Rúa's centre-left government. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party) began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanage-ment drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015.
Political structure: A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house); in practice, however, the presidency dominates. The presidential term is four years. There are 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district, each with its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies and the commodity supercycle contributed to GDP growth of an annual average 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to controls and ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. These policies did not reduce devaluation speculation, and left the economy extremely vulnerable to currency crisis. Macroeconomic adjustments to try to reduce economic distortions are taking place under Mr Macri; these include the shift to a free float at the end of 2015, fiscal and monetary tightening, and reforms to boost domestic supply, but the pace of adjustment has been insufficient to prevent severe currency pressure, and in mid-2018 the government was forced to turn to the IMF for a stand-by lending arrangement involving tighter fiscal targets.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at a lower rate of 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. Under a tax reform approved at end-2017, the corporate income tax rate will fall to 30% in 2019 and 25% in 2021. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions (deposits and withdrawals).
Foreign trade: The current account moved from surplus to deficit in 2010. By 2017 the deficit had widened to 4.8% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Argentina was hit hard by an emerging-market sell-off in May, and although turbulence in the foreign-exchange market has subsided with the announce-ment of a US$50bn IMF stand-by lending arrangement, recent developments could have lasting political consequences for the government. The Fund is supportive of Argentina, and The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect dramatic changes in the course of economic policy, which is already geared towards macroeconomic and microeconomic reforms to restore stability and promote more solid, stable economic growth. The problem for the president, Mauricio Macri, and his ruling centre-right Cambiemos coalition, is that the Fund has a very poor reputation in Argentina, reflecting its role before and after the country's deep economic crisis of 2001-02. Argentina's return to the Fund will, therefore, weigh on the government's approval ratings, and will embolden the opposition, with less than 18 months to go until the presidential election.
The government will be hoping to get its policy agenda back on track in time for the presidential election, when Mr Macri will seek a second term. However, the opposition will be smelling blood and will increasingly obstruct policy. Cambiemos lacks a congressional majority, meaning that the administration has to negotiate legislative support on an ad hoc basis with various factions of the Partido Justicialista (PJ, the Peronist party). The PJ, which dominated politics for decades before Mr Macri's election victory in 2015, is struggling to regroup from that defeat and is beset by internal divisions. The party is currently split between a left-wing, populist faction and a centrist faction that, as yet, has no single, clear leader. The PJ's divisions have until now worked in the government's favour, allowing the government to pursue its legislative agenda with the support of moderate Peronists. Moreover, until now Mr Macri has remained relatively popular, with voters giving him the benefit of the doubt on the need for economic adjustment. But patience is wearing thin.
In this environment, the opposition will begin manoeuvring for position ahead of the presidential election, and the government will now struggle to push its agenda through. In the aftermath of its strong performance in the October 2017 mid-terms, the government moved quickly to pass reforms to the tax system, pensions and competition policy (and in May managed to pass capital market reforms). But in coming months, major reforms will be on hold, and opposition challenges to policy initiatives that are presented will increase. All this means that much-needed reforms to increase the flexibility of labour markets, improve the effective-ness of the judiciary, and enhance investor confidence in institutions and contract rights will be on the back burner. On our current assumption that Mr Macri wins a second term in 2019, we expect that improvements in these areas will start to yield results more clearly late on in our five-year forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The next presidential election is due in October 2019. Notwithstanding the president's current difficulties, we currently continue to assume that Mr Macri will win a second four-year term, based on our assumption of moderate GDP growth and substantial reduction of inflation by then. There are large, and growing, risks to this forecast. Reflecting the difficulties faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist government has won a second consecutive term since the end of the military dictatorship in the 1980s. The emergence of a strong challenger from the Peronist party is therefore likely (although it is as yet unclear who this will be), and the election will be closely fought.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Reflecting efforts by the Macri government to repair relations with trade and investment partners in the region and elsewhere, and we expect relations with key partners to remain strong. The country took over the rotating presidency of the G20 in December 2017, and is pursuing an agenda centred on the future of jobs, infrastructure and food security. The government is keen to seek trade deals under the auspices of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union). The problem for Argentina and its Mercosur partners is that, just as the grouping has started to reverse its own protectionist tendencies, anti-globalisation sentiment has grown in the OECD. However, Mr Macri is continuing to seek support for an EU-Mercosur trade deal from his counterparts in Europe, and negotiations are continuing, although they are slow moving. In the meantime, Mercosur members including Argentina have pushed for free-trade negotiations elsewhere, including with Canada and China, and for closer relations with the Pacific Alliance free-trade area. All of these negotiations are also likely to move slowly, however.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Currency depreciation pressure amid an emerging-market sell-off has intro-duced substantial political uncertainty, but major changes to economic policymaking are not envisaged under the terms of the IMF lending arrangement, other than a more rapid tightening of fiscal policy. The govern-ment has made progress since it came to office at the end of 2015 and began grappling with the task of restoring macroeconomic stability while improving conditions for busi-ness. But macroeconomic adjustment is clearly incomplete: inflation came in at 26.3% in May, amid continued utilities tariff rises (intended to reduce the fiscal burden of subsidies and promote investment by bringing utilities prices towards market rates), and the fiscal deficit remains substantial, at 6% of GDP in 2017.
Still-high inflation has contributed to currency over-valuation, which has in turn produced a large and growing current-account deficit. These imbalances have contributed to the sharp peso adjustment of the past two months, and to the government's decision to seek an IMF lending deal to restore market confidence. The US$50bn stand-by arrangement was approved on June 20th and an initial disbursement of US$15bn was made available immediately for deficit financing and to help to restore reserves coverage ratios. The government may treat the deal as precautionary going forward, and future drawdowns will depend on market access. The deal includes targets for a tightening of fiscal policy to produce a primary fiscal balance by 2020 (in order to contain growth in the public debt/GDP ratio and reduce inflationary deficit financing), and provisions for central-bank target independence to be enshrined in law, to help to tackle the inflation problem (the root of Argentina's external competitiveness problem, which is in turn driving devaluation pressures).
We expect that programme targets will be met, and will gradually reduce inflation and engender macro-economic stability over time. This will have positive implications for the external sector and growth. The biggest risks to this outlook are political, and reflect the possibility that voter (as well as business) confidence in the Macri admin-istration and the economic outlook feeds into further market volatility and economic activity. This would not only complicate the adjustment process, but also threaten our assumption that Mr Macri will secure a second term in power, raising questions as to the future direction of economic policy under a new government.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In its first two years of office the government pursued gradual fiscal tightening (so as not to thwart economic growth), but, in the face of market pressure, it has now accelerated the pace of adjustment under the auspices of the Fund deal. The fiscal targets set out in the deal were broadly in line with our expectations and allow for a relatively gradual adjustment. In fact, we have made modest revisions in the past month to show a laxer than expected primary deficit target of 1.3% of GDP in 2019 (versus our expectation of 0.8% of GDP) under the Fund deal. This partly reflects provisions that allow for increased social safety net expenditure.
Bearing in mind that the government beat its fiscal target in the first five months of 2018 by a substantial margin, the 2018 target should not be difficult to meet, although it will require cuts to planned capital spending, which will have a knock-on impact on economic growth. Apart from capital spending, expenditure restraint will come via a phasing out of costly energy subsidies and the recent approval of a social security reform that will produce substantial savings (0.4% of GDP per year from 2018). The biggest risks to meeting the fiscal target centre on the government's ability to maintain public-sector wage restraint amid above-target inflation and strong public-sector union power, as well as below-target revenue, reflecting an expected deceleration of economic activity this year.
The government is-for now at least-facing a problem with liquidity rather than solvency. With the benefit of US$50bn in IMF lending, and assuming that market access improves as currency pressure subsides (and in the aftermath of Argentina's recent upgrade from "frontier" to "emerging" market status in the MSCI index (MSCI is an index provider whose classifications are widely used by global investors), which will allow for increased capital inflows from institutional investors), financing the fiscal deficit should not prove problematic. However, the public debt/GDP ratio is likely to continue to rise in 2018 to just over 60% of GDP, before stabilising in the remainder of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the central bank) has tight-ened monetary policy sharply to help to stem currency pressures, and will unwind its rate rises only very slowly. Over little more than a week at the start of May the bank raised the policy rate by 1,275 basis points, to 40%. Further currency depreciation is possible in the short term, and further rate rises remain a risk (although for now we expect rates to stay on hold). Recent sharp policy tightening will eventually restore some calm, allowing the central bank to begin to unwind its dramatic rate rise over the next few months. This process will be complicated, however, by weak confidence in the nascent inflation-targeting regime, which means that inflation expectations are not well anchored and pass-through from currency depreciation into consumer prices is relatively high.
Weak confidence in the inflation target reflects several factors, but important among them is the government's own strategic error of relaxing the 2018 inflation target at the end of 2017. The government states that this change was geared at making the inflation target more realistic, but resultant perceptions of discord between the government and the central bank have damaged domestic confidence in the inflation target. This led in June to the departure of the central bank president, Federico Sturzenegger, in an effort to restore credibility in policymaking. His replacement, the former finance minister, Luis Caputo, is well known and well regarded, but more than staffing changes, real progress on disinflation will be required to restore confidence in monetary policymaking.
The BCRA has been clear in its view that current price pressures are temporary, and we share this view. But in the meantime, the latest rapid slide in the currency will feed through to a spike in prices in May-June. We do still expect monthly inflation to start to ease towards 1% on a con-sistent basis late in 2018, once the effects of currency depreciation and tariff adjustment start to fade. This should allow for gradual monetary easing, taking the nominal policy rate to slightly above 30% by year-end. Our forecasts thereafter assume moderately positive real interest rates in the medium term.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Although the latest data show that growth remained firm in the first quarter of 2018, at 1.1% on a seasonally adjusted sequential basis, activity will be hit hard in the second quarter, not just by tighter macroeconomic policy and the jolt to confidence following the currency turmoil and IMF bail-out, but also by the effects of a severe drought, which will hit the harvest of two key crops, soya and maize. Agriculture accounts for a fairly hefty 11% of GDP, and agro-industry is also important to the economy. Reflecting new data showing that the negative effect of the drought will be stronger in the second quarter than we previously expected, we have revised our forecast for real GDP growth in 2018 down substantially this month, to 1.6%, from 2.3% previously. Growth will remain weak in the second half of 2018, and will provide less momentum going into 2019, and on this basis, we have also revised downward our GDP forecast for next year fairly substantially, from 2.9% to 2.3%. For now our forecasts for the second part of the forecast period (2020-22) are unchanged, although the risks to our forecasts have risen substantially. Under our benign baseline forecast, we expect growth to fluctuate around 3% 2020-22, staying below 3% in 2020 amid a projected cyclical downturn in the US, before accelerating back above 3% in 2021-22. This projected acceleration rests on the assumption that that implementation of recently passed and ongoing structural reforms will gradually boost economic activity. There is increasing downside risk to this assumption, in the form of a weakening of consumer and business confidence, and the potential for a much more tense presidential election period in 2019.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
The reduction of inflation will continue to be complicated in the short term by gradual increases in utilities tariffs as these are brought closer in line with market prices. On top of this, rapid recent peso depreciation, in a context of unanchored inflation expectations, will produce substantial pass-through effects, keeping inflation high in the very short term. However, assuming that macroeconomic policy remains tight under the auspices of the IMF deal, domestic demand remains subdued relative to the boom years of 2004-11, and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environment for agricultural and other producers, we continue to expect gradual disinflation in the medium term. It will take quite some time, however, for inflation to fall to single-digit levels. According to our baseline forecast, this will happen towards the end of 2020.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The peso has been badly hit in the past two months as investors that had previously given the administration the benefit of the doubt over its ability to reverse macroeconomic imbalances zeroed in on the country's large fiscal and current-account deficits. The latter reflects clear overvaluation of the peso, a problem that worsened last year as huge inflows of portfolio capital produced real currency appreciation. As a result, at end-2017 the real effective exchange rate was 14% stronger than the average of the previous 20 years. Recent currency adjustment will go some way to reversing this trend, assuming that disinflation occurs as expected from late 2018. In the short term, we believe that co-ordinated efforts by the government and the central bank to regain the confidence of investors will be successful in preventing an uncontrolled devaluation of the peso in coming weeks. However, we expect the peso to continue to depreciate in both nominal and real terms, to address the problem of currency overvaluation. Under our baseline forecast, the currency will depreciate to Ps28.4:US$1 at end-2018 and Ps37.7:US$1 at end-2022. There remains a high risk, however, of much sharper currency weakening in coming months.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
More front-loaded currency weakening than previously projected will provide some boost to external competitiveness, but even so, in 2018 the current-account deficit will remain large, with the boost to net exports of goods and services becoming more evident from 2019. Even in 2022 we expect the current-account deficit to remain substantial (although more manageable), at 2.8% of GDP. After a period of huge inflows of portfolio capital in 2016-17, access to finance will be trickier and more costly in 2018-19; meanwhile, inflows of foreign direct investment will average an unspectacular 2.1% of GDP in 2018-22. This will be reflected in import cover, which recovered from a low of just four months to 7.6 months in 2017, but will dip back to seven months in 2018-22, even assuming that reserves recover slightly in the rest of 2018 from their recent lows of around US$50bn.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Turkey is due to hold early parliamentary and presidential elections on June 24th 2018, ahead of the original date in late 2019.
The elections were brought forward in the light of growing economic uncertainties; the still high popularity of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and the ruling Justice and Development (AKP) party; and the rise in nationalist sentiment in the context of Turkey's military operations in northern Syria.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the elections and remain in power throughout the forecast period (2018-22).
After the elections an executive presidency will replace the current parliamentary system of government. The new system will provide only few checks on the president's powers.
The AKP has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that period political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign-policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
Since the failed coup in 2016 there has been a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a complete rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth from 7.3% in 2017 to a still robust 4.2% per year on average in 2018-22, reflecting higher taxes, higher interest rates, a gradual tightening of global liquidity and more moderate export growth.
We expect an annual average government budget deficit of 3% of GDP on average in 2018-19. We forecast that the budget deficit will narrow gradually, to 1.8% of GDP in 2022, as fiscal revenue increases.
We expect the current-account deficit to widen in 2018, to 6.6% of GDP, before contracting to a still large 4.7% per year on average in 2019-22. Turkey will struggle to meet its important external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but in the global rankings the country falls by 11 places, to 60th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, are introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2018-19: Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey not to raise interest rates significantly remains possible. Risk of the US imposing fines on several Turkish banks over alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran.
2020-22: Banking system remains stable, despite weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: First phase of third airport in Istanbul, the capital, becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Spending on research and development remains moderate at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2020-22: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe (in 1949) and NATO (in 1952), and signed an association agreement with the then European Community (in 1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. A presidential system of government will come into effect after snap elections in June 2018. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted institutional weaknesses that, with the AKP's consent until 2013, had allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) came to US$166bn and imports (fob) to US$225bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn-a sharp widening from US$41bn in 2016. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
On April 18th, after many conflicting statements, the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, of the ruling religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), called early presidential and parliamentary elections. Both votes will be held on June 24th, well ahead of the originally scheduled date of November 2019, as the president seeks to take advantage of his current popularity. The vote will conclude Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. Under the new system the president will be granted wide-ranging executive powers, including in the selection of the majority of top officials in the judiciary, and parliament will be greatly weakened. Municipal elections are still due in March 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, will win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and possibly beyond.
The elections will take place under emergency rule. This was initially introduced after the failed coup attempt to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. Emergency rule has allowed Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place. It has also allowed the government to continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, to curtail freedoms of expression, assembly and association, and to politicise the judiciary. Similar to the situation at the April 2017 referendum, the state of emergency is likely to provide an advantage to Mr Erdogan and the AKP in what will be a highly contested election. Recent changes to the electoral law, including an amendment allowing the use of unstamped ballots, raise the risk of electoral fraud and an illegitimate election outcome. Against this backdrop, the credibility of the election will probably be challenged, which will further polarise the country and increase risks to political and social stability. Although an unlikely prospect, failure by Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win both the presidential and parliamentary elections could throw the political system into chaos and open up irreparable divisions in the AKP.
The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup in July 2016 appear to have eased to a large extent, but security risk remains high. Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK are interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1980s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria are seeking to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK, but risk further fuelling the conflict with the PKK in Turkey's south-east. Failure by the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) to surpass the high 10% threshold for entry to parliament could exacerbate tensions in the south-east. The defeat of IS in Syria and Iraq could result in renewed attacks in Turkey and elsewhere.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The parliamentary and presidential elections will be held on June 24th, earlier than the originally scheduled date of late 2019. The elections were brought forward in the light of the high and growing economic uncertainties, the still high popularity of Mr Erdogan and the AKP, and the rise in nationalist sentiment in the context of Turkey's military operations in northern Syria.
The AKP, in alliance with the Nationalist Action Party (MHP), will face a non-negligible challenge from an opposition that, despite being ideologically diverse, is rallying around a shared "anti-Erdogan" view. The opposition alliance includes the Republican People's Party (CHP); the recently formed Good Party (IP), a group that broke away from the MHP following the MHP's support of the constitutional referendum; the smaller, conservative Islamic Felicity Party (SP); and the Democratic Party (DP). The HDP has not joined the alliance.
The AKP's hegemonic position in Turkish politics has suffered in recent years, but we expect Mr Erdogan and his party to win the presidential election and garner a coalition majority (with the MHP) in the parliamentary election. The opposition is fragmented, Mr Erdogan's popularity is unrivalled and he has the support of the right-wing, nationalist MHP. Importantly, the AKP also has the ability to control the election process through the state of emergency rule.
If Mr Erdogan fails to pass the 50% threshold in the first round of the presidential election on June 24th a second-round run-off would be held on July 8th between Mr Erdogan and the candidate with the second-largest share of votes. In the unlikely case that Mr Erdogan wins the presidential vote but the AKP-MHP coalition loses the parliamentary election, it is likely that the president would call a second parliamentary and presidential election.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. There is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding these allies' concerns that under Mr Erdogan Turkey is pivoting eastwards towards Russia, China and Iran. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; the US's military backing of PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; tensions over gas exploration in the eastern Mediterranean; Turkey's forging of closer relations with non-Western countries; and, more recently, growing tensions with Israel in the aftermath of the US's decision to relocate its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of the country's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals-notably, to become president with executive powers after the elections.
The country's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and increasingly transactional rather than strategic, but we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a complete breakdown in relations. However, this might become unavoidable if the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, the US imposes sanctions on Turkey over violations by Turkish banks of US sanctions against Iran, or Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces or withdraws from NATO, none of which can be ruled out. Operation Olive Branch, Turkey's crossborder military operation in Afrin in north-western Syria that was launched in January 2018, has accentuated tensions with the US. The operation cleared the area of US-backed, PKK-affiliated Kurdish groups that are intent on establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey.
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in neighbouring Syria will continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where they are co-operating but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, an intensification of domestic political instability, rising regional tensions and tightening global liquidity con-ditions could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period (2018-22).
These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements (savings have always been low), but tend to be short-term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region have put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, most recently in May 2018, fuelling an acceleration in inflation as well as increasing the cost to firms of servicing their foreign debt (in local currency terms) and thereby raising the risk of defaults for corporates.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards fiscal loosening and relatively tight monetary policy.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-have given the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy in the aftermath of the attempted coup. As a result, the central government deficit, which captures most of the public-sector expenses, expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to 1.5% in 2017. Despite a series of tax increases this year, increased government spending on defence, security, infrastructure projects, public employment and social benefits will cause the deficit to widen further, to an annual average of 3% of GDP in 2018-19, before gradually narrowing to 1.8% in 2022. We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to decline gradually, from 28.3% of GDP at end-2017 to 26.5% in 2022. Our baseline forecast is predicated on the assumption that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight, especially after the presidential and parliamentary elections, to support investor confidence.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The Central Bank of Turkey will have to keep its monetary policy tight in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility, higher US interest rates and balance sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). A 300-basis-point rise of the late liquidity window lending rate on May 23rd and an announcement on May 28th to simplify the central bank's monetary policy framework suggest that for the time being economic orthodoxy is overcoming political pressures not to raise interest rates ahead of the June elections. We continue to expect that after the presidential and parliamentary elections the Central Bank of Turkey will have additional leeway to respond to currency weakness and inflationary pressures. However, we do not expect this relatively larger capacity will be sufficient to enable the Central Bank of Turkey to raise interest rates to levels that would be credible in bringing inflation down to its 5% target. In the light of Mr Erdogan's unorthodox comments on interest rates, further political pressures against significantly tighter monetary policy cannot be ruled out. In the context of rising regional tensions, tightening global liquidity conditions and rising inflation in the short term, this could prevent the central bank from maintaining investor confidence if financial conditions deteriorate, possibly prompting the imposition of capital controls; however, this is not our baseline scenario.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply, from an annual average of 3.3% in 2016 to 7.3% in 2017, supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. In 2018 we expect growth to slow to 4%. This deceleration reflects the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates, a gradual tightening of global liquidity feeding into a weaker currency, increased domestic instability and higher inflation, all of which will offset planned stimulus measures to boost employment and investment. There are considerable downside risks to our forecast, stemming from foreign capital inflows being deterred by further political instability in the transition to a presidential system of government, regional tensions, domestic financial fragilities and the higher interest rate environment in advanced economies. We forecast that GDP growth will average 4.3% per year in 2019-22.
We forecast that household consumption growth will moderate from 6% of GDP in 2017 to a still solid 3.7% per year in 2018-22 as a result of higher interest rates and slower employment growth. We expect government consumption growth to accelerate from 5% in 2017 to an annual average of 5.8% in 2018-19, easing to a more moderate but still robust 4.8% in 2020-22.
The deterioration in the business environment and foreign investors' confidence since the attempted coup in July 2016 and an increase in the corporation tax rate to 22% from 2018 will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration in yearly investment growth, reflecting public-sector retrenchment and firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
The lifting in June 2017 of Russian sanctions on Turkey (especially in the tourism sector), the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and strong external demand have contributed to a rebound in exports of goods and services. However, we expect export growth to slow in 2018-22. Our expectations of a steady nominal weakening of the lira during the forecast period will dampen import growth and support external competitiveness.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation is stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target, at 11.9% year on year in May 2018. Reflecting the political constraints on the ability of the central bank to tighten monetary policy further, the recent depreciation of the lira and rising global commodity prices, we believe that inflation will average 11.9% this year. This this is based on the assumption that inflation will peak at about 14% year on year in the third quarter and fall to 12.1% by the end of the year. We believe that inflation will decline gradually in the forecast period, reaching 8% in 2022. There are significant upside risks to our revised forecast if the lira depreciates much more rapidly than we are currently forecasting.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The lira lost about 17% of its value against the US dollar in 2017. In 2018 we expect a further depreciation of about 15% in the light of high political uncertainty and decreasing foreign investors' confidence. This pace of depreciation assumes a relatively benign political environment after the presidential and parliamentary elections, a mild shift by the authorities to a more conservative economic stance, a gradual tightening of global monetary conditions and relatively tight domestic monetary conditions. Shocks to any of these assumptions, such as the broad global sell-off in emerging-market assets in April-May 2018 after a faster pick-up in nominal yields in the US, would lead to a more abrupt depreciation. In 2019-22 we expect the pace of depreciation to slow in nominal terms. This will result in a mild appreciation in real terms after six consecutive years of real effective depreciations. We expect the lira to average TL4.90:US$1 in 2022, compared with TL3.65:US$1 in 2017.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Owing to particularly large trade deficits at the end of 2017 and in early 2018, the weakness of the lira and rising global commodity prices, we expect the current-account deficit to widen from 5.6% of GDP in 2017 to 6.6% of GDP this year. However, moderating capital inflows will keep the lira weak and interest rates relatively high, contributing to a slowdown in import demand and a consequent narrowing of the current-account deficit during the forecast period. Turkey's substantial external financing needs will be difficult to meet if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates further. We expect the rebound in tourist arrivals in 2017 to continue, but they will remain vulnerable to a possible resurgence of terrorist attacks in the country.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Following a snap general election in June 2017, in which the Conservative Party lost its parliamentary majority, the prime minister, Theresa May, formed a minority government based on a "confidence and supply" agreement with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP). The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect it to last a full five-year term; its working majority of 13 (down from 17 before the election) will be eroded by by-elections, and it will face domestic and external challenges during the Brexit process.
Mrs May will continue to face difficulties in reconciling opposing factions in her cabinet, who have very different views about negotiating the UK's future relationship with the EU. An important milestone in the Brexit negotiations came in March 2018 when EU leaders approved the terms of the transition period, which will last for 21 months from when the UK leaves the EU in March 2019. However, divisions in the cabinet and on the Conservative backbenches over Brexit are likely to persist in 2018-19.
Completing the agreement on the terms of the UK's withdrawal will take priority in 2018, but talks on the future trading relationship will also begin. The government intends to leave the single market but may remain in a customs union with the EU for an extended period. The outcome of this decision would then be finely balanced between the UK accepting a "softer" Brexit and a snap election that would install a pro-Brexit government that pursues a tougher line in negotiations. Under both scenarios we expect the UK to reach a free-trade agree-ment with the EU by 2021, although the scope of the agreement would vary.
The economy has been resilient in the wake of the Brexit vote, growing by 1.9% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017, but is likely to lose further momentum in 2018-19 as rising inflation and uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations dampen domestic demand. We forecast average annual real GDP growth of 1.5% in 2018-19, picking up to an average of 1.7% per year in 2020-22.
The government's budget deficit narrowed from 4.3% of GDP in 2015 to 1.9% of GDP in 2017. We expect a further gradual contraction in the 2018-22 forecast period, with the deficit reaching 1% of GDP in 2022. The Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) has signalled a readiness to raise interest rates again after doing so in November 2017 for the first time in a decade, and we expect the next increase to take place in August 2018.

The UK's business environment score improves in 2018-22 compared with 2013-17, lifting the country by five places in the global ranking and by four places in the regional ranking. Brexit introduces policy uncertainty, but the UK's strengths-a pro-business policy orientation, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, and flexible labour and product markets-will endure.
Country forecast overview: United Kingdom's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government retains large stake in Royal Bank of Scotland. Public support for energy and rail sector renationalisation.
2020-22: Shake-up of regulatory and competition frameworks post-Brexit. Continued state support underpins house prices.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Reduced foreign investor activity. Government "assurances" encourage investment in the automotive sector.
2020-22: Infrastructure plans offer investment opportunities. Likely changes in tax policies to bolster inward investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: UK formally leaves the EU, but likely transitional agreement to end-2020 implies that status quo arrangements largely continue. Tensions over Irish border. Talks begin on UK-EU free-trade agreement. Modest risk of no deal and hard Brexit.
2020-22: Expected decline in UK-EU crossborder trade. Some new UK-EU trading arrangement possibly phased in.
Taxes
2018-19: Gradual rise in personal income tax allowance, but also in total tax burden. Modest changes to business rates.
2020-22: Planned cut in corporation tax rate to 17%. Ongoing efforts to reduce revenue lost to growing tax avoidance and evasion. Possible changes to value-added tax (VAT) framework if UK leaves the EU's VAT regime after 2020.
Financing
2018-19: Monetary policy is tightened gradually but remains highly accommodative. "Ring-fencing" bank reforms and ongoing capital strengthening (ahead of 2019 deadlines). Steady growth in alternative forms of debt financing.
2020-22: Expected loss of "passporting" rights and restrictions on EU services trade. Modest decline in City of London status.
The labour market
2018-19: Firms defer some hiring decisions amid Brexit uncertainty. Phased increase in compulsory "national living wage".
2020-22: Some restrictions on free movement of labour from EU, but likely to be flexible in response to business concerns.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Modest rise in spending on housing, roads and digital infrastructure. Crossrail service in London begins operation.
2020-22: Construction of high-speed rail link between London and the north of England. EU-funded investment falls.
Technological readiness
2018-19: UK performs well in terms of high e-commerce penetration and strong research base, but research and development (R&D) spending below EU average and limited provision of e-government services. Continued high threat from cyber-crime and cyber-espionage.
2020-22: Possible weakening of research and innovation framework owing to exit from-or more restricted access to-EU structural programmes (such as Horizon 2020) and project financing schemes. Modest rise in public R&D spending.

Background: The end of the second world war coincided with the decline of the UK as an imperial power. Residual links with former colonial territories, close relations with the US and a separate sense of identity delayed UK membership of the European Community (now the EU) until 1973. Successive governments have resisted closer EU integration. In a referendum in June 2016 the UK electorate voted to leave the EU. The future contours of the UK's relationship with the EU are uncertain, but a diminution of UK influence in the region looks inevitable.
Political structure: The UK is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state is Queen Elizabeth II. Parliament has an elected House of Commons (the lower house, 650 seats) and a non-elected House of Lords (the upper house, non-fixed membership of about 800). The general election in June 2017 produced a minority centre-right Conservative Party government, dependent on the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) for a working majority. The main opposition Labour Party increased its parliamentary seats by 30 in the June 2017 snap general election, but its ability to compete with the Conservatives will be undermined when the government redraws parliamentary constituency boundaries, which are currently favourable to Labour.
Policy issues: UK economic policy has yet to return to normal after the financial crisis, with an exceptionally loose monetary stance. Real GDP growth slowed modestly in 2016-17 compared with 2015. The fallout from the Brexit vote will dominate the policy agenda; The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to focus efforts on negotiating the terms of its departure from the EU and on reducing the damaging effect on the economy of the uncertainty created by the vote. This has led to a shift in the UK's monetary and fiscal policy mix, with fiscal policies becoming more significant. Managing Brexit could force policymakers to address structural deficiencies in the UK, such as weak productivity.
Taxation: The headline rate of corporation tax has been steadily reduced, from 28% in 2010 to 19% since April 2018. There are three bands of personal income tax, set at 20%, 40% and 45% (the 45% rate came into effect in April 2013, replacing the 50% rate that was introduced in 2010). The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 20% (raised from 17.5% in 2011). Excise duties on tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe.
Foreign trade: In 2017 exports of goods totalled US$441.2bn and imports amounted to US$615.9bn, resulting in a trade deficit of US$174.7bn. The traditional services surplus rose to US$137.9bn. The overall current-account deficit narrowed in absolute terms, to US$106.4bn, from US$154.9bn in 2016, and fell sharply as a share of GDP, to 4.1%, from 5.8%.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The decision of the prime minister, Theresa May, to call an early general election in June 2017 backfired disastrously for the Conservative Party, which lost its majority. Mrs May has recently recouped some authority through her handling of a nerve agent attack on a former Russian military intelligence officer, Sergei Skripal, and his daughter, Yulia, on March 4th 2018. The prime minister blamed Russia, rallied the UK's international allies and expelled 23 Russian diplomats from the embassy in London. However, the positive political boost for the prime minister has proved to be short lived. The "Windrush scandal"-in which the children of the post-war generation of immigrants to the UK from the Caribbean were hounded by the authorities for official papers that many did not have, and threatened with deportation-unfolded in late April, prompting criticism of the "hostile environment" policy for immigrants pursued when Mrs May was home secretary in 2010-16. The recent appointment of Sajid Javid as home secretary could help to ease political pressure on the government. Mr Javid is the first home secretary from an ethnic minority and is more liberal than the prime minister on immigration matters. Nevertheless, the Windrush scandal has further weakened Mrs May's authority.
Mrs May will also continue to face difficulties in reconciling opposing factions in the cabinet that have different views about negotiating the UK's future relationship with the EU. Divisions in the cabinet and on the Conservative backbenches over Brexit are likely to persist. A number of Conservative rebels have declared their intention to try to force the government to reverse its position on remaining outside a customs union with the EU. Mrs May has been under pressure to present a viable alternative customs arrangement that minimises trade frictions and is acceptable to the Irish government, avoiding a hard border in Ireland. However, neither of the two options that Mrs May has presented have been acceptable to pro-Brexit members of the government or to the EU. As a result, it is looking increasingly likely that Mrs May will opt to stay in a customs union with the EU for an extended period, and that the UK will therefore remain subject to the rules of the single market in many areas. However, doing so could trigger a revolt by pro-Brexit members of the government, leading to an early election.
Brexiteers in the cabinet will continue to be supportive of Mrs May as long as she holds fast to her pledges to leave the single market, the customs union and the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ). They will support the prime minister as long as she pursues their vision of Brexit, which includes bilateral free-trade agreements with non-EU countries. However, Mrs May is also under pressure from those advocating a "softer" Brexit and, as an advocate of Remain during the referendum, this may be her preference too. These divisions have sharpened, presenting a threat to government stability in 2018.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
A snap general election in June 2017 resulted in the Conservatives losing 13 seats, leaving them with 318 in the 650-seat House of Commons (the lower house of parliament). The Labour Party won 30 seats in a swing of almost 10 percentage points from the 2015 election, giving it 262 seats. The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which increased its share of parlia-mentary seats from eight to ten, became kingmaker.
The Conservatives formed a working government, based on a "confidence and supply" arrangement with Northern Ireland's DUP. This arrangement is likely to work in the short term, because neither party wants another election-they are natural allies on questions of sovereignty and the EU, and the DUP is committed to preventing the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, from coming to power given his past association with Northern Ireland's main nationalist party, Sinn Fein. However, the arrangement is politically fragile.
The next general election is scheduled for May 2022. Lacking a parliamentary majority and divided over Brexit, the government will do well to last until then. However, if Mrs May opts to stay in an EU customs union and accept single market rules, the outcome would be finely balanced between the Conservatives accepting a "softer" Brexit, and pro-Brexit members of the government moving to oust her, leading to a pre-term vote. Since April, most opinion polls have put the Conservatives ahead of Labour by a few percentage points, and Labour's poor performance in the local elections in May suggest that it would struggle to win a snap general election.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
The UK will formally leave the single market at the end of the Article 50 process in March 2019. UK and EU negotiators have reached agreement on large parts of the draft withdrawal agreement that they intend to finalise by October, such as citizens' rights, the financial settlement, Euratom and on most areas relating to separation provisions. There is also full agreement on the terms of the transition period, which will last for 21 months after the UK's formal withdrawal. During this period the UK will maintain access to the single market, but will be bound by the obligations of membership. The UK made several concessions that are unpalatable to Brexiteers: EU law will still be applicable; EU budget contri-butions will continue; the UK will have no say over fishing quotas; and there will be reciprocal free movement and subsequent entitlement to settled status until the end of the transition period. A win for the UK is that it will not be bound by the EU's trade policy, enabling it to negotiate and agree (but not implement) new trade deals during the transition.
There is an increasing risk that the EU and the UK will fail to reach agreement on the Irish border issue, and that this will scupper the withdrawal agreement. Proposals for a "customs partnership" and a "highly streamlined customs arrangement" have so far been met with scepticism and it is looking increasingly likely that the government will implement some form of its "backstop" proposal to effectively keep the UK in a customs union with the EU beyond the end of the transition period in 2021. Under this scenario, the UK would remain subject to single market rules in many areas and the scope of a future trade agreement with the EU would therefore be limited.
However, this would be in breach of Mrs May's "red lines" and could trigger a revolt by Brexiteers, leading to the prime minister's removal, a snap election and the return of a committed pro-Brexit government. The Economist Intelligence Unit would expect a pro-Brexit government to pursue a tougher line in the negotiations and aim for a comprehensive free-trade agreement outside of the single market and customs union. Trade flows with the EU should be facilitated by the close nature of the future trading relationship, which should involve some degree of regulatory alignment. However, a viable alternative solution to the EU customs union would still need to be found, and a hardline stance on both sides would increase the risk of a complete breakdown in the negotiations.
Realistically, only the framework of a trade deal will be agreed by the time the UK withdraws in 2019, as completing the withdrawal agreement will take priority in 2018. However, transition arrangements will allow negotiations to continue, and we expect a deal to be in place by 2021.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The UK's departure from the EU may encourage policymakers to address some of the structural deficiencies that have held back the economy in recent years, including lacklustre productivity growth, insufficient innovation and poor infra-structure. The chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond, announced a National Productivity Investment Fund to boost the UK's digital infrastructure and spending on research and develop-ment over the next five years. Proposals to reform the UK's housing market have focused on introducing greater speed and flexibility into the planning process. We expect these measures to support the recovery in productivity, but they are too modest in scope to close the UK's productivity gap with its G7 peers.
The Queen's Speech in June 2017 set out the government's legislative agenda, which was dominated by Brexit. Eight of the 27 bills relate to the transfer of EU law into British law, a UK customs regime, independent trade policy, controls on immigration, fisheries policy, agricultural policy, nuclear safeguards and the UK's ability to impose international sanctions. In a further sign that Brexit is the government's priority, the parliamentary session will last for two years rather than one, ending two months after the UK's withdrawal at end-March 2019.
The centrepiece of the autumn budget in November 2017 was a sizeable increase in spending on the National Health Service (NHS). In March 2018 Mrs May said that the government would this year draw up a "long-term funding plan" to secure the future of the NHS.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Data suggest that the government has already met its "fiscal mandate" of a structural deficit smaller than 2% of GDP by fiscal year 2020/21. The budget deficit narrowed sharply in 2017, to 1.9%, from 3% of GDP in 2016, owing to strong growth in tax revenue. This implies some scope for higher public spending in the autumn budget statement. However, in the remainder of our forecast period (2018-22) we expect the government to continue to aim to nudge down discretionary spending as a proportion of GDP. We expect the deficit to contract to 1.6% of GDP by 2020 and 1% by 2022. We forecast that public debt will decline from 88% in 2018, to reach 81% by 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
At its meeting in May 2018 the monetary policy committee (MPC) of the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) voted to keep the main policy interest rate unchanged at 0.5%, seven months after raising it by 25 basis points for the first time in a decade. Seven members of the nine-strong committee supported this position, with two members voting to increase the policy rate by 25 basis points, to 0.75%. The MPC is keen to begin normalising its policy rate, although recent soft economic data are likely to mean that the BoE will delay its next rate rise until August 2018. We expect a gradual tightening cycle to follow, with a series of 25-basis-point increases in the policy rate over the next five years, taking it to 2.25% by end-2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
The economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. Average annual real GDP growth was firm in 2016 and 2017, at 1.9% and 1.8% respectively. However, the annual pace of growth slowed throughout 2017. We expect real GDP growth to average 1.4% in 2018 and to remain broadly stable in 2019, at 1.5%.
We expect the modest slowdown in 2018-19 to be led by a deceleration in domestic demand. Consumer spending will weaken in response to the continued squeeze on real household incomes from high inflation. Consumer spending was fairly resilient to this pressure in 2017, reflecting employment gains, high levels of household borrowing and a decline in the savings ratio. In 2018 we expect employment growth to slow and greater uncertainty about the economic outlook to push up precautionary savings. Consumer spending will recover in 2019-22 as inflation eases, uncertainty recedes and unemployment edges lower. However, increased borrowing costs arising from tighter monetary policy will hold back the pace of the recovery in these years. We forecast that investment spending will decelerate in 2018-19 as a result of heightened un-certainty during difficult Brexit trade negotiations and higher cost pressures as a result of sterling's depreciation, before recovering in 2020-22 as these effects fade.
Mitigating the extent of the domestically driven slowdown in 2018 will be a positive contribution to GDP growth from the external balance as export volumes benefit from a competitiveness boost as a result of sterling's depreciation, while the weaker domestic demand environment reduces import growth. From 2019 we expect the trade balance to exert a drag on GDP growth owing to our forecast for a recovery in domestic demand, which will push up import growth again. Our expectation of a business cycle downturn in the US in 2020 and a deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU, which should take effect in 2021 and result in looser trade ties than before, will also constrain exports in 2020-22. We expect real GDP growth to pick up to 1.7% on average in those years.
Trade policy is the biggest risk to our forecast for economic growth globally. The EU received temporary exemption from new US tariffs on steel and aluminium imports, announced in March, but the exemption was allowed to expire on June 1st. We expect the EU to retaliate with tariffs of its own on selected US imports, raising the risk that the US responds with tariffs on EU automotive imports. A desire to avoid further escalation to a broader trade war should mean that tit-for-tat measures end there, but risks to this forecast are high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
The headline rate of annual inflation-as measured by the consumer price index including owner occupiers' housing costs (CPIH)-accelerated to 2.6% on average in 2017, up from 1% in 2016. The increase partially reflects a rebound in oil prices, but has been amplified by the sharp depreciation of sterling since the Brexit vote. The pound has since reversed much of this appreciation and, in response, inflation has decelerated in early 2018. However, we expect the pound to weaken again in 2018-20, and oil prices are rising rapidly this year. We expect inflation to remain above the BoE's official 2% target for much of 2018, averaging 2.4%, even as domestic price pressure weakens. Tighter monetary policy will bring inflation back towards the bank's target from 2019; we forecast that inflation will ease to 1.9% next year and 2.1% on average in 2020-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
There was a sharp drop in the external value of sterling after the Brexit vote. Sensitivity in the foreign-exchange markets to the Brexit news flow has contributed to volatility in the value of the pound, which lost further value against both the euro and the US dollar in 2017, although it appreciated sharply against the dollar in early 2018. The pound has been fairly resilient since mid-2017, and we expect it to remain broadly flat against the euro in 2018-19, at about EUR1.14:£1 on average (which compares with EUR1.22:£1 in 2016), before weakening more sharply in 2020-partly reflecting the difficulty in completing Brexit negotiations, but also tighter monetary policy in the euro zone. We then expect it to recover modestly against the euro in 2021-22, as a new UK-EU trade relationship is established.
The pound has recently lost value against the dollar, but remains at a stronger level than in 2017; we expect it to average US$1.39:£1 in 2018, before weakening slightly in 2019-20 and recovering some value in 2021-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
The merchandise trade balance will keep the current account in deficit throughout 2018-22, offsetting surpluses on the services account. The current-account deficit narrowed to 4.1% of GDP in 2017, from 5.8% in 2016. We forecast that it will narrow further in 2018, to 3.8%, as a larger services surplus offsets a slightly larger trade deficit. In 2019-20 we expect the current-account deficit to widen to 4.5% on average as domestic demand recovers. From 2021 we expect looser trade relations with the EU to mean a larger goods trade deficit and smaller services surplus, although this will be offset by a reduction in secondary transfers as the UK reduces its contribution to the EU budget. We forecast an annual average current-account deficit of 4.5% of GDP in 2021-22.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
An early election in October 2017 was won by the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, who has since become chancellor at the head of a majority coalition government of the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to last a full term.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to significant tensions with other EU member states as it did in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition. This is largely because of the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
The new government will focus on integration and immigration policy, and will attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. Significant structural reforms are unlikely owing to low government cohesion.
We forecast that the government budget will remain in deficit-albeit well within the EU mandated limit of 3% of GDP-throughout the 2018-22 forecast period, as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to just above 67% by 2022, from 78.2% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 3.1% in 2017. We forecast a continuation of strong growth this year, at an upwardly revised 2.7%, and for growth to moderate to 1.7% on average in 2019-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2018-22, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. We expect annual average EU harmonised inflation of 2% in 2018-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years, at about 2%. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain broadly stable, at 2% of GDP on average in 2018-22, driven mainly by a strong surplus on the services balance, supported by tourism inflows.
