Austria's business environment score rises between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22), mainly owing to the improving economy. Austria's strengths as a business location include good infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2020-22: EU maintains focus on bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment continues to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Internet use remains slightly below several regional peers, but research and development remains relatively high.
2020-22: Further progress made on upgrading the large manufacturing sector to take advantage of new technologies.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic, and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government will focus on migration and integration issues, including in the EU context. It will also attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and implement other measures to improve the business environment, including through enabling more flexibility in the labour market.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: Trade relations are dominated by Germany, which accounts for about a third of total imports and exports. The current-account surplus is driven by strong tourism exports boosting the services surplus. We expect modest current-account surpluses throughout the forecast period.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The governing coalition consists of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this coalition to prove relatively stable and to sit out its full term until 2022. This follows several years of little progress on reforms and coalition (as well as party) in-fighting under the grand coalition of the ÖVP and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ), which fell apart in May 2017. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP, reformed the party around himself and moved it closer to the FPÖ on issues such as immigration and integration. As a result, he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election in October, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. The SPÖ's vote share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The FPÖ increased its share of the vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5% of the vote, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
In mid-December, after just over a month and a half of negotiations, the ÖVP and the FPÖ formed a coalition. Under Mr Kurz the ÖVP has moved closer to the FPÖ in many policy areas, and the negotiations thus went relatively smoothly. To assuage concerns from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Moreover, EU policy is handled by the chancellery instead of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is headed by an FPÖ appointee.
The chancellor is from the ÖVP, but the election was nevertheless a decisive moment in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has, to a large extent, been replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties had together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, but a renewed grand coalition had become almost impossible following a breakdown in relations and the reform gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz also owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP's and the FPÖ's programmes, we do not expect the government to implement significant structural reforms, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, on which they are significantly less well aligned than they are on social and cultural matters. In addition, the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on topics such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals. The initial phase of the government's term is likely to be relatively smooth, owing in part to the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union in the second half of 2018. Later in the term the FPÖ might struggle to distinguish itself from the ÖVP, which could lead to tensions between the parties, creating a moderate risk of an early election.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The most recent general election was held on October 15th 2017. Unless the government falls before then-an eventuality to which we assign a low risk-it will sit in the Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament) until the end of its term in late 2022. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions, including the leading role that it played in closing the migration route through the Balkans. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this inflow, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. The new government plans to cut child benefit payments flowing abroad, potentially leading to tensions with eastern member states in particular.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that his government will be pro-EU, and that Austria's EU membership will not be questioned in the coming years. The government plans for Austria to be a leading voice in the bloc in the coming years, especially on migration reform, which should be facilitated by the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union. We expect the government to find broad support for proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ, in 2000, led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations, the reception has been more muted this time. On the previously occasion a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands. However, this will at times lead to tensions with fellow EU members, as shown by the fact that a number of countries are now sharing less intelligence with Austria because the ministries concerned are headed by the FPÖ.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The new government plans to move integration and immigration policy further to the right, including through curtailing benefits for asylum-seekers and cutting child benefits that are sent abroad. It has also presented plans that focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing corporate tax rates and introducing more flexible working hours. Furthermore, it plans to cut a number of labour market programmes aimed at the long-term unemployed and integrating migrants into the labour market. Although it has announced a push to centralise and streamline the welfare system-to which several major stakeholders, including state governors, are likely to object-it does not plan to reform the country's so-called Proporz system, under which the ÖVP and the SPÖ had apportioned public life (state companies, public services, subsidies, regulatory responsibilities). This is despite suggestions from both coalition parties-especially the FPÖ-in the past that they would want to do this. We therefore expect reform momentum to be limited and that the government will struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Driven by both a lacklustre recovery following the financial and euro zone crises and a lack of fiscal consolidation, the fiscal accounts have remained in modest deficit in recent years and within the 3% of GDP limit set by the EU. Strong growth contributed to a narrowing of the deficit to 0.7% of GDP in 2017.
The government plans to reach a small budget surplus in 2019 by cutting spending and at the same time reducing income taxes and the country's sizeable tax wedge. However, it has not yet clearly outlined the spending cuts that it intends to make, barring a number of smaller measures, including cutting spending on asylum-seekers, and we therefore do not share the government's optimism that a surplus can be reached in 2019. Nevertheless, continued robust economic growth will contribute to a further narrowing of the deficit in the coming years; we expect it to average 0.4% of GDP in 2018-22.
The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from 78.2% in 2017 to just above 67% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain worse than in peers such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low interest rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low, in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. However, the ECB's view of the outlook improved markedly during 2017 and, although it remains dovish, we expect a more upbeat tone to emerge this year, and an end to monthly asset purchases under the QE programme at the end of 2018. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the main refinancing rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy stalled and under-performed compared with regional peers, notably Germany. This was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltering reform process in recent years contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. However, the economic recovery gained significant momentum from the second half of 2016. Although in previous years the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, owing in part to a surge in employment in the manufacturing sector. We expect a continued gradual improvement in labour market indicators in the coming years. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.7% this year. Export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, real GDP growth was 3.1% in 2017-above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005 and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue this year, although we forecast slower real GDP growth, of 2.7%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to have largely been a one-off. In the following years we expect a further moderation of growth, to around the economy's potential growth rate of about 1.7%. Driven by the improvement of the labour market, domestic demand will be the main driver of growth. Investment will also make a significant contribution to growth in the first half of the forecast period (2018-22), as business investment continues its recent pick-up after several weak years, and as increasing labour shortages push firms to invest more. We expect average real GDP growth of 1.7% per year in 2019-22. Govern-ment policy is likely to be supportive of growth in the coming years, and the main risks are external. As a highly open economy, Austria is vulner-able to global economic developments, including any shocks to global trade in the case of a potential trade war between the US and the EU.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets, and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy price base effects caused a gradual increase in inflation in 2017, leading to a full-year average of 2.2%. The recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect price growth to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as seen in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
For most of 2015-16 the euro moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1, before a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. However, in 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering rose--and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018 and has weakened slightly since then. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in the wake of the March 2018 general election in Italy-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.21:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by a continued recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. Thereafter we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values have helped the trade balance to move into surplus in recent years, from a deficit in 2009-13. However, the increase in oil prices in 2017 pushed it back into a modest deficit. We expect the trade account to remain around balance, but in deficit, throughout the forecast period. The main driver of the current-account surplus will therefore be the healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourist inflows. This will ensure that the current-account surplus remains broadly flat throughout 2018-22, at 2% of GDP on average.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Turkey is due to hold early parliamentary and presidential elections on June 24th 2018, ahead of the original date in late 2019.
The elections were brought forward in the light of the serious and growing economic uncertainties, the still high popularity of Mr Erdogan and the ruling Justice and Development (AKP) party, and the rise in nationalist sentiment in the context of Turkey's military operations in northern Syria.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the elections and remain in power throughout our forecast period (2018-22).
After the elections an executive presidency will replace the current parliamentary system of government. The new system will provide only few checks on the president's powers.
The AKP has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that period political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
Since the failed coup in 2016 there has been a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a complete rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth from 7.3% in 2017 to a still robust 4.2% per year on average in 2018-22, reflecting higher taxes, higher interest rates, a gradual tightening of global liquidity and more moderate export growth.
We expect an annual average government budget deficit of 3% of GDP on average in 2018-19. We forecast that the budget deficit will narrow gradually, to 1.9% of GDP in 2022, as fiscal revenue increases.
We expect the current-account deficit to widen in 2018, to 6.5% of GDP, before contracting to a still large 4.7% per year on average in 2019-22. Turkey will struggle to meet its important external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but in the global rankings the country falls by 11 places, to 60th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, are introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2018-19: Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey not to raise interest rates continues. Risk of the US imposing fines on several Turkish banks over alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran.
2020-22: Banking system remains stable, despite weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Spending on research and development remains moderate at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2020-22: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe (in 1949) and NATO (in 1952), and signed an association agreement with the then European Community (in 1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. A presidential system of government will come into effect after snap elections in June 2018. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted institutional weaknesses that, with the AKP's consent until 2013, had allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) came to US$166bn and imports (fob) to US$225bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn-a sharp widening from US$41bn in 2016. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
On April 18th, after many conflicting statements, the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, of the ruling religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), called early presidential and parliamentary elections. Both votes will be held on June 24th, well ahead of the originally scheduled date of November 2019, as the president seeks to take advantage of his current popularity. The vote will conclude Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. Under the new system, the president will be granted wide-ranging executive powers, including in the selection of the majority of top officials in the judiciary, and parliament will be greatly weakened. Municipal elections are still due in March 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, will win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and possibly beyond.
The elections will take place under emergency rule. This was initially introduced after the failed coup attempt to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. Emergency rule has allowed Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place. It has also allowed the government to continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, to curtail freedoms of expression, assembly and association, and to politicise the judiciary. Similar to the situation at the April 2017 referendum, the state of emergency is likely to provide an advantage to Mr Erdogan and the AKP in what will be a highly contested election. Recent changes to the electoral law, including an amendment allowing the use of unstamped ballots, raise the risk of electoral fraud and of an illegitimate election outcome. Against this backdrop, the credibility of the election will probably be challenged, which will further polarise the country and increase risks to political and social stability. Although an unlikely prospect, failure by Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win both the presidential and parliamentary elections could throw the political system into chaos and open up irreparable divisions in the AKP.
The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup appear to have eased to a large extent, but security risk remains high. Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK are interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1980s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria are seeking to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK, but risk further fuelling the conflict with the PKK in Turkey's south-east. Failure by the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) to surpass the high 10% threshold for entry to parliament could exacerbate tensions in the south-east. The defeat of IS in Syria and Iraq could result in renewed attacks in Turkey and elsewhere.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The parliamentary and presidential elections will be held on June 24th, earlier than the originally scheduled date of late 2019. The elections were brought forward in the light of the high and growing economic uncertainties, the still high popularity of Mr Erdogan and the AKP, and the favourable rise in nationalist sentiment in the context of the government's military operations in northern Syria.
The AKP, in alliance with the Nationalist Action Party (MHP), will face a non-negligible challenge from an opposition that, despite being ideologically diverse, is rallying around a shared "anti-Erdogan" view. The alliance includes the main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP); the recently formed Good Party (IP), a group that broke away from the MHP following the MHP's support of the constitutional referendum; the smaller, conservative Islamic Felicity Party (SP); and the Democratic Party (DP). The HDP has not joined the alliance.
The AKP's hegemonic position in Turkish politics has suffered in recent years, but we expect Mr Erdogan and his party to win the presidential and parliamentary elections. The opposition is fragmented, Mr Erdogan's popularity is still unrivalled and he has the support of the right-wing MHP. Importantly, the AKP also has the ability to control the election process.
If Mr Erdogan fails to pass the 50% threshold in the first round of the presidential election on June 24th a second-round run-off would be held on July 8th between Mr Erdogan and the candidate with the second-largest share of votes. In this round he would be likely to face Muharrem Ince, the CHP candidate, although a face-off against the IP candidate, Meral Aksener, cannot be ruled out. In both cases the second-round run-off would be turned into a deeply polarising referendum on Mr Erdogan's leadership. In the unlikely case that Mr Erdogan won the presidential vote but the AKP-MHP coalition lost the parliamentary election, a second parliamentary and presidential election (under the revised constitution presidential and parliamentary elections must be held simultaneously) would be likely to be called by the president.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. There is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding these allies' concerns that under Mr Erdogan Turkey is pivoting eastwards towards Russia, China and Iran. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; the US's military backing of PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; tensions over gas exploration in the eastern Mediterranean; Turkey's forging of closer relations with non-Western countries; and, more recently, growing tensions with Israel in the aftermath of the US's decision to relocate its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of the country's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals-notably, to become president with executive powers after the elections.
The country's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and increasingly transactional rather than strategic, but we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a complete breakdown in relations. However, this might become unavoidable if the EU suspends the country's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, the US imposes sanctions on Turkey over violations by Turkish banks of US sanctions against Iran, Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces, or it withdraws from NATO, none of which can be ruled out completely. Operation Olive Branch, Turkey's crossborder military operation in Afrin in north-western Syria that was launched in January 2018, has accentuated tensions with the US. The operation cleared the area of US-backed, PKK-affiliated Kurdish groups that are intent on establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey.
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in neighbouring Syria will continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where they are co-operating but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, an intensification of domestic political instability, rising regional tensions and tightening global liquidity con-ditions could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period (2018-22). These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements (savings have always been very low), but tend to be short term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region have put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, most recently in May 2018, fuelling an acceleration in inflation, increasing the cost to firms of servicing their foreign debt and raising the risk of defaults for corporates.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards fiscal loosening and relatively tight monetary policy through unconventional measures.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-have given the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy in the aftermath of the attempted coup. As a result, the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to 1.5% in 2017. Despite a series of tax increases this year, increased government spending on defence, security, infrastructure projects, public employment and social benefits will cause the deficit to widen further, to an average of 3% of GDP in 2018-19, before narrowing to 1.9% in 2022. We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to decline gradually, to about 27% in 2022. Our baseline forecast is predicated on the assumption that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight, especially after the presidential and parliamentary elections, to support investor confidence.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The Central Bank of Turkey will have to keep its monetary policy tight in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility, higher US interest rates and balance sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). However, because of political pressure not to raise interest rates further, we expect the Central Bank of Turkey to be constrained in its ability to raise interest rates to levels that would be credible in bringing inflation down to its 5% target. Nonetheless, we expect that after the presidential and general elections, the bank will have some increased leeway to possibly tighten its policy stance, albeit via unorthodox and less effective tools. Our baseline forecast is that this mild tightening will help to contain the depreciation of the lira. However, in the context of rising regional tensions, tightening global liquidity conditions and rising inflation in the short term, this may be insufficient to maintain investor confidence and could prompt a hard landing in the second half of 2018; however, this is not our baseline scenario.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply, from an annual average of 3.3% in 2016 to 7.3% in 2017, supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. In 2018 we expect growth to slow to 4% (revised from 4.5% previously). This deceleration reflects the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates, a gradual tightening of global liquidity feeding into a weaker currency, increased domestic instability and higher inflation, all of which will offset planned stimulus measures to boost employment and investment. There are considerable downside risks to our forecast, stemming from foreign capital inflows being deterred by further political instability in the transition to a presidential system of government, regional tensions, domestic financial fragilities and the higher interest rate environment in advanced economies. We forecast that GDP growth will average 4.3% in 2019-22.
We forecast that household consumption growth will moderate from 6% of GDP in 2017 to a still solid 3.7% per year in 2018-22 as a result of higher interest rates and slower employment growth. We expect government consumption growth to accelerate from 5% in 2017 to an annual average of 5.8% in 2018-19, easing to a more moderate, but still robust, 4.8% in 2020-22.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup and an increase in the corporation tax rate to 22% from 2018 will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration in yearly investment growth, reflecting public-sector retrenchment and firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
The lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey (especially in the tourism sector), the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and strong external demand have contributed to a rebound in exports of goods and services. However, we expect growth to slow from 11.9% in 2017 to an annual average of 4.4% in 2018-22, reflecting base effects and our view that 2017 probably represented the recent peak in the global trade cycle. Our expectations of a steady nominal weakening of the lira during the forecast period will dampen import growth.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation is stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target. Reflecting the political constraints on the ability of the central bank to tighten monetary policy further, the recent depreciation of the lira and rising global commodity prices, we have revised our 2018 inflation forecast to 11.8% (from 10.2% previously). This implies inflation peaking at about 14% in the third quarter and falling to 12% by the end of the year. We believe that inflation will decline gradually in the forecast period, reaching 8% in 2022. There are significant upside risks to our revised forecast if the lira depreciates much more rapidly than we are now forecasting.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
We have revised our exchange-rate forecast for 2018-22. We now expect the lira to average TL4.90:US$1 in 2022 (TL4.79:US1 previously), compared with TL3.65:US$1 in 2017. After a fall in the nominal value of the lira of about 17% against the US dollar in 2017, in 2018 we expect an average depreciation of about 15%. This pace of depreciation assumes a relatively benign political environment after the presidential and parliamentary elections, a mild shift by the authorities to a more conservative economic stance, and a gradual tightening of global and domestic monetary conditions. Shocks to any of these assumptions, such as the broad sell-off in emerging-market assets in April-May 2018 after a faster pick-up in nominal yields in the US, would lead to a more abrupt depreciation. In 2019-22 we expect the pace of depreciation to slow in nominal terms. This will result in a mild appreciation in real terms after six consecutive years of real effective depreciations.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Owing to particularly large trade deficits at the end of 2017 and in early 2018, the weakness of the lira and rising commodity prices, we expect the current-account deficit to widen from 5.6% of GDP in 2017 to 6.5% of GDP this year (5.7% previously). However, moderating capital inflows will keep the lira weak and interest rates relatively high, contributing to a slowdown in import demand and a consequent narrowing of the current-account deficit during the forecast period. Turkey's substantial external financing needs will be difficult to meet if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates further. We expect the rebound in tourist arrivals in 2017 to continue, but they will remain vulnerable to a possible resurgence of terrorist attacks in the country.

Full text: United Kingdom--highlights: Political outlook
The minority Conservative government formed after the snap general election in June 2017 depends on the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist party (DUP) for survival. This arrangement should hold in the short term, because neither party wants another election-they are natural allies on questions of sovereignty and the EU, and the DUP is vociferously opposed to the Labour Party. However, the government's 13-seat working majority is likely to dwindle over time. Lacking a parliamentary majority and divided over Brexit, the government will do well to last until the UK's exit from the EU in 2019 and there is a risk of another pre-term election before 2022. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Conservative Party to see through the Brexit negotiations in 2018-21 before contemplating changing the party leadership and risking precipitating another early general election.
United Kingdom--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.63 8.10 19 14 12 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The UK's business environment score improves in 2018-22, lifting the country five places in our forward-looking global ranking and four places in our regional ranking. The Brexit vote in 2016 introduced uncertainty into aspects of the UK's policy framework, especially with regard to external trade and immigration. However, we do not think that Brexit poses a significant risk to the continued functioning of the country's banking system and financial markets. The UK's traditional strengths as a business location-such as a pro-business policy orientation, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, and flexible labour and product markets-will endure. The Brexit shock has also forced policymakers to address some of the country's structural deficiencies, such as insufficient innovation and inadequate infrastructure, but the response so far has been insufficient.

The economy was resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote but has started to lose some momentum. Real GDP grew by 1.9% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017, and we expect it to slow to 1.5% on average in 2018-19. Rising cost pressures stemming from a weaker pound, combined with uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations and the UK's future relationship with the EU, are likely to constrain economic activity, particularly consumer and investment spending. Mitigating the deceleration in 2018 will be a slowing of the pace of import growth while export volumes continue to benefit from sterling's depreciation. This will allow the external balance to deliver a positive contribution to real GDP in 2018. After a transition period, a deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU is likely to take effect in 2021. We expect real GDP growth to quicken to 1.9% by 2022.

The UK population is forecast to grow at an annual average rate of 0.6% over the next five years, supported by "natural change" (an excess of births over deaths) and net immigration. Government efforts to reduce net immigration have proved ineffective; the UK's decision to leave the EU is unlikely to make a huge difference to levels of inward migration to the UK. An ageing population will ensure that pension-related spending accounts for a rising share of total public expenditure, adding to budgetary pressure on public services.

The UK will continue to offer the market opportunities of a rich, developed country. Consumers' spending power has been undermined by the sharp depreciation in the pound in 2016, which has reduced households' purchasing power, but this effect will fade gradually in the coming years. As a mature consumer market, underlying demand will be driven in part by a need to replace ageing stock, technological change and sociological factors, with population ageing underpinning healthcare and leisure spending.
United Kingdom--highlights: Long-term outlook

Real GDP is forecast to grow by an annual average of 1.8% in 2018-30, accelerating to 1.9% in 2031-50 (1.4% and 1.5% in per head terms). The UK has a relatively high participation rate, so there is less scope for raising this than in many other EU countries, and demographics will make less of a contribution to growth. Long-term growth will depend increasingly on future productivity. Technological progress will be an important driver, but productivity levels will remain lower than in the US, Germany and France, reflecting a deficit in intermediate skills and infrastructure shortcomings.

Background: The end of the second world war coincided with the decline of the UK as an imperial power. Residual links with former colonial territories, close relations with the US and a separate sense of identity delayed UK membership of the European Community (now the EU) until 1973. Successive governments have resisted closer EU integration. In a referendum in June 2016 the UK electorate voted to leave the EU. The future contours of the UK's relationship with the EU are uncertain, but a diminution of UK influence in the region looks inevitable.
Political structure: The UK is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state is Queen Elizabeth II. Parliament has an elected House of Commons (the lower house, 650 seats) and a non-elected House of Lords (the upper house, non-fixed membership of about 800). The general election in June 2017 produced a minority centre-right Conservative Party government, dependent on the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) for a working majority. The main opposition Labour Party increased its parliamentary seats by 30 in the June 2017 snap general election, but its ability to compete with the Conservatives will be undermined when the government redraws parliamentary constituency boundaries, which are currently favourable to Labour.
Policy issues: UK economic policy has yet to return to normal after the financial crisis, with an exceptionally loose monetary stance. Real GDP growth slowed modestly in 2016-17 compared with 2015. The fallout from the Brexit vote will dominate the policy agenda; The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to focus efforts on negotiating the terms of its departure from the EU and on reducing the damaging effect on the economy of the uncertainty created by the vote. This has led to a shift in the UK's monetary and fiscal policy mix, with fiscal policies becoming more significant. Managing Brexit could force policymakers to address structural deficiencies in the UK, such as weak productivity.
Taxation: The headline rate of corporation tax has been steadily reduced, from 28% in 2010 to 19% since April 2018. There are three bands of personal income tax, set at 20%, 40% and 45% (the 45% rate came into effect in April 2013, replacing the 50% rate that was introduced in 2010). The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 20% (raised from 17.5% in 2011). Excise duties on tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe.
Foreign trade: In 2017 exports of goods totalled US$441.2bn and imports amounted to US$615.9bn, resulting in a trade deficit of US$174.7bn. The traditional services surplus fell to US$137.9bn. The overall current-account deficit narrowed in absolute terms, to US$106.4bn, from US$154.9bn in 2016, and fell sharply as a share of GDP, to 4.1%, from 5.8%.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The UK is a parliamentary democracy. The legislature consists of an elected lower chamber, the House of Commons (650 seats), and an unelected upper chamber, the House of Lords (about 825 members), which was partly reformed in 1999. Pending a second stage of reform, most members of the House of Lords are appointed life peers. The UK is ruled by a minority government led by the centre-right Conservative Party under its leader, Theresa May, with the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist party (DUP). The Conservatives lost 13 seats in the snap election in June 2017, despite winning a higher percentage share of the vote compared with 2015, and had to negotiate a confidence and supply arrangement with the DUP, giving it a two-seat parliament majority. The Labour Party gained 30 seats in a swing of almost 10 percentage points from the 2015 election, giving it 262 seats. The snap poll in 2017 moved the next scheduled general election to May 2022. However, the government's minority status and the divisions within the Conservative Party over Brexit mean that there is a significant risk of another pre-term poll.

Political outlook: Political stability
Mrs May's decision to call an early general election in June 2017 backfired disastrously for the Conservative Party, which lost its majority. Mrs May has recently recouped some authority through her handling of a nerve agent attack on a former Russian military intelligence officer, Sergei Skripal, and his daughter, Yulia, in the UK on March 4th 2018. The prime minister blamed Russia, rallied the UK's international allies and expelled 23 Russian diplomats from the embassy in London. However, the positive political boost for the prime minister has proved to be short lived. The "Windrush" scandal-in which the children of the post-war generation of immigrants to the UK from the Caribbean were hounded by the authorities for official papers that many did not have, and threatened with deportation-unfolded in late April, prompting criticism of the "hostile environment" policy for immigrants pursued when Mrs May was home secretary in 2010-16. On April 30th Amber Rudd resigned as home secretary after she "inadvertently misled" a parliamentary committee about her knowledge of targets for the removal of immigrants who had arrived in the UK illegally.
The appointment of Sajid Javid (formerly the minister for housing, communities and local government) as Ms Rudd's replacement could help to ease political pressure on the government. Mr Javid is the first home secretary from an ethnic minority and is more liberal than the prime minister on immigration matters. However, the Windrush scandal and the circumstances of Ms Rudd's resignation have further weakened Mrs May's authority.
Mrs May will also continue to face difficulties in reconciling opposing factions in the cabinet that have different views about negotiating the UK's future relationship with the EU. Divisions in the cabinet and on the Conservative backbenches over Brexit are likely to persist. A number of Conservative rebels have declared their intention to try to force the government to reverse its position on remaining outside a customs union with the EU. However, doing so would probably trigger a revolt by pro-Brexit members of the government, leading to an early election. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mrs May to stick to her commitment to leave the customs union and pursue an inde-pendent trade policy. As this will increase trade frictions and risks creating a hard border in Ireland, she is under pressure to present viable alternative customs arrangements.
Brexiteers in the cabinet have been supportive of Mrs May because they want her to hold fast to her pledges to leave the single market, the customs union and the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ). They will support the prime minister as long as she pursues their vision of Brexit. However, the customs union debate shows that Mrs May is also under pressure from those advocating a "softer" Brexit. These divisions have sharpened, presenting a threat to government stability in 2018.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The next five years will be a period of significant political, institutional and constitutional change in the UK. The decision to leave the EU will not only transform the UK's relationship with the EU, but it also raises questions about the status of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland within the UK and the future devolution of powers within the UK.
The implications of Brexit for devolution-the transfer of powers from the central state to the Scottish parliament, the National Assembly for Wales, the Northern Ireland Assembly and the London Assembly, together with their related executive bodies-are not yet clear. Many areas that now fall under the competence of the devolved parliaments/assemblies are covered by EU law. After Brexit the devolved authorities will in theory be able to adopt their own laws and policies in these areas. This could result in growing legal divergence between different regions within the UK. The government has said that it will need to ensure consistency in the legal framework within the UK's internal market and will therefore retain control of some competencies for a limited period.
The European Union (Withdrawal) Bill will determine the degree to which the devolved authorities will be able to amend retained EU-derived laws that fall within their areas of competence. The UK government has proposed that the majority of the 158 devolved areas for which policy is decided in Brussels will be handed directly to the Scottish and Welsh parliaments. However, it wants to retain control temporarily of 24 areas, including agriculture, fisheries, food labelling and public procurement to ensure the observance of common rules and regulations across the UK internal market. This has met political opposition in Scotland, which objects that it would be prevented from passing laws in some of the devolved areas for up to seven years. On May 15th 2018 the Scottish parliament refused to give its consent to the bill.
It is possible that a compromise will be agreed, but ultimately the UK govern-ment can impose the legislation on Scotland, although this is politically undesirable and would overturn two decades (since the latest phase of devolution began in 1997) of constitutional convention and precedent. The devolved powers of the sub-national authorities reside with the national government, and the British state remains by law a unitary state. This means that the central government can take back control of certain competences, as it is minded to do for a time-limited period in certain areas after Brexit.
The government has previously ignored the will of the Scottish parliament, as in 2016, when Mrs May ruled out a second independence referendum for Scotland. At that time Scotland's first minister and leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), Nicola Sturgeon, received endorsement (69-59) from the Scottish parliament to request a Section 30 order from the UK government seeking permission to hold a second referendum. There is little evidence to suggest that support for independence has shifted much since the first independence referendum, in September 2014, when it was rejected by 55% to 45%. Also, the SNP lost 21 seats at the 2017 election, suggesting that there is little popular support for a second referendum and that the SNP's approval ratings are slipping. If there were another independence referendum by 2021, we would expect another vote to reject it.
The UK's decision to leave the EU, and the government's stated commitment to leaving the EU single market and customs union, has also raised questions about the status of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. The border has become a focal point of negotiations between the EU and the UK, with the former demanding that the British government come up with concrete proposals for avoiding a "hard border" between the north and the south after Brexit. As at May 2018 the EU had rejected the two main proposals advanced by the British government. We expect that a solution will be found, but there is a significant risk that the Irish border issue will derail the negotiations.
Mrs May's government has abandoned plans for a revision of the boundaries of the UK's parliamentary districts, aimed at ensuring a more equitable distribution of seats according to population. These changes, which had been planned for after the June 2017 snap general election if the government had increased its majority, would have reduced the number of members of parliament (MPs) by 50 to 600, and probably provided the Conservatives with another 15-20 seats. After she lost her parliamentary majority Mrs may accepted that the govern-ment would not be able to get the legislation through the House of Commons (the lower house of parliament) in the face of opposition from the Labour Party, and the Liberal Democrats and smaller parties, given that the DUP is also opposed to the plan.
Political outlook: Election watch
A snap general election in June 2017 resulted in the Conservatives losing 13 seats, leaving them with 318 in the 650-seat House of Commons. The Labour Party won 30 seats in a swing of almost 10 percentage points from the 2015 election, giving it 262 seats. The DUP, which increased its share of parlia-mentary seats from eight to ten, became kingmaker.
The Conservatives formed a working government, based on a "confidence and supply" arrangement with Northern Ireland's DUP. This arrangement is likely to work in the short term, because neither party wants another election-they are natural allies on questions of sovereignty and the EU, and the DUP is committed to preventing the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, from coming to power given his past association with Northern Ireland's main nationalist party, Sinn Fein. However, the arrangement is politically fragile, and the govern-ment's 13-seat working majority (down from 17 seats before the election) will dwindle with each by-election.
The Conservatives and Labour remain almost neck and neck in recent opinion polls, on about 40-41%. The next general election is scheduled for May 2022. Lacking a parliamentary majority and divided over Brexit, the govern-ment will do well to last until then, and there is a risk of another pre-term election. We expect the Conservative Party to see through the Brexit negotiations in 2018-21 before it contemplates changing the party leadership and risks precipitating another early general election.
Political outlook: International relations
The UK will formally leave the single market at the end of the Article 50 process in March 2019. UK and EU negotiators have reached agreement on large parts of the draft withdrawal agreement that must be finalised by the autumn, such as citizens' rights, the financial settlement, Euratom and on most areas relating to separation provisions. There is also full agreement on the terms of the transition period, which will last for 21 months after the UK's formal withdrawal. During this period the UK will maintain access to the single market, but will be bound by the obligations of membership. The UK made several concessions that are unpalatable to Brexiteers: EU law will still be applicable; EU budget contri-butions will continue; the UK will have no say over fishing quotas; and there will be reciprocal free movement and subsequent entitlement to settled status until the end of the transition period. A win for the UK is that it will not be bound by the EU's trade policy, enabling it to negotiate and agree new trade deals during the transition.
There is a risk that the EU and the UK will clash on the Irish border issue, and that this will scupper the withdrawal agreement, but this is not our forecast. Mrs May must present an alternative customs arrangement that allows the UK to have an independent trade policy, minimises trade frictions and is acceptable to the Irish government. Proposals for a "customs partnership" and a "highly streamlined customs arrangement" have so far been met with scepticism. Trade flows with the EU should be facilitated by the close nature of the future trading relationship, which should involve some degree of regulatory alignment. However, Mrs May will need a more concrete viable alternative solution well before the UK-EU trade agreement is finalised.
Negotiations on trade will come with their own challenges, as competing interests among the member states will complicate the process. During trade talks the EU will resist attempts by the UK to cherry-pick from the benefits of membership, but the end result is likely to be a more comprehensive trade deal than that negotiated by the EU and Canada in 2016.
There are numerous obstacles to the successful conclusion of the negotiations, but we believe that compromises will make a deal possible, particularly given the economic incentive to maintain existing trade ties. Realistically, only the framework of a trade deal will be agreed by the time the UK withdraws in 2019, as completing the withdrawal agreement will take priority in 2018. However, transition arrangements will allow negotiations to continue, and we expect a deal to be in place by 2021.

The UK's score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings rises from 7.63 in the historical period (2013-17) to 8.10 in the forecast period (2018-22). The country moves up five places in the global ranking to become the 14th most attractive business location in the world, and at a regional level the UK climbs four places to eighth among its 17 peers. The main drivers of this improvement are higher scores in the financing and taxes categories, which party reflect reforms following earlier damage caused by the global financial crisis. In the wake of the Brexit shock, policymakers have also made a more concerted effort to address some of the country's structural deficiencies, such as insufficient innovation. After a period of weaker economic activity and greater business caution-given the complexity of the Brexit process-we expect the UK's macroeconomic environment to improve gradually. Policymakers have devoted more resources to implementing structural reforms, and the UK will to retain many features of an attractive business location. However, the combination of a weak and divided government, a lack of consensus in the UK on an agreed form of Brexit, and uncertainty over the future policy and regulatory framework in areas such as immigration and crossborder trade imply a challenging period ahead for business.

Its traditional strengths will still make UK a favoured destination for FDI
The UK's traditional strengths as a business location have been a pro-business policy orientation, a low burden of regulation, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, and flexible labour and product markets. The scores for the foreign trade regime and market opportunities fall, reflecting a likely deterioration in trading conditions with the UK's largest export partner (the EU). The business environment will be supported by fairly robust digital infrastructure and a well-developed innovation base, but underlying weaknesses, such as a complex tax regime, relatively poor transport infrastructure, weak productivity and a deficit in intermediate skills, will persist.
