Business environment outlook: United Kingdom's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government retains large stake in struggling Royal Bank of Scotland. Brexit focus constrains reforms to improve weak trends in investment and productivity. Signs of rising public support for renationalisation in energy and rail industries.
2020-22: Shake-up of regulatory and competition frameworks post-Brexit. Continued state support underpins house prices.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Reduced foreign investor activity in financial and real estate sectors. Government "assurances" to attract inflows and encourage investment in largely foreign-owned automotive sector.
2020-22: Infrastructure plans offer investment opportunities. Likely changes in tax policies to bolster inward investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: UK formally leaves the EU, but likely transitional agreement to end-2020 implies that status quo arrangements largely continue. Tensions over Irish border. Talks begin on UK-EU free-trade agreement. Modest risk of no deal and hard Brexit.
2020-22: Expected decline in UK-EU crossborder trade. Some new UK-EU trading arrangement possibly phased in.
Taxes
2018-19: Gradual rise in personal income tax allowance, but also in total tax burden. Modest changes to business rates.
2020-22: Planned cut in corporation tax rate to 17%. Ongoing efforts to reduce revenue lost to growing tax avoidance and evasion. Possible changes to value-added tax (VAT) framework if UK leaves the EU's VAT regime after 2020.
Financing
2018-19: Monetary policy is tightened gradually but remains highly accommodative. "Ring-fencing" bank reforms and ongoing capital strengthening (ahead of 2019 deadlines). Steady growth in alternative forms of debt financing.
2020-22: Expected loss of "passporting" rights and restrictions on EU services trade. Modest decline in City of London status.
The labour market
2018-19: High employment persists but firms defer some hiring decisions amid Brexit uncertainty. Likely reduced inflows of EU workers. Phased increase in compulsory "national living wage", but whole-economy wage growth remains subdued.
2020-22: Some form of restrictions on free movement of labour from EU, but likely to be flexible in response to business concerns. Policymakers struggle to respond to weak productivity and deficit in intermediate skills.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Modest rise in spending on housing, roads and digital infrastructure. Crossrail service in London begins operation.
2020-22: Construction of high-speed rail link between London and the north of England. EU-funded investment falls.
Technological readiness
2018-19: UK performs well in terms of high e-commerce penetration and strong research base, but research and development (R&D) spending below EU average and limited provision of e-government services. Continued high threat from cyber-crime and cyber-espionage.
2020-22: Possible weakening of research and innovation framework owing to exit from-or more restricted access to-EU structural programmes (such as Horizon 2020) and project financing schemes. Modest rise in public R&D spending.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.8 6.9 66 50 17 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The macroeconomic environment for business has been underpinned in recent years by solid employment growth, resilient consumer demand, supportive financing conditions and a cyclical upturn in global growth (driven in part by major EU trading partners) that bolstered manufacturing and export activity in 2017. The depreciation in sterling since the Brexit referendum-in April 2018 the currency was 9% weaker in trade-weighted terms than two years' earlier-has provided a competitive boost to some firms, although its overall impact has been modest in historical terms.
In recent years the underlying trend in UK activity has been constrained by fiscal austerity, sluggish productivity, subdued investment spending (by both the government and the private sector) and an increase in Brexit-related uncertainty. However, the softening in activity also reflects a natural moderation in GDP growth after it accelerated to a post-crisis high of 3.1% in 2014. This partly accounts for the "decoupling" of UK output trends from the improved growth performance in other advanced peer economies since early 2017, and particularly in Europe, where the post-crisis recovery period began much later.
Economic activity will firm as Brexit-related uncertainty recedes
Nevertheless, we expect the UK's macroeconomic environment to improve during the forecast period. Demand in consumer-facing sectors has weakened owing to a deterioration in household purchasing power relating to sterling's weakness, but it is likely to be supported in the years ahead by high levels of employment and a gradual firming in real wage growth. The main driver of UK growth in recent decades has been household spending, and consumer confidence should improve as uncertainty recedes. Major capital spending plans by businesses may remain on hold until there is greater clarity over future trading arrangements, but we expect this to be temporary. The public finances have steadily improved, and financing conditions are favourable, implying some scope for fiscal support. Downside risks stem from high levels of consumer debt and a recent decline in household savings. The current account will continue to record a sizeable deficit, posing external financing risks.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.5 9.3 8 2 4 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The UK has long provided one of the world's most favourable environments for private enterprise, having pioneered the liberalisation of product markets and privatisation of state assets in the 1980s and early 1990s (in contrast to most other EU countries, where state monopolies have been deregulated only after the adoption of liberalising measures at EU level). Given this leading role in freeing up product markets, the UK has less scope for further advances than many countries. The regulatory burden faced by business is comparatively low, with the UK ranked seventh globally in the World Bank's Doing Business 2018 report. The number of procedures, time taken and costs involved to start a new business are all below the OECD average, and administrative processes involved in the payment of taxes, obtaining credit and utilities, resolving insolvency and the protection of minority investors are relatively modest. Competition policy has been strengthened by reforms and stands up to comparison with other high-income countries, although recent reviews of the banking, grocery and energy sectors have yielded limited reforms. With the exception of the National Health Service (NHS), state ownership in major sectors of the UK economy is fairly limited. The government retains a majority stake in the struggling Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), one of the "big four" commercial banks, has holdings in parts of the nuclear and rail industries, and has steadily become more involved in the UK's housing market through a series of debateable policy interventions in the post-crisis period.
Rising business uncertainty over future regulatory framework
The policy environment for private enterprise should remain broadly favourable, with comparatively low levels of regulation in product and labour markets. A post-Brexit transition period to end-2020 will offer some near-term clarity for businesses, although uncertainty over future immigration and cross-border trading arrangements will temporarily impinge on business planning. Brexit is likely to involve a restructuring of the UK's regulatory, competition and legislative frameworks, with implications for almost all sectors.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
9.1 9.1 7 6 5 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The UK has one of the world's most liberal environments for foreign investors. Since the 1980s successive governments have been favourably disposed towards foreign direct investment (FDI), reflecting a broad view across the political spectrum that the location of economic activity and corporate headquarters is more important than its nationality. Liberalised product markets, deep capital markets and London's status as the financial capital of Europe have facilitated foreign takeovers of many domestic firms, and governments have mostly been strikingly relaxed about such deals. Over recent years FDI inflows have been concentrated in finance, real estate, technology and knowledge-based services industries such as professional services and the creative sector.
Since the global crisis FDI inflows have been focused increasingly on London and the south-east, particularly in the financial and real estate sectors. However, both sectors face uncertainty related to Brexit, and inflows are likely to slow. Another trend has been an increasing share of FDI that reflects "corporate reconfiguration"-changes in complex multinational ownership structures-which has a minimal impact on output and employment in the host economy. This is likely to continue.
The short-term outlook for FDI inflows will be clouded by uncertainty over the UK's post-Brexit trading framework despite the government's promotion of an outward-looking "global Britain". In the near term we expect a steady pattern of FDI inflows, with activity supported by government "assurances" to existing large-scale foreign investors in sectors such as automotive and pharmaceuticals. The government also plans to reduce the corporation tax rate in stages to 17% in 2020, from 19% currently. However, should Brexit uncertainty persist, there is a risk that major disinvestments or project relocation will occur.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
9.1 9.1 12 18 7 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The UK's foreign trade regime is strongly defined by its membership of the EU, so the country's scheduled formal exit from the bloc in March 2019 implies a significant overhaul over the forecast period. The existing framework will remain in place until at least March 2019, with full freedom of movement of goods, services, capital and persons within the EU, no tariffs or quotas in the bloc, limited non-tariff EU trade restrictions and (outside agriculture) moderate customs duties relating to trade with non-EU countries, which is largely governed by multilateral agreements administered by the World Trade Organisation (WTO).
Trade agreement between EU and UK will take some years to negotiate
Beyond March 2019 there is still considerable uncertainty as to the likely form of trading arrangements. Both polarised outcomes of either "no Brexit' (implying no changes) or a "no-deal hard Brexit" (implying an immediate shift to WTO rules and disruption to UK trade) are unlikely, but each could occur. In our view the most probable sequencing of events is that the status quo arrangements largely remain in place for most of the forecast period while complex negotiations on a new EU-UK free trade agreement (FTA) continue. A transition period to end-2020 has been provisionally approved, implying continued single-market access and customs union membership for 21 months after the UK's formal exit, although final agreement on this remains contingent on all other outstanding issues related to the UK's withdrawal also being settled by late 2017, which is not guaranteed given continued tensions and disagree-ments relating to the Irish border. Assuming that a workaround on this issue can be found, it is quite possible that the transitional period could subsequently be extended beyond its current end-2020 deadline, both because of the scale of work involved in trying to facilitate a new EU-UK FTA, and also because a new customs/border arrangements may not be in place by the end of the transition period.
The government has repeatedly stated that the UK will leave the single market and the customs union (which allows goods to move freely without customs checks), so that it can negotiate trade deals with countries outside the EU. Remaining within the customs union would give the UK tariff-free access to EU markets, but would mean adopting a common external tariff and accepting mutual recognition of some EU-wide regulations, without having a vote on them. The government insists that it will leave the EU customs union, but as of May 2018 it remained undecided over its approach to future customs arrangements.
The government will pursue an FTA to try to minimise costly non-tariff barriers (technical regulations, compliance requirements, "rules of origin" documentation) that will be imposed outside the bloc. There are numerous obstacles to the successful conclusion of negotiations, but we believe that compromises will make a deal possible, particularly given the economic incentive to maintain existing trade ties. During trade talks the EU will resist attempts by the UK to cherry-pick from the benefits of membership, but the end result is likely to be a more comprehensive trade deal than that negotiated by the EU and Canada in 2016.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.0 7.4 40 17 11 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The tax regime has a number of attractive features from a business perspective. The overall tax burden has remained fairly stable and below the EU average over the past decade-the UK's tax/GDP ratio was 35% in 2016 (latest comparable Eurostat data), well below an EU average of 40%-taxation of labour income is competitive, and the headline corporate tax rate is comparatively low (following a series of cuts since 2008). However, there are also some less appealing aspects. The steady trend in the overall tax take has masked significant structural changes in the composition of revenue, driven by recent governments' strong appetite for manipulating tax rates to influence short-term behaviour. This has made the tax system more onerous and complex, and the absence of a coherent medium-term tax strategy implies some uncertainty for households and businesses. In addition, marginal tax rates on corporate investment are high (owing to elevated business property taxes and a limited capital allowance regime), the system of residential property taxation is regressive and outdated, and tax avoidance among the wealthy is widespread. In terms of the structure of tax receipts, the share of revenue from personal income, property and indirect taxes (such as value-added tax-VAT) is above the EU/OECD average, and a lower share is derived from corporate income and social security contributions.
The headline corporation tax rate will be reduced to 17% by 2020
The UK has a competitive regime for taxation of labour income, with one of the lowest tax wedges in the EU. The tax burden on households has risen over the past decade, in response to various "stealth" taxes (such as on travel and insurance) and because of "fiscal drag"-taxpayers pushed into higher tax brackets as thresholds failed to keep pace with inflation-although reforms in recent years have partly reversed the fiscal-drag effect. The standard VAT rate is 20%-slightly above the OECD average. Reduced rates apply to a comparatively wide range of goods and services. Excise duties on fuel, tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe. The headline corporation tax rate has been lowered by successive governments, from 30% in 2007 to 19% as at April 2018. Under current government plans it is scheduled to fall to 17% in 2020.
There is limited room for manoeuvre for major tax reform, given the state of the public finances, the uncertain economic outlook and the Conservative government's 2015 election pledge not to raise in-come tax, National Insurance contributions (NICs) or VAT until 2020. Recent budgets have been modest in scope, incorporating various "stealth" reforms to push the overall tax burden marginally higher. The changing composition of the labour market, reduced revenue streams from financial services and North Sea oil, and continued aggressive tax-planning practices by most large multinational firms to reduce their tax liabilities imply that the tax burden will increase gradually over the forecast period.
The government's occasional pitch to transform the UK into a "Singapore-style" low-tax, low-regulation economy in the event of a poor Brexit deal lacks credibility. The Singapore model is reliant on high immigration, state intervention and a minimal social safety net, which are unlikely to appeal to a majority of UK voters. The EU may demand assurances in Brexit negotiations over future UK tax policies in an effort to protect the bloc against fiscal dumping. Changes are likely to the UK's VAT framework after 2020, assuming the UK opts to leave the EU's VAT regime. These could affect domestic tax rates for consumers and also have implications for crossborder trading arrangements.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.6 8.9 27 4 10 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The UK financial sector was a notable casualty of the global market turmoil a decade ago, but steady progress has since been made to repair the damage. The underlying resilience of the banking sector has improved, as institutions have raised their capital and liquidity buffers amid tighter regulation and major restructuring. The rescued RBS remains in a weak state, but on aggregate the Tier 1 capital ratio of the banking sector compares favourably with other high-income countries and non-performing loan ratios are among the lowest in the EU. Annual Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) stress tests against severe economic scenarios imply that the sector is reasonably well placed to withstand financial shocks, with the stock of high-quality liquid assets held by major UK banks around four times the level before the global crisis. Previously lax domestic supervisory and regulatory frameworks have been tightened, with more robust capital and liquidity provisioning, implementation of bank "ring-fencing" reforms and measures to reduce mortgage risk in the UK's highly leveraged housing market (such as tighter underwriting standards for owner-occupier mortgages). In its recent Financial Stability Report the BoE judged that domestic financial risks-excluding those related to Brexit-were at a "standard level", although it noted that current low debt-financing costs could obscure underlying strains, particularly in the consumer credit market and commercial property sector. A large external financing requirement implies that the UK will remain vulnerable to a reduction in foreign investor appetite.
Restrictions on UK-EU financial services trade are likely to emerge
Brexit implies considerable uncertainty for the UK financial services sector. The City of London is deeply integrated in global-particularly EU-financial markets, and although it will retain its status as one of the world's leading financial centres, some post-Brexit restrictions on financial services trade with the EU are inevitable, as is a gradual decline of the sector's influence at a global level. The loss of "passporting" (the right for UK-regulated financial companies to do business in the EU) and a decline in the UK's current dominance of the euro clearing market are the most likely consequences. The levels of future EU market access for UK financial firms will be dependent on an agreement on "mutual recognition and regulatory equivalence", elements of which are contentious. There has been no major exodus of financial sector jobs and operations from the UK, but we expect a gradual and steady net outflow to financial centres within the euro zone and to major rivals such as New York and Singapore.
The credit cycle has firmed over recent years, supported by the low interest rate environment, although total private-sector lending growth has remained quite modest, averaging about 4% in 2016 and 2017 (compared with double-digit growth in the pre-crisis period). This reflects subdued activity in the large market for mortgage lending, whereas the smaller stock of unsecured consumer credit has expanded sharply. This carries potential risks given the underlying weakness of household finances, although growth has eased moderately since mid-2017. Bank lending to corporates contracted for seven successive years to 2015 and will remain weak. There has been an increase in alternative forms of debt financing (peer-to-peer, crowdfunding), which will continue.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.5 6.7 16 16 7 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Labour market conditions will remain favourable
The UK labour market is among the most flexible in the world, with a decentralised system of wage bargaining and fairly liberal laws on redundancy. In recent years this has facilitated solid employment growth and a steady decline in joblessness. Headline indicators in early 2018 continued to impress-an employment rate of 75.4% was the highest since comparable records began in 1971, and an unemployment rate of 4.2% was the lowest since 1975. Participation of female and older workers has increased in response to ongoing pension reforms. However, these positive developments have been accompanied by some less attractive features of the labour market: a protracted period of flat or declining real wages; weak productivity growth; and a rising share of "less secure" employment (agency jobs and temporary or "zero-hours" contracts), mostly in low-wage, low-skill occupations that point to the gradual emergence in some areas of a two-tier "insider-outsider" labour market that is more traditionally associated with continental European economies such as France and the Netherlands. Average real-term weekly earnings are not expected to recover to pre-crisis levels until at least 2025 (this would imply a 17-year period of stagnant wages, which is unprecedented in modern times). The UK's productivity performance since 2008 has been poor, with growth in output per hour and output per worker considerably weaker than its long-term pre-crisis trend, and slower than in almost all peer economies.
Under the Labour government of 1997-2010 the UK moved closer to the "social model" prevailing in much of continental Europe by signing the EU's social chapter, introducing a minimum wage and strengthening temporary workers' rights. There was also a marked increase in labour immigration from within and outside the EU. A steady net inflow of foreign labour has since continued, amid demand from firms seeking to fill skilled positions and minimise their overall wage costs. As in many countries, public sentiment in the UK towards immigration has hardened, alongside mostly ineffectual government targets to reduce the inflow of foreign workers. The issue of immigration played a significant role in the Brexit referendum, with the decision to withdraw from the EU viewed by many "Leave" voters as a means to allow the government to "take back control" of the UK's borders, although there is little agreement on what form this may take in practice.
Free movement of labour from the EU will continue for a limited time
The post-Brexit transition period up to end-2020 would imply that the free movement of labour would continue for a time after the UK's formal exit at end-March 2019. The form of any future UK-EU relationship after 2020 remains highly uncertain. Barring a "no deal" scenario, business lobbying for access to foreign labour is likely to mean that any final agreement on immigration will be fairly flexible, albeit while still allowing the government to claim that it has greater control. Some restrictions on EU workers' labour-market access and rights in the UK are likely to be implemented, but may not materialise until after the forecast period.
Official data and anecdotal evidence suggest that inflows of EU workers have fallen since the Brexit referendum. Given the weaker outlook for the economy and more strident nationalistic sentiment in the UK, this trend is likely to continue, raising the prospect of recruitment difficulties in sectors that are more reliant on foreign labour, such as retail, hospitality and healthcare.
Recent reforms include the introduction in April 2017 of a new apprenticeship levy (equivalent to 0.5% of employment costs, paid by all firms with a wage bill above £3m-US$3.8m) and a phased increase up to 2020 in the compulsory "national living wage" for workers over the age of 25. In April 2018 business groups called for major reforms to be made to the apprenticeship levy, amid widespread criticism of its design.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.3 7.8 19 16 12 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
A long-term infrastructure investment strategy is overdue
The quality of UK network infrastructure is modest by developed-country standards, and only limited improvements are expected. Standards are by no means uniform. The main shortcomings are highly congested road and urban rail networks, airport capacity constraints in southern England, limited (and costly) new energy-generation capacity and a distorted housing market suffering from chronic undersupply. By contrast, the UK is among the region's better-performing countries in terms of digital connectivity, and is one of the world's largest e-commerce markets. Mobile network coverage and provision of high-speed broadband services are above the regional average, although broadband costs are relatively high. Liberalised utility markets are dominated by former regional monopolies, with energy costs around the EU average.
The UK has long suffered from low levels of public infrastructure investment. Current policy plans imply a modest rise in state-backed infrastructure spending on housing, roads and innovation, albeit from a low base and with the prospect of accompanying falls in EU-funded structural investment. Private-sector involvement will remain low. Since 2015 a new National Infrastructure Commission (NIC) has been tasked with planning infrastructure priorities over a 30-year horizon-a welcome step towards establishing a coherent investment strategy, which had been ignored by successive governments. However, delivery of major projects will continue to be hampered by a complex planning framework, high land prices, vested interests and funding issues. Total infrastructure investment will remain below the OECD average.
Attracting new private investment in electricity generation will require consumer-funded price guarantees from the government, similar to a contentious 2016 deal signed with EDF, a French energy group, to build the first nuclear-power plant in the UK for a generation. Construction is to be completed by the mid-2020s.
Airport capacity constraints will remain severe
Airport infrastructure is well developed, but capacity constraints are particularly severe in and around London. After years of delay, in October 2016 the government provisionally approved a third runway at Heathrow-the world's busiest two-runway airport. Major doubts persist over the project, however, amid strong local opposition, environmental concerns and legal threats. No increase in capacity is expected over the forecast period.
A number of rail projects are progressing, most notably a 118-km east-west rail link under central London (Crossrail), due to begin services from late 2018. A high-speed rail network (HS2) from London to major northern cities received parliamentary approval in 2017. A decade-long construction programme will begin this year, amid widespread local opposition and spiralling cost projections.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
9.2 9.2 6 11 5 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
This category aims to show the extent to which the business environment is open to innovation, digitally connected and prepared for technological disruption. The UK scores reasonably well on a regional and global basis, mainly owing to the scope and quality of its existing digital infrastructure; extensive e-commerce and e-business penetration, above-average digital skill levels, and a well-developed framework of research and innovation infrastructure arising from its strong scientific and university base. Weaker aspects are a comparatively low level of research and development (R&D) spending (across the public and private sectors), modest linkages between the science and business sectors, and fairly limited provision of e-government services. Whereas the UK ranked among seven "innovation leaders" in the European Innovation Scoreboard 2017-scoring particularly well in terms of its research structure and workforce skills-R&D intensity has remained broadly flat over the past decade, with total spending of 1.7% of GDP in 2016 below the EU average of 2% and far behind the highest ratios of more than 3% in Sweden and Austria (as well as Switzerland, South Korea and Japan). There is also significant regional disparity in R&D expenditure across the UK. Recent studies suggest that the proportion of UK companies using industrial robotics in the manufacturing sector or deploying emerging digital technologies (such as augmented reality or artificial intelligence) is among the lowest in the OECD. A National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) was established in October 2016 to combat the increasing threat from cyber-crime. Part of the Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ) intelligence service, the NCSC was formed by integrating three separate cyber-related agencies. According to its annual report, an estimated 40% of UK businesses suffered at least one cyber-related attack in 2017. Recent events have underlined the threats posed to national sovereignty, business interests and personal privacy from the targeted activities of state-backed organisations (in April 2018 the NCSC identified Russia as the UK's "most capable hostile adversary in cyberspace"), cyber criminals and the dominant global technology companies.
The UK will retain a strong scientific and university base, and the government has pledged to increase levels of public R&D investment. However, there is a risk that overall funding for research and innovation will be squeezed by ongoing austerity and the UK's likely exit from-or more restricted access to-EU structural programmes (such as Horizon 2020) and project financing schemes later in the forecast period.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The UK's departure from the EU may encourage policymakers to address some of the structural deficiencies that have held back the economy in recent years, including lacklustre productivity growth, insufficient innovation and poor infra-structure. The chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond, announced a National Productivity Investment Fund to boost the UK's digital infrastructure and spending on research and develop-ment over the next five years. Proposals to reform the UK's housing market have focused on introducing greater speed and flexibility into the planning process. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects these measures to support the recovery in productivity, but they are too modest in scope to close the UK's productivity gap with its G7 peers.

The Queen's Speech in June 2017 set out the government's legislative agenda, which was dominated by Brexit. Eight of the 27 bills relate to the transfer of EU law into British law, a UK customs regime, independent trade policy, controls on immigration, fisheries policy, agricultural policy, nuclear safeguards and the UK's ability to impose international sanctions. In a further sign that Brexit is the government's priority, the parliamentary session will last for two years rather than one, ending two months after the UK's withdrawal at end-March 2019.
The centrepiece of the autumn budget in November 2017 was a sizeable increase in spending on the National Health Service (NHS). In March 2018 Mrs May said that the government would this year draw up a "long-term funding plan" to secure the future of the NHS.

Data suggest that the government has already met its "fiscal mandate" of a structural deficit smaller than 2% of GDP by fiscal year 2020/21. The budget deficit narrowed sharply in 2017, to 1.9%, from 3% in 2016 of GDP, owing to strong growth in tax revenue. This implies some scope for higher public spending in the autumn budget statement. However, in the remainder of our forecast period (2018-22) we expect the government to continue to aim to nudge down discretionary spending as a proportion of GDP. We expect the deficit to contract to 1.6% of GDP by 2020 and 1% by 2022. We forecast that public debt will decline from 88% in 2018, to reach 81% by 2022.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy

At its meeting in March 2018 the monetary policy committee (MPC) of the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) voted to keep the main policy interest rate unchanged at 0.5%, five months after raising it by 25 basis points for the first time in a decade. Seven members of the nine-strong committee supported this position, with two members voting to increase the policy rate by 25 basis points to 0.75%. The MPC is keen to begin normalising its policy rate, although recent soft economic data are likely to mean that the BoE will delay its next rate rise until August 2018. We expect a gradual tightening cycle to follow, with a series of 25-basis-point increases in the policy rate over the next five years, taking it to 2.25% by end-2022.

The economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. Average annual real GDP growth was firm in 2016 and 2017, at 1.9% and 1.8% respectively. However, the annual pace of growth slowed throughout 2017, from 2.1% in January-March to 1.4% in October-December, and preliminary data show a further slowdown in the first three months of 2018, to 1.2%. In response to these weak first-quarter data, we have revised down slightly our forecast for full-year real GDP growth in 2018, from 1.5% to 1.4%. We expect real GDP growth to remain broadly stable in 2019, at 1.5%.

We expect the modest slowdown in 2018-19 to be led by a deceleration in domestic demand. A looser fiscal stance will provide some support to real GDP growth throughout the forecast period, but consumer spending will weaken in response to the continued squeeze on household disposable incomes from falling real wages. Consumer spending was fairly resilient to this pressure in 2017, reflecting employment gains, high levels of household borrowing and a decline in the savings ratio. In 2018 we expect employment growth to slow and greater uncertainty about the economic outlook to push up precautionary savings. Consumer spending will recover in 2019-22 as inflation eases, uncertainty recedes and unemployment edges lower. However, increased borrowing costs arising from tighter monetary policy will hold back the pace of the recovery in these years. We forecast that investment spending will decelerate in 2018-19 as a result of heightened uncertainty during difficult Brexit trade negotiations and higher cost pressures as a result of sterling's depreciation, before recovering in 2020-22 as these effects fade.
Mitigating the extent of the domestically driven slowdown in 2018 will be a positive contribution to GDP growth from the external balance as export volumes benefit from a competitiveness boost as a result of sterling's depreciation, while the weaker domestic demand environment reduces import growth. From 2019 we expect the trade balance to exert a drag on GDP growth owing to our forecast for a recovery in domestic demand, which will push up import growth again. Our expectation of a business cycle downturn in the US in 2020 and a deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU, which should take effect in 2021 and result in looser trade ties than before, will also constrain exports in 2020-22. We expect real GDP growth to pick up to 1.8% on average in those years.
Trade policy is the biggest risk to our forecast for economic growth globally. In March the US announced new tariffs on steel and aluminium imports; a number of countries, including the EU, received an exemption, which was rolled over at the beginning of May. This expires on June 1st, and there is a risk that if the US lets it expire and applies tariffs to EU exports, the bloc will retaliate with tariffs of its own, leading to a broader trade conflict.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
The UK's decision to leave the EU may over time have a significant influence on the sectoral profile of the economy, although the precise outcome will depend on the details of the Brexit deal that is reached between the UK and the other 27 EU member states. One industry facing considerable uncertainty is the UK's large financial services sector. London is currently unrivalled as the EU's leading centre for financial services activity, but this position would be called into question if firms based there lost their current "passporting" rights to operate across the EU. London, unlike New York, does not enjoy a domestic financial hinterland. Although domestic financial markets are highly developed, their size is limited by the UK's economic output of £2trn (US$2.6trn, about 3.3% of world GDP) and a population of 66m (about 1% of the global total). Instead, London and other centres of financial business in the UK have turned to international, and especially European, activities. The industry has managed to dominate sophisticated, high-value activities such as trading foreign exchange and financial derivatives, managing alternative assets or writing crossborder insurance contracts.
UK financial services will thrive after Brexit
Our baseline forecast assumes that the UK's financial services sector will retain its pre-eminence in Europe after Brexit. The advantage enjoyed by the City of London (and Canary Wharf) is overwhelming compared with every other European city and anywhere in the world with the exception of New York. This advantage derives from its unrivalled supportive infrastructure in terms of law, culture, language, tax system, sectoral expertise and regulatory environment. The factors that have made the UK a world leader in financial services are not contingent on its membership of the EU.

Nevertheless, leaving the EU is likely to hit services activity more sharply than manufacturing-because reaching agreement on goods trade tends to be much simpler than doing so on services trade-and this is particularly salient for the UK given how dominant the services sector is. It has grown in importance over a period of decades and now accounts for just less than 80% of UK value added-a comparatively high share among developed economies, although slightly below that of France and Belgium. In contrast, the UK's industrial base has contracted steadily as a share of total output, although for all the talk of decline the country is still among the world's ten largest manufacturers. Industry (including construction) accounts for 20% of GDP, and manufacturing comprises around half of this industrial total. The main sectors have shown differing trends since the economic downturn in 2007-08. Output in manufacturing has increased sluggishly, and is still slightly below its pre-crisis peak (0.8%). Output in construction expanded rapidly since 2013 and, despite a downturn in early 2018, remains 6% above its pre-crisis peak. By contrast, services output has expanded steadily in the decade since 2008, to almost 15% above its pre-crisis peak.

The construction sector currently accounts for about 6% of GDP. Despite the UK experiencing one of the world's most sustained increases in house prices in the period up to 2008, the construction sector did not expand anywhere near as strongly as in Spain, the US or Ireland. The stringency of planning regulations and vested interests in supporting solid house price inflation has held back the construction of new homes in recent decades, especially in and around London. To keep up with robust population growth, the government has introduced polices aimed at unlocking supply, and in 2017 committed to delivering the biggest annual increase in house-building since the 1970s. However other aspects of the government's housing policy remain supportive of prices. Growth in house-building has nevertheless become a bright spot in an otherwise struggling construction sector. New orders for commercial work and infrastructure projects slowed in 2017 and were hit further by the collapse in early 2018 of Carillion, the UK's second-largest construction and outsourcing firm. Only modest growth is expected across the construction sector over the forecast period.
As in other developed economies, the manufacturing sector has accounted for a falling share of UK GDP. This partly reflects the fact that households spend a growing share of their income on services as their wealth increases. However, the decline has been more pronounced than in almost every other industrial-ised country. The deep recession of the early 1980s dealt a permanent blow to the country's industrial heartlands, but it is notable that the declining importance of manufacturing has been more pronounced since the late 1990s-the sector accounted for almost 27% of output in 1997. The persistent strength of sterling for much of the period between the mid-1990s and 2006-07 weakened the competitiveness of export-oriented manufacturers, at the same time as labour-intensive industries were unable to compete with the rise in imports from expanding emerging economies with lower wage costs. Industrial investment declined further from already comparatively low levels. Against this backdrop, and with policymakers focusing their attention on and collecting revenue from the financial and business services sectors, we expect services and manufacturing to maintain their respective shares of output over the forecast period.

The headline rate of annual inflation-as measured by the consumer price index including owner occupiers' housing costs (CPIH)-accelerated to 2.6% on average in 2017, up from 1% in 2016. The increase partially reflects a rebound in oil prices, but has been amplified by the sharp depreciation of sterling since the Brexit vote. The pound has since reversed much of this appreciation, but we expect it to weaken again in 2018-20, and oil prices are likely to rise further this year. As retailers continue to pass on high input costs to customers, we expect inflation to remain above the BoE's official 2% target for much of 2018, averaging 2.4%, even as domestic price pressure weakens. Tighter monetary will bring inflation back towards the bank's target from 2019; we forecast that inflation will ease to 1.9% next year and 2.1% on average in 2020-22.

There was a sharp drop in the external value of sterling after the Brexit vote. Sensitivity in the foreign-exchange markets to the Brexit news flow has contributed to volatility in the value of the pound, which lost further value against both the euro and the US dollar in 2017, although it appreciated sharply against the dollar in early 2018. The pound has been fairly resilient since mid-2017, and we expect it to remain broadly flat against the euro in 2018-19, at about EUR1.15:£1 on average (which compares with EUR1.22:£1 in 2016), before weakening more sharply in 2020-partly reflecting the difficulty in completing Brexit negotiations, but also tighter monetary policy in the euro zone. We then expect it to recover modestly against the euro in 2021-22, as a new UK-EU trade relationship is established. Meanwhile the pound has recently lost value against the dollar, but remains at a stronger level than in 2017; we expect it to average US$1.39:£1 in 2018, before weakening slightly in 2019-20 and recovering some value in 2021-22.

The merchandise trade balance will keep the current account in deficit throughout 2018-22, offsetting surpluses on the services account. The current-account deficit narrowed to 4.1% of GDP in 2017, from 5.8% in 2016. We forecast that it will narrow further in 2018, to 3.8% on average, as slower growth in imports due to softer domestic demand reduces the deficit on the goods account and supports a larger services surplus. In 2019-20 we expect the current-account deficit to widen to 4.5% on average as domestic demand recovers. From 2021 we expect looser trade relations with the EU to mean a wider goods trade deficit and smaller services surplus, although this will be offset by a reduction in secondary transfers as the UK reduces its contribution to the EU budget. We forecast a current-account deficit of 4.6%of GDP per year in 2021-22.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in United Kingdom
Stocks and flows
Since the early 1990s the UK has been one of the top recipients of foreign direct investment (FDI) among the world's advanced economies and the biggest recipient of FDI in the EU. In 2017 the UK held the fourth-largest stock of global FDI, around half of which was from other EU countries, according to figures from the OECD. The book value of the stock of FDI in the UK totalled US$2trn at the end of 2017, equivalent to 79.1% of GDP. Relative to GDP, the UK's inward FDI stock is the highest in the G7 group of industrialised countries, although it is well below that of several medium-sized European economies such as Ireland, the Netherlands and Sweden.
Following the slump in global mergers and acquisitions (M&A) at the beginning of the 2000s, annual FDI inflows into the UK rose strongly in 2005-08, peaking at US$253bn. During this period the number and scale of FDI projects into the UK-mostly in the form of M&A-confirmed the country's status as one of the world's top recipients of FDI. The global financial crisis and severe economic recession resulted in a marked slowdown in inflows, as access to all forms of financing was restricted. Since 2010 the trend in FDI inflows has been steady rather than spectacular, averaging an annual US$53bn in 2010-15, but in 2016 inward investment surged to US$265.8bn, largely as a result of the foreign acquisition of two major UK companies: SABMiller, a multinational beverage producer; and ARM Holdings, a technology firm. In 2017 FDI inflows fell back to US$46.6bn.
Origin and distribution
US companies have long been the largest inward direct investors in the UK, although taken together the EU28 account for the largest share of the total inward FDI stock. As at the end of 2016 (latest data) the US accounted for 34.4% of the UK inward direct investment stock. As a region the EU accounted for a cumulative 42.6% of the inward FDI stock at the end of 2016. The share of Asian countries (primarily Japan) has been fairly stable over recent years, at just below 8%. Financial services, electronics and automotives have traditionally accounted for a large share of inward FDI into the UK and remain important sectors, but the composition is steadily changing, with the UK attracting greater investment in areas such as business services, pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, information technology, software development and energy generation.
Determinants
The UK's attractiveness as a location for FDI over the past 20 years has rested on a policy of openness to foreign investors, a strikingly relaxed attitude to foreign takeovers of domestic companies, liberalised product markets, a flexible labour market (by European standards in particular), deep and liquid capital markets, external economies of scale in sectors such as financial services (where London's position as a financial centre has developed and fed on a large pool of qualified banking, legal and other business services staff) and membership of the EU (which gives firms located in the UK access to the world's largest trading bloc). There is some risk that the UK's withdrawal from the EU will undermine this attractiveness, although its status as a magnet for FDI has hinged on factors other than its EU membership. A less tangible but still important magnet has been the status of English as the world's leading business language. A steady reduction in the headline rate of corporation tax has been a policy priority of the Conservative Party over recent years, designed to encourage multinational companies to be based and invest in the UK (although the success of this approach is far from conclusive).
Impact
FDI has had a positive effect on the economy, even if studies suggest that this is sometimes exaggerated. Inward direct investors employ about 2m workers in the UK, and many of the country's most productive business units, such as the Nissan and Toyota car plants, are foreign-owned. Evidence for broader spillover effects is more mixed. Although foreign companies are often held to improve working practices and quality standards in local companies, empirical evidence suggests that positive spillover effects-if they occur at all-are geographically concentrated, partly because of low levels of labour mobility.
Potential
In the long term the UK should continue to be a broadly attractive location for FDI, although an economic slowdown in 2018-19 and uncertainty about the country's future relationship with the EU may deter some investors, especially from EU countries, in the short term. Some investors will also remain wary of the UK's persistent macroeconomic imbalances (a still large fiscal deficit, a substantial current-account deficit and high levels of private-sector debt), as well as vulnerabilities in the banking sector. A major weakness of the UK business environment will remain the congestion and unreliability of its land transport infrastructure, with no major improvements expected on this front over the next five years. Nevertheless, existing clusters and economies of scale in sectors such as pharmaceuticals, financial services, bio-technology and software development will remain powerful magnets for foreign entrants, and significant potential exists for large-scale, long-term investments in the energy and transport sectors.

Net international migration will be the main driver of steady population growth
The UK population totalled an estimated 66.2m in 2017, up from 59m in 2000 and 57m in 1990. During the 1990s population growth averaged 0.3% per year. It has accelerated over the past decade, with growth averaging 0.67% per year in 2013-17. Up until the mid-1990s the rise in the population was primarily driven by "natural change" (that is, more births than deaths). This remains a significant factor, but over the past two decades the primary driver has been net inter-national migration into the UK. According to the latest official estimates, net migration totalled 244,000 in the year ending September 2017, which was at a similar level to 2014, and followed record levels of net migration in 2015 and 2016. Net migration remains well above the government's target of less than 100,000.
The UK's decision to leave the EU is likely to have an impact on the rate of inward migration to the UK over time, but the probable effect should not be overstated, not least because there may simply be a shift in the balance of migration to the UK in favour of non-EU citizens at the expense of EU citizens. In the year to end-September 2017, 220,000 EU citizens (down by 47,000, or 17.6% year on year) and 285,000 non-EU citizens (up by 26,000, or 10% year on year) came to the UK. Of the 334,000 people who left the country over the same period (a year-on-year increase of 9,000), 125,000 were UK citizens, 130,000 were EU citizens and 80,000 were non-EU citizens.
Whatever UK-EU deal is agreed in the years ahead is likely to involve restrictions on migration to the UK from the other EU member states, perhaps in return for some restrictions on UK services trade with the bloc. It is too early to gauge the precise outline of such a compromise, but it may involve something like an emergency brake on migration over a certain threshold rather than a swingeing reduction in the number of arrivals, which would cause considerable strain in many sectors of the economy. The impact of the Brexit referendum on UK demographics therefore might not be huge.
Over the past decade population growth was faster in England than in the other constituent nations of the UK, lifting its share of the total to an estimated 84.2% in 2016 (compared with 8.2% for Scotland, 4.7% for Wales and 2.9% for Northern Ireland). The strongest growth has been in London-the destination of more than a third of international migrants in recent years-followed by the east and south-east regions of England. These trends will continue, providing a steady stream of labour in and around the capital, but also placing more pressure on already overstretched transport infrastructure and housing supply.
An ageing population will add to fiscal pressures over the forecast period
Births are continuing to outnumber deaths. The number of live births has fluctuated in recent decades but has stabilised since the 1960s baby boom and has generally been between 700,000-800,000 since the 1970s. Births peaked recently at 813,000 in 2012, the highest since 1990. The long-term trend in the death rate has been more stable than the birth rate, and the number of deaths declined steadily until 2011, as people are living longer. More recently deaths began to rise slightly, until 2016, when they decreased to 597,000.
Natural increase is one factor accounting for population growth in the UK, but as discussed above, net migration has been the main driver since the mid-1990s. The direct effect of net migration has increased the population by more than 250,000 people on average per year in 2004-2016; this is an average of about 52,000 more people per year than the natural change for the same period.
As in most developed economies, the UK population is ageing-albeit not quite as rapidly as in some EU countries-as the mortality rate declines (particularly among males). This implies that pension-related spending (the largest single component of UK public-sector expenditure) will continue to account for a rising share of total public spending, adding to budgetary pressure on all public services, including healthcare, given the current government's policy inclination towards fiscal consolidation. Since the mid-1970s the median age of the UK population (the age at which half of the population is younger and half is older) has risen from 34 years to 40 years. In 2016 there were 285 people aged 65 and over for every 1,000 people aged 16 to 64 years. The share of the population aged 65 or over is projected to rise steadily, to 19.4% in 2022, from 17.2% in 2012. The share of the working-age population peaked in 2008-09 and will continue to fall gradually over the forecast period.

The market opportunities available to businesses operating in the UK will partly depend on the country's future relations with the EU. At present the UK's membership of the EU means that the effective size of the domestic market is not the UK population of 66m but the EU population of 507m. Following the Brexit decision at least some businesses-probably in the services sector-are likely, over time, to find themselves either shut out of the EU market or facing increased costs and regulatory requirements to trade there. In addition, the process of exiting the EU may be disruptive in the short term.
Notwithstanding these challenges in the short and medium term, outside the EU the UK's large, rich and flexible economy will continue to provide opportunities for inward investors and global exporters. With nominal GDP of US$2.63trn (at market exchange rates) in 2017, the UK is the fifth-largest economy in the world (after the US, China, Japan and Germany). GDP per head at market exchange rates was US$39,691 in 2017, ranking the UK in 11th position within the EU28, sandwiched between France and Italy. On The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts, GDP per head at market exchange rates will rise over the forecast period (2018-22).
Brexit uncertainty will weigh on consumer spending in 2018-19
When assessing relative output, however, it can be more informative to make these comparisons using purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion rates rather than market exchange rates. PPP explicitly adjusts for differences in price levels between countries that are not always captured by market exchange rates. On the PPP measure, nominal GDP totalled US$2.9trn in 2017, ranking the UK as the ninth-largest world economy (after China, the US, India, Japan, Germany, Russia, Indonesia and Brazil). In terms of GDP per head at PPP (at US$43,771 in 2017), the UK ranked 27th in the world and 11th in the EU28. GDP per head on a PPP basis is forecast at just below US$50,000 in 2022. The UK consumer market totalled US$1.7trn in 2017 and is projected to expand to more than US$2trn by 2021 as domestic demand recovers.
Growth in full-time employment and house prices, together with favourable credit conditions, has supported consumer spending over the past two years, despite a deterioration in purchasing power following the drop in the pound in 2016. Inflation accelerated, and amid falling real wages, consumers sustained desired levels of spending by saving less and taking on more debt. However this trend is likely to prove unsustainable, particularly as uncertainty about the implications of Brexit has started to weigh on house prices and consumer sentiment. The robust labour market and a recent return to mild growth in real wages should be supportive factors, but we expect growth in private consumption to slow in 2018-19.

Demand for healthcare and leisure will increase as society ages
The UK is a mature consumer market. Beyond the influence of a heightened period of economic uncertainty, and also cyclical factors, on consumer spending, demand will tend to be driven by a need to replace ageing stock, product development and technological change, and wider sociological factors. Demographic trends are likely to have an important effect on spending patterns over the coming years. The population of the UK is ageing, albeit less rapidly than in some other west European countries. The UK's ageing demographic profile, allied to sociological trends, will underpin demand for healthcare and leisure. However, income inequalities across the UK are higher than the west European average, and given the subdued outlook for income growth in the coming years, this trend is likely to persist-or deteriorate further-over the forecast period. The UK's Gini coefficient-where zero represents perfect income equality and 100 perfect income inequality-stands at 33.2, compared with a west European average of about 31.7.

Brexit notwithstanding, the UK is set to outperform its regional peers
Initial conditions: From the early 1990s up to 2008 the economic performance of the UK improved relative to that of many of its regional peers, owing in part to a sharp rise in labour utilisation. A similar pattern emerged in the wake of the global financial crisis, with strong employment growth fuelling a comparatively strong recovery in the UK. The pace of UK growth has since softened, and The Economist Intelligence expects this to continue in the next few years, particularly owing to sluggish productivity growth and Brexit uncertainty. We do not expect Brexit to have a negative effect on the country's long-term growth prospects, as many of the main factors underpinning this in our model are not related to EU membership. The UK's departure from the EU may have a mildly negative effect on some sources of growth such as external trade, but it may have a modestly positive effect on others, such as deregulation and fiscal transfers.
Over the long-term forecast horizon, which stretches to 2050, we expect economic performance to remain relatively robust. This reflects our view that the country's policymakers will adjust to the new reality over time and develop new pro-growth strategies. With comparatively robust demographic tailwinds-we do not anticipate a sharp post-Brexit tightening of immigration-trend rates of real GDP growth will be stronger in the UK than in Europe's other large economies. For example, our forecast for average annual UK real GDP growth of 1.8% in 2018-50 compares with figures of 1.4% in both Germany and France.
In terms of long-term growth prospects, the UK's advantages have traditionally included a comparatively low regulatory burden, a flexible labour market and a business environment that is conducive to foreign investment. These areas of economic management will be affected by Brexit, but we expect them to remain advantages for the UK. On the negative side, factors that tend to constrain the UK's long-term outlook include over-reliance on wealth effects generated by the volatile financial and real estate sectors, high levels of private-sector debt and a deficit in "intermediate" labour market skills. These have contributed to the development of an unbalanced economy. Levels of productivity in the UK, in terms of output per hour worked, lag well behind those in the US, Germany and France. This weak trend is worrying and will weigh on medium- and long-term growth if not reversed. There is a chance that the Brexit shock will result in a policy shake-up that will address some of the shortcomings that have underpinned this poor productivity performance.
Demographic trends: The working-age population is forecast to rise gradually over the long-term horizon, and the share of the population aged 65 or over will continue to increase. By 2050 those aged 65 and over are projected to account for 25.5% of the population (up from 18.5% in 2017). The share of the working-age population peaked at 66% in 2008-09 and is forecast to decline steadily to 58.3% by 2050. The labour force participation rate is just below 80%-slightly lower than in Denmark and Norway but well above the OECD average. This suggests that some scope exists for raising participation levels, but less than in most of the UK's peers.
The UK's trading relationships will be fundamentally altered by Brexit
External conditions: The UK is a highly trade-dependent economy and so its decision to leave the world's largest trading bloc will have implications for its long-term prospects. Proponents of Brexit argue that it will unleash the UK's trading potential in other parts of the world. We are sceptical about this argument. First, this new latitude in trade policy-as an EU member the UK is prohibited from agreeing trade deals on its own behalf-will probably come at the price of weaker trade links with the EU, which is the UK's most significant trading partner. Second, there may be deeper factors than EU membership that have hampered the UK's ability to expand its exports to the world outside the EU, such as weaker policy supports than are offered in many other EU countries, and a business culture that is less familiar with and enthusiastic about tackling the challenges involved in trading with new markets.
Multilateral trade liberalisation talks have been foundering in the face of increased political resistance, particularly in Europe and the US. Moreover, global trade growth has slowed significantly in the wake of the financial crisis-in part because of the changing structure of global supply chains-and remains at risk from an increase in protectionist sentiment. The development of the emerging economies in Asia, South America and parts of Africa will present both opportunities and challenges for UK companies. Amid some volatility-and a continued slowdown in China-we expect relatively solid growth to continue across the emerging world, changing the shape of the global economy and the role of major players on the world stage. Regardless of the precise contours of the UK's post-Brexit settlement, the EU is likely to remain the country's most important export destination. Given the demographic, structural and political headwinds that the bloc faces, we expect the EU's long-term growth to remain lacklustre. The underlying weakness of the euro zone also represents a significant tail risk to the UK, as it remains conceivable that it could lead to a partial or complete break-up of the currency bloc. This would be highly disruptive for the UK economy and its financial system.
Institutions and policy trends: The UK is a healthy democracy with a well-entrenched rule of law (guaranteeing security of contracts), liberalised product markets and a rigorous competition policy regime. The country's decision to leave the EU represents a break with decades of policy consensus. It remains too early to gauge how effectively policymakers and institutions will cope with the challenges involved in taking the UK out of the EU. Questions remain about the capacity of the government and bureaucracy to handle what lies ahead. Aside from dealing with Brexit, the UK must address long-standing weaknesses if it is to raise its overall level of productivity.
Long-term prospects depend on an improvement in productivity
Long-term performance: The UK has less scope for raising labour force participation than most other developed economies, so its long-term economic prospects will depend on raising productivity. It will have to meet three major challenges in this regard: improving its human capital by boosting intermediate and vocational skills; raising the quality of infrastructure for land transport; and relaxing the UK's strict planning regulations, which have contributed to a boom-bust cycle in the residential housing market, raised commercial rents, reduced competition and prevented firms from operating at their most efficient scale. A number of factors could prevent the UK from closing the productivity gap with some of its peers. Examples include the relative scarcity of land, which will require GDP growth to be balanced against other social objectives, and the UK's relatively low share of spending on R&D. The economy is forecast to grow at a respectable pace until 2050. However, many emerging-market economies will expand far more rapidly. Not only are their demographic profiles more favourable, but they also have significant potential for catch-up in areas ranging from institutional quality, regulatory efficiency and education to the application of information and communications technology (ICT).
