Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
The Climate Change Act (CCA) of 2008 established a legally binding target to cut UK greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 and a framework to help to make sure that the target is achieved. The act commits the government to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 80% of 1990 levels by 2050 and requires the government to set legally binding "carbon budgets" as stepping stones towards the 2050 target. A carbon budget is a cap on the amount of greenhouse gases emitted over a five-year period. The first five carbon budgets have been put into legislation and cover the period up to 2032.
The CCA established the Committee on Climate Change (CCC), an independent, statutory body, to advise the government on emissions targets and report to parliament on progress in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and preparing for climate change. The act also requires a five-yearly Climate Change Risk Assessment (CCRA) and National Adaptation Programme (NAP) to address the identified risks and increase national resilience, and set out the UK government's objectives, proposals and policies for responding to these risks. The first CCRA was presented in 2012 and the second in January 2017. The government adopted a NAP in 2013, and another will be published in 2018.
The 2017 CCRA identified six priority areas requiring urgent action over the next five years.
Flooding and coastal change risks to communities, businesses and infrastructure.
Risks to health, well-being and productivity from high temperatures.
Risks of shortages in the public water supply, and for agriculture, energy generation and industry, with impacts on freshwater ecology.
Risks to natural capital, including terrestrial, coastal, marine and freshwater ecosystems, soils and biodiversity.
Risks to domestic and international food production and trade.
New and emerging pests and diseases, and invasive non-native species, affecting people, plants and animals.
The 2018 adaptation report will set out the main priorities for adaptation according to these six key themes. The first NAP in 2013 set out more than 370 actions for the UK government, businesses, councils, civil society and academia to address the findings of the first CCRA. The most recent review of the NAP in July 2017 found that the actions outlined in the 2013 programme had largely been delivered: 51% of actions were assessed as complete and an additional 35% were considered on track or continuing. New measures have been introduced in some priority areas, in part prompted by the severe storms and flooding in 2015-16. Measures include more funding for flood and coastal defence projects, and steps to encourage flood resilient repairs to be made to affected properties as standard practice. The 2017 review concluded that the next NAP in 2018 will need to be strengthened, in particular in the six priority areas identified in the 2017 CCRA. Overall, the UK government's readiness to address both adaptation and mitigation measures bodes well for the long-term outlook.
Technological developments
Technological change and innovation will be a determinant of growth over the coming decades. The capacity of countries to harness technological change and disruption will have a major impact on their long-term economic prospects. The UK has a relatively strong starting position in terms of the adoption and development of new technology. According to the technological readiness category of The Economist Intelligence Unit's Business Environment Rankings, the UK is well placed in terms of its openness to innovation, digital connectedness and preparation for technological disruption.
The UK performs well on all the main variables that determine a country's capacity to benefit from technological change. The UK's strengths include its education system, employment policies, ability to attract talented innovators, a sophisticated digital infrastructure, advanced e-commerce and e-business penetration, above-average digital skill levels and a well-developed framework of research and innovation infrastructure as a result of its strong scientific and university base. According to the 2018 edition of the Digital Economy and Society Index (DESI), a composite index published by the European Commission, the UK is one of the highest-performing countries in Europe and performs well by global comparison too. The index brings together a set of 34 indicators across five principal policy areas.
Connectivity: fixed broadband, mobile broadband, fast and ultrafast broadband and broadband prices.
Human capital: basic skills and internet use, advanced skills and development.
Use of internet services: citizens' use of content, communication and online transactions.
Integration of digital technology: business digitisation and e-commerce.
Digital public services: e-government and e-health.
According to DESI, the UK is among the nine highest-performing countries in the EU, coming seventh behind Denmark, Sweden, Finland, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Ireland. The UK is a magnet for FDI into Europe, and industries at the technological frontier such as automotives, aerospace engineering, information and communication technology (ICT), biotechnology and micro-electronics have attracted much investment and international talent. Investment in London's Silicon Roundabout and other regions has helped to make the UK a leading technological hub.
However, the UK lags Europe's front-runners in other areas. The UK spends comparatively less on research and development (R&D) than its European peers; it spent 1.7% of GDP on R&D in 2016, below the EU average of 2% and well below the 3% of the best performers. Regarding automation, the UK lags Europe's front-runners such as Germany and some of the east European countries such as the Czech Republic. The UK industrial sector will have to work hard to increase automation and data exchange in manufacturing technologies to remain at the technological frontier. The education system will also need to adapt to ensure that skills in ICT, especially in programming and operating robotic systems, are sufficiently widespread. Links between the science and business sectors will need to be strengthened as efforts to boost innovation continue.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Venezuela--highlights: Political outlook
By increasingly undemocratic means and greater reliance on the military, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has tightened its hold on power. Meanwhile, the main opposition grouping, the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, has slid into disarray amid harassment from the PSUV's and its own penchant for infighting. However, the civic-military alliance maintaining the PSUV in power is eroding as oil production rapidly declines. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that, as a way of gaining international legitimacy and financing, pragmatic military and civilian members of the ruling PSUV regime will allow some opposition participation by 2019. Outside of the threat of PSUV hardliners, this uneasy alliance will face substantial challenges to stability, as its attempts to correct the current severe macroeconomic distortions will affect entrenched interests, some of which may initially support the new administration. We expect the process to be chaotic and likely to feature several false starts. The possibilities of a prolonged period of chaos, an outright military dictatorship or a military-heavy government fronted by civilians remain potential outcomes.
Venezuela--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
3.57 3.69 81 80 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela's position in our business environment ranking improves in 2018-22 to 80th place globally, nonetheless meaning that it remains one of the least attractive locations of the 82 countries covered in our rankings. This reflects unpredictable state inter-ventionism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and difficulties in accessing foreign exchange. Weak and politicised institutions, an unpredictable tax regime, a rigid labour market, and deteriorating infrastructure will also impair the business outlook. Assuming a political transition later in the forecast period, improvements will emerge. But these will take time, given the damage done by heterodox policymaking. There will also be only modest advances in addressing the country's structural constraints, and curbing corruption and bureaucratic inefficiency.

Exchange rate BsF:US$ (av) 530.7 122,999.6 7,944,078.1 12,108,199.6 16,970,911 20,825,459
A combination of highly distortionary economic policies and subdued global oil prices will prolong Venezuela's recession in 2018-20. Large budget deficits-due to a narrow revenue base and dropping oil production-will continue to spur money printing, driving inflation. Oversupply of local currency, limited exports and foreign-exchange controls will fuel a black market for foreign currency despite continued devaluations of the official exchange rate. Our fore-casts for 2021-22 are more positive, based on the benign assumption that substantial international financial assistance will help a pragmatist admin-istration to stabilise the economy.

Venezuela will enjoy a structural demographic bonus in 2018-22, as it will experience a more rapid increase in its working-age population than in its overall population. The old-age dependency ratio will remain low by developed-country standards, but population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily indebted social security system in a context of volatile public finances.

US-dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. The economic crisis and falling real incomes will continue to restrict purchasing power. Although Venezuela is generously endowed with natural resources, extremely challeng-ing conditions will keep private-sector investment well below potential.

Assuming a political transition in 2019 that will lift economic distortions and improve the business environment, we expect that Venezuela's economy will begin to recover. But the damage inflicted to the economy in recent years will prove difficult to reverse. As such, recovery will be gradual, with GDP growth averaging 0.9% annually in 2018-30. In 2031-50 we forecast that Venezuela's real GDP growth will pick up to 3.1% as rising investment in human capital boosts labour productivity growth, helping to offset deteriorating demographics. Persistent oil dependency will be difficult to undo, and a weak productive base will limit overall economic output.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is how to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 1.3% of GDP that year.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The ruling party, originally called the Movimiento V República and transformed into the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) in 2006, has been in power since 1999. The populist-nationalist PSUV was initially ruled by the late president, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013). Since Mr Chavez's death, the party has been led by the current president, Nicolás Maduro. Over most of its tenure, the PSUV has wielded practically uncontested power, initially owing to Mr Chavez's immense popularity, and later through electoral manipulation and systematic campaigns to disenfranchise opposition parties and sideline them from state institutions. The Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) coalition is the largest opposition grouping, joining a series of small parties with the country's four largest: Primero Justicia, Acción Democrática, Un Nuevo Tiempo, and Voluntad Popular. The MUD holds a majority in the National Assembly, but the body is essentially powerless, as the PSUV-only Constituent Assembly (ANC) has granted itself remit over all legislative matters. The politicised Supreme Court (TSJ) and the executive have recognised the ANC, turning it into the country's de facto legislature and relegating the National Assembly.
This adverse context for the opposition has been compounded by the group's own penchant for infighting, with opposition figures often creating short-lived splinter groups and internal factions within parties. This has resulted in scepticism amongst the populace, even amongst the 70% or so of Venezuelans that oppose Mr Maduro. The MUD has attempted to re-launch itself by creating the Frente Amplio Venezuela Libre, composed of the MUD plus a wide-ranging group of non-governmental associations. The attempt, however, has been met with further suspicion from the public. Despite the opposition's weakness, the PSUV's unpopularity has meant that it increasingly relies on military personnel to maintain power. The arrangement is mostly fuelled by opportunities for corruption, resulting in patronage and in a variety of opaque internal civic-military factions that coexist within the regime.

Political outlook: Political stability
Despite a decimated economy and spiralling hyperinflation, the ruling PSUV and the president, Mr Maduro, retain their hold on power. However, we expect worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition, most likely ushering in a government with nominal opposition participation-a "mixed administration"-in 2019.
The opposition, of which the MUD is the biggest grouping, remains in disarray. Apart from infighting, this reflects the PSUV's systematic campaign to disfranchise opposition parties and sideline them from state institutions. After years of ineffectual leadership, most citizens, even those opposing the PSUV, distrust opposition parties. This has left them incapable of channelling the anti-government sentiment brewing in response to the country's dire economic situation.
In this context of unrest and repression, the PSUV is increasingly dependent on the military for support. The country is run by an alliance composed of civilians and military personnel identified with the PSUV, and a network of businessmen that enjoy military or political connections. The accord is sustained by opportunities for arbitrage and corruption schemes made possible by foreign-exchange controls; subsidised imports of basic goods; and control of large and inefficient public-sector companies. The ultimate source of resources flowing through this patronage train is PDVSA, the state-owned oil company, whose exports account for the vast majority of foreign-exchange inflows.
Jeopardising the arrangement is the rapid decline in oil production owing to mismanagement and underinvestment. Resultant strains have been exposed by purges of the military, the latest coming in March. Unless the administration turns PDVSA around (we see this as unlikely, as the government lacks the required expertise or financing), we believe that the patronage system supporting Mr Maduro will be at risk of collapse by late 2018 or early 2019.
What happens next is hard to predict, given the military's involvement in government and the opposition's weakness. The transition is likely to be violent. An outright military government is possible, as is internal re-organisation, with PSUV civilian figureheads fronting a military-heavy administration. Such administrations would probably look to Russia and China, erstwhile generous backers, for aid to stabilise both the economy and PDVSA. However, we believe that the required financing-tens of billions of US dollars per year-is beyond Russia's means. China, meanwhile has scaled back its relations with Venezuela since 2015. As such, financing will have to come from western sources-specifically multilaterals and governments-who would demand democratic reforms. Thus, we believe that the most likely outcome is a "mixed administration", in which pragmatically minded military and PSUV leaders allow opposition participation as a way of gaining inter-national legitimacy. There should be no shortage of opposition figures willing to participate. Indeed, Henri Falcón-the only opposition figure of relevance running in the May 20th presidential election-is running on a "mixed administration" platform.
The upcoming election introduces the risk that a mixed administration may be ushered into power before 2019. This is because the elections may trigger US sanctions on the oil trade, hastening the erosion of the patronage regime, as the US is PDVSA's largest cash-paying market. Similarly, arrears on bonded debt may lead to asset seizures in the US that impede trade. However, as no legal action has yet been taken, the timing of these is uncertain.
Regardless of its timing, the shift to a mixed administration will face challenges. The PSUV's internal stability is a concern, as the end of the current regime is likely to unleash jostling for prominence between PSUV factions. Secondly, the democratic reforms that western lenders would insist on may not be acceptable to some PSUV figures. If such hardliners persevere and financing is not attained, a mixed administration would lose its purpose. However, this would limit access to the foreign financing required to stabilise the economy, leaving patronage system in permanent peril. Therefore, we expect that a balance will be struck and foreign financing secured. However, the financing would underpin a macroeconomic programme that-by eliminating the economy's distortions-would close avenues for corruption and upset regime insiders, another destabilising pitfall. Other hurdles of uncertain size will remain. These include the judiciary, the de facto legislature that is the Constituent Assembly, and violent extremist supporters of the current regime known as colectivos.
Overall, we expect a chaotic transition starting in late 2018 or early 2019. The process will be highly uncertain and may feature several false starts. We expect curtailed political stability in 2019-22.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
In 2018-22 Venezuela will continue to suffer from one of the weakest political and institutional frameworks in the region. Under Mr Chávez, the decision-making process was characterised by arbitrary decisions, often subject to reversals, and the Maduro government has proved little different in this respect. There is scarce discussion of policy proposals among the wider public, and the technical quality of the laws passed is extremely patchy. Institutional effectiveness will remain very poor, undermined by a politicised judiciary and high levels of corruption. Moreover, the credibility of the country's institutions will continue to decline, with particular concerns about a lack of accountability and transparency, including in the use of public finances and the management of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. The most extreme example of discretionary policymaking and the unstable institutional framework has been the installation of the ANC, which is solely composed of PSUV members, as the opposition boycotted its election. The ANC has given itself a two-year remit and has also expanded its responsibilities to include the legislative powers reserved to the National Assembly. It has become the government's main tool for pushing through its policies, stifling dissent and ensuring the PSUV's durability in power. In tandem with the TSJ and the National Electoral Council the ANC has stripped leading opposition figures and parties of their political rights, imposed electoral timetables that benefit the government, and passed laws suppressing dissent.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast assumes that by 2019 a "mixed administration" will be in power, in which pragmatically minded military and PSUV leaders will allow opposition participation under the guise of "national unity", as a way of gaining international legitimacy in order to access the foreign financing required to stabilise the economy. However, the process may feature a number of false starts and be highly fluid, as the internal dynamics within the civic-military PSUV alliance are extremely opaque. Once a modicum of stability is achieved, the mixed administration will continue to be constrained in its policymaking effectiveness, as it will be limited in its approach to key policy challenges. For example, massive corruption and clientelism in the provision of subsidised goods and utilities would be hard to eliminate without upsetting regime insiders and risking political stability. Similarly, PDVSA will be a crucial part of this process. The company is an enormous source of direct and indirect profits for regime insiders, but mismanagement and corruption there will need to be curtailed to a minimum to stabilise both the company and the country's macroeconomy. Foreign investment will need to be secured to lift output, but this will require a wholesale reform of the oil sector's institutional framework. This is itself an endeavour that will require considerable political capital, which will probably be in short supply.
Key to this and other institutional rehabilitation efforts will be the ANC and the TSJ, both of which are considered illegitimate by the opposition and most foreign governments. Depending of the balance of power within the new "unity" government and the PSUV, these bodies may continue to exist or be abolished. If they remain in place, an agreement of governability between them and the new regime will surely be needed.
Violent crime is expected to remain a major problem, fuelled by corruption in the judiciary and law enforcement. Drug-trafficking will remain a worrisome issue with criminal networks well established in the country. US authorities have repeatedly accused high-ranking military and civilian government members of drug-trafficking (those accused deny the allegations). Furthermore, the homicide rate has risen sharply over the past 15 years. According to official figures, Venezuela recorded a homicide rate of 58 per 100,000 people in 2015, although private sources claim that the rate was much higher. Subsequent measurements by a well-regarded local think-tank, the Observatorio Venezolano de Violencia, put the national murder rate in 2017 as high as 89 per 100,000, among the highest in the world. Aside from homicides, there have been numerous high-profile kidnappings for ransom in urban areas, a development that has increased concern over police corruption and mis-management. This increase in criminality will not be halted unless measures are adopted to improve the competence and effectiveness of law enforcement agencies and the criminal justice system, reduce rates of impunity, and boost youth employment.
Political outlook: Election watch
Elections for the presidency and municipal and state legislatures are scheduled for May 20th. Most of the opposition is boycotting the elections in protest of the rigged electoral process. Mr Falcón, a former MUD and PSUV member, is courting regime pragmatists to facilitate his victory by offering a path to regime change in a mixed-administration scenario, promising to start a "national reconciliation" and obtain international financing.
However, Mr Falcón must secure international and local legitimacy in order to show regime pragmatists that he is a credible alternative to Mr Maduro, something that he is yet to do. Mr Falcón is rumoured to be attempting to entice other opposition figures to abandon their boycott by offering to secure new electoral guarantees. We do not foresee success in those negotiations, as the current boycott stems from failed MUD-PSUV negotiations on electoral rules. However, further electoral postponements could well still take place in the run-up to the election, as the regime may fear further international sanctions following rigged elections. Following the installation of a mixed administration, an electoral timetable may be announced, as international financing will almost surely come with demands for democratic reforms.
Political outlook: International relations
Most regional governments have denounced the Venezuelan government, as has the EU. The most effective sanctions have come from the US, which has instituted country-level sanctions that deny Venezuela the possibility of refinancing its debts. Oil sanctions are not part of our baseline assumption, but the more hawkish US foreign policy team increases the risk of sanctions following the May 20th elections. A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia and China. Both have provided financing in the past, but seem unwilling to provide the several billions of dollars needed to stem the decline of oil output.

The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings place Venezuela among the world's least attractive investment locations during the historical period (2013-17). The country climbs one spot (to 80th place) for the current forecast period (2018-22). During the presidency of Nicolás Maduro, an extremely weak macroeconomic context and heightened political conflict has been added to the already weak institutional framework present during the preceding administration of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013). The slight improvement in the rankings reflects our expectation that a new government will, starting in 2019, usher in some economic reforms.
Improvement later in the forecast period assumes a political transition
Our forecasts currently assume that by late 2018 pragmatists in the military and the PSUV will allow opposition participation in government as a way to gain international legitimacy in order to access the foreign financing required to stabilise the economy. We expect this "mixed administration" to steady the economy and bring forth some improvements in business conditions. In particular, we expect better treatment of foreign investors, and less restrictive labour, tax and foreign-exchange conditions. However, political stability will be very fragile, reflecting entrenched interests, and the pressures from current administration extremists that will undoubtedly resist the mixed admin-istration's policies.

Given these concerns on political stability, the longstanding macroeconomic imbalances, the breadth and depth of regulation created during the Chávez and Maduro administrations, and the grave institutional decay of the past two decades, substantial changes to the business environment are unlikely during 2018-22.

Business environment outlook: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Corruption and selective application of regulations (such as maximum prices) remain common and undermine free competition. Property rights remain weak.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Opaque currency controls add to uncertainty, severely restrict private-sector access to foreign exchange and impede trade. New government in 2019 starts removing exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Amid severely high inflation, financing remains only available in the short term and banking sector shrinks in real terms.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Underinvestment in the water and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2018-19: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies.
2020-22: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The macroeconomic environment will remain weak
During the forecast period, Venezuela's macroeconomic environment will rank as the least attractive of all 82 countries covered in our index, barring Angola. This reflects several factors, most of which can be traced to the extremely poor management of economic policy, notwithstanding our expectation of more rational policymaking in the forecast period. Inherited imbalances and political stability concerns means that public deficits will remain high, as will inflation. The prolonged institutional decay of the past 20 years will be hard to reverse, as will the exodus of technocrats from government offices, which will keep policymaking quality low.
A collapse in international oil prices in 2014 brought with it a massive contraction of both exports and government revenue, as the oil sector (which provides the vast majority of exports) is dominated by PDVSA, the national oil company. Since then, the government has monetised subsequent fiscal deficits and severely rationed foreign exchange in order to both service external debt and afford subsidised food imports. The result of this has been a massive contraction of imports, high inflation, and a growing black market for both foreign currency and basic goods. Since late-2017, despite recovering oil prices, the dwindling production at PDVSA (itself caused by mismanagement and underinvestment) has exacerbated these problems and led to hyperinflation, a runaway black-market exchange rate, further shortages of basic goods, and the accumulation of arrears on external debts.
The current administration seems unable to formulate new policy thinking, resorting instead to ad-hoc interventionism, for example setting maximum prices, confiscating goods from retailers and distributors, and raiding banks suspected of facilitating black-market foreign-exchange transactions. The need for distortionary controls and ad-hoc interventionism stems from several years of unsustainable, expansionary macroeconomic policy, which is geared towards retaining government support.
By late-2018 or early 2019, we expect that collapsing oil production, which ultimately funds the patronage system, will lead to an internal fracture and change of administration, which we currently believe is most likely to take the form of a pragmatic but uneasy alliance between various current government and opposition members. This administration will, out of necessity, seek substantial foreign capital to help to return the economy to sustainable growth. To secure this investment, some moderate improvement in macroeconomic policymaking will take place. However, political stability, the depth of economic distortions that have built up over a prolonged period and the need to overhaul considerable portions of current regulations means that changes will be slow and they will take time to filter through to actual performance.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
3.3 3.3 74 76 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition will remain unaltered in 2018-22 and Venezuela's ranking in this category will be among the least business-friendly among the 82 countries assessed in the business environment rankings. Under our expectation of a new government in 2019, we expect little immediate improvement in the overall stance towards private enterprise. Most of the restrictive policies enacted against private enterprise can be traced to attempts at retaining support for the government from either entrenched economic elites or the public populace. Given our expectation of limited political stability, a reversal of current de facto and de jure limitations is unlikely.
Operating conditions have long been challenging, but the current government will refuse to alter its stance-characterised by bias against free markets, weak, politicised and inefficient institutions, and widespread price-fixing-despite the scale of the economic crisis. Uncertainty over contract and property rights, distortionary price and exchange controls, and the cumbersome burden of government regulation will continue to restrict businesses' freedom to compete under Mr Maduro.
Under Mr Maduro, there have been fewer takeovers of private companies, partly reflecting that performance in nationalised firms has slipped since the government's intervention. However, the threat of state interference remains high, especially in the politically sensitive sectors of financial services, and food production and distribution. The government has recently begun a 90-day intervention in Venezuela's largest bank, Banesco, ostensibly to curb black-market foreign-exchange transactions. Raids, fines and confiscations on retailers violating maximum prices are a common occurrence and will continue under Mr Maduro.
Our expectation of little improvement in 2018-22 reflects the complex legal framework that sustains the current economic distortions, and the political and economic instability that is expected to reign in the country in the forecast period. In the context of the institutional decay that has occurred in recent years, improving competition policy, and restricting lobbying and corruption would require an overhaul of regulatory bodies and legal frameworks that would take years.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
3.7 5.1 77 73 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Policy under a successor government is likely to be much friendlier for investors
Venezuela's score and ranking for policy towards foreign investment improves between the historical and forecast period, reflecting anticipated changes in policy stance under our forecast mixed administration in 2019. However, the score will remain low and Venezuela will continue to rank low in both the overall and regional rankings. We expect that, to coax necessary foreign investment, the new government will improve investor protections, reduce the threat of expropriation and display less favouritism to firms hailing from politically sympathetic countries.
Although the 1999 constitution establishes national treatment for foreign capital, in practice the government has prioritised investment from firms tied to, or owned by, friendly governments, thereby diminishing opportunities for other firms. The fact that the World Bank's International Centre for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) is currently considering 17 cases lodged by companies affected by the nationalisation drive under Mr Chávez will prove a further disincentive to foreign companies, particularly as there is little indication that the Maduro regime has either the will or the ability to make compensation payments. Indeed, close to a dozen cases have already been ruled on by the ICSID, with awards against the Venezuelan government totalling close to US$5bn. The government has only agreed payment plans on a limited number of these cases, and only under threat of seizures in foreign courts.
We expect the next government to take a friendlier approach towards foreign investment in the hopes of inciting investors to rebuild the decimated domestic productive capacity. The improvement in the score and ranking reflects our expectation that the risk of nationalisation and/or expropriation will be lower under the next government.
We expect the next government to focus its efforts in attracting investment into the oil sector given its importance to the country's economic health. Even under the Maduro administration PDVSA has partnered with private companies, with the majority of joint ventures being related to production or refining of extra-heavy oil from the Orinoco belt. Official data is not available but estimates on production suggest that it is these joint ventures that have kept production from dropping further as output in operations fully controlled by PDVSA have collapsed. Under the new government, these efforts will be expanded. This will almost certainly require a reform of the current legal framework, which caps foreign participation in joint ventures at 40%. However, this will require considerable political capital and, as such, more aggressive measures (such as partly privatising PDVSA or the elimination of the requirement that PDVSA be involved in all oil projects) will be difficult to see through.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
3.3 3.7 78 78 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Easing currency controls will prove difficult and will progress only slowly
We expect a slight improvement in conditions in this category between 2013-17 and 2018-22, but not enough to alter Venezuela's global ranking. Although official policy towards foreign investors will improve under a new government later in the forecast period, easing capital controls will prove extremely challenging, with the process likely to be gradual. Even by the end of the forecast period, access to foreign currency is likely to be restricted, hampering foreign trade.
As long as Mr Maduro remains in power, he will retain stringent controls on foreign currency, with problems relating to the exchange regime representing a major barrier to foreign trade. Current exchange controls (introduced in 2003) have been progressively tightened amid growing balance-of-payments problems. In practice, the private sector has no access to the official rate. The preferential exchange rate known as Dipro of BsF10:US$1 was eliminated in January 2018 and in theory both private- and public-sector transactions are done through the Dicom, a heavily managed foreign-exchange auction system. However, the government-which monopolises the country's export sector-has not supplied the auction system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and dollars essentially impossible to find at the official rate. Since the start of the year the Dicom rate has devalued by 94%, and the latest auction, held in early May, set the Dicom rate at BsF69,000:US$1. Even at that rate of depreciation, demand vastly outstrips supply; the black-market exchange rate was over BsF650,000:US$1 in early May. Given the depth of distortions, there is a possibility that the country may be forced to dollarise or adopt a new domestic currency at some point in the forecast period.
Difficulty in remitting profits earned in Venezuela will remain one of the most significant challenges of doing business for foreign companies operating in the country. Capital controls mean that official permission is required to remit profits, but with foreign exchange being scarce, remittances are waitlisted. Many foreign-owned companies have not been able to remit their profits for several years. With the Dicom rate depreciating at such a rapid pace, the waitlisted profit remittances lose value in dollar terms. This will continue to happen the medium term. Reports of foreign companies choosing to mothball operations or wind down their presence in the Venezuelan market are common.
Bilateral trade partners will continue to struggle in their relations with the Maduro government. Restricting foreign exchange to the private sector has resulted in a plummeting of imports. Outside of exchange controls, red tape, corruption and inefficiency also hinder trade, and corruption in the customs service will remain endemic. The acute foreign-exchange shortage has meant that even public-sector imports have been limited or gone without payment. Indeed, public complaints from trade partners about non-payment to suppliers are a regular occurrence and the trend is likely to continue. Even imports from known economic and political allies have dropped drastically since the beginning of the recession. Official data are not available, but IMF data show that between 2014 and 2017 imports from China decreased by 71% and from Russia by 88%.
Under the next administration, we expect some macroeconomic reforms, the return of international credit and a correction in PDVSA. This will aid balance--of-payment dynamics and will facilitate the gradual removal foreign-exchange controls. However, the pace of removals will largely depend on how successful the mixed administration is at restoring international credit and turning PDVSA around. Overall, we expect limited progress, as shown by the discrete increase in score.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.1 5.6 66 61 9 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Improvements in the tax regime are likely under an opposition government
The tax regime will remain a constraint to investment but will undergo some minor improvements under a new government later in the forecast period. Rates of direct corporate taxation are currently moderate, with a top corporate income tax rate of 34% (excluding oil companies, for which the rate is set at 50%), but tax laws, regulations and procedures are complicated, inconsistent and subject to frequent arbitrary adjustments. A series of new taxes introduced in 2009 in many cases doubled the effective tax rate on earnings. These taxes formed part of wider reforms such as a sports law, a new science and technology law, a worker training law, and a municipal law, but included new fiscal charges on businesses, some of which are levied on gross revenue rather than net earnings. The measures are unlikely to be rolled back under the Maduro government. The new government may reverse some, but the deteriorated state of public finances imposes limits on tax cuts.
The tax base is narrow: according to the latest official data disclosed by Venezuela's tax authority (Seniat), tax income accounted for just 12% of GDP in 2012. The Seniat regularly reports massive increases in tax collection (in March the year-on-year increase was over 900%) but given hyperinflation, tax collection is actually shrinking in real terms. Despite the recent deterioration in the public finances, we do not believe that tax rises are likely under the current administration. Mr Maduro has shown little interest in raising revenue to offset massive increases in public spending and appears content with financing the huge fiscal deficit through public debt issuance, which is monetised, driving hyperinflation. In addition, the president will be reluctant to pass measures that would further alienate his already-dwindling support base.
Based on our assumption that a new government will take over and begin enacting policy adjustments later in the forecast period, we expect efforts will be focused-at least initially-on improving compliance-a difficult task, given the deterioration of state institutions over the course of the past 15 years.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
3.3 2.9 77 79 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Financing conditions will remain difficult
Venezuela's score for financing deteriorates in the forecast period, given the weak state of the banking sector and on the assumption that improvements in access to medium-term finance for the private sector, and in eliminating distortions, will occur only beyond the forecast period. The government has continued its policy of directed lending, which requires private banks to channel credit to specific sectors at preferential rates (including agriculture, mortgages and tourism).
In nominal terms, bank credit grew by almost 6000% in 2013-2017, reflecting a captive domestic liquidity and spiralling inflation. In real terms, however, we estimate that this represented a 92% contraction. For companies borrowing from local banks, credit remains predominantly short term. As only a small percentage of the population has sufficient funds to purchase investment and savings products, the capital market also remains shallow. Following a political transition, we expect interest rates to be gradually rationalised, but sector-specific measures will also be required and financing will remain a major weakness of the business environment throughout the forecast period.
In early May 2018, the government announced a 90-day intervention in Venezuela's largest bank, Banesco. The intervention may be the start of a nationalisation drive of the banking sector. The impact of such move would be limited both for the public finances and for financing conditions, as the banking sector's deposits and loans have been decimated in real terms, making them irrelevant as a source of potential wealth for the government or credit to the private sector.
The soundness of the financial system and the quality of regulation will remain key concerns. A bout of instability in 2009 prompted the government to take control of a number of small banks and brokerage houses. The government passed new legislation in 2010, but this has not resulted in a tighter regulatory framework. In line with reform legislation passed in other sectors, the government has simply established a new layer of bureaucracy, rather than trying to tackle the patchy enforcement of existing regulations. Weak skills in regulatory agencies and political meddling in oversight decision-making will remain problems and will continue to undermine efforts to identify and support ailing banks at an early stage.
A removal of the many price, export, capital and foreign-exchange controls after an expected political transition would be risky to the stability of the financial system. For instance, normalisation of interest rates would almost surely have an adverse effect on loan performance and credit creation. Careful co-ordination with the country's banks to reduce pressures on the financial system will be required. The gradual lifting of the directed lending system would also allow for better allocation of resources and the medium-term stabilisation of interest rates.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.0 4.2 80 80 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Labour market rigidities will persist under the Maduro regime
Venezuela's labour market will remain among the least flexible in the world in 2018-22. Although a marginal improvement in the underlying score is expected as a new government begins to take steps to ease the highly-regulated labour market, the process will be gradual and come only at the end of the forecast period, meaning that the impact on the overall score in 2018-22 will be very limited. The highly distorted exchange-rate system makes it virtually impossible to assess wage costs in US dollar terms in comparison with the rest of the region. However, a 2012 labour reform increased non-wage costs considerably: obligatory non-wage costs, employers' social security contributions, mandatory profit sharing, and childcare and food allowances added more than 70% to the basic wage costs for large and medium-sized companies, and 30% for smaller companies. Under the assumption of a political transition, we expect some of the most egregiously restrictive regulations to be reformed later in the forecast period.
Wage and non-wage costs come on top of a long-standing firing freeze, under which staffing levels (excluding managers, short-term workers and high-income earners) can be reduced only via collective agreement. Some workers cannot be fired at all, including, for example, pregnant women and their partners, and workers with children with a disability or illness. In practice, companies looking to shed staff are forced to negotiate "voluntary redundancy" agreements with workers; these typically centre on extremely generous severance payments, further adding to employment costs. Employment tribunals are generally hostile to private-sector employers, a factor used by workers and union representatives to their advantage. Moreover, companies that make recourse to voluntary redundancies have at times been targeted for nation-alisation, representing a further disincentive for the private sector.
Finding skilled labour would be likely to remain problematic even under an opposition-led government, as the results of decades of underinvestment in education will take time to reverse, meaning that even basic skills will remain scarce in much of the workforce. Chronic underinvestment in scientific and technical skills, as well as political interference in universities and technical colleges, has damaged the quality of the country's tertiary education system. Massive emigration has also taken its toll. No official data exists, but local estimates put total emigration in the past two decades at close to 3m people, with over 1m having left in the past two years. Anecdotal evidence suggests that among those leaving, a large proportion were middle-class professionals with good employment prospects abroad. This has worsened skill shortages. Although some are more likely to return to the country under our assumption of regime change, this is unlikely to gather substantial pace during the 2018-22 forecast period, as many Venezuelans will wait until the political and economic situation stabilises before returning.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
3.5 3.8 78 76 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Underinvestment will cause many services to deteriorate
Following years of mismanagement and underinvestment, Venezuela's infrastructure has fallen into disrepair and we only expect marginal improvement in 2018-22. Despite repeated pledges by the government to implement ambitious infrastructure projects, state-led investment under Mr Maduro has been and will remain erratic, and most plans are unlikely to advance. A post-transition government will be keen on making up the shortfalls, but progress will be limited owing to fiscal constraints and the difficulties in attracting long-term foreign direct investment into infrastructure. Some multilateral assistance should be forthcoming.
Reliable access to electricity will be one of the main causes for concern for businesses operating in Venezuela in 2018-22. Frozen nominal electricity tariffs have led to rapid growth in demand in recent years. Water levels at the Guri dam-which generates most of the country's hydropower (which, in turn, accounts for over 50% of total electricity generation)-have recovered from critically low levels, but with little new capacity coming on stream, the country will remain highly exposed to drought. In addition, chronic underinvestment in the transmission and distribution network has resulted in repeated and widespread blackouts across the country. Overhauling the entire system will likely take years, meaning that electricity rationing and unscheduled or scheduled blackouts will remain a risk through 2022.
Problems with the water supply service are widespread and mounting. According to the 2011 census, 85% of Venezuelan households received running water. However, the situation has since drastically changed owing to lack of maintenance. There have even been reports of untreated waters reaching the faucets and a well-regarded local non-governmental organisation, Médicos por la Salud, estimates that around 79% of public hospitals do not have a regular supply of water. Although electricity cuts are currently the main concern for producers, irregular supply of water will undoubtedly also affect the business environment.
Government policies complicate air travel. Long delays in authorising the remittance of international air carriers' profits outs of Venezuela have prompted several carriers to reduce or suspend services. Data compiled by ProDavinci, a reputable news and commentary site, reveals that the number of available seats on international flights to and from Venezuela dropped by 63% between 2013 and 2017. The reduced service, coupled with firm demand (as Venezuelans have sought to travel overseas to bring US dollars back into the country, where they can sell them on the black market), has sent airfare prices soaring. Moving freight through the country's ports, which are under military control, has also proven complex; reports of corruption are common
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
3.0 2.7 77 77 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption.
Venezuela is not well prepared for technological disruption
As in all other categories of the business environment rankings, Venezuela ranks extremely poorly at both the regional and global level. In 2018-22 the score drops slightly, on the expectation that the quality of internet services will continue to deteriorate, reflecting increased demand and lack of investment.
Price and tariff regulations affect the quality of technological infrastructure in Venezuela, because high consumption levels are not matched by capital expenditure. Chronic underinvestment in scientific and technical skills, and massive "brain drain" also limit Venezuela's technological readiness. Moreover, acute skills shortages in technology will not be resolved in the short term, and private investors will wait for the political and economic situation to stabilise before making substantial capital expenditure commitments.
Although the Maduro administration, like the Chávez government before it, has directed state investment towards a variety of high-tech sectors, resources have been allocated inefficiently. For instance, the administration funded the construction of a factory to manufacture mobile telephones, but underinvested in the mobile network infrastructure, leading to poor service. Similarly, the government also built a factory to build educational computers, but school curriculums, educational materials and teaching standards have not been revised to train children in computer programming.
Internet and mobile network services are some of the cheapest in the world. However, lags in price adjustments make it difficult to cover the rising cost of maintaining the level and quality of the services. In addition, theft of equipment from companies' network infrastructure is common. As a result, service is unreliable and internet speeds are low even when compared with neighbouring countries.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The government remains unable and unwilling to undertake the policy changes needed to address its main challenges, namely declining oil production, spiralling hyperinflation and mounting arrears on external debt. Most sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including those of PDVSA) are now in arrears, but the government maintains that it has not defaulted, despite calling for debt restructuring. Restructuring appears impossible, owing to US financial sanctions and, more fundamentally, because the government lacks a credible economic programme. There is no sign yet of lawsuits by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer the promise of late payment to lengthy legal battles. Investors may also be waiting for news of policy changes following May election or a change in country leadership. In the meantime, the both the sovereign and PDVSA are open to legal challenges in the US. This is especially concerning for PDVSA, as it could involve seizure of assets, including Citgo, a US-based PDVSA subsidiary, which could impede exports, the regime's economic lifeline.
In the meantime, the government must grapple with a build-up of inflationary and currency depreciation pressures. Monetisation of large public deficits and dwindling exports has led to foreign currency rationing and hyper-inflation. The government has devalued the official exchange rate, but monetary imbal-ances persist and foreign-exchange continues to be rationed. Economic policy will remain interventionist in the short term, deepening the economic crisis that drives our baseline forecast of a move towards a mixed administration.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect more orthodox economic policies to be implemented. However, the administration will face considerable internal limitations in addressing key policy challenges. For example, wastefulness at state-owned firms and massive corruption and clientelism schemes built around the delivery of subsidised goods and services would be hard to roll back without antagonising government backers, risking political instability. Thus, we would expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA.
Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. Internal cohesiveness in the "mixed administration" will be key, as the PSUV is ideologically opposed to such borrowing and multilateral financing is likely to come with conditions on democratic reforms. Meanwhile, PDVSA must open itself to foreign investment to secure the finance needed to bring output back on track. This will require considerable political capital, as it would imply a wholesale revision of the sector's institutional framework. Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV will remain a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members, who would oppose accepting international assistance and reforming policy.
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. As a result, we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.

Authorities have not published data on fiscal accounts since 2011, when the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit was 12% of GDP. We forecast an NFPS deficit of 15.5% of GDP in 2018, which will largely be financed by printing money. High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2018-22 period, ending 2022 at 6.9% GDP.

The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. At the end of April, M2 increased by 4,400% year on year. The government will take three zeroes off the currency on June 4th, but has not announced any change in policy. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation, and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan.
