Economic forecast: Economic growth
Amid ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-20, following an estimated contraction of 13.9% in 2017. Our forecast recovery in 2021-22 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF financial and institutional assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of the country's oil wealth at its centre. However, the reform programme will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we only expect a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of over 50% in 2013-20.

Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract as well, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in investment in the oil sector. Oil output-already in the midst of a long decline owing to mismanagement and underinvestment-has contracted beyond expectations in recent months; we now expect it to bottom out at 1.2m barrels/day (b/d) in early 2020, down from an average of 1.95m b/d in 2017. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from around 2019, oil production will start a recovery in the second half of 2020, but will remain below 2m b/d even at the end of our forecast period in 2022. Export volumes will only start to recover in 2021, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Oil sector: With proven levels approaching 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the largest reserves in the world, making it a major oil producer and exporter. However, the energy sector has suffered from disinvestment and mis-management owing to political interference. The state is accorded exclusive ownership of PDVSA, the nationalised oil and gas firm, and its subsidiaries. Since 2007 oil exploration, extraction and storage activities have been reserved for state-owned enterprises or companies in which the state holds a stake of at least 60%.
The latest PDVSA data put oil output at an average of 2.6m barrels/day (b/d) in 2016, while OPEC estimates put it at 2.2m, in line with data from the International Energy Agency (IEA). Regardless, in 2017 and the start of 2018 PDVSA's output has fallen dramatically as underinvestment and mis-management take their toll. Latest IEA data estimate output at 1.5m b/d in March, making Venezuela vastly over compliant with the 2.1m b/d ceiling agreed with OPEC. Official data is not available, but production estimates suggest that it is joint ventures with foreign investors that have kept output from dropping further. As the joint ventures deal predominately in heavy and extra-heavy oil, and as production of lighter oil is collapsing, PDVSA has been forced to import more diluents from the US, further damaging its already crippled finances.
PDVSA's main joint-venture partners are Russian firms (Gazprom, Lukoil and Rosneft), CNPC (the Chinese state oil company), Chevron (US) and Eni (Italy). The government has shown a preference for Russian and Chinese firms, but even co-operation with these partners has reportedly been rocky at times given, among other things, pervasive corruption at PDVSA, complex regulatory and planning requirements, difficulties securing foreign exchange to afford production imports, and criminality in areas surrounding at oil production and refining facilities.
Dwindling production and a punishing debt redemption schedule have stretched PDVSA's financing to its limits. Suppliers and oil services firms have denounced delays in payments. Schlumberger, a US-based oil services firm, reportedly scaled back operations in Venezuela in 2016 and in 2017 wrote off at least part of PDVSA's debts. PDVSA has also fallen behind on its external debt obligations, with a majority of its almost US$30bn in outstanding external bonded debt accumulating arrears. One of the bonds that PDVSA remains current on, which matures in 2020, has 50% of Citgo, a PDVSA subsidiary, as a collateral. Another 50% of Citgo is reported collateral on a loan extended by Rosneft. Citgo has been a vital part of PDVSA's operations, as it refines and commercialises Venezuelan oil in the US, PDVSA's largest cash-paying market. As such, losing control of Citgo would be a substantial setback for PDVSA. In November 2017 Mr Maduro dismissed PDVSA's CEO and the country's oil minister in a move ostensibly aimed at improving management and reducing corruption. However, the move seems in reality to have been politically motivated, and improvements in management under the Maduro admin-istration are extremely unlikely.
As such, PDVSA's financial difficulties and perennial mismanagement suggests that the current decline in output is irreversible for as long as the present government remains in power. With PDVSA in debt arrears and unable to articulate a credible restructuring plan to creditors, we expect that a turnaround of the oil sector will only be possible after a new government is in office. We expect that any new government will prioritise the improved management of PDVSA and will attempt to open the company to increased co-operation with international investors (and perhaps even allow outright foreign operations in the country), a necessity given that PDVSA will be unable to afford the required investments. However, this will require a complete overhaul of the sector's current legal framework, which will require considerable political capital, and which remains uncertain.

A decimation of domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly has estimated that monthly inflation was 67% in March, bringing year-on-year inflation to over 9,000%. We expect inflation to average over 10,000% in 2018. There is a high risk of a hyperinflationary spiral in coming months that increases inflation to well above our current forecast and necessitates a dramatic adjustment, probably involving a resort to currency substitution.

Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 94%. The rate is supposedly determined by an auction system, but the government-which mono-polises the country's exports-has not supplied the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible, even at the current rates. In early May the black-market exchange rate was around BsF650,000:US$1; the official rate stood at BsF69,000:US$1.
Given the existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market and growing hyperinflation, the government may, as part of a stabilisation plan, introduce a new domestic currency or attempt some kind of currency substitution in the future. Under our current political assumptions, similar measures may be undertaken after 2019. The exact nature and implementation of the plan is hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.

We expect the current-account surplus to reach US$6bn in 2018 (2.6% of GDP at the distorted exchange rate, which overstates the GDP in dollar terms), owing to continued import compression. However, Venezuela's lack of access to foreign finance means that the current-account surplus will not be enough to meet the country's financing needs. Indeed, excluding arrears, we calculate that principal repayments of sovereign and state-owned companies' bonded debt alone will amount to US$3.5bn in 2018. As such, we expect further arrears in 2018 and 2019. By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following a debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored and imports will begin a recovery. We expect the current account to go into a deficit of 4.8% of GDP in 2020 at a less highly distorted exchange rate. Recovering oil production and the re-structured interest payment schedule facilitate a narrowing of the current-account deficit to 3.2% of GDP in 2022.
Assuming that a new administration takes power from around 2019, we expect financial and investment inflows to provide sufficient financing, stabilise balance-of-payments dynamics and help to rebuild reserves coverage. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to anticipating a "mixed administration" capable of retaining power, it hinges on a substantial assistance package from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process within 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-22, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Venezuela
Stocks and flows
According to the IMF (whose figures differ somewhat from local sources), the stock of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Venezuela stood at US$30.1bn in 2016, the last year in which actual data have been provided. This is around one-third less than a peak of US$48.9bn in 2007 and is primarily the result of significant disinvestment, notwithstanding the government's strict capital controls. Using the overvalued official exchange rate (which overstates GDP in dollar terms) the FDI stock was 5.3% of GDP, a massive drop from the nearly 50% of GDP of 2003. Overall, FDI inflows have been very volatile in the past 20 years, affected by both political and macroeconomic factors. During the oil opening of 1996-98, inward FDI peaked at an annual average of US$4.4bn a year. By historical standards, inward FDI held up well in the first three years of the presidency of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), averaging US$3.8bn per year in 1999-2001. As political conflict intensified, FDI inflows began to decline in 2002-08 (averaging US$1.8bn per year), and in 2009-a year of great volatility in the world economy and adverse domestic developments in Venezuela-the country registered disinvestment of US$1.1bn (some negative inflows were also the result of compensation for nationalisations). Inward FDI has recovered afterwards, averaging an estimated US$4.3bn per year in 2011-13, because of greater investment from China in energy and housing. It declined considerably afterwards, to US$1.9bn a year in 2014-16, likely as a reflection of both sliding international oil prices and foreign investors increasing disillusionment with the government's inability to comply with investment agreements and manage the economy. Outbound FDI in Venezuela is considerable, reaching a stock of US$32.7bn in 2016. However, this tally is dominated by investments abroad by PDVSA, the state oil company.
Origin and distribution
The energy sector, and oil in particular, remains the main magnet for FDI. US and European oil companies have major investments in the country, even after forced changes to the ownership structure of most contracts. After oil, banking and communications have been the main recipients of FDI. Spanish banks have the largest foreign presence in the financial sector, although the Venezuelan state has bought back some operations. Other notable FDI inflows come from Chile (in forestry activities) and Canada (in the mining industry). In recent years Venezuela has courted new investment partners in Brazil, China, Russia and Iran, with limited success. Domestic economic problems in most of these countries mean that short-term efforts will be focused on seeking investment from China and Russia.
Determinants
Following a period of booming FDI inflows in the 1990s, driven by oil and telecommunications openings, an uncertain political and policy environment-including threats of nationalisation-and a volatile macroeconomic climate have served to keep FDI well below potential, particularly in the non-extractive sectors. In the extractive sector, FDI inflows have been affected by the government's restrictive hydrocarbons investment regime, which mandates that PDVSA must hold a minimum 60% stake in the oil and gas sector and levies high taxes and royalties on private partners. The vast reserves of extra-heavy oil in the Orinico Belt require substantial technical know-how and massive investment to be put to production, an environment where major oil companies would thrive. Many major companies are already present via joint ventures or were already present before nationalisation drives. Venezuela's oil sector will continue to be a major draw to FDI under more sustainable economic and regulatory policies.
Impact
Foreign investment in oil brought accelerated growth in output, from 2.4m barrels/day (b/d) in 1994 to a peak of 3.4m b/d in 1999. Foreign investment in the extractive sector has fallen since then, contributing to a decline in oil output, reinforced by PDVSA's inability to drive production. Foreign involvement has had a less dramatic impact in other sectors, such as domestic manufacturing or services, but this in turn has resulted in high levels of import dependence. As FDI has flowed mostly into capital-intensive industries, its impact on employment and skills levels has been limited.
Potential
Potentially attractive opportunities for FDI exist in an array of sectors, such as oil and gas, petrochemicals, coal, aluminium, gold, forestry, power, tourism and telecoms. There is additional potential in some manufacturing and agricultural niches (for example, leather goods, cocoa and rum). Further comparative attractions are Venezuela's transport infrastructure, which, despite lack of investment and maintenance, is still fairly good by regional standards, and the country's strategic geographic location. However, FDI inflows will be severely curtailed by concerns over the government's policy stance, difficulties in accessing foreign exchange, the weak macroeconomic environment and the fragility of the legal framework. A more noticeable upturn in FDI inflows will have to wait until after a political transition takes place, insofar as the new government undertakes a commitment to improve the business environment, address exchange-rate distortions and controls local prices.

A demographic bonus will be wasted as a result of economic woes
Although population growth will remain weak because of a falling birth rate, Venezuela will enjoy a demographic bonus in 2018-22, but this will be largely squandered as a result of poor economic policies and a resulting deep recession that has left a greater proportion of the population outside the labour force. The annual population growth rate has been steadily decreasing from 2.8% in the 1980s to 2.3% in the 1990s and 1.8% in 2000-10, and reaching 1.2% in 2013-17. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the annual rate of population growth to tick up slightly, averaging 1.3% in 2018-22. Part of the slowdown in population growth has been growing emigration since the 2000s. No official data exist, but local estimates put total emigration in the past two decades at close to 3m people, with over 1m having left in the past two years. The small increase in population growth in 2018-22 assumes a reversal of this trend as political and economic stability improves with the arrival of a new government. This will lead to a rise in the participation rate and a faster growth rate in the labour force compared with that of the working-age population. The total population is expected to reach 33.5m by 2022, with just over one-quarter of the population under the age of 14 and two-thirds of the population between 15 and 64 years of age. Population density is low, at 34 people/sq km as per official estimates from 2017. Distribution between urban and rural areas is highly uneven, with around 90% of the total population living in urban centres. Underdeveloped rural infrastructure, limited job opportunities in the countryside and fixed agricultural prices (in many cases, below the cost of production) will result in a continuing trend of urbanisation in 2018-22, creating problems in the main cities.
The labour participation rate declined in 2004-12 (owing to an increased uptake of education linked to the government's social programmes), but ticked up marginally in 2013 and 2014, before falling again in 2015 as economic conditions worsened as job seekers became discouraged. The government has stopped producing labour data, but we expect that continued economic contraction and diminishing real wages (we estimate that, in real terms, the minimum wage plus food vouchers has lost some 95% of its value since mid-2013) has driven participation down further. Although we are forecasting some improvement later in the forecast period as the economic crisis is reversed, we expect the participation rate to remain below 70% until 2022. A very poor business environment, economic malaise and extremely restrictive labour regulation will continue to limit job creation, forcing more people to seek work in the informal sector, which is already estimated to account for around half of employment. According to the authorities, the official unemployment rate fell from 8.5% in 2010 to 6.8% in 2015. However, given that this coincided with a sharp deterioration in local economic conditions, it is likely that it reflects inflexible labour laws (which make it virtually impossible to lay off workers) rather than any significant job creation. It is also possible that the data are unreliable, as it is highly implausible that unemployment has remained low in the midst of a deep economic recession, with a growing number of companies folding.
Poverty indicators improved during the tenure of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), but these data are no longer published by the authorities. Independent academic sources estimate that poverty rates have risen sharply in the context of collapsing economic activity and hyperinflation. A study by three well-regarded universities estimated the poverty rate at 87% in 2017. Shortages of medicines and surgical supplies are creating huge problems in the healthcare system, while insufficient vaccines are resulting in the re-emergence of diseases that had previously been practically eradicated.
Public services will remain under strain from a lack of resources
The old-age dependency ratio will remain low by developed-country standards but, in the context of volatile public finances, population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily burdened social security system. Public hospitals will continue to suffer from crumbling infrastructure, and lack of supplies (including medicines) and equipment. The latter are mainly imported, or assembled from imported parts, and supplies have fallen victim to a lack of US dollars. Hospital building and rebuilding programmes have been a failure, owing to mismanagement of funds and shortages of building materials. Even a parallel welfare system, the Sistema Nacional de Misiones, is struggling to function as the government makes cuts and inflation erodes purchasing power. Overall, the provision and quality of public healthcare and education services is therefore expected to deteriorate further. This will also reflect long-running problems including a pronounced deficit of technical and basic skills, and the continued emigration of professionals, particularly doctors and nurses.

Although Venezuela appears to be a middle-income country, a sharply overvalued exchange rate artificially inflates US dollar income measurements. In dollar terms, and using a weighted average of the country's official exchange rates, we estimate that GDP per head stood at US$16,013 in 2017. Estimates using purchasing power parity (PPP) give a lower figure of US$12,558. Using the black-market exchange rate, at over BsF100,000:US$1 in late 2017, compared with the official weighted average of BsF843:US$1), these calculations would result in a significantly lower GDP per head figures. Given the country's ongoing recession, and a partial closing of the gap within official and black-market exchange rates, we expect GDP per head and disposable incomes to fall in the medium term, before beginning to pick up in PPP terms from 2021. These forecasts are based on the benign assumption that a political transition materialises without severe economic disruption, and that growth recovers thereafter.
Several factors will restrict purchasing power, including hyperinflation, and persistently high levels of poverty and income inequality. Although national statistics show a dramatic improvement in social indicators in recent years, the data have been disputed, and independent studies have suggested that inequality has not fallen as quickly as the government indicates, and that the middle-income class has shrunk. According to the UN Human Development Programme, 6.6% of the population survived on less than US$1.25/day (in purchasing-power terms) in 2012, a higher proportion than in almost any other country in the region.
Investment potential will only be tapped after a political transition
Venezuela is a reasonably sized consumer market and has the potential to become an attractive investment location, although this will have to wait until a more market-friendly administration takes over from the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela. The country has vast reserves of natural resources (including oil, gas, coal and precious metals), an array of spectacular natural tourist attractions, relatively good physical infrastructure and a fairly favourable geographical location given its proximity to the US. However, poor economic policies have contributed to a volatile GDP profile and a deterioration of public services and human capital over the past two decades. The unattractiveness of the business environment is compounded by inadequate contract and property rights. Moreover, continued high poverty levels and a deterioration in health-care and education provision in the past three decades have contributed to an erosion of skills and productivity, which has also been exacerbated by an exodus of talented individuals to work abroad.

A weakened productive base will sustain demand for imported goods
In common with the rest of the Latin American region, spending on food, beverages and tobacco accounts for the largest share of total consumer expenditure, and this will remain the case throughout the forecast period. Sharp growth in mobile-telephone usage and an underdeveloped urban public transport system (which has boosted car ownership) are the main factors behind the relatively heavy weighting of expenditure on transport and communications. Most consumer goods industries will remain underdeveloped, a legacy of "Dutch disease", whereby dependence on energy exports leads to currency appreciation and therefore a lack of competitiveness in manufacturing exports, with a consequent decline of the latter sector. Furthermore, shortages of foreign exchange have led to import controls, resulting in a scarcity of consumer goods that are not produced domestically.
The scale of the country's ongoing recession will lead to major contraction in retail sales volumes throughout most of the forecast period, and only a modest improvement from 2021. Despite recent corrections to the exchange rate (and our forecast of further corrections in 2019), the bolivar will still be overvalued, so sales in US dollar terms are not an accurate indicator of consumer demand.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term outlook is based upon a transition to a new government (in 2019) that pursues sounder policies and improves the business environment. However, despite the prospects of a more market-friendly government and the gradual elimination of the country's economic distortions, long-term growth will remain underwhelming, and will continue to be subject to boom and bust cycles linked to the oil market. We therefore project that Venezuela's real GDP per head will contract by an average of 0.2% in 2018-30 (this figure is also influenced by major contractions in 2018-19). Growth will average a healthier 2.4% in 2031-50 but the country's population is unlikely to reach a high standard of living within the forecast period. Indeed, by 2050 we forecast that per head GDP at purchasing power parity will be US$35,157-a low value for a country with Venezuela's endowment of national resources. Although we expect the business environment to improve, the country's weak institutions, dependency on the extractive industry and a weak productive base will remain significant barriers to growth.
Initial conditions: After averaging growth of 10% in 2004-08, real GDP fell sharply in 2009-10. Although the economy recovered in 2011-12 on the back of aggressive fiscal spending, growth slowed sharply again in 2013, with the economy slipping into a deepening recession in late 2014. We estimate that by the time the economy returns to growth in 2021, real GDP will have halved, making the recession the country's most severe since compilation of national statistics data began. The heterodox policy framework that has been in place for over a decade has been a major factor in hampering GDP growth, while an opaque and distorted exchange-rate system has provided opportunities for corruption on a large scale, further undermining the institutional framework and maintaining income inequality. Given the sharp deterioration in conditions in recent years, there is potential for improvement in the policy and political environment in the long term under new administrations, but there is significant risk of an outright economic collapse before then (or afterwards, if the transition is particularly chaotic). In addition, institutional deterioration is very deep-rooted and will prove harder to reverse.
On a more positive note, a higher skills base and reasonably good infrastructure by regional standards provide scope for faster overall growth and a rise in personal incomes. Nevertheless, underinvestment in human capital and infrastructure is eroding these advantages and, given fiscal difficulties, this trend will take time to reverse. Successive governments have failed to take advantage of Venezuela's proximity to developed US and European markets relative to its South American neighbours, as internal geography and a lack of investment in infrastructure in the interior have limited Venezuela's chances of becoming a regional hub for transport and commerce.
Demographic trends: As in most other emerging-market countries, growth in the working-age population will slow in the long term, while rising partici-pation rates will ensure that the labour force will grow at a brisker pace. Venezuela will continue to enjoy supportive population dynamics, with the dependency ratio of old to young low by comparison to OECD levels even in 2050. Even with life expectancy growing steadily, the share of the population aged 65 and over will be only around 16% in 2050 (although rising from an estimated 6.6% in 2017), while the proportion of the population at working age will remain high, at 65%. A particular risk to productivity is the "brain drain" seen in recent years as many experienced professionals have left the country to work abroad with no guarantee of returning, even after economic conditions stabilise following a change in government.
Diversifying away from oil will be one of the key long-term challenges
External conditions: Oil, which we estimate currently accounts for some 95% of export revenue, will continue to dominate the Venezuelan economy. However, there will be an effort to diversify the productive base in the long term, given the severe consequences of the economy's dependency on oil (particularly on the external and fiscal balances). During the Hugo Chávez (1999-2013) and Nicolás Maduro eras Venezuela and its allies have taken a confrontational stance against US policy and US-led efforts at economic integration. This stance will soften once a new government is in power, which will result in an economic rapprochement with some of its faster growing neighbours, such as Colombia and Peru. It will also signal the end of programmes such as PetroCaribe, a scheme in which Venezuela provided subsidised oil to regional economies as a way of gaining international goodwill, which was financially viable only as a result of historically high oil prices. A gradual real devaluation of the exchange rate will be necessary for Venezuela to be competitive in non-commodity sectors, as will be the removal of state control over key productive sectors that have export potential. Capital control, trade restrictions and other barriers currently designed to keep foreign currency from leaking out will gradually be pared down as well, although further liberalisation of trade is unlikely to be a priority for the next government until well into the next decade. In the meantime, links with Asia will be strengthened, and the country's close relationship with China is not likely to be compromised, given that country's significant investment potential.
Institutions and policy trends: Under the assumption of a change in government that gradually ushers in improved policymaking over the long term, our long-term forecast assumes that there will be a gradual improvement to the policy environment. We assume that some of the most distortionary elements of the current policy framework, including price and exchange controls, will be scaled back gradually in the medium term, reducing the large black-market exchange-rate premium and increasing economic openness by the end of the long-term forecast period. However, the prospects for improvements in other aspects of the business environment are less encouraging, given that they will take far longer to address. For example, strengthening of the non-oil public finances will prove unfeasible until the economy is sufficiently diversified. Given that the economy will still be highly vulnerable to the fluctuations of the price of oil, the fiscal position will remain highly pro-cyclical. An overhaul of the overstaffed and inefficient bureaucracy will be difficult to achieve, even with an administration fully composed of the current opposition. This is owing both the political costs of redundancies, and the fact that many current opposition parties are ideologically inclined to have the state play a major role in the economy. Within the context of a deficient administrative framework, progress in reforming social security and labour legislation will be slow at best, as the new government will want to retain some of its powers of patronage in order to avoid a loss of support from the withdrawal of Chávez-era benefits. Endemic corruption and politicisation will be difficult to root out, even assuming other improvements in the policy environment.
The economy will remain vulnerable to external shocks and cycles
Long-term performance: Even once the most distortionary elements of current economic policy are abandoned, the deterioration of the skills base over the past decade will mean that Venezuela's potential GDP growth will have been eroded, although there is still some scope for recovery in 2021-40, when growth will average a respectable 3.5%. It will then slow down to an average of 2.7% in 2041-50. A higher trend rate of GDP growth would be possible if a significant change in the policy direction is coupled with more favourable external conditions (mainly oil prices) than currently forecast, thereby allowing for rapid and thorough implementation of much-needed structural reforms. Under our baseline scenario, however, achieving reforms beyond those necessary for a post-transition adjustment will prove very complicated. As it is, the overall economy will remain vulnerable to continuing cycles of boom and bust, with negative consequences for macroeconomic stability and growth, and constraining the prospects for catch-up with more developed economies, despite some solid projected growth late in the forecast period. The key variables to a successful turnaround will be the degree to which the economy is diversified from oil and whether the business environment improves to the point that domestic and external investment become key drivers of growth.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Venezuela is vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change owing to both geographical limitations and the government's inadequate focus on preparedness. Venezuela is deemed extremely vulnerable to climate change given its population distribution along coastal lines on unstable terrains. 75% of the country's population is estimated to live in the 20% of the territory facing the Caribbean sea. Given low maintenance of infrastructure and little disaster preparedness, the population centres there are exposed to torrential rains, mudslides and flash floods. According to a recent study by a local and internationally recognised expert, Juan Carlos Sanchez, even within established rainfall patterns, variance has resulted in the number of extreme events per year growing in the past decade. Longer-term trends in rainfall will also affect the country. A study performed by the Universidad Simón Bolívar, a well-regarded university, has concluded that rainfall in the northwest of the country could fall by 25% by 2060. This would not only cause internal migration, but also drive the country into further food insecurity (Venezuela is already heavily reliant on imports of foodstuffs). In addition, changing rain patters may disrupt hydroelectricity generation, a major problem given that this represents over 50% of the country's electricity.
The government has done little to address these challenges. Its public works programmes concentrate on traditional infrastructure projects and there is minimal focus in the way of disaster preparedness. In a recent forum with a United Nations delegation, authorities touted their plans to build apartment blocks in place of shantytowns, the logic being that concrete buildings would hold up to flooding better. There is scarce official data on carbon emissions or pollution in the country, but environmental policies are generally deemed poor by specialised observers. PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm, has been routinely accused of poor environmental protection in both its oil and gas operations.
Migration and urbanisation
Venezuela experienced rapid urbanisation through the majority of the second half of the 20th century as the country's oil wealth was developed. According to data from the World Bank, the percentage of urban population grew from 60% in 1960 to almost 90% by the late 1990s-high by global standards but in line with most large southern cone countries. Oil exports, especially at the start of this process, funded large-scale real estate developments and infrastructure works in budding urban centres, attracting prospective workers from the countryside. In addition to a growing middle class fed by spill-over from the country's oil wealth, the rural exodus towards the cities also created sprawling shantytowns across major metropolises, which-public housing programmes have been unable to eradicate. Income inequality in urban centres is especially acute, feeding crime and political tension. This is perhaps best exemplified by Caracas, the capital, where income and wealth disparities have correlated with voter preferences for the ruling PSUV and the opposition parties.
Emigration, previously a limited phenomenon, has become a major issue. No official data exist, but out of a total population of around 31m, local estimates put total emigration in the past two decades at close to 3m people, with over 1m having left in the past two years. These émigrés were initially primarily driven by political reasons, but the exodus is now also driven by criminal violence (Venezuela has one of the world's highest murder rates) and woeful economic conditions. Anecdotal evidence suggests that those leaving have been primarily young, well-trained professionals, which has harmed the economy's prospects further. Under The Economist Intelligence Unit's expectation of a political transition, some of these émigrés are expected to return; how many will and how fast remains unclear.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Argentina--highlights: Political outlook
The ruling centre-right Cambiemos coalition government is under increasing political pressure amid recent currency volatility, but will be hoping to get its policy agenda back on track in time for the presidential election, when the president, Mauricio Macri, will seek a second term. However, the opposition will increasingly obstruct policy. Cambiemos lacks a congressional majority, meaning that the administration has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda on an ad hoc basis with various factions of Argentina's dominant Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party). In this environment, the opposition will begin manoeuvring for position ahead of the presidential election, and the government will now struggle to push its agenda through. On our current assumption that Mr Macri wins a second term in 2019, we expect that the pace of reform will increase, and will start to yield results more clearly late on in our five-year 2018-22 forecast period.
Argentina--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.58 6.14 71 51 10 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Argentina's position in our business environment ranking improves substantially between the historical and forecast periods. The weak historical ranking reflects the legacy of expansionary and distortionary macroeconomic policies, and a deterioration in the legal and regulatory framework. The Macri administration will continue to iron out distortions, which, although contri-buting to still-high inflation in the short term, will improve the business environ-ment. However, depending on the extent of public opposition and economic volatility, there is a risk that the government may be forced to backpedal, implying that implementation would be less successful than we currently assume.

Fiscal tightening, combined with severe drought, will lead to a deceleration of GDP growth towards 2% in 2018. Thereafter, however, we expect a moderate pick-up in 2019-22 towards 3% on average. There are downside risks to our GDP forecasts, as attempts by the government to engineer a relatively smooth adjustment to a lower-inflation environment could prove extremely challenging, keeping both consumption and investment below potential. There is also some upside risk, however, as investment could take off beyond expectations once the gains from macro-economic adjustment materialise and assuming that efforts to restore confidence in the rule of law make progress. But even in this scenario, in the absence of deeper structural reform than we currently envisage, the potential growth rate will remain closer to 3% than to 4%.

Population growth has slowed in recent decades and is expected to remain below the Latin American average, although it will be outpaced by growth in the labour force in the outlook period. An ageing population will place a heavy demand on healthcare services, which have deteriorated in recent years. The effects of this decline will be lasting, but relatively high skills levels mean that the stock of human capital will, nonetheless, remain a source of compara-tive advantage, although improvements in some other Latin American countries will narrow the gap between Argentina and much of the rest of the region.

Argentina's wealth of natural resources, a large domestic market with high per-head incomes relative to much of the rest of the region, and proximity and preferential access to the large Brazilian market represent attractive long-term opportunities for foreign investors (assuming that the Brazilian economy recovers gradually). However, economic adjustments to rein in inflation will deter investment in the very short term, at least as businesses wait on the sidelines while Mr Macri pushes through the necessary-but politically and socially difficult-adjustments.
Argentina--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2018-30 2031-50 2018-50
Growth and productivity (% change; annual av)
Growth of real GDP per head 2.1 2.2 2.2
Growth of real GDP 3.0 2.8 2.8
Labour productivity growth 1.5 2.2 1.9
Our forecast for annual average GDP growth of 2.8% in 2018-50 assumes that the contribution of capital to growth will be firm in the first part of the forecast period, before tapering off somewhat. We also assume that as growth in the working-age population slows, the increase in the availability of labour will slow, meaning that growth will become more dependent on productivity gains. To the extent that they are achieved, these gains are likely to be made via technology transfer and higher foreign invest-ment. Although Argentina's abundant natural resources and relatively strong skills base represent solid economic potential, the country will struggle to achieve the productivity gains needed to converge with developed-market income levels.

Background: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983, after 50 years of instability and military regimes. Economic liberalisation in the 1990s drove firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and fail-ure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of Fernando de la Rúa's centre-left government. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party) began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanage-ment drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015.
Political structure: A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house); in practice, however, the presidency dominates. The presidential term is four years. There are 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district, each with its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies and the commodity supercycle contributed to GDP growth of an annual average of 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances in the economy in the form of double-digit inflation, real peso appreciation and a deterioration of the balance of payments. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to controls and ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. These policies did not reduce devaluation speculation, and left the economy extremely vulnerable to currency crisis. Macroeconomic adjustments to reduce economic distortions and set the economy on a more solid long-term footing are taking place under Mr Macri; these include peso devaluation in 2015, fiscal and monetary tightening, and, more recently, reforms to boost domestic supply.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at a lower rate of 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. Under a tax reform approved at end-2017, the corporate income tax rate will fall to 30% in 2019 and 25% in 2021. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions (deposits and withdrawals).
Foreign trade: The current account moved from surplus to deficit in 2010. By 2016 the deficit had widened to 2.7% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Present government: The president, Mauricio Macri, took office on December 10th 2015 for a four-year term ending in December 2019. Mr Macri was elected on the ticket of the Cambiemos electoral alliance. This alliance includes Mr Macri's own party, the centre-right Propuesta Repúblicana (Pro), along with the centrist Unión Cívica Radical and the smaller left-wing Coalición Cívica. Mr Macri's party is in a minority both in the Senate (the upper house of Congress) and the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house). Following a good performance in mid-term elections in October 2017, Cambiemos has a plurality of seats in the lower house. In the Senate, various moderate factions of the Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party) hold the largest number of seats, followed by Cambiemos. The government relies on support from moderate Peronists to pass legislation.

Political outlook: Political stability
Argentina has been hit hard by an emerging market sell-off in recent weeks, and although market turbulence is likely to subside, recent developments will have lasting political consequences for the government, which has been obliged to seek an IMF lending agreement to help ease market concerns and end a damaging peso run. The Fund is likely to be supportive of Argentina, and The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect dramatic changes in the course of economic policy, which is already geared towards macroeconomic and microeconomic reforms to restore stability and promote more solid, stable economic growth. The problem for the president, Mauricio Macri, and his ruling centre-right Cambiemos coalition, is that the Fund has a very poor reputation in Argentina, reflecting its role before and after the country's deep economic crisis of 2001-02. Argentina's return to the Fund will, therefore, weigh on the government's approval ratings, and will embolden the opposition, with less than 18 months to go until the presidential election.
The government will be hoping to get its policy agenda back on track in time for the presidential election, when Mr Macri will seek a second term. However, the opposition will be smelling blood and will increasingly obstruct policy. Cambiemos lacks a congressional majority, meaning that the administration has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda on an ad hoc basis with various factions of the Partido Justicialista (PJ, the Peronist party). The PJ, which dominated politics for decades before Mr Macri's election victory in 2015, is struggling to regroup from that defeat and is beset by internal divisions. The party is currently split between a left-wing, populist faction and a centrist faction that, as yet, has no single, clear leader. The PJ's divisions have until now worked in the government's favour, allowing the government to press on with its legislative agenda with the support of moderate Peronists. Moreover, until now Mr Macri has remained relatively popular, with voters giving him the benefit of the doubt on the need for economic adjustment. But patience is wearing thin.
In this environment, the opposition will begin manoeuvring for position ahead of the presidential election, and the government will now struggle to push its agenda through. In the aftermath of its strong performance in the October 2017 mid-terms, the government moved quickly to pass reforms to the tax system, pensions and competition policy (and in May it managed to pass capital market reforms). But in coming months, major reforms will be on hold, and opposition challenges to policy initiatives that are presented will increase. All this means that much-needed reforms to increase the flexibility of labour markets, improve the effective-ness of the judiciary, and enhance investor confidence in institutions and contract rights will be on the back burner. On our current assumption that Mr Macri wins a second term in 2019, we expect that improvements in these areas will start to yield results more clearly late on in our five-year forecast period.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
A concentration of power in the executive helps to speed progress on the government agenda, but results in a lack of transparency in decision making. The trend towards a concentration of power in the executive has occurred ever since the 2001-02 economic crisis, at which point extraordinary powers were given to the president to expedite policymaking. Mr Macri has periodically used decree powers to push through policy measures and political appointments, particularly when Congress is in recess. Like his predecessors, the president also relies on transfers to the provinces to secure the support of powerful regional governors for his agenda. To a significant extent, governors control the voting positions of senators in their provinces.
Although Mr Macri may be more likely to pursue them than his predecessor, reforms that would successfully address longstanding institutional weaknesses and strengthen the bureaucracy will prove politically difficult. The permanent state bureaucracy is made up mainly of low-paid clerical jobs. The professionals responsible for designing and implementing policy are appointed on short-term contracts, which are renewed with each change of government (or even minister).
Reforms to improve the legal system are required
Reforms are required to improve the legal system, which has for decades been plagued by corruption and inefficiency. Under the presidency of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15), the courts resisted pressure to side with the government; the Supreme Court ultimately declared that a legal reform threatening judicial independence was unconstitutional, ensuring that the law (which had been passed by a razor-thin margin in Congress) did not come into effect. The presence of a non-Peronist executive provides some opportunity for a new judicial reform proposal that addresses the problems of corruption and inefficiency in the judiciary (there has been a historic tendency for executive-branch overreach among Peronists). Significantly, upon taking office Mr Macri quickly filled two vacant seats on the Supreme Court with candidates viewed as highly qualified and unbiased. However, we are not optimistic about significant reform measures being taken in the short term, given Mr Macri's minority position in Congress. Without a strengthening of the legal system, it will be difficult to address the problem of corruption in government. A number of investigations into members of the Fernández government are under way, but voters have complained of a lack of convictions.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next presidential election is due in October 2019. Notwithstanding his current difficulties, we still currently assume that Mr Macri will win a second four-year term, based on our assumption of moderate GDP growth and substantial reduction of inflation by then. There are large, and growing, risks to this forecast. Reflecting the difficulties faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist government has won a second consecutive term since the end of the military dictatorship in the 1980s. The emergence of a strong challenger from the Peronist party is therefore likely (though it is as yet unclear who this will be), and the election will be closely fought.
Political outlook: International relations
Reflecting efforts by the Macri government to repair relations with trade and investment partners in the region and elsewhere, and we expect relations with key partners to remain strong. The country took over the rotating presidency of the G20 in December 2017, and is pursuing an agenda centred on the future of jobs, infrastructure and food security. The government is keen to seek trade deals under the auspices of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union). The problem for Argentina and its Mercosur partners is that, just as the grouping has started to reverse its own protectionist tendencies, anti-globalisation sentiment has grown in the OECD. However, Mr Macri is continuing to seek support for an EU-Mercosur trade deal from his counterparts in Europe, and negotiations are continuing. Our forecasts do not currently assume a successful conclusion of free-trade talks with the EU, but there is some upside risk to this forecast.

The Economist Intelligence Unit's global business rankings measure the quality and attractiveness of the investment environment in 82 of the world's largest economies, including 12 in Latin America. Argentina makes a large improve-ment in the overall rankings between the historical (2013-17) and forecast (2018-22) periods. Partly, Argentina's improvement is a legacy of a change of govern-ment at the end of 2015, which saw a change in the policy mix away from expansionary and distortionary macro-economic policies, along with efforts to improve a weak legal and regulatory framework, and promote trade and invest-ment. The president, Mauricio Macri, has made significant strides in rolling back the distortions that characterised the previous administration's tenure, resulting in a noticeable improvement in the investment climate and prompting an improvement in the component scores across virtually every area of the business environment.
Improvement of investment environment under new government
Our forecasts currently assume that there will continue to be improvements in a number of key areas of the business environment, including policy towards private enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, and financing. To Argentina's benefit, it already scores highly in a number of categories in which improvements are generally difficult and take longer to bear fruit, such as infrastructure and market opportunities. The only area in which we expect to see a deterioration (albeit marginal) is the labour market, as it will prove politically very difficult to advance controversial reforms in this area, and labour costs will remain high. We currently expect an improvement in the macroeconomic environment, but acknowledge downside risks to this forecast related to recent volatility.

Business environment outlook: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2020-22: Continued work to build faith in legal and regulatory frameworks. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2018-19: Proactive, welcoming approach to foreign investment. Attempts to resolve outstanding disputes with creditors.
2020-22: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Any remaining foreign-exchange controls are likely to be removed. Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance, comprising Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.
2020-22: Possibility that new free-trade agreements are signed.
Taxes
2018-19: Further gradual reductions of export taxes to encourage domestic supply. Tax reforms to promote investment and reduce tax pressure.
2020-22: Comprehensive tax reform to improve federal-provincial revenue sharing a possibility, but obstacles to reform persist. System remains complex, despite recent reforms.
Financing
2018-19: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2020-22: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2018-19: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of unions remains strong.
2020-22: Limited progress on labour reform. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2018-19: The Macri administration continues to improve contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes.
2020-22: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Quality of e-commerce business environment good. Upgrade of 4G capabilities.
2020-22: More progress on increasing scope of e-government as part of process to reduce red tape. Increase in research and development spending as percentage of GDP, but still relatively low compared with more developed markets.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
