Macroeconomic environment will improve sharply during the forecast period
Despite a forecast improvement in the score for Argentina's macroeconomic environment between the historical and forecast period, the country's global ranking only registers a relatively small improvement (remaining one of the weakest among the 82 countries covered in the business environment ranking-BER-model), while the regional ranking remains unchanged (Argentina places 11th, ahead of only Venezuela). The macro-economic environ-ment is forecast to improve during 2018-22, but, by regional and economic comparison, distortions, in the form of high inflation, relatively low reserves coverage ratios, and a large current-account deficit, will remain high. Indeed, of all of the areas covered by our BER model, Argentina's ranking in this category is the worst.
The main area of the macroeconomic environment that registers a notable improvement in the forecast period is the quality of policymaking, as Mr Macri's policy stance is much more investor-friendly than that of his predecessor, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15). However, progress in addressing the distortions put in place by Ms Fernández is proving gradual, with the consequences of still-high levels of inflation and a still-large fiscal deficit taking their toll on the macroeconomy (as well as on the business environment more broadly). Although we do expect progress over the course of 2018-22, with fiscal tightening helping to reduce the deficit, disinflation taking hold and the external position becoming more sustainable, the pace of improvement will be relatively gradual. This will not only hamper medium-term growth potential, but will also sustain the economy's vulnerability to a deterioration in external or domestic conditions.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.5 6.3 57 43 9 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The economy will benefit from the return to a market-friendly policy stance
Argentina's score and ranking for private enterprise and competition improves substantially for the 2018-22 forecast period under our assumption that the Macri government will continue to introduce measures that actively encourage private investment and promote competition. The Fernández government had a track record of arbitrary decision-making that was often detrimental to the private sector, eroding confidence in the legal framework, hampering the freedom of businesses to compete and giving rise to allegations of crony capitalism. During the forecast period, we expect a revamped competition commission to focus on more rapid and thorough enforcement of antitrust violations. Across the public sector, a reduction in red tape is likely; legislation reducing red tape for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) was approved in 2017. The government will also remain committed to scaling back price controls and subsidies, although it may be forced to make significant concessions to cushion the impact on consumers of what are significant adjustments. Although these efforts will be hampered by lobbying by special interest groups in the context of Argentina's long tradition of political clientelism, we expect significant improvements in all of these areas. That said, state participation in key sectors, including energy, utilities and banking, is expected to continue.
Under Ms Fernández, the Comisión Nacional de Defensa de la Competencia (CNDC, the competition authority) was a weak and ineffective body, doing little to prevent monopolistic practices or protect consumer rights. This is changing under Mr Macri. He appointed a new head of the CNDC in February 2016, Esteban Greco, who focused immediately on crafting a reform to the existing competition legislation. The reform, which was passed in December 2017, transforms the CNDC into an independent body (the Autoridad Nacional de la Competencia), tightens penalties for companies found guilty of competition-related offences, improves controls on mergers and acquisitions, and creates an under-secretariat responsible for investigation, training and education. Closer co-operation with US competition authorities to train staff on mergers and acquisitions will also raise standards in this area.
Agricultural export taxes and quotas are continuing to be scaled back. Immediately upon taking office, Mr Macri eliminated export taxes on wheat, beef and corn. He also reduced the tax on soybeans-the most important export crop-from 35% to 30% in early 2016. From January 2018 the tax has been cut by half a percentage point per month, a process that will continue until December 2019, when the tax will have fallen to 18%. There has been local pressure for the government to accelerate this process, in order to help producers who are struggling with the effects of a recent severe drought, but we expect the cuts to continue as scheduled.
The process of scaling back price controls on consumer goods will progress very slowly in the short term. Upon taking office, the government kept a price control programme, Precios Cuidados, in place, as it sought to curb the pass-through effect on inflation of currency devaluation, but it reduced the number of basic consumer items covered from 500 to 317. But since then a number of new products has been added to the list, with 436 products now covered, in response to rising inflation. Renewed efforts to reduce price controls on consumer goods are unlikely until inflation begins to subside.
There has been more progress on efforts to scale back government energy subsidies by raising electricity and natural gas tariffs. After taking office, the government introduced hefty price increases for end-users, with gas bills quadrupling for most consumers and electricity bills rising by around six-fold, despite considerable domestic opposition. In January 2017 the government announced new increases to utility rates in the Buenos Aires metropolitan area of 60-148%. This was followed by further hefty increases in December 2017, with electricity bills rising by an average 44% and natural gas tariffs by an average of 45% nationwide; similar increases were also introduced in April 2018. In total, utility rates have risen around fivefold since 2015 (from an extremely low base). Even with the increases, the government will still be shouldering a sizeable fiscal burden in terms of gas and utility subsidies. The authorities are aiming to scale back subsidies during the remainder of 2018 and 2019, with the aim of aligning domestic rates with market rates by the end of 2019. However, the continued rise in rates is generating significant public opposition, and there is a risk that this timetable may slip if inflation continues to rise in the short term. However, we believe that the government will remain committed to realigning utility tariffs. Measures to cushion the impact on low-income households are more likely than an abandonment or delay in the planned increase in rates.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.6 6.9 69 46 9 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Foreign investment to pick up
Argentina's score and ranking for policy towards foreign investment improve significantly between the historical and forecast period. This reflects Mr Macri's much more welcoming stance towards foreign capital and his efforts to make government policy towards foreign investment more transparent, clear and predictable. Progress on lifting energy tariffs will make foreign participation more attractive, while the sovereign's exit from default in April 2017 lifts a major constraint on foreign investment by reopening access to investment protection schemes (a key factor driving the increase in Argentina's score in this category for 2018-22). The government's more market-friendly approach means that the risk of expropriations is much lower, and government favouritism of domestic firms will be less marked. However, aside from occasional sales of some state-owned assets, we expect outright privatisation to remain off the agenda. The public still places much of the blame for the 2001-02 crisis on the privatisation process of the 1990s, in which foreign firms featured heavily.
Argentina's exit from default has facilitated access to capital markets, but the government's ambitious plans for infrastructure and housing development will still necessitate foreign participation in the context of fiscal expenditure constraints. With this in mind, a bill establishing a public-private partnership (PPP) framework for investment was signed into law in December 2016. Official estimates that it could raise potential capital inflows by US$90bn are likely to prove extremely optimistic, but the legislation will boost foreign participation in the country's infrastructure drive. Since the PPP investment framework became law, around 60 projects have been identified, with more realistic assessments of the additional investment standing at around 1% of GDP per year (around US$6.5bn) over 2018-21.
Energy policy reforms to liberalise tariffs and promote investment are likely to boost multinational interest in deals to commercialise Argentina's vast shale oil and gas reserves (the world's second-largest), particularly now that international energy prices have risen moderately from the 2015-16 lows. The Fernández government expropriated oil producer YPF in 2012 and paid heavy subsidies to suppress domestic petrol prices, with investment falling sharply as a result. Since then, the official policy stance has changed and YPF has signed a series of exploration and production (E&P) contracts with private-sector companies to develop the Vaca Muerta shale deposits in Neuquén province. The development of Vaca Muerta has been progressing slowly, because of the vast scale of the investment needed and the lack of local infrastructure, so the government is seeking to boost investment in the energy sector by developing other areas, offering significant deepwater exploration contracts in the Austral (5,000 sq km), Western Malvinas (90,000 sq km) and North Argentina (130,000 sq km) basins. The last two are generally unexplored, while the Austral Basin is known largely as an offshore gas play. It is expected that there will be at least two licensing rounds. For the first, bids will be submitted in November, with the results announced in December.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.2 6.9 73 60 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
An easing of controls is well under way
Mr Macri's rapid moves to dismantle currency controls upon taking office are the main factor driving the improvement in Argentina's score and ranking in this area. Rather than a steady and gradual process, the government opted for an immediate lifting of controls and simultaneous devaluation of the peso, on the basis that this would provide clarity, transparency and a strong signal of the government's commitment to change. Most export duties were removed and the requirement for official authorisation from the tax bureau for all US dollar purchases and profit remittances was lifted. The peso has weakened considerably since then, and although the pace of depreciation has been relatively steady, there have been several periods of rapid depreciation (most recently in December 2017 and again in May 2018). However, the monetary authorities have responded with conventional tools (including sharp interest rate rises) rather than the re-imposition of new controls, which we believe is highly unlikely under the current government.
After 19 years of on-off negotiations, the prospect of a free trade agreement (FTA) between the EU and Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay-Venezuela is suspended) is growing. There have been three negotiating rounds between the EU and Mercosur so far in 2018 (in February, March and April), with officials hinting that the two sides are close to reaching a deal. There now seems to be a greater consensus on several significant obstacles that have long hampered talks-including treatment of agricultural products-and the Brazilian president, Michel Temer, has implied that the only remaining major issue to be resolved between the two sides is the treatment of trade in automobiles. Our economic forecasts do not currently assume that the FTA will be signed and implemented within the forecast period, but there is some upside risk to this assumption. Meanwhile, Mr Macri is also likely to continue to focus on expanding relations with the Pacific Alliance, a trade bloc comprising Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.1 6.1 80 52 12 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Tax reform is likely to fundamentally address long-running deficiencies
The tax system is one of the areas of the business environment in which Argentina registers the most significant improvements between the historical and forecast periods, shifting from the worst-ranked in the Latin America region to among the best. The approval of a comprehensive tax reform bill in December 2017 is the main factor explaining the improvement. During the historical period, Argentina's score in this area was dragged down by a high level of corporate tax (35%-one of the highest in the region), significant complexity (over 35 different types of tax were collected), as well as a series of distortionary taxes (including agricultural export taxes, a financial transactions tax and a gross turnover tax). The tax reform addresses many of these long-running weaknesses; we expect that it will help to create a more equitable and efficient tax system that supports investment and encourages formal employment.
The tax reform was designed to boost investment. The corporate income tax rate will be reduced from 35% to 25% over a five-year period, as long as profits are reinvested (if they are not, a 10% tax on distribution of dividends will be applied). The reform has also set a tax-free threshold for payroll tax in order to encourage formal-sector employment, also introduced gradually over the course of 2018-22. The counterpart of these tax cuts is an increase in some consumption taxes (including adjustments to excise taxes to make them more progressive) and the introduction of a new capital gains tax. The latter is set at a rate of 15% for dollar-denominated financial assets and inflation-linked assets, and falls to 5% for non-inflation-linked, peso-denominated financial assets. Financial assets include corporate and public bonds, central bank notes (Lebacs), and banks' long-term deposits. There will be a tax-free threshold of Ps52,000 (US$3,000). The government has opted to maintain the financial transactions tax (which it had initially wanted to phase out) until 2022, partly to compensate for lost revenue.
Improvements to the system of revenue-sharing with the provinces are also expected in 2018-22. Along with tax reform and the budget, Congress also passed a provincial fiscal responsibility law and so-called provincial "fiscal pact". Together, the measures will secure the commitment of the provinces to restraint in spending and tax pressure, and to the reduction of distortionary taxes. It will also put an end to lawsuits by the provinces related to the transfers of federal government revenue and lays out a series of changes to this system of transfers, called "co-participation", a reform that was attractive to provincial governors and the legislators that are influenced by them.
The Macri government has passed several tax measures to improve conditions for SMEs that have been particularly badly hit by deteriorating economic conditions. Since the start of 2017, SMEs have been exempt from the minimum notional income tax levied on companies' assets. This tax accounts for a very small share of total tax revenue (well under 1%), but is burdensome for SMEs (particularly for manufacturing companies who generally have more assets in the form of equipment than service providers), as it must be paid even in the event of losses. In addition, SMEs are now able to offset bank debit and credit tax against income tax. SMEs are also able to pay value-added tax (VAT) on sales every three months rather than monthly, which will assist with cashflow. Finally, to encourage investment, the law offsets up to 10% of new investment in capital goods and infrastructure against income tax.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.0 7.0 72 32 8 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Argentina's score and ranking for financing improve the most significantly of all the areas of the business environment between the historical and the forecast period. For the most part, this reflects the huge constraints to finance in place in much of the historical period, which resulted from continued sovereign default. Argentina's deal with holdout creditors and exit from default in 2016 has paved the way for much-improved access to external credit for corporate borrowers. At the same time, a combination of financial sector reforms and a gradual move towards macroeconomic stability should help to develop the availability of long-term finance domestically. That said, large foreign companies will meet much of their financing needs through external sources. Banking sector regulation and supervision are expected to improve, while financial soundness and profitability indicators will remain solid. However, some weaknesses in the system will persist: notwithstanding an improvement, financial markets will remain relatively shallow by comparison with similarly ranked peers, as will levels of banking penetration.
Argentina's particularly weak score and ranking in the historical period is explained by several factors. Apart from the fact that the sovereign remained in default, these included the nationalisation of private pension funds in 2008, which was a serious blow to the funds' growth and had a lasting impact in the following years. Argentina's private pension-fund administrators were the country's most important institutional investors and were a growing source of finance in the local capital markets. The Administración Nacional de Seguridad Social (Anses, the social security agency, which took over the nationalised pension fund assets) was able to allocate up to 50% of assets in local private companies' shares and up to 10% of assets in foreign government securities.
A capital markets reform passed in May 2018 is likely to improve financing conditions in two main ways: by facilitating access to credit for SMEs and by boosting the mortgage market. A new electronic credit invoice system will improve access to credit and also improve the risk rating of SMEs that supply big companies. The reform also establishes the conditions for the creation of a market to securitise mortgage loans, a development that will require increased supervision, particularly of inflation-indexed mortgages.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.2 5.1 57 70 6 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Labour market reforms are unlikely
The labour market is the only area of the business environment in which we expect a deterioration (albeit marginal) between the historical and forecast periods, with Argentina's regional ranking also slipping by two places and the global ranking falling by 13 places. The labour force is well-educated, productive and flexible. But labour costs are high by international comparison, and this issue will be resolved only slowly over the forecast period as the peso appreciation of the past decade (in real terms) is gradually unwound. At the same time, we do not expect substantial progress on labour market reform or in addressing a highly unionised labour market that produces a high incidence of strikes. In the short term, difficult economic adjustments that are contributing to a decline in real wages and a cut in purchasing power will translate into a continued high level of strikes, particularly as the government continues to rein in wage increases against the backdrop of still-high levels of inflation.
The passage of comprehensive labour reform is unlikely during 2018-22, given the recent deterioration in relations between the government and organised labour. Mr Macri has effectively shelved plans for a broad-based reform bill, instead choosing to focus on only one aspect-an amnesty for employers who register informal workers. The government is likely to submit a bill to encourage labour formalisation by forgiving fines due by employers for having informal workers, as long as they have formalised the employees' contracts. However, even by the government's estimates, the measure would be likely to lead to the incorporation of only around 200,000 of the country's 4.5m informal workers into formal labour markets (and potentially far fewer). As such, these measures are unlikely to boost Argentina's score in this area over the course of the forecast period.
Skills shortages and mismatches have become more of a problem for business in the past decade, compounded by a lack of effective training pro-grammes in both the public and private sectors. Secondary and tertiary enrolment are very high by regional standards, but educational outcomes are not as strong as would be expected given high enrolment rates, and vary widely by province. At the same time, access to job training tends to be unequal and informal. We do not expect any significant improvement in these areas during the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.8 5.0 58 57 7 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
More private investment will help to upgrade infrastructure
Argentina's score for infrastructure remains relatively unchanged between the historical and forecast periods, as does the country's global ranking, although its regional ranking improves markedly as other Latin American countries register notable deteriorations. The country boasts a well-developed telecommuni-cations network, as well as relatively low property rental costs. However, physical infrastructure has suffered over the past decade from a lack of investment. We currently assume that Argentina's exit from default, the passage of PPP legislation and improvements in contract rights will help to boost investment both in transport infrastructure and energy. However, such projects will take time to come on stream, explaining the fact that Argentina's score improves only modestly in 2018-22, and raising the risk that infrastructure bottlenecks will continue to hamper growth in the meantime.
The risk of energy shortages will persist in the short term at least, given long project completion times. Demand for electricity and gas has soared in the past decade, but as tariffs for residential and business consumers are lifted, demand growth is expected to slow. Argentina reached a final agreement with China in October 2017 to construct a fourth and fifth nuclear reactor in Argentina, with construction expected to begin in the second half of 2018. Aside from this, prospects are less certain. Despite Argentina's vast hydroelectric potential, no further large projects are under way. The government has undertaken auctions in the renewable sector since early 2017, under its RenovAR project, and is preparing an offshore energy auction in the conventional sector (scheduled for November 2018), but successful bids are unlikely to translate into new capacity until late in the forecast period (or even after). In the short term at least, the lack of new energy capacity coming on stream will maintain dependence on imports, and increase exposure to weather-related problems at existing hydropower facilities.
Although the mobile telecoms market has matured in recent years, there remains significant room for development in the quality and scope of mobile-telecoms services. Although substantial investments have been announced by telecoms companies, whether these materialise (thus resulting in noticeable improvements during the forecast period) will partly depend on the ability of the government to draft and pass a new communications law to improve competition and operating conditions. Despite the fact that the government is likely to encounter resistance to some of its reform proposals in other areas, telecoms reform is less controversial, and we expect progress on this issue during the forecast period. Broadband penetration is the highest in Latin America, owing to high per-head income and strong competition, which has kept subscription fees low and the quality of service high. 4G coverage, at just over 70%, is among the highest in the region.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.8 6.9 42 34 2 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption.
Argentina registers one of its highest scores in this area of the business environment, and although it is only mid-ranked by global comparison, it is the strongest ranked in Latin America during the forecast period. High levels of mobile subscriptions and broadband penetration underpin the score, given that they are critical to driving broader technological developments including mobile apps and cloud computing, which in turn helps to drive economic growth across a variety of sectors and facilitate an increase in productivity. However, regulation and governance remain relative weak points (and are what distinguishes Argentina from higher-ranked global peers), while the backdrop of a highly distorted macroeconomic policy environment has prevented signifi-cant private investment, which has hampered research and development and the number of patent applications.
The process for applying for a patent in Argentina has traditionally been a long one, with complex procedures and administrative deficiencies contributing to large backlogs in the Instituto Nacional de la Propiedad Industrial (INPI, the national institute of industrial property). However, an agreement signed between the European Patent Office (EPO) and the INPI in February 2018 is likely to facilitate the granting of patents during the forecast period. Similar agreements that already exist between the EPO and Mexico, Chile, Colombia and Brazil have made the application process simpler and quicker, resulting in an increase in successful patent applications. Alongside collaboration with the EPO, Argentina has agreed a "Patent Prosecution Highway" with the US Patent and Trademark Office that similarly aims to expedite the review of patent applications. Argentina is also focusing on other measures, including fast-tracking applications that have already received approval in other countries, taking on more specialist staff at INPI and digitalising internal processes, in an attempt to boost efficiency.
The e-commerce environment is expected to remain strong. Online retail was quicker to develop in Argentina than in many other countries in the region, supported by an early and rapid take-up of mobile broadband. According to the Cámara Argentina de Comercio Electrónico, the e-commerce chamber, purchases via the internet grew by 52% in value terms in 2017 (a similar growth rate to 2016), reaching Ps156.3bn (US$7.8bn). Online and mobile banking is already popular and is used to conduct routine transactions, aided by well-developed mobile banking services and a modern payments system that meets international standards. Logistics is somewhat weaker, with most delivery companies failing to deliver as rapidly as in similarly ranked countries. This reflects a legacy of weak investment in physical infrastructure, which has hampered the quality of the road network and led to some port delays.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Currency depreciation pressure amid an emerging market sell-off has intro-duced substantial political uncertainty, but we assume that major changes to economic policymaking will not take place under an IMF lending arrangement, barring a more rapid tightening of fiscal policy. The govern-ment has made progress since it came to office at the end of 2015 and began grappling with the task of restoring macroeconomic stability while improving conditions for busi-ness. But macroeconomic adjustment is clearly incomplete: inflation came in at 25.4% in March, amid continued utilities tariff rises (intended to reduce the fiscal burden of subsidies and promote investment by bringing utilities prices towards market rates), and the fiscal deficit remains substantial, at 6% of GDP in 2017.
Still-high inflation has contributed to currency over-valuation, which has in turn produced a large and growing current-account deficit. These imbalances have contributed to the sharp peso adjustment of recent weeks, and to the government's decision to seek an IMF lending deal (which the government asserts that it will treat as precautionary) to restore market confidence. An IMF stand-by arrangement (SBA) will come with conditionality, but in public comments and in its executive board assessment undertaken during Article IV consultations, the Fund has been supportive of the Macri government's policy framework, and The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect dramatic changes, although tougher, frontloaded fiscal targets do seem likely.
As under our previous assumptions, we expect that fiscal tightening, combined with a winding-down of utilities tariff adjustments and relatively tight control of nominal wage rises, will gradually reduce inflation and engender macro-economic stability over time. This will have positive implications for the external sector and growth. The biggest risks to this outlook are political, and reflect the possibility that voter (as well as business) confidence in the Macri admin-istration and the economic outlook feeds into further market volatility and economic activity. This would not only complicate the adjustment process, but also threaten our assumption of that Mr Macri will secure a second term in power, raising questions as to the future direction of economic policy under a new government.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy

Budget balance -6.0 -5.0 -4.0 -3.2 -2.9 -2.6
Government debt 56.5 56.6 56.3 55.5 54.8 53.8
The government has pursued gradual fiscal tightening (so as not to thwart economic growth) but is under increasing pressure to accelerate the pace of the adjustment. In early May, amid a peso rout, the Treasury revised its primary deficit target for 2018 to 2.7% of GDP, down from 3.2% previously. Bearing in mind that the government beat its fiscal target for the first quarter of 2018 by a substantial margin, this target should not be difficult to meet, although it will require cuts to planned capital spending, which will have a knock-on impact on economic growth. Apart from capital spending, expenditure restraint will come via a phasing out of costly energy subsidies and the recent approval of a social security reform that will produce substantial savings (0.4% of GDP per year from 2018). The biggest risks to meeting the fiscal target this year centre on the government's ability to maintain public-sector wage restraint amid above-target inflation and strong public-sector union power, as well as below-target revenue, reflecting an expected deceleration of economic activity this year.

With negotiations on a formal lending arrangement with the IMF ongoing, we have made a tentative, moderate revision to our forecasts for the reduction of the primary deficit in coming years. We now expect a move back into fiscal surplus to happen slightly quicker than under the government's current plans. Capital spending is already very low as a percentage of GDP, providing increas-ingly limited room for cuts. As such, further savings will need to be made from current spending, including wages and transfers; these will be politically diffi-cult-and potentially unsustainable. On this basis, we do not expect an IMF deal to include any sharp fiscal shock; however, there is some risk to the assumption that the IMF will endorse the government's gradual adjustment policies.
The government is facing a problem with liquidity rather than solvency. Bearing in mind that a majority of the sovereign's financing needs for this year are already met, and assuming that market access improves after the latest sell-off, financing the moderate public debt ratio (which we expect to come in at 58% of GDP this year) should still be manageable. That said, unless Argentina receives and decides to draw down on IMF funds, financing costs will rise, with knock-on implications for debt interest payments and the overall fiscal deficit, which will narrow more slowly than the primary deficit.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022
Prime lending rate (av) 26.6 29.6 20.6 14.8 12.3 11.3
Deposit rate (av) 19.0 21.6 12.6 6.7 4.7 4.2
The Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the central bank) has tight-ened monetary policy sharply to help stem a peso rout in early May, and will unwind its rate rises only slowly. In the space of little over a week, the bank raised the policy rate by 1,275 basis points, to 40% on May 3rd. Further currency depreciation is possible in coming days, and further rate rises remain a risk (although for now we expect rates to stay on hold). Recent sharp policy tightening will eventually restore some calm, allowing the central bank to begin to unwind its dramatic rate rise over the next few months. This process will be complicated, however, by weak confidence in the nascent inflation-targeting regime, which means that inflation expectations are not well anchored and pass through from currency depreciation into consumer prices is relatively high.
Weak confidence in the inflation target reflects several factors, but important among them is the government's own strategic error of relaxing the 2018 inflation target at the end of 2017. The government states that this change was geared at making the inflation target more realistic. It may also have been keen to address peso overvaluation by encouraging an interest-rate cut. But efforts to engineer currency depreciation this way have been anything but smooth, partly because resultant perceptions of discord between the government and the central bank have damaged domestic confidence in the government's commitment to fighting inflation.
The BCRA has been clear in its view that current price pressures are temporary, and we share this view. But in the meantime, the latest rapid slide in the currency will feed through to a spike in prices in May-June that will leave the year-end inflation target of 15% well out of reach (inflation was 25.4% in March). We do still expect monthly inflation to start to ease towards 1% on a con-sistent basis later in 2018, once the effects of currency depreciation and tariff adjustment start to fade. This should allow for gradual monetary easing, taking the nominal policy rate to slightly above 25% by year-end. Our forecasts thereafter assume moderately positive real interest rates in the medium term.

A spike in interest rates and a tightening of fiscal policy (to include real cuts in capital spending) amid currency pressures will weigh on economic activity. We have revised our forecast for real GDP growth in 2018 to 2.3%, down from 2.7% previously. Although the latest data suggest that growth remained firm in the first quarter of the year, activity will be dampened later this year, not just by tighter macroeconomic policy, but also by the effects of a severe drought, which will hit the harvest of two key crops, soya and maize. Agriculture accounts for a fairly hefty 11% of GDP, and agro-industry is also important to the economy.
For now, our view of GDP growth beyond 2018 remains broadly unchanged, although the risks to our forecasts have risen substantially. Under our benign baseline forecast, we expect growth to fluctuate around 3% 2019-22, dipping in 2020 amid a projected cyclical downturn in the US, before accelerating back above 3% in 2021-22. This projected acceleration rests on the assumption that that implementation of recently passed and ongoing structural reforms will gradually boost economic activity. There is increasing downside risk to this assumption, in the form of a weakening of consumer and business confidence, and the potential for a much more tense presidential election period in 2019.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
A severe drought will hit the soybean crop badly this year and lead to a contraction in agricultural production. But notwithstanding the poor 2018 outturn, agriculture will continue to be a key contributor to the Argentinian economy. Although it has accounted for around 10% of GDP over the past decade, and for around 20% of private employment, these figures underesti-mate its contribution, as they do not include agro-industry. Weak soft commodity prices relative to the boom years of the commodities supercycle will have some dampening impact on agriculture; however, we believe that a more important factor in the sector's growth prospects will be the easing of export taxes and quotas by the Macri administration. This follows a period of ever-tightening controls implemented by the administration of the former president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15), to keep domestic prices low, which ultimately restricted profitability and hence output. A more stable, clear and attractive environment for agriculture producers will boost output. It will also support agro-industry (including the processing of Argentina's key crop, soybean) and bolster a manufacturing sector that is currently struggling amid still-weak demand both at home and in Brazil. We expect a mild economic recovery in Brazil in 2018-22, which will also help to produce a moderate pick-up in Argentinian manufacturing in 2018-22.
Better incentives should boost key sectors
Mining and energy are two sectors with great potential. Argentina has vast shale and gas resources, but, to date, commercialising them has proven difficult, particularly in the wake of the nationalisation of the country's largest energy company, YPF, in 2012. The Macri administration has started to tackle some of the main problems constraining investment, which, apart from a lack of confidence in the rule of law, include price controls that keep gas prices well below the international market price. In 2017 the government announced a series of measures to boost investment and domestic production, thereby reducing reliance on imports. The measures include the "flexibilisation" of labour conditions in Vaca Muerta, a 30,000-sq-km oil field located in southern Argentina that is the world's second-largest shale gas reservoir and fourth-largest shale oil reservoir. The government is also hoping to eliminate price distortions gradually, but will retain high gas prices as an incentive to investment in the medium term. In exchange, oil companies including YPF, Total (France), Pan American Energy (Argentina), Chevron (US), Shell (UK/Netherlands) and Dow (US) have agreed to invest US$5bn in Vaca Muerta in 2017. These increases in investment should see exploration and production activity in the sector rise steadily this year and in the remainder of the forecast period.
The mining sector also has substantial potential. It shares the mineral-rich southern Andes mountains with Chile, long recognised as one of the world's mining powerhouses. But mining has been slow to develop in Argentina relative to its potential, partly because international companies are put off by a patchwork of different provincial taxes and regulations, some of them restrictive; for example, various provinces ban open-cast mining. In an effort to boost investment in the sector, the federal government persuaded most provinces to agree in June 2017 to harmonise regulations, with provincial mining royalties capped at 3%. Under the deal, there will be a separate 1.5% levy for provincial infrastructure funds. At the signing ceremony Mr Macri said that mining was a "pillar of job creation" capable of creating 125,000 new jobs, and made clear that the government's position that it is possible to develop the industry and employment while protecting the environment. The government's aim is to more than double total mining investment to US$25bn over the next eight years, up from US$10bn in 2007-15.
There are reasons for optimism-not least because of growing interest in Argentina's lithium deposits at a time when global demand for the metal is rising, owing to its use in a new generation of batteries. But both mining companies and environmental groups have approached the new code with some caution, saying that there has been little consultation on it, and noting that it will need legislative approval at both federal and provincial level, a potentially lengthy process.
While noting the benefit of harmonised regulations, mining companies are particularly wary of the tax burden, on the basis that provinces currently charging lower royalties may use the new code as an excuse to raise them up to the 3% ceiling (although government officials have claimed that there will be no changes in royalties on existing mines). Mining companies have also complained that a change in the taxable base from the total "pithead" value (before transport or transformation) to total gross sales would imply an increase in the tax burden. Despite these reservations, we believe that the new code is a positive signal for a neglected industry, and, along with rising metals prices, it will help to attract additional investment inflows and boost the sector's growth in the medium term.

The reduction of inflation will continue to be complicated in the short term by gradual increases in utilities tariffs as these are brought closer in line with market prices. On top of this, rapid recent peso depreciation, in a context of unanchored inflation expectations, will produce substantial pass-through effects, keeping inflation high in the very short term. However, assuming that macroeconomic policy remains tight (particularly under the auspices of an IMF deal), domestic demand remains subdued relative to the boom years of 2004-11, and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environment for agricultural and other producers, we continue to expect gradual disinflation in the medium term. It will take quite some time, however, for inflation to fall to single-digit levels. According to our baseline forecast, this will happen towards the end of 2020.

The peso has been badly hit by a sell-off in recent weeks as investors that had previously given the administration the benefit of the doubt over its ability to reverse macroeconomic imbalances zeroed in on the country's large fiscal and current-account deficits. The latter reflects the fact that the peso is clearly overvalued, a problem that worsened last year as huge inflows of portfolio capital produced real currency appreciation. As a result, at end-2017 the real effective exchange rate was 14% stronger than the average of the previous 20 years. We believe that co-ordinated efforts by the government and the central bank to regain the confidence of investors-by tightening monetary policy sharply, revising the fiscal target and seeking the formal backing of the IMF-will be successful in preventing an uncontrolled devaluation of the peso in coming weeks. However, volatility will remain likely at least in the short term. We expect the peso to continue to depreciate in both nominal and real terms, in a development that will begin to address the problem of currency overvaluation. Under our baseline forecast, the currency will depreciate to Ps26.99:US$1 at end-2018 and Ps35.9:US$1 at end-2022. There remains a high risk, however, of much sharper currency weakening in coming months.

More front-loaded currency weakening than previously projected will provide some boost to external competitiveness, but even so, in 2018 the current-account deficit will remain large, with most of the boost to net exports of goods and services becoming evident from 2019. Even in 2022 we expect the current-account deficit to remain substantial, at 3.2% of GDP. After a period of huge inflows of portfolio capital in 2016-17, access to finance will be trickier and more costly in 2018-19; meanwhile, inflows of foreign direct investment will average an unspectacular 2.1% of GDP in 2018-22. This will be reflected in import cover, which recovered from a low of just four months to 7.6 months in 2017, but will dip back to seven months in 2018-22, even assuming that reserves recover slightly in the rest of 2018 from their current lows of around US$54bn in mid-May. Reserves are now almost US$10bn below the record high of US$64bn registered in January this year (this followed a large global bond issue).

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Argentina
Stocks and flows
The inward foreign direct investment (FDI) stock was US$77bn (12% of GDP) in 2017 and the outward stock of FDI was US$41bn (6% of GDP). Inflows of FDI to Argentina have been volatile in recent decades and have followed economic cycles of boom and bust. In the 1990s inflows to Argentina increased substantially, reaching 3.7% of GDP in the second half of the decade, reflecting a privatisation programme and acquisitions of domestic private firms. This was followed by a collapse in inward FDI to 1.4% of GDP in 2001-03, reflecting Argentina's default on its foreign debt in 2001 and a subsequent deep recession. Devaluation stimulated a rapid recovery of inward FDI in subsequent years, with inflows averaging 3.7% of GDP in 2003-08. Since then, however, FDI inflows have weakened, from 3% of GDP in 2008 to an annual average 1.8% of GDP in 2009-15. Since Mauricio Macri became president in December 2015, the government has worked to address concerns about the strength and predictability of the legal and regulatory environment. For now, however, inward FDI remains subdued (at 1.9% of GDP in 2017), amid investor concerns over the long-term sustainability of recent improvements to contract rights and rule of law.
Origin and distribution
US firms account for a quarter of the stock of FDI, followed by Spanish firms (16%), and Dutch firms (11%). Chilean, Brazilian and Uruguayan companies account for around 5% each. Spanish firms have invested in privatised utilities, banking and energy. European firms in the utilities and banking sectors were hit hard by the 2001-02 crisis. As many companies disinvested after the crisis, firms from Brazil, Mexico and Chile bought up cheap assets. In 2015 the largest foreign direct investor in Argentina, by some distance, was the US, followed by Spain. The potential for an influx of Chinese FDI, focused in particular in agri-business, is substantial. However, the latest local-source data on FDI inflows into Argentina by country show that, in 2016, only 2% of FDI flows came from China (with the main flows of FDI coming again from the US and the EU, particularly Spain).
Determinants
FDI into Argentina is quite broadly spread; oil accounts for 20% of the stock, followed by chemicals, the automotive sector, metal minerals, the financial sector and telecommunications, although in the past decade almost half of FDI inflows have gone into manufacturing. Historically, Argentina has attracted investors hoping to take advantage of a relatively affluent and protected domestic market. During the 1990s, and as a result of rapid trade liberalisation, domestic market-seeking investment focused on sectors that showed comparative (or even absolute) advantages or were naturally protected from foreign competition (non-tradeable services, such as utilities). Efficiency-seeking investments have been less common, and have been mainly limited to the automotive industry, where government incentives have been in place for over a decade. Recent FDI in services (including information technology-IT) has been attracted by Argentina's skilled workforce and relatively low wages.
Impact
The presence of foreign subsidiaries has brought positive spillovers (both within and across industries) in manufacturing, but only in sectors where domestic firms have proven sufficiently adaptable. In other cases, increased competition from foreign investors, or a preference on the part of the latter for foreign suppliers, has damaged local firms. Telecoms is one example of a sector where the quality of service and technology has been transformed by foreign investment. Foreign investors own most of the privatised utilities. After the 2001-02 maxi-devaluation, which in effect broke the terms of foreign investors' contracts (and after the government declined to renegotiate), investment declined. The contribution of foreign firms to local research and development activities has been limited, as technical progress has been mainly embodied by imported capital goods and turnkey plants. Foreign firms account for a large share of Argentina's exports.
Potential
The major attractions for FDI will be a growing and relatively high-income domestic market, strong natural-resource endowments and, to a lesser extent, Argentina's potential as a manufacturing base. A relatively large pool of skilled human capital and a large stock of natural resources constitute Argentina's long-term advantages. Argentina's exit from default in 2016 will also act as a spur to FDI inflows, by facilitating investor access to investment guarantees and trade finance, which has until recently been lacking.

Population growth will remain slow
Population growth has slowed in recent decades and is expected to remain below the Latin American average. Owing to a relatively low birth rate, the percentage of the population aged 14 or under is low by Latin American standards, and is falling. A declining gross birth rate and longer life expectancy also account for the high and rising share of the population aged 65 years and over, although, at just over 11%, this is still below that of OECD countries, where shares above 15% are the norm. Even so, the ageing population places increasing demand on Argentina's healthcare services, which have deteriorated signifi-cantly in recent years.
The forecast rise in the economically active portion of the population is chiefly the result of an expected increase in the female participation rate. The latter was 55% of the working-age female population in 2017, up from 51% in 1990 but still below a total labour force participation rate of 68% (and below the OECD average female participation rate of 63%), and can be expected to rise in the forecast period. Although the gross birth rate is forecast to fall over the next decade, the gross mortality rate is expected to stay broadly constant as the ageing of the population offsets improvements in healthcare conditions. Argentina has in the past been the recipient of much inward migration (an estimated 85% of the population is of European descent) and has established quite a flexible approach to immigration. Although outward migration from countries such as Venezuela and Haiti in recent years has caused some political tension in other countries in Latin America, such as neighbouring Chile, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Argentina's policy in this area to remain relatively flexible in the forecast period, enabling economic sectors such as agriculture and construction to continue to benefit from immigrant labour. Our positive medium-term economic forecasts for Argentina suggest that inward migration could pick up in the forecast period, following a period of substantial outward migration in recent decades. Partly owing to strong ties to Europe, 600,000 Argentinians are estimated to live abroad. Around one-third of these emigrated in the years immediately follow-ing the 2001-02 economic crisis. These newer emigrants are mainly middle-class young people who have moved to Spain, Italy and the US, many of whom benefit from dual Italian or Spanish citizenship.
An urban population with marked regional disparities
The population is highly urbanised. More than 90% of the country's population is concentrated in urban centres-one of the highest ratios in the world. The Buenos Aires metropolitan area contains almost one-third of the national population; when the hinterland of Buenos Aires (the pampas) is included, the proportion rises to two-thirds. Overall, population density is low, at 13 inhabitants per sq km (around one-third of the Latin American average), although this aggregate figure masks wide regional disparities: in the capital there are 13,679 inhabitants per sq km, whereas in the southern provinces of Santa Cruz and Chubut population density is just 0.8 and 1.8 inhabitants per sq km respectively. Most measures of social and economic development show marked disparities between rural and urban areas, with per-head incomes and healthcare and education indicators much better in the Buenos Aires area than elsewhere.
Argentina's lead in regional healthcare and education standards will erode
Although Argentina's healthcare indicators still compare favourably with those of most of its neighbours, social conditions worsened markedly during the 1998-2002 recession, and in many areas problems have persisted ever since, suggesting that expenditure has become inefficient. The healthcare and education systems are in urgent need of reform. Even so, a high level of educational attainment by regional standards means that the stock of human capital will remain a source of comparative strength, although improvements in some other Latin American countries will close the gap within the region.

Argentina's wealth of natural resources, large domestic market (with high per-head incomes relative to much of the rest of the region), and proximity and preferential access to the large Brazilian market represent attractive long-term opportunities for foreign investors. On top of this, The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast of a shift to moderate GDP growth rates of an annual average 2.9% in 2018-22, and an improvement in the environment for business, suggests an increase in domestic market opportunities in the medium term.
Some improvement in purchasing power expected
Argentina is a middle-income country with one of the highest levels of GDP per head in the region-US$22,167 at purchasing power parity (PPP) exchange rates in 2017. Demographics are generally supportive of growth: the population is estimated at around 44m (the fourth-largest in Latin America), and is reasonably young, albeit not as young as that of most other countries in the region. Moreover, urbanisation is high, at more than 90% of the population. However, as in much of the region, income inequality and poverty remain high. According to recently released data from INDEC, the national statistics institute, the poverty rate came in at 25.7% in the second half of 2017. The extreme poverty rate was 4.8%. Although this represents a clear improvement on 2016, when the economy was in recession, the poverty rate is clearly still high. There are significant geographical disparities, with poverty rates highest outside of the capital, Buenos Aires. By national comparison, the poverty rate was highest in the north-east region, at 33.2% in the second half of 2017. In Greater Buenos Aires province, which encircles but does not include the capital city, the poverty rate was also high, at 25.5%, probably reflecting the impact of a steep decline in manufacturing in the province, which has only recently begun to ease. By contrast, the poverty rate was just 9% in the capital itself.
A full analysis of the poverty data over time is complicated by a lack of historical data. A deterioration of statistical quality during the previous administration led to unreliable poverty statistics; in the latter years of the previous administration, INDEC stopped publishing poverty statistics altogether. Under new leadership, INDEC began publishing poverty data in mid-2016, using new methodology that is not comparable with the discredited historical data. However, the mid-2016 INDEC data are similar to figures published by the Centro de Estudios Distributivos Laborales y Sociales (Cedlas), a social policy research institute at the Universidad Nacional de La Plata. According to Cedlas, the poverty rate is roughly similar to data from the first half of 2011, implying that there was no progress on poverty reduction between 2011 and 2016. In the medium term, lower inflation rates and steady economic growth should help to reduce poverty through spillover effects. In the meantime, however, poor social conditions will contribute to insecurity and social unrest.

A long-term shift in consumer attitudes was brought about by the economic crisis of 2001-02, which changed patterns of goods consumption markedly. A shift towards cheaper brands and lower-cost, high-volume outlets was not reversed even during the boom years of 2004-07. However, we expect the proportion of income spent on food, beverages and tobacco to fall gradually in the forecast period, and for the proportion of consumer spending on hotels and restaurants, healthcare, leisure and education to grow. This assumes growth in purchasing power as real disposable incomes rise over the course of the forecast period, driven by growth in employment, income redistribution via Argentina's relatively new conditional cash transfer schemes, and greater efforts at financial inclusion, which suggest a steady increase in access to bank credit during the forecast period. One difference between Argentina and the rest of the region will be the age of the population. Argentina's population will remain markedly older; just over 11% were aged 65 years and over in 2017. This will affect consumption patterns, notably pushing up overall expenditure on healthcare.

Abundant natural resources and a skilled labour force underpin potential
Argentina has historically been susceptible to cycles of boom and bust, reflecting both a vulnerability to external conditions and domestic policy challenges. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecast rests on the assumption that Argentina will adopt a more sustainable economic model that reduces fiscal and external imbalances, allowing the economy to grow by an average of 2.8% in 2017-50.
Initial conditions: Argentina's GDP per head of US$14,398 in 2017 (US$22,167 at purchasing power parity) is one of the highest in the region. However, as it is still only one-third of the US figure, there is clearly potential for Argentina to catch up to developed-country levels. The internal market is relatively large and, although the territory is extensive, there are few internal geographical obstacles, although Argentina is distant from developed-country markets and high transport costs will place an extra burden on exporters. For a decade after the 2001 maxi-devaluation, labour was cheaper than during the 1990s, but the gains from devaluation had been eliminated by 2012 amid high inflation and sustained real wage growth. Despite two decades of gradual de-industrial-isation, Argentina retains a solid skilled labour base, and the capacity to carry out high-level research and development. It will attract manufacturing invest-ment, but its competitiveness as a global manufacturing centre will lag behind Asian rivals. Argentina has strong comparative advantages in agriculture, although, as a commodity producer, it will face more volatile terms of trade than Asian competitors. This means that growth is likely to be uneven.
Demographic trends: Argentina shares demographic as well as cultural features with Europe. The average age of the population is higher than in most of the rest of the region and population growth both in percentage and absolute terms is expected to be slightly lower. We expect population growth of 0.6% per year in 2017-50, less than half the average recorded in 1980-2000. At present, the working-age population is still growing faster than the overall population, but we expect this trend to change from around 2030. Although labour force participation rates will continue to rise gradually towards OECD levels, from an estimated 64% in 2020, growth in the labour force will slow as a result. Particularly towards the end of the long-term forecast period, the contribution of labour to GDP will therefore be weaker.
The population is more urbanised and better provided with healthcare than in other Latin American countries, leading to a life expectancy of around 76 years, similar to that of many developed countries. Given the existence of the welfare state and the severe weakening of the finances of the state and private pensions systems in the past two decades, the growing elderly population will increasingly generate strains on the public finances.
External conditions: Growth-determining factors exogenous to Argentina will include the level of developed-country interest rates (in the past this has been strongly correlated with the volume of capital flows into Latin America and has had a major impact on growth) and commodity prices. Argentina will remain highly dependent on income from exports of agricultural commodities to provide an investible surplus for deployment elsewhere in the economy. Restricted access to finance since the 2001 default has raised the cost of capital in the past decade by forcing reliance on financing from the shallow, more expensive domestic market. However, Argentina's exit from default in April 2016 implies improved access to international capital markets to facilitate stronger growth in investment, particularly in agriculture, energy and infrastructure.
Institutional weaknesses will constrain growth
Institutions and policy trends: Disappointing economic outcomes have been the indirect result of shortcomings in policymaking and institutions. Argentina scores moderately to poorly on measures of corruption, security and the rule of law. Our analysis suggests that an improvement in the overall institutional climate would have a significant impact on long-term growth, but institutional reforms will take a long time to bear fruit. The quality of policymaking is likely to improve more rapidly. The government of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15) clashed with foreign investors over the terms of contracts, and oversaw a phase of ad hoc intervention in the economy. A more market-friendly administration, led by Mauricio Macri, is seeking to address these problems, and we assume that the government will succeed early on in the long-term forecast period in establishing a new framework for foreign investors in sectors such as utilities.
GDP will grow by an annual average of 2.8% in 2018-50
Long-term performance: We forecast that average annual GDP will grow by 2.8% in 2018-50, with the growth rate peaking at 3% in 2018-30, before slowing to 2.6% by 2041-50. Our forecasts assume that the contribution of capital to growth will be firm in the first part of the 2018-50 forecast period, before tapering off somewhat over the latter part of the period. We also assume that as growth in the working-age population slows, the increase in the availability of labour will slow, meaning that growth will become more dependent on productivity gains. To the extent that they are achieved, these gains are likely to be made via technology transfer and higher foreign invest-ment. Firms will increasingly look beyond national borders in order to achieve economies of scale, and this will stimulate efficiency gains. Having said this, and although Argentina's abundant natural resources and relatively strong skills base represent solid economic potential, the country will struggle to achieve the productivity gains needed to converge with developed-market income levels. This is particularly the case in the light of low levels of domestic investment in research and development, and we expect limited progress in catching up with developed country incomes, even in the long-term forecast period.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Climate change represents a risk to Argentina's long-term growth rate, most obviously through its impact on the important agriculture sector. This vulnerability has been evident this year, with severe drought expected to lead to a sharp drop in output of key crops such as soybeans and maize, with knock-on impacts on real GDP. Since it came to office in late 2015, the Macri administration has worked to develop a comprehensive climate change plan; one element of this is the increased use of renewable energy, including hydroelectric, wind and solar power. Despite having some of Latin America's most abundant natural energy resources, less than 2% of the country's electricity currently comes from renewable energy. Under the "RenovAr" programme, Argentina is now targeting a total of 20% of electricity from renewable sources by 2025. As part of its climate change mitigation efforts, Argentina is aiming to overachieve its nationally determined contribution (NDC) originally submitted under the Paris Agreement.
The Macri administration is also in the process of developing sectoral mitigation and adaptation plans for agriculture, transport, infrastructure, forests, industry and energy, with a view to unveiling a new national climate change plan in 2019. The central government is also working on the development of a climate change map, to work with local and provincial authorities to determine geographical vulnerabilities and develop adaptation and mitigation plans, and financing, accordingly. In the Uruguay River area on the border between Argentina and Uruguay, a joint initiative between the two countries is in progress to try to increase the resilience of vulnerable coastal populations in this area. Continued progress in all these areas, both in the planning and implementation stages, will be necessary to reduce the long-term impact on growth as a result of climate change.
Technological developments
Argentina's high skills base by regional comparison will be a key factor supporting the country's ability to adapt to technological disruption in the long term. Combined with high per-head incomes, this helps to explain the country's leading position in Latin America with regard to mobile and broadband penetration, e-commerce and m-commerce, and the strength of sectors such as software development and financial technology (fintech). The capital city, Buenos Aires, is a hub for both these industries in Latin America. It is the largest exporter of software in the region, and is a large and rapidly growing centre for fintech centred on payment systems, corporate financial management, consumer and business lending, and new technologies for existing financial institutions
The e-commerce environment is expected to remain strong, and m-commerce will grow, supported by high penetration of mobile broadband. Online retail has been quicker to develop than in many other countries in the region, and is still growing rapidly (by over 52% in 2017). Online and mobile banking is already popular, and is used by customers to conduct routine transactions, aided by well-developed mobile banking services and a modern payments system that meets international standards.
Regulation and governance remain relative weak points, while a backdrop of still-high inflation and macroeconomic distortions will in the short term continue to deter significant private (including foreign investment), to the detriment of research and development, and the number of patent applications. Recent reforms to simplify patent applications should, however, produce improvements going forward.
A continuing weakness that shows fewer sign of progress as yet is logistics, with most delivery companies failing to deliver as rapidly as is the case in similarly ranked countries. This reflects a legacy of weak investment in physical infrastructure, which has hampered the quality of the road network and led to some port delays. We assume better progress in this area in the long term, which will be necessary to insert Argentina into global value chains, and allow for "leapfrogging" to tilt industrial production more rapidly towards high-tech, high-value-added products.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.
