Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Germany--highlights: Political outlook
Germany will be governed by a grand coalition comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party the Christian Social Union (CSU) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD) until the next election in 2021. The government will have a smaller majority than in its previous term and will be significantly more fractious. The SPD will be more vocal in order to differentiate itself from the CDU, and possible successors to Angela Merkel, who has held the position of chancellor since 2005, will jockey for position within the CDU. The inclusion of a far-right populist party in the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament), the Alternative for Germany (AfD), for the first time in decades will also increase political instability.
Germany--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.19 8.24 8 10 4 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany's score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environ-ment rankings improves slightly between the historical period and the forecast period, mainly owing to the better macroeconomic environment. However, faster improvements elsewhere mean that the country slips in the global and regional rankings. The main strengths of the business environment are political stability, a highly skilled labour force, openness to trade and investment, and well-developed (if ageing) infrastructure. A strong research and innovation fram-ework is another advantage. Weaknesses include a high tax burden on labour income and on companies, alongside high administrative costs. Germany's open economy is also exposed to a slowdown in global trade flows. The economy is relatively well-prepared to deal with technological changes.
Germany--highlights: Economic outlook

We forecast average annual GDP growth of 1.9% in 2018-22, driven in large part by consumer spending, in the light of a tightening labour market, solid wage growth and low borrowing costs. Fiscal policy is likely to become slightly less restrictive (although still highly prudent) and public investment will support robust business investment. We expect substantial (if gradually declining) current-account surpluses, against a backdrop of continuing recovery across the euro zone, despite external pressure for Germany to do more to boost domestic demand. In the longer term the weak demographic outlook will weigh more heavily on economic growth. The main risks to the outlook are external, with a more protectionist global trade environment, driven mainly by tariff impositions by the US, being the most pronounced.
Germany--highlights: Demographic outlook

Labour force growth   0.7 0.5
Germany's demographic outlook is challenging, even in a European context. Long-standing natural decline, as deaths outnumber births, combined with political constraints on net immigration mean that the population will grow only marginally over the forecast period. The working-age population will start to decline, and the average age will rise, putting pressure on the pensions and healthcare systems, and exacerbating labour shortages. The influx of migrants from the Middle East and North Africa in 2015 will have only a small influence on the demographic outlook, and successfully integrating these newcomers into the labour market will require significant policy efforts.

Germany will remain the world's fourth-largest economy at market exchange rates in 2022. Germany is the largest consumer market in Europe by population, and market opportunities will be supported by the tight labour market and solid wage growth over the forecast period. The country's changing age profile will do much to shape demand, particularly in the area of leisure services for the large retired population. The consumer market will continue to be characterised by a preference for inexpensive goods for most day-to-day needs and high-quality purchases in special circumstances.
Germany--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2018-30 2031-50 2018-50

Growth of real GDP 1.6 1.2 1.4

Over the long-term forecast period the economy's growth will be constrained by markedly poor demographics. Real GDP growth will ease from an average of 1.6% in 2018-30 to 1.2% in 2031-50, although on a per-head basis the rate of growth will remain broadly steady. Notwithstanding the demographic headwinds, Germany has many attributes that are conducive to sustainable long-term growth, including a highly skilled workforce, stable institutions and openness to innovation. It needs more reform, including of the pension system, progress on which we expect to be slow. We expect this to weigh slightly on long-term economic performance.

Background: The modern German state was founded in 1870. After the second world war (1939-45) Germany was divided into two parts: a liberal parliamentary democracy in the west and a totalitarian communist regime in the east. On October 3rd 1990, after the end of the Soviet Union's hegemony in central and eastern Europe, Germany was reunified.
Political structure: Germany is a federation of 16 states, or Länder, each of which has its own constitution, government and parliament. The states are primarily responsible for policing and education. The federal parliament comprises the directly elected Bundestag (the lower house) and the Bundesrat (the upper house) of representatives of the state governments. The federal chancellor, the head of the executive, is elected by the Bundestag and can be brought down only by the election of a successor. A grand coalition comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD) governed from 2013 to 2017. Coalition talks following the 2017 election were lengthy, but eventually resulted in another grand coalition, which took office in March 2018.
Policy issues: Internationally, the government's agenda will include the Brexit negotiations between the EU and the UK; EU reform efforts, in collaboration with the French president, Emmanuel Macron; managing relations with the US president, Donald Trump, especially over trade issues; and shaping the EU's response to Russia, in the wake of the annexation of Crimea in 2014. Domestically, the government aims to ensure a sustainable medium-term budget surplus, increase investment spending, ensure continued progress on its Industry 4.0 agenda and shift away from nuclear energy.
Taxation: The federal corporation tax rate was cut from 25% to 15% in 2008. The effective corporate tax rate, including a municipal trade tax and a solidarity tax, is about 30-33%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45%. Social security contributions are shared equally between employers and employees. The main value-added tax (VAT) rate is 19%.
Foreign trade: Export earnings picked up to US$1.4trn in 2017, from US$1.3trn in 2016. Import costs also picked up, to US$1.1trn, from US$1trn. This resulted in a rise in the goods trade surplus to US$300bn; the services deficit narrowed to US$18.4bn. The EU is still the largest single goods export market for Germany, but it has been more successful than most in diversifying its markets and selling into fast-growing emerging markets over the past decade.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Germany is a federal democracy, with major powers delegated to the 16 states (Länder). In March 2018 the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD) reformed their grand coalition following a difficult and protracted coalition-building process. The bicameral parlia-ment comprises the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament), whose members are elected on a system of modified proportional representation, and the Bundesrat (the upper house), which consists of representatives of the 16 state govern-ments. The coalition has a majority in the Bundestag but not in the Bundesrat.

a Before the 2005 election, the Party of Democratic Socialist (PDS) merged with a new group, the Election Alliance for Jobs and Social Justice (WASG). The joint party was named the Left Party. Before 2005 the results relate to the PDS alone.
Political outlook: Political stability
In the federal election in September 2017 the centre-right CDU and its smaller Bavarian sister party, the CSU, won the largest share of the vote. The centre-left SPD had its worst election result in the post-war period, after governing with the CDU in 2013-17. Following a failed attempt by the CDU to form a coalition without the SPD, another grand coalition was formed in early 2018 and installed on March 14th. Although German politics will remain over-whelmingly centrist and consensus-driven in The Economist Intelligence Unit's 2018-22 forecast period, there will be a greater divergence of views both in the Bundestag and in the cabinet, resulting in more robust debate and a less predictable outlook.
The SPD's previous experiences in coalition under Angela Merkel, the leader of the CDU and chancellor since 2005, have been woeful, and the party's public support has collapsed from 41% in 1998 to about 18% in current opinion polls. The SPD is suffering the same fate as many other European social democratic parties at present-including those in France and the Netherlands-and is losing its status as one of the two "big tent" parties, in part as a result of the political fragmentation of its traditional working-class electorate. A change in the party's leadership-with Andrea Nahles, the labour and social affairs minister in the outgoing government, taking over-offers the prospect of a change in the party's fortunes. The SPD controls the ministries responsible for finance, foreign affairs, and labour and social affairs in the incoming government, and will attempt to use these positions to differentiate the party from Ms Merkel's CDU in the coming years. This will lead to further tensions between the coalition partners and contribute to a more volatile political scene.
The CDU is not in as precarious a position as the SPD, but it will also find this term more challenging and unstable than the previous one. The fall in the CDU's vote share in the 2017 election, the lengthy coalition negotiations and the party's generosity to the SPD in the negotiations have all weakened Ms Merkel at the start of what will almost certainly be her last term. Strong pressure both from within the CDU and from the CSU to move to the right on issues such as immigration and integration will hamper government effectiveness. This will also play into the contest to succeed Ms Merkel as the dominant figure on the centre right, which will create political instability, especially in the latter part of the government's three-and-a-half-year term.
The far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) entered the Bundestag for the first time in the October election. Not only is this the first time that a far-right party has been represented in the Bundestag in more than 50 years, but with another grand coalition taking office, it has become the largest opposition party. The AfD is now the second-largest political force in much of the former East Germany, where voters' dissatisfaction with the govern-ment's handling of the 2015-16 migration crisis fed into deeper frustrations about the lack of convergence between east and west Germany since reunification. It is already proving to be a loud and fractious presence in the Bundestag, but it will also be subject to in-fighting, given divisions between radicals and less extreme members.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The quality of administration is high, and the implementation of policies that have been passed by the federal parliament is sound. The federal structure of the government means that considerable responsibility falls on the 16 states that constitute the federal republic. An advantage of this is that many issues are decided with the closer democratic involvement of the electorate. States have a strong incentive to improve their own quality of governance, as comparisons with other states are easy to make, although one drawback is that the quality of public services such as education can vary significantly between states. Another disadvantage is that co-ordination can be troublesome in policy areas where the states have a large role. This has been the case in recent years. For instance, although the federal government had allocated additional funds for infrastructure investment, lower governments were often unable to use these for additional investment owing to capacity constraints.
The design of the system also means that the constitutional powers enjoyed by the Bundesrat may on occasion limit the ability of the federal government to push through reforms in the face of opposition at state level. However, the upper house does not have the right of veto on all aspects of legislation, and the proportion of laws requiring its approval was reduced in 2006. The last of these changes aimed to reduce the share of legislation requiring Bundesrat approval from about 60% to 35-40%, but the actual impact has been less dramatic. In exchange for this loss of influence over federal legislation, the states now have greater influence over the implementation of federal laws and have gained some additional powers, particularly in education.
Majority governments are the norm in Germany, at both the federal and the state levels. This generally ensures smooth policymaking, as the coalition agreement usually sets out in advance what the government will be working on throughout its term. In the coming years we expect increased pressure on policymaking at the federal level, as the coalition is likely to be more fractured than in its previous term. The SPD's wish to differentiate itself more clearly from the CDU will hamper effective policymaking, and jockeying for position within the CDU to replace Ms Merkel as leader of the party will weigh on government effectiveness.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next federal election is scheduled for 2021. A state election is due to be held in Bavaria in October 2018, and in the run-up to this date tensions within the coalition are likely. The CSU may decide to go against the coalition line on issues such as migration in order to ward off the electoral threat from the AfD.
Political outlook: International relations
The external environment has become a source of uncertainty in recent years. The UK's vote to leave the EU, strains over the migrant relocation agreement, and the challenges to the bloc posed by the governments in Hungary and Poland have put pressure on the European community. Meanwhile, further afield, the actions of Donald Trump, Vladimir Putin and Recep Tayyip Erdogan-the presidents of the US, Russia and Turkey respectively-are serving to undermine the global rules-based order that Germany has always held as the gold standard. The election of Emmanuel Macron as president of France was welcomed in Germany as enabling a more balanced Franco-German partner-ship at the heart of the bloc. Nevertheless, Germany is likely to remain the most influential player in the EU owing to the structural elements supporting German power within the bloc, most importantly its dominant economy.
Mr Macron's proposed European reforms, especially those regarding the euro zone, have met with mixed reactions. There is a broad consensus in Germany against fiscal transfers within the bloc, and despite some positive notes on euro zone reform in the coalition agreement, Germany will-together with several other north European countries-refuse to agree to any reforms that might in-crease fiscal risk sharing. More likely to find German support are proposals such as greater defence integration and European border control. So far Ms Merkel has been cautiously open to the process of reform kick-started by Mr Macron, and she is likely to support the idea of further integration among "coalitions of the willing" within the EU.
The US is, and will remain, Germany's most important non-EU partner on the global stage, but the relationship between Mr Trump and Ms Merkel has been rocky so far. Mr Trump has been critical of Germany's trade surplus with the US and its below-target spending on defence. We expect tensions to continue in the coming years, with the US's decision in March to impose tariffs on steel and aluminium imports possibly a harbinger of similar conflicts to come, even though the EU was granted a temporary waiver, which was extended for another 30 days at the end of April. Efforts will also be made to lessen German dependence on the US for defence-although spending is unlikely to be raised to a level sufficient to break this dependency. In the meantime Ms Merkel will continue to manage the relationship to avoid confrontations with Mr Trump.
Following the annexation of Crimea in 2014 Germany took a decisive line against Russia, breaking with decades of relatively good relations and pushing against the reluctance of many south and central European nations to impose far-reaching EU sanctions-a position that it has maintained ever since. This was highlighted by its decision, in line with a large number of other EU countries, to expel four Russian diplomats in the wake of an attack in the UK on a former Russian military intelligence officer on March 4th. We expect the EU sanctions to remain in place over the medium term, although pragmatic co-operation between Germany and Russia will continue, especially on energy.

Germany's score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings increases slightly from 8.19 in the historical period (2013-17) to 8.24 in the forecast period (2018-22). However, owing to larger gains elsewhere, the country falls in the global and regional rankings. Germany was the eighth most attractive business location in the world in 2013-17, but it drops to tenth position in 2018-22, and the country's regional ranking declines from fourth to sixth place among its 17 peers. Strong fundamentals underpin Germany's high score and ranking for the macroeconomic environment, supporting a small improvement in financing conditions. Modest declines in the foreign trade and market opportunities categories reflect the uncertainty for business caused by the Brexit process and the broader push-back against global trade liberalisation. Overall, most of the scores in our business environment categories are expected to remain broadly stable-an indictment of the previous coalition government's unadventurous policy agenda and our expectation that "reform fatigue" will endure over the coming years. This is disappointing given the fiscal space in Germany's public finances, the weaknesses that persist in the tax system and network infrastructure, and the country's demographic challenges.
Political stability will mainly be tested by region-wide issues
Germany's main strengths are its political stability, skilled labour force, openness to external trade and investment, and strong research and innovation framework. The political environment is reasonably robust, with a mature democratic system and efficient public administration, but stability will be tested by internal coalition pressures and region-wide issues related to immigration, Brexit, Russia and reform of euro zone structures. The tax regime places a substantial burden on labour income and on companies, alongside high administrative costs. The phase-out of nuclear power raises questions about the cost of renewables and energy supply security.
Enlarge this image.
Business environment outlook: Germany's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The state maintains its involvement in the financial sector, railways and telecommunications. Firms' administrative burden is reasonable, but some areas of weakness remain. Protective regulation across the services sector persists.
2020-22: Limited prospects for reforming regulated services professions. State ownership levels remain broadly unchanged.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: The government generally welcomes foreign direct investment, but takeovers of major media, infrastructure and finance companies could run into political resistance. Investment from China is increasingly unwelcome.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressures and EU law.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Risk of worsening EU-Russia relations and US-sparked trade tensions leading to a global trade war.
2020-22: Informal UK-EU trade arrangement and ongoing formal talks expected, but risk of no deal and disruption to trade.
Taxes
2018-19: Some fiscal loosening begins, including some targeted tax cuts via phased abolition of "solidarity surcharge", but a comparatively high tax burden persists.
2020-22: Incremental income tax relief is likely amid pressure to strengthen work incentives for lower-income earners. Possible phased abolition or reduction of "solidarity surcharge". Modest reform of corporate tax regime.
Financing
2018-19: European Central Bank (ECB) policy stance and unprecedented liquidity hold down banks' funding costs, but pressure on margins persists amid weak profitability and tighter regulation. Moves to attract financial services firms from UK.
2020-22: Banks face further calls to boost equity bases. Possible US-led rollback of some global financial sector regulation.
The labour market
2018-19: Unemployment remains low. Restrictions on temporary employment. Skilled labour shortages start to emerge.
2020-22: Limited prospects for reform to address structural challenges arising from ageing demographics and rising share of migrant workers. Increased provision of childcare facilities leads to moderate rise in female participation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Modest rise in public infrastructure investment. Focus on maintenance of existing road and rail networks. Further delays in opening of flagship airport in Berlin. Continued calls from energy sector for improvement of power grid.
2020-22: New sources of finance are sought through public-private partnerships, but investment remains limited.
Technological readiness
2018-19: The government prioritises upgrading the country's digital infrastructure, starting with an optical fibre network.
2020-22: Efforts continue on Industry 4.0, which focuses on upgrading the country's manufacturing prowess through increased use of automation and connected systems. Increasing threat from cyber-crime and cyber-espionage.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.6 9.2 2 1 2 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
A robust economic upswing in recent years has been supported by a resilient labour market, modest inflation, solid household finances, external stimulus from relatively low oil prices and accommodative European Central Bank (ECB) monetary policy, and a synchronised expansion of global demand. We expect the euro zone economy to lose some momentum as pent-up demand fades, but macroeconomic fundamentals in Germany will remain broadly favourable, with healthy public finances, low unemployment, a competitive export sector and helpful financing conditions, backed by a strong institutional framework.
However, a number of structural supply-side challenges will become more apparent. Relatively weak business investment and public infrastructure spending over the past decade, viewed alongside the government's limited reform plans, does not augur well for medium-term productivity and potential growth. Policy will also be tested by ageing demographics and a gradual decline in the working-age population (raising the risk of skilled labour shortages), emerging strains in parts of the housing market and the disruptive impact of new technologies on the dominant automotive sector.
Germany's large current-account surplus has long implied an inefficient allocation of resources, domestically and within the euro zone. It reflects an unusually large volume of savings in Germany (that are largely invested abroad), driven in part by fiscal conservatism, low investment and population ageing. It also underlines the significant exposure of the economy to world trade flows and to shifts in external demand. An increase in global trade protectionism represents the most serious near-term risk to growth, with businesses also facing uncertainty over the UK's Brexit process, the prospect of a downturn in the US economy in 2019-20 and weakening Chinese demand.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.3 8.3 13 13 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Policy towards private enterprise and competition is generally liberal and will remain so over the forecast period. Particular strengths include a well-developed framework for research and innovation, a stable legal code and integrated supply chains across the EU. The competition authority, the Federal Cartel Office, has a solid reputation for being unbiased and efficient. However, Germany fares less well in other areas of the business environment. Weaknesses include inefficiencies in the corporate tax regime, restricted competition in parts of the services sector and subdued entrepreneurial activity. The country's regulatory framework for companies is reasonable, but lags some of its regional peers. According to the World Bank's 2018 Doing Business report, the administrative processes involved in obtaining utilities and credit, enforcing contracts and resolving insolvency are fairly low. In contrast, the number of procedures and time taken to set up a new business are well above the average for high-income OECD countries, tax administration is often complex and costly, and registration of property can be protracted.
Protective regulations across the business services sector will persist
Liberalisation of product markets has progressed gradually, but regulations remain comparatively restrictive in some utilities and transport sectors, retail and business services. There has been negligible domestic reform in these areas and successive governments have resisted efforts to open up the EU services market to greater competition. EU-wide access to the German public procurement market is more restricted than in the UK and France.
Across the wider economy, state involvement is fairly modest. Most domestic post-crisis emergency measures in the financial sector have been rolled back, although the state retains holdings in three recapitalised banks and will continue to oversee the run-off of substantial legacy assets in a Special Fund for Financial Market Stabilisation (SoFFin). The framework of state-owned regional and savings banks carries political clout. The federal government wholly owns the state railway, Deutsche Bahn; holds a 32% share in the former national telecommunications monopolist, Deutsche Telekom; and has a 21% stake in the former postal monopoly, Deutsche Post.
Recent reforms to reduce firms' administrative burdens have been modest and no major changes are anticipated in 2018-22. A 2016 "bureaucracy relief" act introduced a "one-in, one-out" rule for new regulations likely to impose costs on companies, and eased record-keeping requirements for start-ups.
Studies by the European Commission have showed Germany to have some of the most restrictive regulation in business services among all EU member states, with around a third of the labour force estimated to be employed in regulated professions (these include lawyers, accountants, architects and engineers). Strong vested interests point to limited prospects for reform, with the government showing little inclination to enact liberalising measures.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.7 8.7 10 10 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
FDI policy is fairly liberal, but greenfield investment is preferred
Policy towards foreign investment is fairly liberal-as in most EU countries-but subsidies or financial incentives aimed directly at attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) are limited and focused mainly on research and development (R&D) support. Germany Trade and Invest (GTAI) is the federal body responsible for FDI relations, with a state-owned development bank, KfW, the main provider of financial subsidies. Investor programmes do not discriminate between foreign and local investment. As in most countries, green-field FDI is viewed as preferable to foreign acquisitions of domestic companies. Restrictions on hostile takeovers are considerable, whether the acquirer is foreign or domestic. Notice of strategic goals and "acting in concert" is mandatory for large investments. Constraints are more pronounced with respect to acquisitions of major utility companies, reflecting security of energy supply issues. According to data from the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), in 2016 Germany was home to the eighth-largest stock of FDI in the world, and the fourth largest in the EU after the UK, Ireland and the Netherlands.
The government has the right to veto acquisitions of equity stakes above 25% in German companies by non-EU investors if these are deemed not to be in the national interest. The veto has yet to be applied, but could be tested in the coming years amid gradual signs of an increasing pushback (at both domestic and EU level) against FDI inflows from Asia, and particularly China. A recent rise in these inflows has prompted concerns over the potential loss of technological know-how and the sale of strategic assets, especially in the case of investment by Chinese state-owned firms. In 2017 the European Commission announced plans to establish a regional framework for screening FDI into the EU on grounds of national security. Some member states have criticised the plans as being clearly protectionist in nature, although the Commission argues that similar initiatives exist in other major trading partners such as China and the US.
A recent trend in many countries has been an increasing share of FDI activity reflecting "corporate reconfiguration"-changes in complex multinational ownership structures-which often has a minimal impact on output and employment in the host economy. This is expected to continue over the forecast period as firms' tax-planning practices continue to evolve.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
9.6 9.1 7 18 3 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Trade talks will focus on bilateral deals, amid global trade tensions
Germany's foreign trade regime is defined by its EU membership. Free movement of goods, services, capital and persons exists within the EU and we do not expect any exchange controls. No tariffs or quotas are permitted within the bloc and the EU has abolished most other non-tariff restrictions. The EU trades with Norway and Iceland under the European Free Trade Association (EFTA), has a range of bilateral agreements with Switzerland and a customs union with Turkey. Only agriculture is excluded from all these arrangements.
Trade between EU member states and third countries has been largely governed by multilateral agreements administered by the World Trade Organisation (WTO), but there has been minimal progress in world trade talks over the past decade. Growing opposition in many countries (notably the US) to further trade liberalisation implies no prospect of headway over the forecast period. The EU's focus will be on bilateral deals and we expect further gradual progress to be made in this area. The backdrop will be challenging, however, given a rise in protectionist measures implemented by governments around the world and the recent transition in US trade policy from protectionist rhetoric to more concrete action. These actions are likely to inhibit global trade flows and there is a notable risk that an escalating chain reaction of measures could occur, threatening a more dramatic fraying of the multilateral trade system.
The EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) will gradually come into force in 2018-22. CETA will eliminate most trade tariffs, ease border procedures and increase regulatory co-operation. In December 2017 the EU finalised an economic partnership agreement with Japan that will create the world's largest free-trade area. The deal will come into effect from early 2019, although there will be a lengthy transition phase for most measures over the next decade. In April 2018 the EU and Mexico agreed in principle to a trade deal that would include a significant reduction of tariffs.
Germany will play a leading role in the complex Brexit negotiations ahead of (and following) the UK's scheduled withdrawal from the EU in March 2019. The UK accounts for about 6.6% of German exports and is the country's fifth most important trading partner. The wider political context (and the EU's strong negotiating position) will, however, drive a resolute German approach in the talks. There is a clear risk that a breakdown in talks could lead to a "hard Brexit" without any form of trade accord in prospect.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.7 6.9 24 30 6 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Tax burden will remain high on labour income and companies
The tax/GDP ratio in Germany has remained broadly stable over the past decade and stood at 40% in 2016 (latest available data), in line with the EU average and slightly below that for the euro zone (41%). Direct taxes on personal income and net social security contributions account for a higher than average share of overall tax receipts, and a lower proportion of revenue is derived from taxes on corporate income, goods and services (such as value-added tax, VAT), and property. There are three personal income tax rates, ranging from 14% to 45%, with the top rate levied on annual incomes over EUR260,500. There is also a "solidarity surcharge"-a 5.5% levy on income that has been in effect since 1991 to finance reunification costs. The standard VAT rate is 19%, slightly below the EU average, with a reduced rate of 7% on certain goods and services.
Despite robust jobs growth in Germany over recent years, the tax system is not that supportive of employment or private investment, with a relatively high tax burden on labour income and on companies. In 2017 the average single worker faced a tax wedge-the difference between workers' take-home pay and what it costs to employ them-of 49.7%, the second highest in the OECD, after Belgium. This high burden, including on low-income workers, acts as a disincentive for second earners and partly accounts for the modest full-time employment rate among women. The tax burden on firms is also elevated, even though the headline federal corporation tax rate is just 15%. After including the impact of a local trade tax (Gewerbesteuer) and the solidarity surcharge, the effective average corporation tax rate is around 28%, compared with an EU average of about 21%. In addition, the country's tax system for firms is quite complex, with fairly high administration costs. Tax treatment favours debt over equity, which could hinder private investment and might partly account for Germany's underdeveloped venture capital market.
The public finances are robust by advanced economy standards, with the general government budget recording a fourth consecutive annual surplus in 2017. This implies more room for manoeuvre than in most peer economies, but with both major parties broadly supportive of a cautious fiscal stance, no significant overhaul of tax policy is expected.
The one agreed change by the new coalition government is a gradual phased abolition of the solidarity surcharge for lower- and middle-income earners, which will provide some modest tax relief. There are also likely to be some targeted measures to incentivise business investment, building on recent reforms to the tax framework for start-ups and investment funds.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.8 8.1 13 16 6 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Support for the financial sector will continue, amid slow reforms
Germany's financial sector was badly affected by the 2008-09 global slump. Officials and regulators were slow to acknowledge the failings in the banking system, which had invested heavily in exotic asset-backed securities. The underlying resilience of the sector has since improved, in response to significant balance sheet restructuring and consolidation, and as banks have bolstered their capital bases, asset quality and liquidity positions in line with tighter regulation and stronger economic conditions. At end-2017 estimates of Tier 1 capital adequacy were around the regional average and the share of non-performing loans was modest. Huge monetary support from the ECB has reduced banks' funding costs and supported a pick-up in credit growth, but the protracted low-interest-rate environment has weighed heavily on bank profitability in Germany, which is among the weakest in the EU. Despite a moderate shift towards commission- and fee-based revenue generation, the business model of most German banks remains geared towards interest income, which has resulted in low returns on equity. Comparatively high operating costs and rising pressure on margins from regulatory requirements and the adoption of digitisation have spurred major cost-cutting programmes and job losses across the sector, including at the two largest financial institutions, Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank. More structural adjustments will be required over the forecast period to avert a potential loss of investor confidence, and doubts will persist about the underlying strength of some state-owned regional lenders (Landesbanken), which faced huge losses during the crisis and remain in a weakened condition. Germany has a tradition of small local credit co-operatives and public-sector savings banks (owned by local authorities) that aim to service the Mittelstand. These account for the majority of credit institutions, and strong competition among them is one reason why retail banking in Germany is less profitable than in other European countries.
The credit cycle in Germany and across the euro zone has firmed over recent years amid improved economic conditions. According to ECB figures, total lending by financial institutions to the German private sector (including to other financial intermediaries) rose by 4.6% in 2017, a modest acceleration from growth of 4.2% in 2016 and 3.1% in 2015. This followed three successive years of decline. Demand for mortgage borrowing has risen by a steady 4% per year since 2015. Recently there has been faster growth in unsecured consumer credit and in lending to corporates, but sentiment showed signs of weakening in early 2018.
Internally generated funds account for an above-average share of corporate financing in Germany, reflecting firms' lower reliance on capital markets than in most large advanced economies. Equity capital accounts for the largest share of funding, but is below the EU average. Bank credit was traditionally the preferred financing channel, being comparatively cheap and available at long maturities, but demand has weakened over the past decade amid a steady process of deleveraging. The private-equity and venture capital markets are growing, but remain small in an international comparison. Securitisation and use of credit derivatives are quite common, but the market is not as developed as in some other high-income countries.
Brexit-related market volatility and regulatory changes could lead to additional costs and capital needs for parts of Germany's financial sector. The UK's exit from the EU will also create more opportunities for the expansion of the country's financial services hub of Frankfurt, as regulatory requirements will mean that London's relative appeal as a financial centre partly diminishes. A specific objective of the new coalition programme is to make Germany a more attractive location for financial institutions.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.9 6.6 11 18 4 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
A well-performing labour market, but demographic challenges lie ahead
Germany has a robust labour market, with a high rate of employment, solid employer-employee relations, a well-respected apprenticeship system, a statutory nationwide minimum wage and a record-low jobless rate (3.4% of the labour force in March 2018, the third-lowest level in the EU and far below an EU average of 7.1%). Unemployment has fallen steadily over the past decade (from a peak of 11.2% in 2005) and the employment rate has trended higher, to almost 80% at end-2017 (among those aged 20-64). Recent labour demand has been bolstered by the economic upswing, but the impressive headline labour market indicators can also be traced back to the impact of contentious reforms implemented by previous governments. Liberalising measures, tighter welfare eligibility and decentralisation of wage bargaining were accompanied by a long period of earnings restraint that strengthened productivity, jobs growth and competitiveness during the 2000s, when most EU countries experienced a steady increase in labour costs. This approach was unpopular with workers in Germany at the time-and constrained household spending-but has since underpinned the country's consistently high employment rate. Recent evidence would suggest that it has also lowered the rate at which unemployment would generate wage inflation. Despite a record-low jobless rate and growing labour shortages, average whole-economy earnings growth has remained very subdued, although collective wage agreements signed in early 2018 point to a modest acceleration over the next couple of years.
Alongside modest wage growth, there are some other less positive features of the labour market. Although the overall female employment rate is comparatively high (75% at end-2017), participation of women in full-time equivalent work is modest, partly owing to limited childcare availability and tax system disincentives for second earners. About 5m Germans (mainly female) were employed in part-time, low-wage "mini-jobs" at end-2017. Across the economy as a whole, the share of low-skill, low-wage employment has risen steadily over the past decade. There is also a significant gap between the employment and inactivity rates of female EU and non-EU nationals (more so than for men), implying transition issues for those with a migrant background into the labour market, and underuse of potential labour. Although the employment prospects of older workers have improved, the challenges posed by Germany's ageing population mean that reforms will be needed to strengthen incentives for later retirement (in contrast to a 2014 pension bill that expanded early retirement options) and improve lifelong learning policies.
Skilled labour shortages have been a topic of debate in Germany for some time, but the problem appears to have become more acute over the past year, with surveys regularly highlighting firms' concerns over a lack of skilled labour and its impact on business operations. Germany's negative demographic trends mean that the situation is only likely to get worse. Inflows of migrant labour will help to some extent and Brexit could be beneficial, by attracting more financial services staff to Germany and re-routing some immigrants who would otherwise have gone to the UK. However, vacancy rates suggest that these arrivals will not be sufficient to meet labour demand. As the political mood is not conducive to greater immigration, the focus may need to shift to removing incentives for early retirement or encouraging female full-time employment.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.8 8.0 15 12 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Infrastructure is decent, but greater capital investment is needed
The quality of network infrastructure has traditionally been one of the strengths of Germany's business environment, but a period of subdued capital investment has resulted in a modest deterioration of standards and raised concerns that capacity issues could hamper progress in digitisation and the medium-term energy transition policy (Energiewende) towards renewables. We expect some improvement over the forecast period in response to an upturn in public investment, targeted primarily at digital infrastructure and social housing, although some weaknesses will persist.
Transport infrastructure is well developed, but spending restraint has contributed to rising congestion and a backlog of repairs. The previous government announced a new Federal Transport Infrastructure Plan (FTIP) in 2016, proposing expenditure of EUR270bn on about 1,000 projects up to 2030. About 70% of the intended funds will be allocated to maintaining existing road and rail networks. The FTIP is more of a basic framework for policy than a specific funding plan. Its broad focus is welcome, but implementation will depend on attracting private investment, and overcoming regulatory hurdles and weak co-ordination between federal and local government. Airport investment will be underpinned by robust passenger demand, but construction of a new flagship airport, Berlin-Brandenburg, has been beset with problems and budget overruns. Opening has been repeatedly delayed from 2011 to 2020. The mobile telecoms and broadband markets are competitive, but Germany lags many of its peers in provision of high-speed broadband services.
The post-Fukushima decision by the government in 2011 to phase out domestic nuclear power by 2022 has driven a steady shift towards other forms of renewable energy, subsidies for which have contributed to high household energy bills. Expansion of renewables' capacity is ahead of target, but its share of the energy mix has been constrained by the sluggish pace of power grid development and dependence on heavily polluting coal. Carbon emissions are declining only slowly, undermining Germany's green credentials.
Since 2015 the government has allocated EUR4.5bn to a national broad-band programme that aims to provide network speeds of at least 50 megabits per second (mbps) across Germany by end-2018. This objective is unlikely to be met, mainly because of still limited fast broadband availability in rural and remote areas, but steady improvements in the network are expected in the coming years, as this has become one of the new government's main policy objectives.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
9.4 9.7 2 2 2 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
This category, introduced in 2018, aims to show the extent to which the business environment is open to innovation, digitally connected and prepared for technological disruption. Germany scores highly on a regional and global basis, reflecting the scope of its existing digital infrastructure; strong e-commerce and e-business penetration; above-average digital skill levels; a national Industry 4.0 initiative aimed at supporting digital manufacturing; and a well-developed framework for research and innovation. A weaker aspect is the fairly limited scope of e-government services. Total investment in R&D was 2.9% of GDP in 2016, one of the highest ratios in the EU. R&D intensity has trended steadily higher over the past decade, driven primarily by larger firms in the medium- and high-tech manufacturing sectors. Germany ranked among seven "innovation leaders" in the European Commission's European Innovation Scoreboard 2017, scoring particularly well in terms of business investment and small and medium-sized enterprise innovation activity, but lagging its peers in the areas of financing support and entrepreneurship. There are pockets of entrepreneurial dynamism, such as Berlin, but measures of innovative high-growth firms and start-up activity have weakened slightly in recent years. Germany has established a National Cyber Response Centre and has updated its official cybersecurity strategy on several occasions since 2011. According to the Global Cybersecurity Index, published by the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) in 2017, Germany was ranked 24th globally in terms of its commitment and capacity to deal with the rapidly increasing threat from cyber-crime and cyber-espionage.
In late 2016 the government unveiled its Digital Strategy 2025, setting objectives for the deployment of fifth-generation (5G) mobile services by end-2020 and a nationwide gigabit-capable infrastructure network by 2025. The EUR100bn project will be driven by a public-private consortium comprising the government and telecoms operators.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The presence of the Social Democratic Party (SPD) in the previous government enabled progress on some typically social democratic policy goals, including the introduction of a lower retirement age for some workers and a statutory minimum wage. The coalition agreement suggests that a slight loosening of fiscal policy can be expected, to be implemented through increased public invest-ment in infrastructure and digital technologies, greater spending on childcare, and by lowering income tax. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any large-scale structural reform efforts.
We expect significant structural challenges to have emerged by the 2020s. The poor demographic outlook is a particular problem, with the working-age population heading into decline and the population structure ageing. The dominant automotive sector also faces rising uncertainty following the Dieselgate emissions-rigging scandal and allegations of cartel behaviour, and given disruptive technological trends in the industry. The government's Industry 4.0 initiative is intended to ensure that the dominant German manufacturing sector remains at the fore-front of advances in robotics, artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things, but the country will face strong competition from China, South Korea and Japan in these areas in the coming decades. Social changes will also require policymakers' attention, with crucial questions including how best to integrate large numbers of refugees and whether the need to combat terrorism should supersede the country's long-standing aversion to surveillance.

Steady consolidation of the public finances was a focus of the outgoing government, which in 2017 met its schwarze Null target-a balanced federal budget on the national measure-for the fourth consecutive year, at 1.3% of GDP. Public spending will be nudged upwards and the surplus downwards during the forecast period by increased health and long-term care expenditure, and by a degree of fiscal loosening. Nonetheless, with revenue growth remaining solid, and given the deep-seated commitment across the political spectrum to the schwarze Null target, we expect the public finances to stay in surplus throughout our forecast period, even if the government decides to increase spending and lower income taxes. As a result, the public debt/GDP ratio will continue to fall, from a peak of 81.1% in 2010 to less than the EU mandated limit of 60% from 2019.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy

The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. However, the ECB's view of the outlook improved markedly during 2017 and, although it remains dovish, we expect a more upbeat tone to emerge this year, and an end to monthly asset purchases under the QE programme at the end of 2018. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate, to 0.25%, in early 2020, followed by five more rises that lift the main refinancing rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.

Real GDP growth averaged 2.5% in 2017, the strongest annual expansion since 2011, in line with a cyclical upturn across the euro zone. Private consumption provided the largest contribution to growth, followed by investment spending. Industrial output and trade volumes picked up significantly.
We expect private consumption to remain the main driver of 2.3% GDP growth in 2018 as employment continues to rise and nominal wage growth strengthens. Increases in state pensions and low borrowing costs will further support household spending. The tight labour market is starting to feed through into significant wage increases, with the union for metalworkers, IG Metall, achieving a wage rise of about 5% for almost 4m workers, and public-sector workers getting wage increases of over 3% in 2018 and 2019. However, just below half of German workers are covered by collective wage agreements, meaning that headline wage growth will remain below these figures.
External demand will remain robust, with growth in the US picking up and growth in the euro zone easing only marginally. We expect external trade to contribute positively to German GDP again in 2018, supported by continued momentum in industry. Given intensifying capacity constraints in manufacturing, and the emergence of skills shortages in the light of the tight labour market, we expect gross fixed capital formation to provide a further spur to headline GDP growth this year.
Domestic conditions will continue to be supportive in the remainder of the forecast period and private consumption will remain the largest contributor to growth. Investment spending will receive a boost from increased public investment; greater business investment, driven by capacity constraints and investment in new technologies; and moderate additional residential construction. Although this will push up imports, the competitiveness of the manufacturing sector will keep the external balance's contribution to headline growth positive. Nevertheless, we expect growth to slow from an annual average of 2.3% in 2017-19 to just above its potential rate in 2020-22, at 1.7%.
Downside risks to the economic outlook include a more protectionist US trade policy and a disorderly UK exit from the EU, although neither of these forms part of our core scenario. A further challenge is that the country's flagship industry, the automotive sector, risks being disrupted by technological change after a long-term emphasis on diesel technology. Over the longer term, Germany's poor demographic outlook will increasingly constrain potential growth, with the working-age population declining.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Services account for about 69% of GDP, industry (including construction) for 30% and agriculture the remainder. Manufacturing accounts for about 23% of gross value added-a considerably higher proportion than in most other industrialised economies. Moreover, in contrast with many of Germany's peers, manu-facturing's share of gross value added has remained broadly stable over the past two decades. Nevertheless, we expect industry's share of gross value added to edge down slightly in our 2018-22 forecast period, to just under 30% in 2022. A fall in the relative importance of manufacturing is the inevitable result of rising living standards: as people get wealthier they spend a higher proportion of their income on services and a lower pro-portion on manufactured goods. However, it also reflects the changing nature of manufacturing, as even Germany's industrial champions increasingly provide value added through services supplied in conjunction with manufactured products.
Strong industrial sector faces medium-term threats from new technology
Germany's most important manufacturing sectors are automotive, electrical and mechanical engineering, chemicals, and food, drink and tobacco. Germany is the global leader in the production of premium cars, an industry that has benefited from robust competition between several domestic companies, ownership structures that have enabled firms to make long-term investment, and a host of innovative supplier companies in the mechanical and electrical engineering sectors. Although many of the industry's main European markets experienced a weak recovery following the 2008-09 global financial crisis, sales in emerging markets such as China and India have been strong. As major producers of capital goods, German firms were able to weather the years following the global financial crisis by profiting from rapid industrialisation in emerging markets. Capital goods demand from within the euro zone has now started to recover, offsetting slower growth in many emerging markets.
Most industries derive competitive advantages from Germany's well-developed system of vocational training, good physical infrastructure and research base, and a tax system that encourages capital investment. German manufacturers will continue to profit from emerging-market demand, and the outlook for demand from other European countries should gradually improve further. Low interest rates will continue to stimulate residential construction, ensuring relatively strong growth in overall construction activity. However, from 2022 onwards we expect larger threats to the dominance of German industry to emerge, particularly to the automotive industry. New technologies, such as electric cars and self-driving cars, could pose challenges the industry's position, especially as it is still dealing with the fallout of the diesel-emissions scandal and the move away from diesel technology, in which it had invested heavily in recent decades.
The services sector is the largest component of GDP and comprises a broad range of activities, from retailing to financial services, logistics and healthcare. Services sector growth in Germany was relatively weak in the years following the global financial crisis, held back by subdued growth in household income. However, with the recent strong improvements in the labour market and the concurrent improving outlook for private consumption, services sector activity expanded relatively strongly in 2016-17 and we expect it to continue to do so in the coming years. One source of uncertainty is the financial services industry. In common with the rest of Europe, German financial services were hit hard by the economic downturn. Although solvency indicators have improved, many German banks remain vulnerable to the effects of any renewed shock. Furthermore, the sector has seen relatively little reform in recent years compared with regional peers. The weakness of the banking sector has the potential to restrict growth prospects over the forecast period. A possible upside risk is that some financial services activity may move from London to Frankfurt following the UK's departure from the EU. Although some relocations have already been announced, we expect these moves to remain relatively limited, and do not expect Frankfurt to take over London's role as Europe's main financial hub.
Agriculture contributes less than 1% of GDP, one of the lowest proportions in the EU. We expect this share to remain broadly unchanged throughout the forecast period as public- and private-sector investment continues to focus on other sectors of the economy.

Price growth rose to 1.7% in 2017, driven primarily by energy price base effects. Underlying inflationary pressures remain weak, but we expect wage growth to pick up soon, in part driven by a number of recently struck collective bargaining agreements that included significant pay rises for, among others, workers in the public and metals sectors. This will start feeding through into inflation in the course of this year. With only a modest further recovery in energy prices over 2018-22, we expect price growth to remain slightly below the ECB's target of "below, but close to, 2%", although relative economic out-performance will keep inflation above the euro zone average. We forecast average annual inflation in Germany of 1.7% in 2018-22.

For most of 2015-16 the euro moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1, before a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. However, in 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018 and has stabilised just below this level in March-April. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in the wake of the March 2018 general election in Italy-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.21:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. Thereafter we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.

Germany's sizeable current-account surplus declined slightly in 2017, to 8.1% of GDP, from a historical high of 8.9% in 2015, in part driven by a widening secondary income deficit as remittance outflows increased following several years of high immigration. Germany will continue to post huge trade surpluses, reflecting the competitiveness of its manufacturing sector and comparatively low levels of domestic consumption and investment. This will continue to generate large domestic savings that are mainly invested abroad, leading to a solid primary income surplus. Trade and primary income surpluses will comfortably outweigh small structural deficits on the services and secondary income accounts. We expect the current-account surplus to remain substantial, declining gradually to just above 6% of GDP by 2022. These large surpluses will continue to provoke criticism, within Europe and globally, about Germany's role in prolonging demand shortfalls in much of the rest of the euro zone.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Germany
Stocks and flows
Germany is an attractive destination for foreign investment, but on balance the country is a net exporter of long-term capital. The skills of its workforce, the availability of supplier companies, the quality of the research and innovation framework, and a reliable administrative and legal environment make Germany one of the most attractive destinations in the world for inward foreign direct investment (FDI). However, relative to GDP the stock of such investment is lower than in some other comparatively sized economies. Following a significant increase in inflows during the 1990s, the rate of growth of FDI then slowed, falling below the world average. The global financial crisis then reduced inflows to around a tenth of previous years' levels at the lowest point, in 2008. Inward foreign investment has since recovered, but outflows have continued to be larger than inflows. At end-2017 the inward FDI stock was equivalent to just under 45% of GDP, compared with around 90% for the EU as a whole.
Origin and distribution
As is the case in other developed countries, the FDI stock in Germany is increasingly dominated by service providers rather than by manufacturers, although manufacturers remain important, in line with the relatively large size of the manufacturing sector. Around three-quarters of Germany's inward FDI stock originates from other EU member states-although this sometimes includes investment from outside the EU that is transferred through countries such as the Netherlands and Luxembourg (the largest and second-largest foreign direct investors in Germany respectively), often for tax reasons. The most important investor from outside the EU is the US. Authorities and companies have become increasingly hesitant about increasing investment from China, which often targets mid-sized companies with significant technological knowhow. This is likely to weigh on investment from China in the coming years, as Germany has put its weight behind new investment screening measures at the EU level. Most outward investment is to other EU countries, but investment in Switzerland, the US, Russia and China is also significant.
Determinants
German labour costs are among the highest in the world, but have been made more competitive by a period of falling or stagnant growth in real wages over the past decade. A minimum wage was introduced in 2015, but has not had a significant effect on employment levels, reflecting at least in part the healthy state of the labour market. Regulations such as the right of worker representatives to sit on company boards (up to half of board members) have deterred some foreign investors, but in practice the system of workforce representation in companies often helps company management bodies to communicate their strategies and, where necessary, explain the need for changes in working practice-or even reduced pay in difficult circumstances. The tax environment remains, on balance, a downside. Foreign investors, including a rising number of private equity firms, are attracted by the large number of profitable medium-sized companies specialising in niche markets. Additional strengths are the country's good infrastructure, the generally high quality of the workforce, and strong research and innovation activity.
Impact
Foreign-owned companies employ about 2.5m people in Germany. Many FDI inflows take the form of acquisitions rather than greenfield investment, so that the immediate impact on employment is not clear (and in some cases has initially been negative). In industry, especially manufacturing, the dominance of German firms means that FDI has had only a limited impact. Although manufacturing made up 23% of gross value added in 2016, it represented just under 10% of the inward FDI stock. Foreign investment in Germany's services sector is likely to have had a larger impact on the domestic economy, boosting productivity via the introduction of new technology and less hierarchical organisational structures. Investment by private equity groups has also helped to inject capital and managerial expertise into slow-growing family-owned businesses.
Potential
Germany's skilled workforce and sound infrastructure make it a good location for specialised manufacturing. More generally, the structure of German industry is still relatively fragmented, providing foreign investors with the opportunity to participate in sectoral consolidation and to reap economies of scale through acquisitions. The generational changeover at the helm of many small and medium-sized companies provides opportunities for foreign investors, although in many cases foreign involvement is not appreciated. The still moderate level of property prices-by west European standards-and increasing demand for housing, especially in urban areas, may attract investors into this sector. A poor demographic outlook, with the population expected to go into decline by 2022, will constrain Germany's potential as a consumer market. Regulatory barriers to inward investment are likely to increase in the coming years, as political pressure to protect sensitive industries has increased in recent years and broadened from traditional strategic industries, such as defence, to high-tech industries, driven by the desire not to sell technology to future competitors. This is likely to happen both at the European and the domestic levels, and will increasingly lead to delays in approving projects, and larger numbers of rejections of takeovers.
