Germany's population fell in every year between 2002 and 2011, but high levels of net immigration underpinned population growth in subsequent years. The population reached 82.8m in 2017, up from 80.5m in 2012, boosted in particular by the impact of the migrant crisis in 2015. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the rise in the population will moderate in 2018-22, with the total stabilising at around 82.9m in 2022, before starting to decline.
The population has seen negative natural change ever since reunification
The population has recorded a natural decline in every year since German reunification, with the death rate higher than the birth rate, and this will continue to be the case in 2018-22. The birth rate plummeted after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, especially in East Germany. In 1991 830,019 births were recorded in Germany, but by 2011 this number had fallen to 662,685. More recently, this trend has reversed, with the fertility rate rising to 1.59 children per woman in 2016-the highest figure since 1973-reflecting both policy efforts, such as an expansion in childcare provision and parental benefits, and a higher fertility rate among immigrant communities. Nonetheless, this was still below the EU average of 1.6, and well below the replacement rate of 2.1.
The decline in the population in the early 2000s was caused not just by a fall in the birth rate, but also by negative net immigration. In total, the population contracted by 1%, or about 800,000 people, between 2002 and 2012. However, this trend has now also reversed, with population growth in 2012-17 coming from positive net immigration. This peaked in 2015 during the migrant crisis, when a sharp rise in inflows of migrants and refugees from conflict zones in the Middle East and North Africa were attracted to Germany in particular because of its strong economy and initially welcoming policy stance. However, the sheer volume of arrivals soon proved politically unsustainable, prompting a hardening of the government's position. The influx of migrants slowed in 2016, reflecting the closing of the Balkan route into the EU and an agreement between the EU and Turkey to halt migrants crossing illegally to the bloc from Turkey, brokered by Germany. We expect further deals to be agreed with other countries as needed to ensure that the experience of 2015 is not repeated.
The working-age population will continue to decline
This means that the demographic outlook will remain poor. As in the region more broadly, the population is ageing, with the old-age dependency ratio expected to rise over the forecast period and the working-age population already in decline. We expect the share of the population aged 15-64 to fall from 65.5% in 2017 to 63.9% in 2022. Although these shares remain higher than those in France, the UK or Italy, the rate of decline is faster. This is likely to lead to greater pressure on the pensions and healthcare systems. It will also exacerbate labour shortages, given robust economic activity at present in Germany and an increasingly tight labour market-Germany has the second-lowest unemployment rate in the EU. Efforts have already been made to attract more women and older workers into employment, but there will be diminishing returns from these over the forecast period. Policy innovation will also be needed to attract immigrants into the labour market, and in particular to integrate the recent arrivals from the Middle East and North Africa. Although the current economic upswing and a range of integration programmes are helping with this, full labour market integration is likely to be a long process.
Germany has the second-highest number of immigrants in the world, after the US, with more than 16m first- and second-generation immigrants. The largest groups in 2016 were from Turkey (which is double the size of any other group), Poland, Syria, Italy, Romania and Greece. Aside from a large inflow of migrants from the Middle East and the Balkans in 2015-16, the turnaround in net immigration since 2011 reflects a rise in the number of people migrating to Germany from Poland, Romania and Bulgaria, and to a lesser extent from crisis-hit members of the euro zone, such as Italy and Greece. The economic recovery currently under way across the bloc means that these inflows are now easing, but Brexit may result in some financial services staff moving to Germany, while other immigrations who would otherwise have gone to the UK may start to consider Germany as an alternative option.

Germany will remain the fourth-largest economy in the world in 2022
As measured by GDP at current exchange rates, Germany is the fourth-largest economy in the world, behind the US, China and Japan. According to The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts, this will still be the case in 2022, with German GDP standing at US$4.8trn. This is still significantly bigger than the fifth-largest economy in the world on this measure, the UK, which we forecast at US$3.3trn in 2022 (we expect the French economy to be worth US$3.2trn). Germany is the largest economy in Europe, and accounts for just over a fifth of total EU GDP. On a purchasing power parity (PPP) basis, which adjusts for differences in price levels between countries that are not always captured by market exchange rates, the German economy is the fifth largest in the world, behind India, the US, China and Japan.

Consumer demand will rise moderately over the forecast period
Germany is the largest consumer market in the EU in terms of population size. However, GDP per head is only the sixth highest in the EU, and the market for consumer goods is further reduced by an elevated savings rate, a cultural reluctance to buy on credit, the second-highest tax wedge as a percentage of labour costs in the OECD in 2017 (after Belgium) and a low proportion of national income accounted for by wages and salaries. Consumer spending played a relatively modest role in Germany's post-crisis recovery, with private consumption accounting for an average of only 0.1 percentage point of GDP growth in 2007-10, and 0.6 percentage points in 2011-14. However, it has become a more important driver of GDP growth more recently, in line with a strengthening of employment growth, as well as a temporary boost to real incomes from lower oil prices, increases to state pensions and the introduction of a minimum wage in 2015. Collective bargaining arrangements to increase wages in specific industries are now being agreed, and will feed into real earnings growth in 2018-22. This will support consumer spending; but with real personal disposable income forecast to rise by 1.3% per year in 2018-22 compared with 1.6% in 2013-17, demand is likely to moderate over the course of our forecast period.
The shift towards domestic-demand-driven growth in recent years is lending support to housing-related areas of the German economy, with a significant pick-up in house price growth since 2010. We expect this firmer trend in housing market activity to continue, and, combined with the rise in the number of single and two-person households-which now comprise three-quarters of the total-this will support sales of white goods. As in many countries, the profile of bricks-and-mortar retailing is changing owing to the strong growth of online shopping and consumers' increasing demand for convenience. E-commerce sales totalled an estimated EUR48.7bn in 2017, up by 10% from 2016, according to the German Retail Federation (HDE). Meanwhile, traditional mainstays such as bookshops, consumer electronics stores and household appliance chains are disappearing, and department stores are struggling to remain profitable. Reflecting the high market share of discounters, consumers will retain a strong price focus for staples, including food and clothing, but high-end income gains will also sustain demand for luxury goods.
Population ageing will influence spending patterns
Germany is a mature consumer market, but demographic trends will have an important influence on spending patterns over the next few years. The population is ageing, and, according to Germany Trade and Invest, people older than 50 years now account for over half of purchasing power. This brings with it a rising demand for age-related services, particularly in the health sector, and for products-for example, in the tourism industry-that cater specifically for the needs of the elderly. Meanwhile, the increasing awareness in the working-age population that the public pension system will not remain as generous as it is at present will boost demand for retirement savings products in the financial services industry.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: Germany has many attributes that are conducive to sustainable long-term growth, including a highly skilled workforce, good infra-structure and stable institutions. Its economic underperformance prior to the 2008-09 global financial slump was largely the result of deficient con-sumer demand, but also reflected supply-side rigidities in services. The situation in the labour market and wage dynamics indicate that the rebalancing towards consumption-driven growth is set to continue over a multi-year time horizon. The structural shift towards a more services-oriented economy still has further to go in Germany than in many other OECD members, owing to the relatively high share of the manufacturing industry in overall GDP. Growth in services is likely to come from areas connected with the manufacturing sector.
Demographic trends: The Economist Intelligence Unit expects negative demographic trends in the coming decades, with the total population set to shrink by 0.12% per year on average in 2018-50, and the working-age population set to decline at an even more rapid rate of 0.56% per year. The tightening of conditions for long-term unemployment benefits has increased the incentive to search for employment, and additional measures in the same direction are likely in the long term. The partial reversal of previous plans to raise the retirement age from 65 to 67 between 2012 and 2029 will add to demographic challenges, although we expect some relief to come from increased participation of older workers. Immigration from central and eastern Europe could make a modest contribution to alleviating labour shortages, and further liberalisation of immigration rules for highly skilled workers from non-EU countries is possible. The large-scale immigration from the Middle East and Africa seen in 2015 has provided a temporary boost for the demographic outlook, but integrating a significant percentage of the newcomers into productive parts of the economy is likely to be a process that spans decades.
External conditions: As an export-oriented country, Germany benefits from the broadly liberal world trade order. Generally, it suffers less than other developed countries (for example, Italy) from competition from emerging markets, such as China and India, owing to its specialisation in high-technology capital goods. This specialisation will also allow Germany to benefit from strong demand from these countries as they upgrade their capital stock. However, over the longer term German output will come under more pressure as manufacturers in emerging markets become more sophisticated and challenge German producers head on in high-end merchandise goods. Within the EU the liberalisation of trade in services should continue (albeit slowly). A worsening of the global trading environment and increased protectionism represent a significant risk to Germany, given its open economy.
Institutions and policy trends: Germany's low growth in the early 2000s focused the minds of politicians and policymakers on the need for economic reforms, many of which were implemented, along with more flexible bargaining about wages and other working conditions. Our expectation is that national and EU initiatives will continue to strengthen competition, but there is a risk that the recent loss of faith in market-based solutions will persist. Under the previous government there were already signs that the reforms that have underpinned strong growth in recent years were being partly reversed. Although the public finances are currently in a healthy state, further reform is needed to make them sustainable in the long term. Little movement in this direction, for instance via reform of the pension system, is currently in sight, and we expect policymaking to continue to be slow. This will start posing a drag on growth in the first half of our long-term forecast period.
Long-term performance: Our forecast of the economy's long-term average annual growth rate is 1.4%, with a slowdown from 1.6% in the first half of the forecast period (to 2030) to 1.2% in the second half. A contraction of the working-age population is a major driver of this weakening overall growth rate. Accordingly, the picture looks slightly more favourable on a per-head basis, with growth of real GDP per head averaging 1.5% throughout the forecast period, broadly in line with growth since reunification in 1990. GDP per head in 2050 will therefore be around US$141,380, marginally behind Norway and the Netherlands but ahead of Denmark and Finland. GDP per head in the UK and France will remain smaller, at US$112,250 and US$110,900 respectively. In terms of the size of the German economy overall, we expect it to be overtaken by India in the 2030s, making it the fifth largest in the world by 2050. Although productivity growth in Germany will be almost as strong as in the US, the less favourable demographic outlook means that the real economy will go from 22% the size of its US counterpart in 2017 to 18% in 2050.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Germany claims to be a global leader in tackling climate change, and its Energiewende, or energy transition, focuses on expanding renewables generation. This effort has been comparatively successful, with renewables accounting for 38% of the country's power supply in 2017, and rising to 42% in January-April 2018. However, Germany is still dependent on coal, one of the most polluting fossil fuels, which accounted for just over 40% of total power generation in 2017.
Germany is seeking to cut emissions by 40% from 1990 levels by 2020, 55% by 2030 and by at least 80% by 2050. These ambitious targets have been made more difficult by the 2011 decision to phase out nuclear power, a low-carbon source of energy that at the time accounted for over 20% of generation. Germany's emissions have fallen over the past decade, but only incrementally, with very modest cuts in emissions in the power sector largely negated by slight increases in other sectors, such as transport and manufacturing, and more recently by stronger economic growth.
Efforts to mitigate climate change, including by increasing the share of renewables in the country's energy mix, will remain a government priority over the medium to long term, and we expect public support to be maintained-even in the face of rising electricity prices. Germany's high technological level and self-perception as a global leader in this area will support progress in reducing emissions, and The Economist Intelligence Unit is cautiously optimistic about the long-term outlook, even if the 2020 target is likely to be missed.
The country's exposure to the impact of climate change, meanwhile, will remain comparatively low, given its geographical position-with limited coastal areas-and temperate climate. We expect the government to remain willing and able to provide the infrastructure upgrades necessary in the face of more extreme weather patterns in the future. However, the country's heavy reliance on exports-which we expect to reach 50% of GDP by 2020-and on imports means that supply-chain risk may increase as other countries on which it depends are affected.
Technological developments
Technological advancements will have a significant effect on Germany over the long term for a number of reasons. First, the share of manufacturing in GDP is much higher in Germany than in most other developed European countries, with industry accounting for just over 30% of the economy. According to the OECD, along with agriculture, manufacturing is the industry most exposed to automation globally. In general, the OECD found that jobs in Germany (as in central and eastern Europe, and Japan) were easier to automate than those in the UK, US, Nordic countries and the Netherlands.
Second, Germany is typically strong at research and development (R&D), and innovation, which could make a transition to higher automation rates both more likely and quicker. In 2016 Germany spent EUR1,125 per head on R&D, according to Eurostat, the fourth-highest level in the EU, and almost double the average for the bloc. In 2017 33,425 patents were filed in Germany, the fourth-highest level in the world after the US, Japan and China, according to the European Patent Office.
Third, Germany is already starting from a strong position. Of the countries looked at in a recent report by the International Federation of Robotics, Germany had the highest density of industrial robots in the manufacturing industry in Europe, and the third highest in the world after South Korea and Singapore. Germany's ratio of 309 industrial robots per 10,000 workers was more than double that of France (132). Its stock of industrial robots was 41% of the European total in 2016.
Germany is already working to increase automation and data exchange in manufacturing technologies as part of its Industry 4.0 strategy, and efforts to embed new technologies across the industrial sector will continue over the long term. This is likely to be disruptive for the automotive sector in particular, as e-mobility gains pace and autonomous vehicles are further developed, and as diesel technologies are gradually phased out. It is also likely to prove difficult for the Mittelstand, the often family-owned small and medium-sized enterprises found across the country that are central to Germany's manufacturing prowess, as they may struggle to acquire the digital skills needed to compete with new challengers. Efforts to make these firms more resilient to digital disruption will gain pace in 2018-50. Although the country will not supplant the US as a leader in innovation, adoption of new technology will be consistently strong.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
An early election in October 2017 was won by the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, who has since become chancellor at the head of a majority coalition government of the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to last a full term.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to significant tensions with other EU member states, as it did in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition. This is largely because of the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
We expect the new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. Significant structural reforms are unlikely due to low government cohesion.
We forecast that the government budget will remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the 2018-22 forecast period, as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to just above 67% by 2022, from an estimated 78.4% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 3.1% in 2017. We forecast a continuation of strong growth this year, at 2.5%, and for growth to moderate to 1.7% on average in 2019-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2018-22, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. We expect annual average EU harmonised inflation of 2% in 2018-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years, at about 2%. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain stable overall, at 2% of GDP on average in 2018-22, driven mainly by a strong surplus on the services balance, supported by tourism inflows.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's business environment score rises between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22), mainly owing to the improving economy. Austria's strengths as a business location include good infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2020-22: EU maintains focus on bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment continues to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure
Technological readiness
2018-19: Internet use remains slightly below regional peers, but research and development remains relatively high.
2020-22: Further progress is made on upgrading the large manufacturing sector to take advantage of new technologies.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government will focus on migration and integration issues, including in the EU context. It will also attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and implement other measures to improve the business environment, including through enabling more flexibility in the labour market.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: Trade relations are dominated by Germany, which accounts for about a third of total imports and exports. The current-account surplus is driven by strong tourism exports boosting the services surplus. We expect modest current-account surpluses throughout the forecast period.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
In May 2017, after several years of little progress on reforms, and coalition-as well as party-in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP, reformed the party around himself and moved it closer to the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) on issues such as immigration and integration. As a result, he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election on October 15th, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. The SPÖ's vote share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The FPÖ increased its share of the vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5% of the vote, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
In mid-December, after just over a month and a half of negotiations, the ÖVP and the FPÖ formed a coalition. Under Mr Kurz the ÖVP has moved closer to the FPÖ in many policy areas, and the negotiations thus went relatively smoothly. In order to assuage concerns from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Moreover, EU policy is handled by the chancellery instead of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is headed by an FPÖ appointee.
Although the chancellor is from the ÖVP, the election should still be seen as a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has, to a large extent, been replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties had together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, but a renewed grand coalition had become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between them and the reform gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz also owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP's and the FPÖ's programmes, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect the government to implement significant structural reforms, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, on which they are significantly less well aligned than they are on social and cultural matters. In addition, the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on topics such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals, owing in part to internal party upheaval. The initial phase of the government's term is likely to be relatively smooth, owing in part to the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union in the second half of 2018. Later in the term the FPÖ might struggle to distinguish itself from the ÖVP, which could lead to tensions between the parties, creating a moderate risk of an early election.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The last general election was held on October 15th 2017. Unless the government falls before then, it will sit in the Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament) until the end of its term in late 2022. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Three elections for state parliaments have already been held so far in 2018, with one more planned, in Salzburg. These tend to be fought on local issues and give only a limited view of national political developments. Nevertheless, the FPÖ's recent underperformance in Carinthia could push it to take stronger stances at the national level.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions, including the leading role that it played in closing the migration route through the Balkans. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this inflow, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. The new government plans to cut child benefit payments flowing abroad, potentially leading to tensions with eastern member states in particular.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that his government will be pro-EU, and that Austria's EU membership will not be questioned in the coming years. The government plans for Austria to be a leading voice in the bloc in the coming years, especially on migration reform, which should be facilitated by the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union. We expect the government to find broad support for proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the 1999 election led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, the reception has been more muted this time. At that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands. However, this will at times lead to tensions with fellow EU members, as shown by decreased intelligence sharing with Austria by a number of countries owing to the FPÖ heading the relevant ministries.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The new govern-ment plans to move integration and immigration policy further to the right, including through curtailing benefits for asylum-seekers and cutting child benefits sent abroad. It has also presented plans that focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing corporate tax rates and introducing more flexibility for working hours. Furthermore, it plans to cut a number of labour market programmes aimed at the long-term unemployed and integrating migrants into the labour market. However, it does not plan to reform the country's so-called Proporz system, under which the ÖVP and the SPÖ had apportioned public life-state companies, public services, subsidies, regulatory responsibilities-despite suggestions from both coalition parties in the past, especially from the FPÖ, that they would want to do this. We therefore expect reform momentum to be limited and for the government to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Driven by both a lacklustre recovery in the wake of the financial and euro zone crises, and by a lack of fiscal consolidation, the fiscal accounts have remained in modest deficit in recent years and within the 3% of GDP limit set by the EU. Strong growth contributed to a narrowing of the deficit to an estimated 0.7% of GDP in 2017.
The government plans to reach a small budget surplus in 2019 by cutting spending and at the same time reducing income taxes and the country's sizeable tax wedge. However, it has not yet clearly outlined the spending cuts that it intends to make, barring a number of smaller measures including cutting spending on asylum-seekers, and we therefore do not share the government's optimism that a surplus can be reached in 2019. Nevertheless, continued robust economic growth will contribute to a further narrowing of the deficit in the coming years; we expect it to average only 0.3% of GDP in 2018-22.
The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from an estimated 78.4% in 2017 to just above 67% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain worse than in peers such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low-interest-rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low, in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. However, the ECB's view of the outlook improved markedly during 2017 and, although it remains dovish, we expect a more upbeat tone to emerge this year, and an end to monthly asset purchases under the QE programme at the end of 2018. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate, to 0.25%, in early 2020, followed by five more rises that lift the main refinancing rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany. This was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltering reform process in recent years contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. However, the economic recovery gained significant momentum from the second half of 2016. Although in previous years the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, owing in part to a surge in employment in the manufacturing sector. We expect a continued gradual improvement in labour market indicators in the coming years. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.8% this year. Export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, real GDP growth was 3.1% in 2017-above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005 and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue this year, although we forecast slower growth, at 2.5%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to have largely been a one-off. In the following years we expect a further moderation of growth, to around its potential growth rate. Driven by the improvement of the labour market, domestic demand will be the main driver of growth. We expect average real GDP growth of 1.7% in 2019-22. Government policy is likely to be supportive of growth in the coming years, and the main risks are external. As a highly open economy, Austria is vulnerable to global economic developments, including any shocks to global trade in the case of a potential trade war between the US and the EU.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets, and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy price base effects fostered a gradual increase in inflation in 2017, leading to a full-year average of 2.2%. The recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect price growth to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors seen in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
For most of 2015-16 the euro moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1, before a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. However, in 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018 and has stabilised just below this level in March-April. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in the wake of the March 2018 general election in Italy-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.21:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. Thereafter we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in recent years, from a deficit in 2009-13. However, the increase in oil prices in 2017 pushed it back into modest deficit. We expect the trade account to remain around balance, but in deficit, throughout the forecast period. The main driver of the current-account surplus will therefore be the healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourist inflows. This will ensure that the current-account surplus remains broadly flat throughout 2018-22, at 2% of GDP on average.

Country Forecast Venezuela April 2018 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-venezuela-april-2018-updater/docview/2030004485/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: [...]neither path is likely to lend the regime international legitimacy and unlock the foreign financing needed to stabilise both the economy and PDVSA. [...]we believe that the most likely outcome is a "mixed administration", in which pragmatically minded military and PSUV leaders allow opposition participation as a way of gaining international legitimacy. [...]to gain international and local legitimacy, a mixed administration would have to restore civic freedoms and release political prisoners, something that the PSUV side may not abide; furthermore, if such steps are taken, they may increase instability. [...]wastefulness at state-owned firms and massive corruption and clientelism schemes built around the delivery of subsidised goods and services would be hard to roll back without antagonising administration backers, risking political instability. [...]we would expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA. [...]we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+April+2018+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2018-04-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The regime of the president, Nicolás Maduro, will strengthen its grip on power following the installation of a Constituent Assembly in 2017 and presidential elections, widely expected to be rigged, this coming May. However, economic collapse and the erosion of the patronage scheme supporting the government will put the regime's internal cohesion in jeopardy. We expect a traumatic rift that will end in regime pragmatists allowing opposition participation in a "mixed administration" as a way to remain in power from 2019 onwards. There is a risk that the regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,000% at the end of 2017 and will average over 10,000% in 2018. GDP will continue to contract in 2018-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

Venezuela is in 80th position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit business environment rankings for 2018-22, out of 82 countries covered, making it one of the least attractive investment locations in the world. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework adds to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. New government in 2019 removes exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Banks remain profitable, but monetary distortions and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2018-19: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies.
2020-22: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature. In August 2017 the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) installed a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government and a remit to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is how to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, we estimate that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 1.3% of GDP that year.
