Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Despite a decimated economy and spiralling hyperinflation, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) and the president, Nicolás Maduro, retain their hold on power. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition, most likely ushering in a government with nominal opposition participation-a "mixed administration"-in 2019.
The opposition, of which the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) is the biggest grouping, remains in disarray. Apart from infighting, this reflects the PSUV's systematic campaign to disfranchise opposition parties and sideline them from state institutions. After years of ineffectual leadership, most citizens, even those opposing the PSUV, distrust opposition parties. This has left them incapable of channelling the anti-government sentiment brewing in response to the country's dire economic situation.
In this context of unrest and repression, the PSUV is increasingly dependent on the military for support. In effect, a civic-military alliance runs the country. In addition to ideological sensibilities, the accord is sustained by opportunities for arbitrage and corruption schemes made possible by foreign-exchange controls; subsidised imports of basic goods; and control of large and inefficient public-sector companies. The ultimate source of resources flowing through this patronage train is PDVSA, the state-owned oil company, whose exports account for the vast majority of Venezuela's foreign-exchange inflows.
Jeopardising the arrangement is the fact that oil production is declining rapidly owing to mismanagement and underinvestment at PDVSA. Resultant strains have been exposed by purges of the military-the latest coming in March. Unless the administration turns PDVSA around (something we see as unlikely, as the government cannot finance the required investment), we believe that the patronage system supporting Mr Maduro will be at risk of collapse by late 2018 or early 2019.
What happens next is hard to predict, given the military's involvement in government and the opposition's weakness. The transition is likely to be violent. An outright military government is a possibility, as is internal re-organisation, with PSUV civilian figureheads fronting a military-heavy administration. However, neither path is likely to lend the regime international legitimacy and unlock the foreign financing needed to stabilise both the economy and PDVSA. Therefore, we believe that the most likely outcome is a "mixed administration", in which pragmatically minded military and PSUV leaders allow opposition participation as a way of gaining international legitimacy. Given the historical record, there should be no shortage of opposition figures willing to participate. Indeed, Henri Falcón-the only opposition figure of relevance running in the May 20th presidential election-is running on a "mixed administration" platform.
The election introduces the risk that our forecast "mixed administration" may be ushered into power before 2019. This is because the elections may trigger US sanctions on the oil trade. As the US is PDVSA's largest cash-paying market, such sanctions would hasten the erosion of the patronage regime. Similarly, arrears on bonded debt may lead to asset seizures in the US that impede trade, but the timing and extent of such seizures is uncertain, as no legal action has been started yet.
Regardless of its timing, our forecast shift to a mixed administration will face challenges. The PSUV's internal stability is a concern, as the end of the current regime is likely to unleash competition within the PSUV between factions that will jostle for prominence. Secondly, to gain international and local legitimacy, a mixed administration would have to restore civic freedoms and release political prisoners, something that the PSUV side may not abide; furthermore, if such steps are taken, they may increase instability. Although foreign financing should be forthcoming, it would underpin a macroeconomic programme that-by fixing the economy's distortions-would close avenues for corruption and upset regime insiders, another destabilising pitfall. Other hurdles of uncertain size will remain. These include the judiciary, the de facto legislature that is the Constituent Assembly, and the colectivos, a cross between PSUV paramilitaries and community organisers.
Overall, we expect a chaotic transition starting in late 2018 or early 2019. The process will be highly uncertain and may feature several false starts. We expect curtailed political stability in 2019-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Elections for the presidency and municipal and state legislatures are scheduled for May 20th. Most of the opposition are either banned or boycotting the elections in protest of the rigged electoral process. Mr Falcón, a former MUD and PSUV member, is courting regime pragmatists to facilitate his victory by offering a path to a "mixed administration" scenario, promising to secure international financing while simultaneously promising "national reconcili-ation".
However, Mr Falcón must secure international and local legitimacy in order to show regime pragmatists that he is a credible alternative to Mr Maduro, something that he is yet to do. Mr Falcón is rumoured to be enticing the rest of the opposition to abandon their boycott by offering to secure new electoral guarantees. We do not foresee success in those negotiations, as the current boycott stems from failed MUD-PSUV negotiations on electoral rules. However, further electoral postponements may take place, as the regime may fear further international sanctions following rigged elections. Following the installation of the "mixed administration", we expect an electoral timetable to be announced, as international financing will almost surely come with demands for democratic elections.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Most regional governments have denounced the Venezuelan government; the Summit of the Americas, held in the Peruvian capital, Lima, in April, brought further isolation, although it produced no concrete sanctions. The most effective sanctions have come from the US, which has instituted country-level sanctions that deny Venezuela the possibility of refinancing its debts. Oil sanctions are not part of our baseline assumption, but the new foreign policy team in the US introduces risks to this forecast, increasing the possibility of sanctions following the May 20th elections. A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia and China. Both have provided financing in the past, but seem unwilling to provide the several billions of dollars needed to stem the decline of oil output.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government remains unable and unwilling to undertake the policy changes needed to address its main challenges, namely declining oil production, spiralling hyperinflation and mounting arrears on external debt. Most sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including those of PDVSA) are now in arrears, but the government maintains it has not defaulted, despite calling for a debt restructuring. This appears impossible owing to US financial sanctions and, more fundamentally, because the government lacks a credible economic programme. There is no sign yet of lawsuits by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer the promise of late payment to lengthy legal battles. Investors may also be waiting for news of policy changes following the May election or a change in country leadership. In the meantime, the country remains open to legal challenges in the US. This is especially concerning in the case of PDVSA, as it could involve seizure of assets, including Citgo, a PDVSA subsidiary, which could impede exports, the regime's economic lifeline. In the meantime, the government must also grapple with a build-up of huge inflationary and currency depreciation pressures. Monetisation of large public deficits and dwindling exports has led to foreign currency rationing and hyperinflation. In line with our expectations, the government undertook a maxi-devaluation in February 2018, but monetary imbalances persist and foreign-exchange continues to be rationed. Economic policy will remain unsustainable, and ad hoc policy intervention and heavy state control of the economy will persist.
Under our baseline scenario of a "mixed administration", we expect more orthodox economic policies to be implemented. However, such an admini-stration would have considerable internal limitations in addressing key policy challenges. For example, wastefulness at state-owned firms and massive corruption and clientelism schemes built around the delivery of subsidised goods and services would be hard to roll back without antagonising administration backers, risking political instability. Thus, we would expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA.
We assume that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restruct-uring of the government's debt obligations. Meanwhile, PDVSA must open itself to foreign investment to secure the finance needed to bring output back on track. This will require considerable political capital, as it would imply a wholesale revision of the sector's institutional framework. Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV will remain a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending-off more radical party members, who would oppose accepting international assistance and reforming policy.
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. As a result, we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published data on fiscal accounts since 2011, when the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit was 12% of GDP. We forecast an NFPS deficit of 15.5% of GDP in 2018, which will be financed by printing money. High inflation and the overvalued official exchange make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2018-22 period, ending 2022 at 6.9% GDP.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's financing needs, forcing the BCV to print money. Money supply (M2) rose by 3,000% year on year in March. The government has announced that it will take three zeroes of the currency, but has not announced any change in policy. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation, and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Amid ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-20, following an estimated contraction of 13.9% in 2017. Our forecast recovery in 2021-22 rests on an assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF financial and institutional assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of the country's oil wealth at its centre. However, the reform programme will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we only expect a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of over 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract as well, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pickup in investment, which will be focused in the oil sector. Oil output-already in the midst of a long decline owing to mismanagement and underinvestment-has contracted beyond expectations in recent months; we now expect it to bottom out at 1.2m barrels/day (b/d) in early 2020, down from an average of 1.95m b/d in 2017. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from around 2019, oil production will start a recovery in the second half of 2020, but will remain below 2m b/d even at the end of our forecast period in 2022. Export volumes will only start to recover in 2021, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly has estimated that monthly inflation was 84% in January, bringing year-on-year inflation to over 4,000%. We expect inflation to average over 10,000% in 2018. There is a high risk of a hyperinflationary spiral in coming months that increases inflation to well above our current forecast and necessitates a dramatic adjustment, probably involving a resort to currency substitution.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
In February the government announced that the Dicom system, a heavily managed auction platform, would be used by both the private and public sectors. The news came with a massive currency devaluation, to BsF24,898:US$, from the previous BsF3,445:US$1. However, the government-which mono-polises the country's exports-has not supplied the auction system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange more or less impossible, even with the fast pace of depreciation. (The latest Dicom auction, held on April 5th, set the rate at BsF49,500:US$1). In this environment, the black-market foreign-exchange rate continues to weaken; it was at around BsF300,000:US$1 in early April.
Given the existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market and growing hyperinflation, the government may, as part of a stabilisation plan, introduce a new domestic currency or attempt some kind of currency substitution in the future. Under our current political assumptions, similar measures may be undertaken after 2019. The exact nature and implementation of the plan is hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We expect the current-account surplus to reach US$4.8bn in 2018 (2.1% of GDP at the distorted exchange rate, which overstates the GDP in dollar terms), owing to continued import compression. However, Venezuela's lack of access to foreign finance means that the current-account surplus will not be enough to meet the country's financing needs. Indeed, excluding arrears, we calculate that principal repayments of sovereign and state-owned companies' bonded debt alone will amount to US$3.5bn in 2018. As such, we expect further arrears in 2018 and 2019. By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following a debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored and imports will begin a recovery. We expect the current account to go into a deficit of 6.2% of GDP in 2020 at a less highly distorted exchange rate. Recovering oil production and the re-structured interest payment schedule facilitate a narrowing of the current-account deficit to 4.7% of GDP in 2022.
Assuming that a new administration is in power from around 2019, we expect financial and investment inflows to provide sufficient financing, stabilise balance-of-payments dynamics and help to rebuild reserves coverage. This will buttress the stability of the external accounts and facilitate the gradual removal of foreign-exchange controls, narrowing the gap between official and parallel exchange rates. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to anticipating a mixed administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on a substantial assistance package from the IMF, the quick imple-mentation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process within 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-22, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Country Forecast Turkey April 2018 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-turkey-april-2018-updater/docview/2030004483/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: First phase of third airport in Istanbul, the capital, becomes operational. A presidential system of government will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Turkey's involvement in the conflict in neighbouring Syria will continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where they are co-operating but have been pursuing contrasting goals. [...]the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to 1.5% in 2017.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Turkey is due to hold municipal elections in March 2019 and parliamentary and presidential elections in Novem ber of that year. However, these elections could be held earlier than scheduled, even in 2018, if the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his Justice and Development Party (AKP) believe that they have sufficient support to win, or if economic headwinds start to pose a risk to their electoral dominance.
After the presidential and parliamentary elections an executive presidency will replace the current parliamentary system of government. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. The new system provides few checks on the president's powers, moving Turkey closer to one-man rule. Since the failed coup in 2016 there has been a deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a complete rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high.
The AKP has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that period political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised. We now expect that the Turkish authorities will accept a much weaker path for the lira than we expected previously, at least during the first half of the forecast period (2018-22), with consequently higher inflation, larger fiscal deficits and smaller current-account deficits.
We expect annual budget deficits to widen moderately, to 2.9% of GDP on average in 2018-19 (from 2.4% previously), before narrowing gradually after the elections, to 1.8% of GDP in 2022 (from 1.6% previously). The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth from 7.3% in 2017 to a still robust 4.4% per year on average in 2018-22 (4.1% previously), reflecting higher taxes, which will offset the impact of stimulus measures. Our growth forecast assumes that domestic political conditions will stabilise and foreign investor confidence in Turkey will hold up, maintaining foreign capital inflows.
We expect the current-account deficit to remain broadly unchanged in 2018 at 5.7% of GDP, before narrowing to a still large 4.9% per year in 2019-22 (5.2% previously). This will make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is severely constrained and investor confidence deteriorates.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but in the global rankings the country falls by 11 places, to 60th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, are introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2018-19: Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey not to raise interest rates continues. Risk of the US imposing fines on several Turkish banks over alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran.
2020-22: Banking system remains stable, despite weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: First phase of third airport in Istanbul, the capital, becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Spending on research and development remains moderate at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2020-22: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (in 1949) and NATO (in 1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (in 1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. A presidential system of government will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence from the government. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) came to US$166bn and imports (fob) to US$224bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn-a sharp widening from US$41bn in 2016. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Turkey is due to hold municipal elections in March 2019 and parliamentary and presidential elections in November that year. However, the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling, religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) could hold them earlier than scheduled, even in 2018, if they believe that they have sufficient support to win, or if economic headwinds start to pose a risk to their electoral dominance. After these votes an executive presidential system of government will replace the current parlia-mentary system. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, will win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. The constitutional reforms to establish a presidential system, which were approved in a referendum in April 2017, provide few checks and balances on the powers of the president. This will further weaken Turkey's democratic institutions and governance structures, effectively moving the country into a system of one-man rule by Mr Erdogan. Although an unlikely prospect, failure by Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the elections could throw the political system into chaos and open up irreparable divisions in the AKP.
We expect social and political tensions to remain high until the elections in 2019, and possibly beyond. The narrow presidential reform referendum victory, amid allegations of vote tampering, has further polarised the country. It also raised concerns among the AKP's leaders that Mr Erdogan and his party were losing support. With the president's political future dependent on clear victories in all three elections, the government will continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, using the state of emergency law. Emergency rule was initially introduced after the failed coup to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. We expect emergency rule to remain in place until after the elections, because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place. The politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence from the government.
The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup appear to have eased to a large extent, but security risk remains high. Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK are interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1980s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria are seeking to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK, but risk further fuelling the conflict with the PKK in Turkey's south-east. The defeat of IS in Syria and Iraq could result in renewed attacks in Turkey and elsewhere.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
As things stand, we expect Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the next presidential and parliamentary elections and to remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. The opposition is fragmented, Mr Erdogan's popularity is still unrivalled and he has the support of the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Importantly, the AKP also has the ability to control the election process. However, there are concerns within the AKP that the party has lost support since the referendum, and that a victory for Mr Erdogan in the presidential election is far from assured, especially if Abdullah Gul, a former president and co-founder of the AKP, decides to run. The challenge of Mr Gul, combined with that of the charismatic Meral Aksener-who recently formed the Good Party (IP), a breakaway group from the MHP-and the leader of the main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), Kemal Kilicdaroglu, could prevent Mr Erdogan from reaching the 50% threshold for victory in the first round. This would transform the second-round run-off between Mr Erdogan and the candidate with the second-largest share of votes into a deeply polarising referendum on Mr Erdogan's leadership.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the decision of the MHP leadership to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. The HDP risks falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation. This would boost the AKP's seat share. Support for the MHP has also fallen, but in exchange for the MHP's backing of Mr Erdogan in the presidential election, the two parties have agreed an electoral alliance to ensure that the MHP retains its representation in parliament. Under the constitutional changes approved in the referendum there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. There is a considerable risk of a rupture in Turkey's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding these allies' concerns that under Mr Erdogan the country is pivoting eastwards. Many factors have contrib-uted to the deterioration, including political upheaval in Europe and the US; a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; the US's military backing of PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; the Turkish govern-ment's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; tensions over gas exploration in the Eastern Mediterranean; and Turkey's forging of closer relations with Russia, China and Iran. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of the country's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals, notably to become president with executive powers after the next elections, due in 2019.
Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and increasingly transactional rather than strategic, but we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a complete breakdown in relations. However, this might become unavoidable if the EU suspends the country's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, the US imposes sanctions on Turkey over alleged violations by Turkish banks of US sanctions against Iran, Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces, or it withdraws from NATO, none of which can be ruled out completely. Operation Olive Branch, Turkey's cross-border military operation in Afrin in north-western Syria that was launched in January 2018, has accentuated tensions with the US. The operation cleared the area of US-backed, PKK-affiliated Kurdish groups that are intent on establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey.
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in neighbouring Syria will continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where they are co-operating but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period (2018-22). These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short-term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region have already put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, fuelling an acceleration in inflation and increasing the cost to firms of servicing their foreign debt. Under political pressure not to raise interest rates further, especially ahead of the 2019 elections, the Central Bank of Turkey is constrained in its ability to tighten monetary policy. We now expect that the Turkish authorities will accept a much weaker path for the lira than we expected previously, at least during the first half of the forecast period, with consequently higher inflation, larger fiscal deficits and smaller current-account deficits.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards fiscal loosening and relatively tight monetary policy, although these are unconventional measures, at the same time as encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-have given the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy in the aftermath of the attempted coup in July 2016. As a result, the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to 1.5% in 2017. Despite a series of tax increases this year, we expect increased government spending on defence, security, infrastructure projects and public employment ahead of the elections next year to cause the deficit to widen further, to an average of 2.9% of GDP in 2018-19 (2.4% of GDP previously), before narrowing to 1.8% in 2022 (1.6% previously). We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to remain broadly stable at 28-29% in 2018-20, before declining gradually to about 27% in 2022. Our baseline forecast is predicated on the assumption that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and to prevent a surge in domestic demand from causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. However, the risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances has increased, reflecting the impact of political instability ahead of the next elections.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The central bank will have to keep its monetary policy tight in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility, higher US interest rates and balance sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). However, because of political pressure not to raise interest rates further, we expect the Central Bank of Turkey to have to resort to unorthodox and less effective tools to respond to the challenge, which will periodically test investor confidence in the bank's policy stance. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, but since November 2017 it has focused on using its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate to fund the banking system. This rate was gradually raised by a total of 275 basis points in 2017, to 12.75% in mid-December, pushing the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system to 12.75% since January 2018, compared with 7.8% in November 2016.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply, from an annual average of 3.3% in 2016 to 7.3% in 2017, supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. We expect growth to slow to an annual average of 4.4% in 2018-19 (revised up from 4.3% previously), reflecting the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates and a gradual tightening of global liquidity, which will offset planned stimulus measures to boost employment and investment. The main downside risk is that further political instability stemming from the transition to a presidential system of government will deter foreign capital inflows. Upside risk stems from further government stimulus measures, but this could also result in larger than expected fiscal deficits.
We are forecasting that household consumption growth will moderate from 6% of GDP in 2017 to a still solid 3.9% per year in 2018-22 as a result of higher interest rates and slower employment growth. We expect government consumption growth to accelerate from 5% in 2017 to an annual average rate of 5.8% in 2018-19, easing after the elections to a more moderate, but still robust, 4.8% in 2020-22.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup and an increase in the corporation tax rate to 22% from 2018 will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure, generating real growth of 5.5% per year in 2018-19. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration to annual growth of 4.8% per year, reflecting public-sector retrenchment and firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
The lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey (especially in the tourism sector), the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and strong external demand have contributed to a rebound in exports of goods and services. However, we expect growth to slow from 11.9% in 2017 to an annual average rate of 4.7% in 2018-22, reflecting base effects and our view that 2017 probably represented the recent peak in the global trade cycle. Our expectations of a steady weakening of the lira during the forecast period will dampen import growth.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target. Reflecting the political constraints on the ability of the central bank to tighten monetary policy further, continued weakness of the Turkish lira and recovering global commodity prices, we have raised the path of our consumer price inflation forecast to remain above the official medium-term target of 5% throughout the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank does not loosen monetary policy too soon, we expect inflation to ease gradually, to 6.5% by end-2022. There are significant upside risks to our revised forecast if the lira depreciates much more rapidly than we are now forecasting.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
We have revised our exchange-rate forecast for 2018-22. We now expect the lira to average TL4.79:US$1 in 2022 (TL4.26:US1 previously), compared with TL3.65:US$1 in 2017. Nevertheless, after a fall in the nominal value of the lira of about 17% against the US dollar in 2017, we expect the pace of depreciation to slow, keeping the currency broadly stable in real terms during the forecast period. There are substantial risks to this forecast in both directions, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
The moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports has offset the boost to Turkey's main exports from a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions. Owing to particularly large trade deficits at the end of 2017 and in early 2018, we expect the current-account deficit to widen slightly from 5.6% of GDP last year to 5.7% of GDP this year. However, moderating capital inflows will keep the lira weak and interest rates relatively high, contributing to a slowdown in import demand and a consequent narrowing of the current-account deficit during the forecast period. Turkey's substantial external financing needs will be difficult to meet if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates further. We expect the rebound in tourist arrivals in 2017 to continue, but it will remain vulnerable to a possible resurgence of terrorist attacks in the country.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Following a snap general election in June 2017, in which the Conservative Party lost its parliamentary majority, the prime minister, Theresa May, formed a minority government based on a "confidence and supply" agreement with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP). The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect it to last a full five-year term; its working majority of 13 (down from 17 before the election) will be eroded by by-elections, and it will face domestic and external challenges during the Brexit process.
Mrs May will continue to face difficulties in reconciling opposing factions in her cabinet, who have very different views about negotiating the UK's future relationship with the EU. An important milestone in the Brexit negotiations came in March 2018 when EU leaders approved the terms of the transition period, which will last for 21 months from when the UK leaves the EU in March 2019. However, divisions in the cabinet and on the Conservative backbenches over Brexit are likely to persist in 2018-19.
Completing the agreement on the terms of the UK's withdrawal will take priority in 2018, but talks on the future trading relationship will begin this year. The government intends to leave the single market and the customs union, and will aim to reach a comprehensive free-trade agreement with the EU. We expect a trade deal to be in place by 2021.
The economy has been resilient in the wake of the Brexit vote, growing by 1.9% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017, but is likely to lose momentum in 2018-19 as rising inflation and uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations dampen domestic demand. We forecast average annual real GDP growth of 1.5% in 2018-19, picking up to an average of 1.8% per year in 2020-22.
The government's budget deficit has narrowed from 4.3% of GDP in 2015, to an estimated 2.9% of GDP in 2017. We expect a further gradual decline in 2018-22, with the deficit contracting to 1.5% of GDP in 2022. The Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) has signalled a readiness to raise interest rates again after doing so in November 2017 for the first time in a decade, and we expect the next increase to happen by August 2018.

The UK's business environment score improves in 2018-22 compared with 2013-17, lifting the country by five places in the global ranking and by four places in the regional ranking. Brexit introduces policy uncertainty, but the UK's strengths-a pro-business policy orientation, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, and flexible labour and product markets-will endure.
Country forecast overview: United Kingdom's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Lloyds, one of two banks rescued post-crisis by the state, returns to private ownership; government retains big stake in struggling Royal Bank of Scotland. Brexit focus constrains reforms to improve weak trends in investment and productivity.
2020-22: Shake-up of regulatory and competition frameworks post-Brexit. Continued state support underpins house prices.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Government pursues policies to encourage foreign direct investment inflows.
2020-22: Infrastructure plans offer investment opportunities. Likely changes in tax policies to bolster inward investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Talks begin on post-Brexit UK-EU free-trade agreement. UK leaves EU single market (and probably customs union). Possible disruption to crossborder trade. Risk of no deal, with UK subject to World Trade Organisation (WTO) trade rules.
2020-22: Terms of new UK-EU trading arrangement phased in.
Taxes
2018-19: Gradual rise in total tax burden, further reduction in corporate tax rate. Changes to system of business rates.
2020-22: Ongoing efforts to reduce revenue lost to tax evasion. Possible tax increases to support the public finances.
Financing
2018-19: Modest tightening in financial conditions likely in run-up to Brexit. Loose monetary policy persists. "Ring-fencing" bank reforms and ongoing capital strengthening (ahead of 2019 deadlines). Demand for alternative forms of debt financing.
2020-22: Availability of finance unchanged. Possible loss of "passporting" rights and restrictions on EU services trade.
The labour market
2018-19: Firms defer some hiring decisions amid Brexit uncertainty. Possible modest decline in inflows of EU workers. New apprenticeship levy and phased increase in compulsory "national living wage". Wage growth remains subdued.
2020-22: Some form of restrictions on free movement of labour from EU, but likely to be flexible in response to business concerns. Policymakers struggle to respond to weak productivity and deficit in intermediate skills.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Modest rise in spending on housing, roads and digital infrastructure. Crossrail service in London begins operating.
2020-22: Construction of high-speed rail link between London and the north of England. EU-funded investment falls.
Technological readiness
2018-19: UK performs well in research, innovation, new technology adoption, lags somewhat in cyber-security preparation.
2020-22: The research and development (R&D)/GDP ratio remains the same; innovation performance good, full commercial potential unrealised.

Background: The end of the second world war coincided with the decline of the UK as an imperial power. Residual links with former colonial territories, close relations with the US and a separate sense of identity delayed UK membership of the European Community (now the EU) until 1973. Successive governments have resisted closer EU integration. In a referendum in June 2016 the UK electorate voted to leave the EU. The future contours of the UK's relationship with the EU are uncertain, but a diminution of UK influence in the region looks inevitable.
Political structure: The UK is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state is Queen Elizabeth II. Parliament has an elected House of Commons (the lower house, 650 seats) and a non-elected House of Lords (the upper house, non-fixed membership of about 800). The general election in June 2017 produced a minority centre-right Conservative Party government, dependent on the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) for a working majority. The main opposition Labour Party increased its parliamentary seats by 30 in the June 2017 snap general election, but its ability to compete with the Conservatives will be undermined when the government redraws parliamentary constituency boundaries, which are currently favourable to Labour.
Policy issues: UK economic policy has yet to return to normal after the financial crisis, with an exceptionally loose monetary stance. Real GDP growth slowed in 2015-16. The fallout from the Brexit vote will dominate the policy agenda; The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to focus efforts on negotiating the terms of its departure from the EU and on reducing the damaging effect on the economy of the uncertainty created by the vote. This has led to a shift in the UK's monetary and fiscal policy mix, with fiscal policies becoming more significant. Managing Brexit could force policymakers to address structural deficiencies in the UK, such as weak productivity.
Taxation: The headline rate of corporation tax has been steadily reduced, from 28% in 2010 to 20% since April 2015. There are three bands of personal income tax, set at 20%, 40% and 45% (the 45% rate came into effect in April 2013, replacing the 50% rate that was introduced in 2010). The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 20% (raised from 17.5% in 2011). Excise duties on tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe.
Foreign trade: In 2016 exports of goods totalled US$408.1bn and imports amounted to US$591bn, resulting in a trade deficit of US$182.9bn. The traditional services surplus fell to US$127.8bn. The overall current-account deficit widened in absolute terms, to US$154.9bn, from US$149.8bn in 2015, and expanded as a share of GDP, to 5.8%, from 5.2%.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The decision of the prime minister, Theresa May, to call an early general election in June 2017 backfired disastrously for the Conservative Party, which lost its majority. Mrs May has recently recouped some authority through her handling of the nerve agent attack on a former Russian military intelligence officer, Sergei Skripal, and his daughter Yulia on March 4th 2018. The prime minister blamed Russia, rallied the UK's international allies and expelled 23 Russian diplomats from the embassy in London. However, the positive political boost for the prime minister may prove to be short-lived.
Mrs May will continue to face difficulties in reconciling opposing factions in the cabinet, who have very different views about negotiating the UK's future relationship with the EU. An important milestone in the negotiations came on March 22nd when EU leaders approved the terms of the transition period, which will last for 21 months from when the UK leaves the EU in March 2019. However, divisions in the cabinet and on the Conservative backbenches over Brexit are likely to persist in 2018-19.
Brexiteers in the cabinet have been supportive of Mrs May since the election because they want her to hold fast to her pledges to leave the single market, the customs union and the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ). This faction includes the Brexit secretary, David Davis; the international trade secretary, Liam Fox; the environment minister, Michael Gove; and the foreign affairs minister, Boris Johnson. They will support the prime minister as long as she pursues their vision of Brexit. However, Mrs May is also under pressure from those advocating a "softer" Brexit, who favour an extended post-2019 transition period, during which the UK would retain single market and/or customs union access. This group includes the chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond, and the home secretary, Amber Rudd, as well as Mrs May's adviser on Europe, Oliver Robbins. These divisions could sharpen, presenting a threat to government stability in 2018.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
A snap general election was held on June 8th 2017, three years ahead of schedule. Mrs May's decision to call the election was a political miscalculation, resulting in the Conservatives losing 13 seats, leaving them with 318 seats in the 650-seat House of Commons (the lower house of parliament). The Labour Party won 30 seats in a swing of almost 10 percentage points from the 2015 election, giving it 262 parliamentary seats. The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which increased its share of parliamentary seats from eight to ten, became kingmaker.
The Conservatives formed a working government, based on a "confidence and supply" arrangement with Northern Ireland's DUP. This arrangement is likely to work in the short term, because neither party wants another election-they are natural allies on questions of sovereignty and the EU, and the DUP is committed to preventing the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, from coming to power given his past association with Northern Ireland's main nationalist party, Sinn Fein. However, the arrangement is politically fragile, and the government's 13-seat working majority (down from 17 seats before the election) will dwindle with each by-election.
The Conservatives and Labour remain more or less neck and neck in recent opinion polls, on about 40-41%. Labour has lost some of the momentum from the 2017 general election, and has been damaged by persistent evidence of anti-Semitism in the party. The next general election is scheduled for May 2022. Lacking a parliamentary majority and divided over Brexit, the government will do well to last until then, and there is a risk of another pre-term election. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Conservative Party to see through the Brexit negotiations in 2018-21 before contemplating changing the party leadership and risking precipitating another early general election, for which there is no appetite at present.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
In line with the government's intention to honour the Brexit vote by taking control of laws, borders and the budget, the UK will formally leave the single market at the end of the Article 50 process in March 2019. In February 2018 UK and EU negotiators reached agreement on large parts of the draft withdrawal agreement that must be finalised by the autumn. This included agreement on the terms of the transition period, which will last for 21 months after the UK's formal withdrawal from the EU at end-March 2019. EU leaders approved the terms of the transition period at a summit on March 22nd-23rd. There is a risk that a clash between the EU and the UK on the Irish border issue could scupper the withdrawal agreement, but this is not our forecast.
Agreement was reached in many areas, including on citizens' rights, the financial settlement, Euratom and on most areas relating to separation provisions (the continued circulation of goods placed on the market and customs procedures). There is also full agreement on the terms of the transition period-the UK will maintain access to the single market, but will be bound by the obligations of membership. The UK made several concessions that are unpalatable to Brexiteers: EU law will still be applicable; EU budget contributions will continue; the UK will have no say over fishing quotas; and there will be reciprocal free movement and subsequent entitlement to settled status until the end of the transition period. A win for the UK is that it will not be bound by the EU's trade policy, allowing it to agree new trade deals during the transition.
Despite political pressure to stay in the EU customs union, the UK government's official line is that it will leave to pursue an independent trade policy. However, we expect some degree of regulatory alignment that will mean less new physical and technological infrastructure at border areas that might otherwise have been required outside the customs union. The government is likely to seek a complete alignment of regulations in some areas; "mutual recognition" sufficient to sustain trade flows in others; and divergence in other areas where the country would like to set its own regulations.
Negotiations on trade will come with their own set of challenges, as competing interests among the member states will complicate the process. During trade talks the EU will resist attempts by the UK to cherry-pick from the benefits of membership, but the end result is likely to be a more comprehensive trade deal than that negotiated by the EU and Canada in 2016.
There are numerous obstacles to the successful conclusion of the negotiations, but we believe that compromises will make a deal possible, particularly given the economic incentive to maintain existing trade ties. Realistically, only the framework of a trade deal will be agreed by the time the UK withdraws in 2019, as completing the withdrawal agreement will take priority in 2018. However, transition arrangements will allow negotiations to continue, and we expect a deal to be in place by 2021.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The UK's departure from the EU will encourage policymakers to address some of the structural deficiencies that have held back the economy in recent years, including lacklustre productivity growth, insufficient innovation and poor infra-structure. Mr Hammond announced a National Productivity Investment Fund to boost the UK's digital infrastructure and spending on research and develop-ment over the next five years. Proposals to reform the UK's housing market have focused on introducing greater speed and flexibility into the planning process. There will also be a new effort to improve vocational skills. We expect these measures to support the recovery in productivity, but they are still too modest in size and scope to close the UK's productivity gap with its G7 peers.
The Queen's Speech in June 2017 set out the government's legislative agenda, which was dominated by Brexit. Eight of the 27 bills relate to the transfer of EU law into British law, a UK customs regime, independent trade policy, controls on immigration, fisheries policy, agricultural policy, nuclear safeguards and the UK's ability to impose international sanctions. In a further sign that Brexit is the government's priority, the parliamentary session will last for two years rather than one, ending two months after the UK's withdrawal at end-March 2019.
The centrepiece of the autumn budget in November 2017 was a sizeable increase in spending on the National Health Service (NHS). In March 2018 Mrs May said that the government would this year draw up a "long-term funding plan" to secure the future of the NHS.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In the spring statement, delivered on March 13th, Mr Hammond presented slightly upgraded forecasts for GDP growth and the public finances compared with the autumn budget in November 2017. The government is on track to meet its "fiscal mandate" of a deficit smaller than 2% of GDP by 2020/21, implying some scope for higher public spending in the autumn budget statement.
We estimate that the budget deficit stabilised at 2.9% of GDP in 2017, and we expect it to narrow to 2.7% in 2018. In the remainder of our forecast period the government will aim to nudge down discretionary spending as a proportion of GDP. We expect the deficit to contract to 1.9% of GDP by 2020 and 1.5% by 2022. We forecast that public debt will peak at 88.1% of GDP in 2018, before falling to 81% by the end of 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
At its meeting in March 2018 the monetary policy committee (MPC) of the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) voted to keep the main policy interest rate unchanged at 0.5%, five months after raising it by 25 basis points for the first time in a decade. Seven members of the nine-strong committee supported this position, with two members voting to increase the policy rate by 25 basis points to 0.75%. The MPC is keen to begin normalising its policy rate and we now expect the timing for the next BoE rate rise to occur in May or August, rather than in the fourth quarter of 2018. We expect a gradual tightening cycle to follow, with a series of 25-basis-point increases in the policy rate over the next five years, taking it to 2.25% by end-2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
The economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. Average annual real GDP growth was firm in 2016 and 2017, at 1.9% and 1.8% respectively. However, the annual pace of growth slowed throughout 2017, from 2.1% in January-March to 1.4% in October-December. We forecast a further modest growth slowdown in the next two years, to 1.5% on average in 2018-19, led by a deceleration in domestic demand.
A looser fiscal stance will provide some positive support to real GDP growth throughout the forecast period, but consumer spending will weaken in response to the continued squeeze on household disposable incomes from falling real wages. Consumer spending was fairly resilient to this pressure in 2017, reflecting employment gains, high levels of household borrowing and a sharp drawdown of savings. In 2018 we expect employment growth to slow and greater uncertainty about the economic outlook to push up precautionary savings. Consumer spending will recover in 2019-22 as inflation eases, uncertainty recedes and unemployment edges lower. However, increased borrowing costs arising from tighter monetary policy will hold back the pace of the recovery in these years. We forecast that investment spending will decelerate in 2018-19 as a result of heightened uncertainty during difficult Brexit trade negotiations and higher cost pressures as a result of sterling's depreciation, before recovering in 2020-22 as these effects fade.
Survey-based indicators suggest that preliminary GDP data for the first quarter of 2018 will confirm a picture of relatively firm activity when it is released on April 27th. Also mitigating the extent of the domestically driven slowdown in 2018 will be a positive contribution to GDP growth from the external balance as export volumes benefit from a competitiveness boost as a result of sterling's depreciation, while the weaker domestic demand environment reduces import growth. The export boost will ease in 2019, after which we expect the trade balance to exert a drag on GDP growth owing to our forecast for a recovery in domestic demand, which will push up import growth again. Our expectation of a business cycle downturn in the US in 2020 and a deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU, which should take effect in 2021 and result in looser trade ties than before, will also constrain exports in 2020-22. We expect real GDP growth to pick up to 1.8% on average in those years.
Trade policy is the biggest risk to our forecast for economic growth globally. In March the US announced new tariffs on steel and aluminium imports; a number of countries, including the EU, received an exemption. This expires on May 1st and there is a risk that if the US lets it expire and applies tariffs to EU exports, the bloc could retaliate with tariffs of its own, leading to a broader trade conflict.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
The headline rate of annual inflation-as measured by the consumer price index including owner occupiers' housing costs (CPIH)-accelerated to 2.6% on average in 2017, up from 1% in 2016. The increase partially reflected a rebound in oil prices, but has been amplified by the sharp depreciation of sterling since the Brexit vote. The pound has since reversed much of this appreciation, but we expect it to weaken again in 2018-20, and oil prices are likely to rise further this year. As retailers continue to pass on high input costs to customers, we expect inflation to remain above the BoE's official 2% target for much of 2018, averaging 2.4%, even as domestic price pressure weakens. Tighter monetary policy from 2019 will bring inflation back towards the bank's target; we forecast that inflation will ease to 1.9% next year and 2.1% on average in 2020-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
There was a sharp drop in the external value of sterling after the Brexit vote. Sensitivity in the foreign-exchange markets to the Brexit news flow led to significant volatility in the value of the pound in 2017, although it appreciated in the second half of the year. An increase in political risk in the US in January 2018 triggered a surge in the US dollar:pound exchange rate to a post-referendum high of US$1.43:£1. The exchange rate has since receded a little from this level, but we forecast that it will average US$1.40:£1 this year, after averaging US$1.29:£1 in 2017. This forecast reflects the recent resilience in the pound (partly because of the performance of the economy), but also assumes that it will weaken as Brexit negotiations enter their most challenging phase and as the economy slows. We expect sterling to depreciate slightly against the US dollar and the euro in 2018-20, before recovering in 2021-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
The merchandise trade balance will keep the current account in deficit through-out 2018-22, offsetting surpluses on the services account. We expect a narrowing of the current-account deficit, from an estimated 4.6% of GDP in 2017 to 4.3% in 2022 (following a current-account deficit of 5.8% of GDP in 2016), reflecting a shift in the primary income balance as the under-performance of the UK economy reduces income debits (the return that foreign residents receive on their investments in the UK) relative to credits (the return that UK residents receive from their foreign direct investment), and a reduction in secondary transfers from 2021 as the UK reduces its contribution to the EU budget.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
An early election in October 2017 was won by the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, who has since become chancellor at the head of a coalition government of the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ).
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to significant tensions with other EU member states, as it did in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition. This is largely because of the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, low government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
We forecast that the government budget will remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2018-22), as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to just below 70% by 2022, from an estimated 79.5% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 3.1% in 2017. We forecast a continuation of strong growth this year, at 2.5%, and for growth to moderate to 1.7% on average in 2019-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2018-22, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16 and 2.2% in 2017. We expect annual average EU harmonised inflation of 2% in 2018-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years, at about 2%. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain stable overall, at 2% of GDP on average in 2018-22, driven mainly by a strong surplus on the services balance, supported by tourism inflows

Country forecast overview: Business environment rankings

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's business environment score rises between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22), mainly owing to the improving economy. Austria's strengths as a business location include good infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2020-22: EU maintains focus on bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment continues to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure
Technological readiness
2018-19: Internet use remains slightly below regional peers, but research and development remains relatively high.
2020-22: Further progress is made on upgrading the large manufacturing sector to take advantage of new technologies.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government will focus on migration and integration issues, including in the EU context. It will also attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and implement other measures to improve the business environment, including through enabling more flexibility in the labour market.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.7bn and the goods import bill was US$142.3bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$12.2bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 2.1% of GDP.
