Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
In May 2017, after several years of little progress on reforms, and coalition-as well as party-in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, economy minister and leader of the ÖVP. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP and reformed the party around himself. As a result, he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election on October 15th, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. The SPÖ's vote share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) increased its share of the vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5% of the vote, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
In mid-December, after just over a month and a half of negotiations, the ÖVP and the FPÖ formed a coalition. Under Mr Kurz the ÖVP has moved close to the FPÖ in many policy areas (during the campaign the leader of the FPÖ, Heinz-Christian Strache, regularly accused Mr Kurz of copying the FPÖ's programme), and the negotiations thus went relatively smoothly. In order to assuage concerns from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Moreover, EU policy will be handled by the chancellery instead of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is headed by an FPÖ appointee.
Although the chancellor is from the ÖVP, the election should still be seen as a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has, to a large extent, been replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties had together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, but a renewed grand coalition had become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between them and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz also owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP's and the FPÖ's programmes, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, on which they are significantly less well aligned than they are on social and cultural matters. In addition, the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on topics such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals, owing in part to internal party upheaval. As a result, we expect limited progress on significant structural reforms. The initial phase of the government's term is likely to be relatively smooth, owing in part to the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union in the second half of 2018. Later in the term the FPÖ might struggle to distinguish itself from the ÖVP, which could lead to tensions between the parties, creating a moderate risk of an early election.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The last general election was held on October 15th 2017. Unless the government falls before then, it will sit in the Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament) until the end of its term in late 2022. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Three elections for state parliaments have already been held so far in 2018, with one more planned, in Salzburg. These tend to be fought on local issues and give only a limited view of national political developments. Nevertheless, the FPÖ's recent underperformance in Carinthia could push it to take stronger stances at the national level.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions, including the leading role that it played in closing the migration route through the Balkans. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this inflow, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. The new government plans to cut child benefit payments flowing abroad, potentially leading to tensions with eastern member states in particular.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that his government will be pro-EU, and that Austria's EU membership will not be questioned in the coming years. The new government plans for Austria to be a leading voice in the bloc in the coming years, especially on reform of migration, and this should be facilitated by the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union. We expect the government to find broad support for proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the 1999 election led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, the reception has been more muted this time. At that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The new govern-ment plans to move integration and immigration policy further to the right, including through curtailing benefits for asylum-seekers and cutting child benefits sent abroad. It has also presented plans that focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing corporate tax rates and introducing more flexibility for working hours. Furthermore, it plans to cut a number of labour market programmes aimed at the long-term unemployed and integrating migrants into the labour market. However, it does not plan to reform the country's so-called Proporz system, under which the ÖVP and the SPÖ had apportioned public life-state companies, public services, subsidies, regulatory responsibilities-despite suggestions from both coalition parties in the past, especially from the FPÖ, that they would want to do this. We therefore expect reform momentum to be limited and for the government to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Driven by both a lacklustre recovery in the wake of the financial and euro zone crises, and by a lack of fiscal consolidation, the fiscal accounts remained in modest deficit in recent years and within the 3% of GDP limit set by the EU. However, strong growth contributed to a narrowing of the deficit to an estimated 1.1% of GDP in 2017.
The government plans to reach a small budget surplus in 2019 by cutting spending and at the same time reducing income taxes and the country's sizeable tax wedge. However, it has not yet clearly outlined the spending cuts that it intends to make, barring a number of smaller measures including cutting spending on asylum-seekers, and we therefore do not share the government's optimism that a surplus can be reached in 2019. Nevertheless, continued robust economic growth will contribute to a further narrowing of the deficit in the coming years; we expect it to average only 0.4% of GDP in 2018-22.
The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from an estimated 79.5% in 2017 to just below 69% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain worse than in peers such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low interest rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. However, the ECB's view of the outlook improved markedly during 2017 and, although it remains dovish, we expect a more upbeat tone to emerge this year, and an end to monthly asset purchases under the QE programme by early 2019. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that lift the main refinancing rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany. This was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltering reform process in recent years contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. However, the economic recovery gained significant momentum from the second half of 2016. Although in previous years the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, owing in part to a surge in employment in the manu-facturing sector, and we expect a continued gradual improvement in labour market indicators in the coming years. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.8% this year. Export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, real GDP growth was 3.1% in 2017-above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005 and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue this year, although we forecast slower growth, at 2.5%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to have largely been a one-off. In the following years we expect a further moderation of growth, to around its potential growth rate. Driven by the improvement of the labour market, domestic demand will be the main driver of growth. We expect average real GDP growth of 1.7% in 2019-22. Government policy is likely to be supportive of growth in the coming years, and the main risks are external. As a highly open economy, Austria is vulnerable to global economic developments, including any shocks to global trade in the case of a potential trade war between the US and the EU.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets, and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy price base effects fostered a gradual increase in inflation in 2017, leading to a full-year average of 2.2%. The recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect price growth to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors seen in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
For most of 2015-16 the euro moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1, before a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. However, in 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strength-ened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018 and stabilised at just below this level in March. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in the wake of the March 2018 general election in Italy-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.21:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. Thereafter we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in recent years, from a deficit in 2009-13. We expect this trade surplus to decline gradually, with the account moving into deficit from 2019 as robust export growth is outweighed by higher import costs and strengthening domestic demand pushes up import volumes. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourist inflows. Modest primary income surpluses will not be enough to outweigh consistent secondary income deficits. However, the services balance will ensure that the current-account surplus remains broadly flat throughout 2018-22, at 2% of GDP on average.
